fields.headline: Nationwide League round-up
fields.trailText: Chesterfield moved 16 points clear of the Third Division field thanks to an error by the veteran Bobby Mimms at nearby Mansfield, where the kick-off was delayed for 10 minutes to help admit the Stags' best crowd for seasons.
fields.body:
Chesterfield moved 16 points clear of the Third Division field thanks to an error by the veteran Bobby Mimms at nearby Mansfield, where the kick-off was delayed for 10 minutes to help admit the Stags' best crowd for seasons.

And barely six minutes after the 7,899 had settled into their places, Lawrie Dudfield launched a speculative cross that drifted over the former Spurs goalkeeper and found its way in off the back post. "I can't believe it went in," said Mansfield's manager Billy Dearden. "You don't give a team like Chesterfield a goal start that early."

Second-placed Brighton lost 3-1 at Cheltenham, for whom the veteran Bob Bloomer and Grant McCann, on loan from West Ham, scored their first ever league goals. They took the points, moreover, despite being down to 10 men for 70 minutes after Lee Howells was dismissed for a second bookable offence barely two minutes after his first.

Cardiff remain in third place after beating Scunthorpe 3-0 thanks to two goals from Daniel Gabbidon and another from Josh Low, who scored with his first touch. Hartlepool are two points behind after making it 12 games without defeat, Mark Tinkler getting the goal at managerless Macclesfield.

In the Second Division Wigan and Walsall could only manage draws and remain in second and third place respectively, the Latics being held 0-0 at home to fourth-bottom Bristol Rovers while Ray Graydon's team came back from two down at Bournemouth, for whom Jermain Defoe scored his 14th of the season.

Oxford, who had Chris Hackett sent off after 20 minutes for violent conduct, stay rooted to the bottom on 14 points after a 3-1 defeat at Bury, their fourth successive loss.

Jocky Scott's Notts County overcame Northampton, rivals for a play-off place, at Meadow Lane, where Mark Stallard scored his 19th of the season and Nick Fenton clinched the victory with a volley.

In the First Division Huddersfield were beaten at home by Gillingham, their first defeat in 11, and that despite taking the lead through Craig Armstrong. Two goals from Mark Saunders put the Gills in front and though Martin Smith brought Town level from the spot, Marlon King secured the points.

Grimsby moved away from the danger area, a goal from China's captain Zhang Enhua doing for Burnley.

Crystal Palace and Norwich finished with a point and 10 men apiece after Jamie Pollock and Darel Russell were sent off for violent conduct. Mikael Forssell scored for Palace and Craig Harrison deflected a Russell shot past his own keeper for the visitors.

fields.headline: Potters armed but not dangerous
fields.trailText: It was billed as a high-noon showdown in the Potteries after police moved the kick-off forward three hours to midday. But these teams largely fired blanks. There was an awful lot of noise, but little damage.
fields.byline: Ian Bayley at the Britannia stadium
fields.body:
It was billed as a high-noon showdown in the Potteries after police moved the kick-off forward three hours to midday. But these teams largely fired blanks. There was an awful lot of noise, but little damage.

Port Vale have made a habit of tweaking the noses of their more illustrious Potteries neighbours in recent years and this play followed a familiar script. Stoke, roared on by more than 20,000 fans outnumbering the Vale support by 10-1 in the Second Division's biggest crowd of the season, were struggling until James O'Connor headed them into a 55th-minute lead.

Just as their support was preparing to celebrate a derby victory Dave Brammer spoiled the party when he equalised nine minutes from time. It was the least Vale deserved yet if Tony Naylor had made more of two first-half chances Stoke's 13-game unbeaten run could have come to an abrupt end.

Naylor, small and elusive, thrived on the lack of attention paid to him in the first half as Stoke's three centre-backs concentrated on Vale's giant Jamaican striker Onandi Lowe. It was an obsession that would have cost them dear had Naylor cashed in after twice going clear on Birkir Kristinsson.

Stoke's Icelandic goalkeeper saved his side on the first occasion, and delayed Naylor long enough on the second to enable Brynjar Gunnarsson to complete the rescue mission. Naylor, though, made amends with the pass that put Brammer in to score with a sweetly struck right-foot shot from 15 yards.

The City manager Gudjon Thordarson has blended together a cosmopolitan team of Anglo-Scandinavian-Irish extraction who deserve a bigger stage. But they are being held back by too many draws against teams, like Vale, prepared to roll their sleeves up.

"Vale worked harder than us from the start," Thordarson said. "That's why we hardly had a kick for 15 minutes. Too many of our players thought others would do their job for them."

Vale's manager Brian Horton was happy with the repeat of the 1-1 draw at Vale Park in September. "Our midfield bossed the game and we were the slightly better side. Stoke have spent a lot of money on players and they are up there among the big clubs in this division. We have spent pennies by comparison, yet we matched them."

fields.headline: Perryman leaves his hosts in a new York basement
fields.trailText: The next billionaire American tourist to make the obligatory excursion to York might consider an additional purchase to go alongside the Minster musical box and hand-painted miniature pot steam engine.
fields.body:
The next billionaire American tourist to make the obligatory excursion to York might consider an additional purchase to go alongside the Minster musical box and hand-painted miniature pot steam engine.

York City are heading for the Nationwide Conference and nobody connected with the club seems to have the wherewithal or financial clout to save them. Herman Hiedleburger III, your time has come.

York lie bottom of the Third Division after this trouncing by Exeter, the previous occupants. The plague of lost league status has passed through Cumbria - Barrow and Workington have long departed and Carlisle look decidely peeky - and now threatens England's great cathedral cities, with Lincoln, who appropriately have risen from the dead once already, joining York and Exeter in distress. Only the affluent new towns of central and southern England seem to have in-built resistance.

Exeter's recent rally owes much to Steve Perryman, the former Spur, who has pitched up in the south-west as unpaid technical adviser and even took charge of the press conference in which he loyally proclaimed: "The spirit shows the team are still backing the manager." Noel Blake, nevertheless, would be foolish not to feel a little uneasy.

York's chairman Douglas Craig, a solicitor absent on business in London, had lectured exasperated supporters before the match that: "The parrot cry of 'sack the manager' is too simplistic and neither helpful not constructive." Nonetheless, at the final whistle 300 maroon parrots convened in the car park to squawk "Dolan out" - save for the few who followed Craig's advice and repeated "sack the board".

York were so abysmal at the back that their manager Terry Dolan concluded: "On today's evidence it's defenders we need." Yet they have scored only once in nine matches. Their form has even been depicted as dangerous to children. Raymond Wynn, a stalwart of the supporters' club, reflected after defeat at Scunthorpe that: "I noticed a lot of parents with young children and it's a pity they had to witness it."

York have fielded 11 strikers this season, many passing through on short-term contracts (they have to stay at least a month to escape the traffic jams - perhaps Mr Hiedleburger would like to build an underpass, too?)

At least the latest arrival is staying until the end of the season, and has a good pedigree: Lee Nogan, capped twice for Wales and a Wembley winner with Grimsby in 1998. He should have pulled York back to 2-1 down four minutes before half-time, after Exeter's keeper, Arjan van Heusden, failed to hold Steve Agnew's shot, but he was ruled offside.

York trailed inside five minutes when Christian Roberts preyed upon Mark Sertori's shocking pass, and although Neville Stamp struck the bar from 30 yards, they shipped a second when Steve Flack beat the offside trap. Flack forced in a third midway through the second half after Alan Fettis had blocked his initial shot.

In the car park, one fan grabbed a BBC Radio York microphone to complain: "I've been coming here since 1954 and it's the worst I've ever seen."

Craig gained notoriety for refusing to support the campaign to Kick Racism Out of Football. Now York might be kicked out themselves. Some might regard that as a suitable end.

fields.headline: O'Connor leads the way to Blue heaven
fields.trailText: There was a strange and rare emotion among the Birmingham City fans before and after Saturday's victory over West Bromwich. Simply put, it was one of pure contentment.
fields.body:
There was a strange and rare emotion among the Birmingham City fans before and after Saturday's victory over West Bromwich. Simply put, it was one of pure contentment.

A win over the Baggies is always a source of pleasure for the Blues and this time, in the context of the First Division play-off places, it was doubly so. Add this to the prospect of next Sunday's Worthington Cup final against Liverpool in Cardiff's Millennium stadium, and heaven's gates are open.

Neither of these teams has played at the top level since the mid-80s, and the odds are that Fulham, Bolton and Blackburn may deny one or both again this season. Yet having disposed of three Premiership teams in the Worthington Cup - Tottenham, Newcastle and Ipswich - City fans are understandably inclined to believe next season's derby will be against Villa.

Perhaps they are right. The play-offs are, after all, a mini-cup competition and Birmingham have proved themselves adept at the formula this season. Saturday's match was also reminiscent of a cup-tie, and again Birmingham gained the upper hand by applying concerted second-half pressure.

West Bromwich, so near to relegation last season, have been transformed by Gary Megson, who has spent more than £5m in the process. The team reflects the manager. There are few frills, but they play with conviction and re solve. For many seasons Albion have appeared virtually unmanageable. Megson, at last, has provided some cause for cautious optimism.

Having rather weakly lost their previous match away to Sheffield United, Birmingham needed to rebuild confidence, and the manager Trevor Francis was clearly concerned the final against Liverpool was having an adverse effect. He shuffled his pack, and was rewarded with unconditional commitment, epitomised by his skipper Martin O'Connor, who scored the winning goal and drew rich praise from Megson: "It's good to see players like Martin who have played in the lower divisions prove themselves, and get their chance to play in big matches. He was tremendous throughout and set a terrific example."

Dele Adebola, who invariably scores against the Albion, put Birmingham ahead after Fernando Derveld, still acclimatising to English football, failed to realise the full danger of Curtis Woodhouse's cross, which Nicky Eadon headed on for Adebole. The celebrations had barely ceased before Al bion equalised, Tony Butler, with a rare goal, heading in Ruel Fox's free-kick.

"We conceded three goals from set pieces against Sheffield United, and this was poor defending again," said Francis. He had little else to complain about as City dominated the second half.

Albion came to life only in the five minutes bafflingly added by the referee. Lee Hughes might have equalised as they threw in the kitchen sink. " It was the only time in the second half I was really concerned," said Francis.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Ferguson halts dangers to Rangers
fields.trailText:
Scottish Cup fourth round
Ross County 2 - 3 Rangers
fields.body:
A goal from their captain Barry Ferguson sent Rangers into the quarter-finals of the Scottish Cup after Ross County had threatened to wreck their season altogether.

Two goals from Alex Bone cancelled out a Tore Andre Flo opening double before Ferguson struck to spare Dick Advocaat's side's blushes.

Flo struck twice in the first 17 minutes to give Rangers what appeared to be a comfortable lead. But things are rarely simple as far as the fallen champions are concerned this season and only three minutes later Bone struck to put the Highlanders back in contention.

Rangers' first goal was the result of a neat turn by Kenny Miller that left Brian Irvine floundering and his pass set up Flo for a cool finish into the bottom corner.

Flo scored again after Neil McCann had supplied him with the ball, and this time it was Flo who turned Mark Perry before finding the same area of the goal.

But County's response was immediate with their top scorer Bone latching on to a headed flick-on and burying the ball past Stefan Klos.

County's goalkeeper Nicky Walker denied Flo a hat-trick with a fine diving save in the 33rd minute. County survived the resulting corner and con tinued to create chances with Karim Boukraa looking the man most likely.

In the 53rd minute Flo fired an inviting chance wide and a minute later County stunned Rangers with an equaliser.

The home fans were baying for a penalty when Irvine went down in the box with Bert Konterman at his back. Play continued but the ball was cleared only as far as the lurking Bone, who fired past Klos.

The German keeper then produced a spectacular tip-over to deny Boukkra a stunning third from long range.

But three minutes later Rangers restored their lead in the simplest manner when a pass through the centre of County's defence from Claudio Reyna picked out Ferguson's run and he slotted past Walker.

County urged men forward and almost equalised with a minute to go when Klos missed a punch and Scott Wilson had to hack Irvine's header away before it crossed the line.

 The Scottish FA has left Celtic and Dunfermline to arrange another suitable date for their Tennent's Scottish Cup fourth-round replay. The rematch at Parkhead was scheduled to go ahead on February 28 after the clubs drew 2-2 at East End Park yesterday.

However, that date would have clashed with international week and Celtic could have been without more than nine first-team players and Andrius Skerla might have been missing from the Dunfermline side.

fields.headline: Ashton underlines Crewe's control
fields.trailText: Middle-aged men with notebooks are a common sight in Crewe, but the talent spotters outnumber the trainspotters these days.
fields.body:
Middle-aged men with notebooks are a common sight in Crewe, but the talent spotters outnumber the trainspotters these days.

Crewe station has always been a haven for those keen to spot the Inter-City Express from Manchester to London but around the corner at Gresty Road, scouts from the Premiership make a regular pilgrimage attempting to spot the latest product of Dario Gradi's school of excellence.

David Platt, Neil Lennon, Seth Johnson, Danny Murphy, Geoff Thomas, Rob Jones. All of these players, and more, have been nurtured by Crewe and Gradi during his 18 years here before climbing to a higher level of the game. Hence the presence of representatives from Manchester United, Liverpool and Everton during Saturday's encounter with Graham Taylor's Watford.

The reason for their visit was the 17-year-old striker Dean Ashton, tipped to be the next big thing at Crewe.

Despite his youth, Ashton is rumoured to have been the subject of a £1m bid by Arsenal. Wisely, Gradi immediately handed the teenager a three-year contract to keep him at the club.

The big guns are clearly on to something with Ashton. Partnered by Rodney Jack, the youngster led the Watford back four a merry dance before being substituted to a standing ovation late on.

By then, he had scored his second goal for Crewe and sent the scouts home with bulging notebooks. Gradi admits that the player has abundant talent. "Dean wasn't even born when I came to the club in 1983," he said. "He is a good goalscorer, but it's too early to talk about what he will turn into.

"He has the skill and he's made a good start. He has the ability, but now it's all about how he turns out physically."

The strapping forward scored from close range after Kenny Lunt's corner had been headed back across goal by Steve Macauley. After twice going close in the early stages, Ashton had earned his goal.

As did Jack, Ashton's enigmatic strike partner. His crisp finish from a Mark Rivers cross opened the scoring.

The victory moved Crewe further away from the relegation zone, but Watford will have to play much better if they are to make a swift return to the Premiership. On this display, young Ashton is likely to beat Taylor's men to it.

fields.headline: Fulham's guided missile fells Forest
fields.trailText: Luis Boa Morte is not accustomed to making headlines. He spent two years at Arsenal warming the bench, a spell at Southampton occupying another and when he arrived at Fulham it seemed merely a stopping-off station on a slow train down the Nationwide. Now he is a hot property.
fields.body:
Luis Boa Morte is not accustomed to making headlines. He spent two years at Arsenal warming the bench, a spell at Southampton occupying another and when he arrived at Fulham it seemed merely a stopping-off station on a slow train down the Nationwide. Now he is a hot property.

"I wake up on Tuesday and people start calling me from Portugal linking me with Benfica," he said. "But my agent knows nothing, so it is all speculation and I'm not going to give more words about that."

Benfica are probably just the first of many clubs he is going to be linked with. The Portuguese, just 23, is on a season's loan from Southampton and if the Saints decide to cash in the Cottagers are determined to be first in line.

"You don't want to talk about individuals but there's a lot of top players in the team as far as I can see and there's no doubt in my mind, they won't be going anywhere - they'll be staying," the player-coach John Collins said.

Boa Morte prefers to do his talking on the pitch. Gone is the radarless rocket that used to zoom through defences and then self-destruct. Now, under the patient priming of Jean Tigana, he has re-emerged as a smart missile, capable of destroying the tightest defence.

Nottingham Forest had arrived with five across the back and a defensive midfielder Riccardo Scimeca making a sixth, but it only took an instant for Boa Morte to pick up a long clearance, tear in on goal, then lob the ball across to Louis Saha who only had to swivel his hips to notch his 19th league goal this season.

"I think he is a very good player and it's a good partnership because we have a good understanding and every game we play better," said Saha. More importantly as the young Frenchman struggles to retain his touch after a draining winter the more physical Boa Morte, with 13 goals of his own, is assuming the responsibility for leading the line.

Fulham are now 10 points ahead of Bolton and 19 clear of third-placed Blackburn. David Platt's much-improved side remain one place off the play-offs. There is still a suspicion that the Forest manager over-complicates their tactics in the hurly-burly of the First Division but in the second half at least they were a match for Fulham, almost stealing a point when Chris Bart-Williams' rasping free-kick came back off the underside of the crossbar.

"I think we did enough to take something out of the game but we didn't do so, perhaps because of a lack of quality with our final ball. If we play like that until the end of the season we'll win more than we lose and there's a good chance we'll get into a final play-off position," Platt said.

fields.headline: Wiltord picks Chelsea's pocket
fields.trailText: Arsenal's FA Cup talisman Sylvain Wiltord came off the bench to score twice in the last quarter-hour and send Arsene Wenger's men through to a quarter-final tie against Bolton or Blackburn.
fields.body:
If winning a league demands a consistent knack for cracking safe combinations then winning a cup is often all about the art of picking pockets. Certainly Arsenal are in the quarter-finals because in Sylvain Wiltord they have found the French answer to Jack Dawkins, the artful dodger.

Yesterday Wiltord came off the bench here to score twice in the last quarter-hour and win a sixth-round tie that Chelsea briefly threatened to steal from under Arsenal's noses. With five goals in the competition so far Wiltord is fast becoming the talisman who could take Arsène Wenger's team over the Severn Bridge to this season's final in Cardiff.

At times it was difficult to believe that Chelsea had come to Highbury as FA Cup holders. For much of the game they performed with the world-weary passivity of players who had long since given up the idea of winning even a raffle on the road.

Chelsea's sole victory away from Stamford Bridge this season remains their fourth-round Cup win at Gillingham. Yesterday Claudio Ranieri sent out a team to contain Arsenal and by the time his attack had acquired the extra pace of Eidur Gudjohnsen and Jesper Gronkjaer it was merely to chase the game.

Though Arsenal were well worth their victory Wenger will be relieved to have got away with having to pick a defence that, at least on paper, appeared to be made more of straw than bricks. With Martin Keown and Silvinho injured and Tony Adams suspended the Arsenal manager was forced to play Oleg Luzhny, a full-back, at centre-back alongside the ponderous Igor Stepanovs.

At Dynamo Kiev Luzhny was called "the horse" and though it is not known if Latvians ever christened Stepanovs "the cart" the potential danger this pair faced in the speed of Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink appeared Chelsea's best chance of taking an early grip on the tie.

Ranieri, however, seemed more concerned initially with holding the opposition in midfield. Given Patrick Vieira's dominance between the penalty areas the Chelsea coach did have a case but with the suspended Ray Parlour another Arsenal absentee Ranieri might have done worse than start with Gronkjaer, especially on the form the Dane had shown against Manchester United a week earlier.

The delayed introduction of Gudjohnsen also eased the pressure on Arsenal's odd couple at centre-back, a point emphasised when the Icelander struck a post with a bicycle kick two minutes after Hasselbaink had brought the scores level with the best goal of the afternoon.

"That was the turning point," Ranieri shrugged afterwards. "If we had scored then I think we would have won. Arsenal would have been forced to come forward more and we would have hit them on the break."

True perhaps, although the feeling persisted that Chelsea would have done better had their coach's second thoughts been his first. Then again the last two coaches to win the FA Cup at Chelsea, Ruud Gullit and Gianluca Vialli, have both been sacked so maybe Ranieri knew what he was doing.

The way Wenger's players were consistently first to the ball and raced forward in large numbers to support an attack when they were not defending in depth did not suggest a team due to play a Champions League game against Lyon in midweek with a visit to Manchester United four days later.

With Lauren feeding off Vieira and both looking to release Robert Pires on the left Chelsea were on the back foot from the outset and rather fortunate that Dennis Bergkamp had a goal disallowed in the second minute for a push after Pires had taken the ball off Albert Ferrer. Not until the approach of half-time did Chelsea achieve anything of note, if one can call bookings notable.

Celestine Babayaro soured the game by fouling Fredrik Ljungberg and kicking out at Bergkamp. Dennis Wise then became involved in confrontations with Vieira and Pires which led to a minute or two of massed shoving before Hasselbaink, Wise and Thierry Henry were cautioned.

"I felt there were certain moments when a number of players were happy to stay on the pitch," Wenger observed diplomatically. "They needed to put on boxing gloves," Ranieri smiled, but apparently did not see Babayaro taking a swing at Lauren. Fortunately for Babayaro neither did the referee Graham Barber.

Having replaced Sam Dalla Bona, Gronkjaer's first significant act was to give away a penalty by pushing Lauren away from Henry's centre, Henry himself putting Arsenal ahead with the kick. Until then Chelsea had done nothing to suggest they might be capable of drawing level, but just past the hour Gustavo Poyet and Gudjohnsen worked the ball to Hasselbaink, who from the penalty arc beat David Seaman with a superb right-footed shot.

Gudjohnsen's near-miss followed, whereupon Wenger replaced Pires with Wiltord, who proceeded to win the tie. In the 73rd minute he flicked a long ball from Stepanovs, which Marcel Desailly had failed to intercept, past the advancing Carlo Cudicini and in the 85th the dodger scored simply after Lauren had left Babayaro and Gronkjaer in all of a twist to set up the chance.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Taylor quick to restore belief in Leicester's Cup pedigree
fields.trailText: Leicester City are a club with a good sense of direction, which partly explains why they have reached Wembley seven times in the last nine years. But for all their League Cup and play-off prowess, the most cherished trophy has eluded them at the final stage four times, most recently 32 years ago.
fields.body:
Leicester City are a club with a good sense of direction, which partly explains why they have reached Wembley seven times in the last nine years. But for all their League Cup and play-off prowess, the most cherished trophy has eluded them at the final stage four times, most recently 32 years ago.

Perhaps a sense of history weighed on Peter Taylor's mind when he admitted to feeling "nervous" about the "shock potential" of this tie. But his fears were dispelled after 15 minutes, by which time the Premiership team were two goals to the good and pondering the quarter-final draw.

A little belief can go a long way, which is why Taylor surprised his players after the recent poor performance against Everton by telling them they could win the Cup. In a puzzling week, Leicester's manager also issued a "I'll do it my way" message saying that he would continue to change tactics and formations, only to revert to the trusted 3-5-2formation his men prefer.

The contest was a greater puzzle for Danny Wilson's men who, after an unbeaten start to 2001, must have wondered what they had done to deserve such early punishment, only for Leicester to extend the hand of mercy for a long time afterwards.

Even the workaholic Robbie Savage faded from view but Bristol could not capitalise because, for all their attractive football, their finishing betrayed Nationwide status - although Brian Tinnion and Mickey Bell struck the woodwork with curving free kicks that utterly beat Simon Royce.

Between times the hapless Matt Hill - later to give away the killing penalty - headed into his own goal and Scott Murray saw his point-blank shot diverted by Royce's legs.

Wilson thought the result "flattered" Leicester and might have disputed their opener, a diving header from Dean Sturridge which looked suspiciously offside. Taylor, inevitably, thought the scoreline was merited, pointing out his side had been "very professional" in enjoying their "best start to a game for some time".

Disappointingly for Taylor, Ade Akinbiyi - told to "get angry" by the manager after being dropped - offered little evidence that he can adjust to Premiership standards. But at least Leicester's record £5m signing shaded the battle of ex-strikers, with Tony Thorpe's subtle skills fading in the face of imposing defenders.

Wilson slipped up against Taylor in this round of the Cup last year too, but Saturday's elimination was far less embarrassing than Sheffield Wednesday's at Gillingham. There was a verbal slip too as Wilson - perhaps still locked into the Kingstonian marathon - praised his side for their impressive football "against a top-eight Conference team".

Leicester will be without Roberto Mancini for the remainder of this campaign, the Italian having returned home to talk to Fiorentina about becoming their next coach. Taylor spoke in the past tense about the 36-year-old striker's Leicester career.

"I don't regret having him here one bit and the players enjoyed him being here. I hope he's coming back - but I'm not 100 percent sure about that."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Rovers get extra game out of bleak Sommer
fields.trailText: From his seat in the West Stand the Lion of Vienna will have liked what he saw. Much has changed since Nat Lofthouse helped Bolton last win the FA Cup in 1958, but even if the old trophy has lost part of its allure it still has the capacity to conjure up stories of heroes, villains and in Jurgen Sommer's case the downright unfortunate.
fields.byline: Daniel Taylor at the Reebok Stadium
fields.body:
From his seat in the West Stand the Lion of Vienna will have liked what he saw. Much has changed since Nat Lofthouse helped Bolton last win the FA Cup in 1958, but even if the old trophy has lost part of its allure it still has the capacity to conjure up stories of heroes, villains and in Jurgen Sommer's case the downright unfortunate.

In Lofthouse's day these all-Lancashire spats would have had Burnden Park bulging at the seams, but though the sentimentalists may not have it so good at the Reebok Stadium this was, nevertheless, the type of old-fashioned skirmish the competition needs if rumours of its demise are to be dispelled.

That both sides went hell for leather on a toffee-pudding pitch owes much, of course, to Sam Allardyce and Graeme Souness craving a quick fix rather than further congestion to their springtime schedule.

It is already complicated enough. Blackburn return to Bolton in the First Division on Friday and the double bill has now become a trilogy, with the final part to be acted out at Ewood Park on March 7.

In the meantime spare a thought for Sommer. Football can be as unforgiving as it is unfair and, even though there were mitigating circumstances, his place in Bolton's annals is likely to be filed under "best forgotten" after he injured his thigh in the opening minutes and surrendered any chance he had to impress.

It was never going to be more than a cameo role but when Sommer flew in from the United States last week to ease a crisis that had deprived Allardyce of three goalkeepers he had high hopes of playing well enough to find new employers in England.

Instead, the New Yorker dented his employment prospects after watching David Dunn's free-kick sail past him as though he were admiring the Manhatten skyline from the Staten Island ferry. "The goal was my fault but I just couldn't get off my bad leg," he said. "I hold my hands up to accept the blame and if it wasn't for that mistake Bolton would be in the quarters.

"Usually with an injury like that I would have come off but we didn't have another goalkeeper. I figured an injured me in goal was better than a fit Robbie Elliott with the gloves."

Given that handicap it was a wonder Bolton did not concede more against opponents who deserve credit for opting against negativity despite having Garry Flitcroft sent off for two studs-up challenges inside the opening nine minutes. That positive approach was rewarded by Dunn's goal five minutes before the interval.

However, when Michael Ricketts poked in his 19th goal of the season on 63 minutes a third contest in 18 days was added to the agenda. Let battle recommence.

fields.headline: Pearce inspires team of all the talents
fields.trailText: One local radio station carried a surreal traffic bulletin on Saturday afternoon, warning drivers that the A1(M) was "a bit soapy southbound". The joke was lost on most as a convoy of 60 coaches heaving with happy Hammers blew bubbles all the way back to the East End.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
One local radio station carried a surreal traffic bulletin on Saturday afternoon, warning drivers that the A1(M) was "a bit soapy southbound". The joke was lost on most as a convoy of 60 coaches heaving with happy Hammers blew bubbles all the way back to the East End.

West Ham may be without a league win this year but their dreams of a first final in 21 years are looking less fanciful. Having seen off Manchester United, Harry Redknapp's side breached another fortress on Saturday to condemn Sunderland to their first Cup defeat at the Stadium of Light.

Paolo di Canio's goal 14 minutes from time had been enough at Old Trafford, so Frédéric Kanouté repeated the dose on Wearside, erasing the memory of a succession of earlier missed chances. Most of the 5,500 travelling fans had left London at 4.30am, yet it was the Frenchman who had appeared half asleep, miscontrolling Christian Dailly's through-ball and scuffing Michael Carrick's pass wide. Kanouté was also hauled back by the assistant's flag 11 times; no Premiership player has been offside so often in a game this season.

But, with Joe Cole, Frank Lampard and Carrick effervescent in midfield, Sunderland's back-line continued to play dangerously high up the pitch. Lampard fluffed another duel with Thomas Sorensen before setting up the only goal. "They're all frightening talents," said Redknapp. "You've always got a chance with such special players in your team; if one isn't having a good game, someone else will deliver the goods."

While the visitors were all subtle promptings, their youthful midfield skipping among the clutter to caress the ball into space, Sunderland huffed and puffed, flinging balls towards Niall Quinn. The Irishman might have had a penalty when he buckled under Igor Stimac's tug. "The lad had his arms locked around Niall - his fingers were linked together," bemoaned Darren Williams. "If that's not a penalty, then I don't know what is."

But Quinn was unlikely to prevail against three such wily centre-backs. Dailly looked revitalised, Stimac was assured despite having played only one reserve game after a long-term calf injury. And there was Stuart Pearce.

"He's worth his weight in gold," said Redknapp of the 38-year-old. "The kids look at him and learn from his attitude. I just say to them: 'Watch him work, train, head, close people down.' You don't need coaches when you've got people like him. He doesn't stand three yards off people and watch them collect the ball; he gets up their arse and tackles them. But he wants to win everything and he'd happily kick someone up in the air in training as well."

For all his glittering career, Pearce has never won the FA Cup. "I think 1-0 flattered them given the amount of chances we had," he said. "It was a superb performance; there are some fantastic young players in the side playing alongside the older pros - the three lads in midfield have old heads on young shoulders - but it all blends quite well."

The crowd winced whenever Pearce and Quinn crunched into challenges on the back post. "The longer the game went on the better he seemed to get," said the Irishman. "He's an absolute example for any kid who wants to know how a professional footballer should conduct himself. I played my first game against him in 1985 and he's still brilliant."

It was Pearce who snuffed out the home side's best opportunity. Quinn, tight to the goalline, cushioned Chris Makin's looping cross on his instep, flicking it back beyond Sébastien Schemmel and turning smoothly to lob into the six-yard box. Kevin Phillips jumped, only for Pearce to materialise from nowhere and power the ball over the bar.

George McCartney gave the ball away from the resultant corner and Carrick fed Lampard. The midfielder danced around three opponents and slipped his pass through a disorganised rearguard for Kanouté to outpace Makin and, as Sorensen tore out of his area, slide the ball into the net.

fields.bodyText: One local radio station carried a surreal traffic bulletin on Saturday afternoon, warning drivers that the A1(M) was "a bit soapy southbound". The joke was lost on most as a convoy of 60 coaches heaving with happy Hammers blew bubbles all the way back to the East End. West Ham may be without a league win this year but their dreams of a first final in 21 years are looking less fanciful. Having seen off Manchester United, Harry Redknapp's side breached another fortress on Saturday to condemn Sunderland to their first Cup defeat at the Stadium of Light. Paolo di Canio's goal 14 minutes from time had been enough at Old Trafford, so Frédéric Kanouté repeated the dose on Wearside, erasing the memory of a succession of earlier missed chances. Most of the 5,500 travelling fans had left London at 4.30am, yet it was the Frenchman who had appeared half asleep, miscontrolling Christian Dailly's through-ball and scuffing Michael Carrick's pass wide. Kanouté was also hauled back by the assistant's flag 11 times; no Premiership player has been offside so often in a game this season. But, with Joe Cole, Frank Lampard and Carrick effervescent in midfield, Sunderland's back-line continued to play dangerously high up the pitch. Lampard fluffed another duel with Thomas Sorensen before setting up the only goal. "They're all frightening talents," said Redknapp. "You've always got a chance with such special players in your team; if one isn't having a good game, someone else will deliver the goods." While the visitors were all subtle promptings, their youthful midfield skipping among the clutter to caress the ball into space, Sunderland huffed and puffed, flinging balls towards Niall Quinn. The Irishman might have had a penalty when he buckled under Igor Stimac's tug. "The lad had his arms locked around Niall - his fingers were linked together," bemoaned Darren Williams. "If that's not a penalty, then I don't know what is." But Quinn was unlikely to prevail against three such wily centre-backs. Dailly looked revitalised, Stimac was assured despite having played only one reserve game after a long-term calf injury. And there was Stuart Pearce. "He's worth his weight in gold," said Redknapp of the 38-year-old. "The kids look at him and learn from his attitude. I just say to them: 'Watch him work, train, head, close people down.' You don't need coaches when you've got people like him. He doesn't stand three yards off people and watch them collect the ball; he gets up their arse and tackles them. But he wants to win everything and he'd happily kick someone up in the air in training as well." For all his glittering career, Pearce has never won the FA Cup. "I think 1-0 flattered them given the amount of chances we had," he said. "It was a superb performance; there are some fantastic young players in the side playing alongside the older pros - the three lads in midfield have old heads on young shoulders - but it all blends quite well." The crowd winced whenever Pearce and Quinn crunched into challenges on the back post. "The longer the game went on the better he seemed to get," said the Irishman. "He's an absolute example for any kid who wants to know how a professional footballer should conduct himself. I played my first game against him in 1985 and he's still brilliant." It was Pearce who snuffed out the home side's best opportunity. Quinn, tight to the goalline, cushioned Chris Makin's looping cross on his instep, flicking it back beyond Sébastien Schemmel and turning smoothly to lob into the six-yard box. Kevin Phillips jumped, only for Pearce to materialise from nowhere and power the ball over the bar. George McCartney gave the ball away from the resultant corner and Carrick fed Lampard. fields.headline: Lucky, plucky Wycombe thrive
fields.trailText: Wimbledon, of course, should have won with a swagger, by a Buckinghamshire mile. They looked more than one division better than Wycombe and led 2-0 with less than 20 minutes remaining.
fields.body:
Wimbledon, of course, should have won with a swagger, by a Buckinghamshire mile. They looked more than one division better than Wycombe and led 2-0 with less than 20 minutes remaining.

Besides, Steve Brown's late equaliser - which took the game to a replay at Selhurst Park tomorrow - should not have stood. When the ball was played forward there appeared to be two, or possibly three, Wycombe attackers in offside positions. On Saturday night the suspicion was confirmed by Match of the Day's Holy Trinity of Lineker, Brooking and Hansen.

But any neutral here on Saturday afternoon was tempted to rejoice with Brown, Wycombe's very experienced midfield player, for he had a harrowing tale to tell.

He might not have played at all, having missed training on Thursday and Friday. On the first of those days Maxwell, his son of only 15 months, underwent a serious stomach operation.

"It was a life threatening, six-hour major operation" he explained "and the last of a whole series of ops. But after what my girlfriend, Nichola, has been through I feel I can now put football in perspective. I just wish she could have been here today.

"I used to eat, drink and sleep the game. But not after what has happened to Maxwell. Now, if I have a bad game, I just make sure I do better next time. But I don't take a game home with me any more.

"I knew I was going to score today. When I get those feelings they are always proved right. I was going to wear a T-shirt saying so. I wish I did now. I know I didn't train but I always wanted to play today."

Wycombe, for whom tomorrow's replay will represent their eighth match in the campaign, had never reached the fifth round before. And they appeared to have no chance of being involved in yesterday's quarter-final draw as they trailed Wimbledon by two goals in the 72nd minute.

Wimbledon, given confidence by their unexpected replay success over Middlesbrough in midweek, had taken the lead with a header by Mark Williams in the 32nd minute. Then Patrick Agyemang scored his first senior goal just before half-time.

Wycombe's PA announcer appeared to have given up the ghost at the interval, when he reminded everyone that the team had already created history by getting this far.

The catalyst for Wycombe's comeback came 10 minutes after the break when their manager Lawrie Sanchez, whose winning goal for Wimbledon against Liverpool in the 1988 final had created one of the Cup's great upsets, brought on three substitutes.

The most influential of these was Sam Parkin. Parkin, just 19 and on loan from Chelsea, did not score but he has an eye for goal and immediately unsettled Wimbledon's back four.

It was his 72nd minute cross that led to Wycombe's first goal by Michael Simpson, via the heel of Peter Hawkins and the right post. Then, following a free-kick on the edge of the six-yard box, conceded by Hawkins, Brown scored the equaliser, getting ahead of two Wimbledon defenders to scramble the ball over the line.

Sanchez said: "It's nice for the fans. This is not for Terry Burton and I. We have been here before. What I really want to do is get in a play-off position.

"Three subs can change a whole unit in the side. Sometimes the move can see you getting beat by six or seven. But only one team was going to win this match at the end.

"Martin O'Neill is God here. He set the benchmark. He got this club in the league and won trophies. If I can achieve half what of he achieved I'll be pleased. We can get into the First Division. We do not get big enough crowds for the Premiership. But we can survive in the First Division with crowds of 10,000.

"We have a good pitch, good stands and we've just bought our own training pitch. After eight years in the league this is still a young league club."

Sanchez's most immediate concern now is the awful state of the Selhurst Park pitch. "In a time of multi-million pound players it's amazing that no one seems to worry about the quality of the pitches," he said.

fields.headline: Liverpool keep good times rolling
fields.standfirst: Houllier's side maintain interest on four fronts as City are swept aside
fields.trailText: And so, as Liverpool roll on, Manchester City continue to roll over. Teams on fine runs are accidents waiting to happen but Liverpool cleared a tricky hurdle in some style yesterday and their season is poised for an intriguing cli max. As the campaign hurtles towards its sharp end Gérard Houllier's team is still locked in combat on four fronts and with so little time between key fixtures they might just forget how to stop winning.
fields.body:
And so, as Liverpool roll on, Manchester City continue to roll over. Teams on fine runs are accidents waiting to happen but Liverpool cleared a tricky hurdle in some style yesterday and their season is poised for an intriguing cli max. As the campaign hurtles towards its sharp end Gérard Houllier's team is still locked in combat on four fronts and with so little time between key fixtures they might just forget how to stop winning.

"We have done well in the cup competitions this season; we have enjoyed them," said Houllier after learning his side face a short trip to Tranmere Rovers or a rather longer one to Southampton in the tournament's quarter-finals.

An uninspiring, 35-mile stretch of invariably clogged motorway is all that separates the great cities of Liverpool and Manchester and yet though the reds of the former and the blues of the latter currently share the same grand stage in footballing terms, they actually have little in common.

Both enjoy fine support and both have a rich pedigree but, arguably, there the similarities end; those who decry the Premiership as a cash-conscious haven for sport's nouveau riche should remember that there are haves and have-nots even among the elite.

In the days leading up to this tie, the City manager Joe Royle had made great play of the fact he was lacking eight, possibly nine, senior players. Had they been miraculously restored to health late on Saturday evening they would not all have played yesterday, of course, but statistics, however distorted, remain an under-pressure manager's most dependable ally.

If Royle was down to the bare bones, his opposite number yesterday had far too many bodies to play with.

Luxury is when you can take your team to Rome, beat the Serie A leaders comfortably and then make four unforced changes. The Frenchman must be the envy of his peers.

The rotation of household names with fragile egos comes easily to Houllier these days and so out went Robbie Fowler, Gary McAllister, Nick Barmby and Michael Owen, whose brace had done for Roma on Thursday.

But shuffling your pack becomes akin to a pleasure when you have so many aces at your disposal and though Liverpool's football never flowed quite as it did in the Olympic Stadium, it was always going to be too much for a City defence that seemed to be peopled by leaden-footed men of enormous girth.

City struggled from the first whistle and had Liverpool not chosen to lift a collective foot off the accelerator pedal after sweeping into an early two-goal advantage, all the arguments would have been gathering dust long before the interval.

Although much of Liverpool's early football was mesmerising, they required a slice of good fortune to underscore their superiority. Well, that's the way it looked, anyway.

Seven minutes in, Jari Litmanen released Vladimir Smicer with the first of many sublime touches. As Smicer worked his way into a shooting position he was knocked to the ground by the City goalkeeper Nicky Weaver - or maybe he was not.

Adamant that Weaver had made no contact, City, to a man, protested. It was all to no avail though and Litmanen stroked home the penalty.

"It wasn't a penalty and without going into too much detail it was fiction, a ridiculous decision," said Royle. "That is the last thing you need when playing at Anfield."

Only five minutes later City were undone for a second time, Emile Heskey collecting Litmanen's magnificent through ball before steering home low and extremely hard.

As Mancunian heads dropped the abacuses were out. And then, strangely, Liverpool stopped playing. Royle's teams are rarely pretty or sophisticated but they never give up and so a competitive edge was restored to an afternoon that had looked to be dead in the water.

The outcome was briefly placed in some doubt when Andrei Kanchelskis curled a shot just inside Sander Westerveld's far post but, from a City perspective, it proved to be a false dawn.

Liverpool increased the tempo of their game and duly prospered, again by way of a penalty for another Weaver foul on Smicer. No arguments this time though and with Litmanen having been substituted at half-time Smicer did the honours crisply and efficiently.

Markus Babbel turned home a neat header from a Christian Ziege free-kick with five minutes remaining and Shaun Goater steered in a very late consolation for the visitors but by that point Liverpool had switched to auto-pilot, conserving their energies in readiness for the arrival on Thursday of Roma.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Campbell offers Eriksson a ripping reminder
fields.trailText: Amid the talk of England's defensive future lying with Wes Brown and Rio Ferdinand, it has been easy to forget the 26-year-old who has captained his country and is not planning international retirement just yet. "Miserly" may be a dirty word at White Hart Lane but Sol Campbell is doing much to ensure it applies to Tottenham's back line.
fields.byline: Jon Brodkin at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
Amid the talk of England's defensive future lying with Wes Brown and Rio Ferdinand, it has been easy to forget the 26-year-old who has captained his country and is not planning international retirement just yet. "Miserly" may be a dirty word at White Hart Lane but Sol Campbell is doing much to ensure it applies to Tottenham's back line.

His contribution to Spurs' seventh clean sheet in eight matches was watched by Sven-Goran Eriksson. And if the challenge posed by Spain on Wednesday week is liable to be sterner than that offered by Stockport, the ripped footwear and reverent words of a man England will meet next month confirmed Campbell's worth.

"I went in for a challenge with him and it destroyed my boot," said Jarkko Wiss, the Stockport midfielder who helped Finland to a 0-0 draw against a Campbell-less England in October, and may opt for ski boots if the Spurs captain plays in the return World Cup qualifier on March 24.

"It was a normal tackle but I felt it in my bones. My boot was torn and I'll have to get new ones; the sole was ripped off. He has the physique of a boxer and he's really tough to play against. He's a hard man."

Campbell dealt comfortably with the physical threat posed by another Finland international, the striker Shefki Kuqi, and George Graham believes his captain should start against Spain. With Tony Adams retired from international football and his Arsenal team-mate Martin Keown injured, Eriksson may look to an experienced player to partner Brown or Ferdinand. The way Campbell guided the youngsters around him must have been noted.

"At set pieces he doesn't shout but he's always telling the other players like Ledley King where to go," Wiss said. "There's so much respect for him. He has an aura about him."

The versatile King gave such an accomplished performance at centre-back alongside Campbell that Graham said he may have to change his mind in thinking the 20-year-old's career lies in midfield. And if King gave Spurs fans - and Eriksson - hope for the future, others did the same. The home side ended the match with an all-English, all-home-grown back five and six players aged 21 or under.

"I think that's the way of the future," Graham said. "If you can get two or three players through from your youth policy, it can save £30-40m."

Simon Davies, 21, is not such a product, having arrived for £700,000 from Peterborough last season, but he made an impressive contribution after replacing the injured Oyvind Leonhardsen early on, scoring twice and showing discipline in his tackling and passing.

Spurs have lacked a goalscoring midfielder and Davies looked to be one, finishing well after running on to a Les Ferdinand header and later taking a Tim Sherwood pass in his stride and scoring with confidence. But Tottenham had rarely looked in danger from the moment King headed them in front inside five minutes.

By the time Mike Flynn put a Luke Young cross into his own net for No3, Stockport's dreams, like Wiss's boot, were in tatters. Campbell will hope he has the chance to send the Finn back to his cobbler next month.

fields.headline: Battling Tranmere bottom out after Cup high
fields.trailText: Southampton, for once with few relegation worries, have every reason to buck the trend and concentrate on the Cup and not the league. Yet on Saturday they played like dogs.
fields.body:
Southampton, for once with few relegation worries, have every reason to buck the trend and concentrate on the Cup and not the league. Yet on Saturday they played like dogs.

Tranmere, in severe danger of dropping from the First Division, should surely be saving their best performances for the relegation battle. But once more they lifted themselves to a higher plane in the Cup, a competition they have no realistic hope of winning.

Why do they do it? "I'm sick of answering that question," replied their manager John Aldridge, clearly perplexed by it. His team's giant-killing Cup runs have claimed six Premiership scalps in recent seasons, including last month's fourth-round win at Everton. But neither that nor this plucky draw that means a replay tomorrow, could make up for what happened to them in the First Division in their absence.

"To come in at full-time and find we had gone bottom of the league was a real sickener," said the veteran striker Paul Rideout. "It will mean nothing to us winning the FA Cup if we get relegated. Even a win on Tuesday night [in the replay] means nothing if we go down."

The worry is turning into a health hazard for Aldridge. "I never stop thinking about it," he admits. "I can't sleep at night. It's doing me in."

It seems that, unlike many of the top clubs, those in the lower divisions find the magic of the Cup irresistible. It is one of the illogical laws of the old trophy. And here is another: Premiership sides will always underestimate the threat of lesser opposition no matter how many pre-match warnings the manager issues.

"We worked all this week on not under-estimating them," said Glenn Hoddle. "But we had too many players on five or six out of ten out there. We didn't create enough. There wasn't enough good play out there to deserve the victory."

Not even a half-time roasting could improve matters. "I had a few stern words with them. But we let ourselves down today. There is a feeling around the city that, with relegation less of a worry, this could be our year in the Cup. But you've got to go and do it."

Southampton boasted the bulk of possession and did have the ball in the back of the net three times. But each effort was disallowed, two for offside and one for impeding the goalkeeper. The first decision was the only dubious one, as the man ruled offside when Dean Richards headed in did not seem to be interfering with play.

Tranmere's goalkeeper John Achterberg also saved well from Marian Pahars, who otherwise was disappointing, as was James Beattie. Recently touted as an England possible, he played more like a striker heading for a call-up to Southampton reserves.

Tranmere had Clint Hill carried off with an ankle injury but even without him the defence performed heroically around the veteran Richard Jobson.

Merseyside's poor relations lacked attacking invention, though, and their best two chances were presented to Andy Parkinson via South ampton errors. First Jo Tessem's slip left the nippy striker free on goal but Paul Jones pulled off an instinctive save from the ensuing shot. Then a Richards error let in Parkinson again and only Claus Lundekvam's last-ditch tackle saved the day.

And so to the replay. Hill is doubtful for Tranmere but Southampton's plight is worse. Matthew Oakley has joined an already large injury list, Dan Petrescu is Cup-tied, Tahar El Khalej is on international duty and Hoddle admits he will have to call up some youngsters. Poor old Tranmere. No one is helping them get their priorities right.

Tranmere, in severe danger of dropping from the First Division, should surely be saving their best performances for the relegation battle. But once more they lifted themselves to a higher plane in the Cup, a competition they have no realistic hope of winning. Why do they do it? "I'm sick of answering that question," replied their manager John Aldridge, clearly perplexed by it. His team's giant-killing Cup runs have claimed six Premiership scalps in recent seasons, including last month's fourth-round win at Everton. But neither that nor this plucky draw that means a replay tomorrow, could make up for what happened to them in the First Division in their absence. "To come in at full-time and find we had gone bottom of the league was a real sickener," said the veteran striker Paul Rideout. "It will mean nothing to us winning the FA Cup if we get relegated. Even a win on Tuesday night [in the replay] means nothing if we go down." The worry is turning into a health hazard for Aldridge. "I never stop thinking about it," he admits. "I can't sleep at night. It's doing me in." It seems that, unlike many of the top clubs, those in the lower divisions find the magic of the Cup irresistible. It is one of the illogical laws of the old trophy. And here is another: Premiership sides will always underestimate the threat of lesser opposition no matter how many pre-match warnings the manager issues. "We worked all this week on not under-estimating them," said Glenn Hoddle. "But we had too many players on five or six out of ten out there. We didn't create enough. There wasn't enough good play out there to deserve the victory." Not even a half-time roasting could improve matters. "I had a few stern words with them. But we let ourselves down today. There is a feeling around the city that, with relegation less of a worry, this could be our year in the Cup. But you've got to go and do it." Southampton boasted the bulk of possession and did have the ball in the back of the net three times. But each effort was disallowed, two for offside and one for impeding the goalkeeper. The first decision was the only dubious one, as the man ruled offside when Dean Richards headed in did not seem to be interfering with play. Tranmere's goalkeeper John Achterberg also saved well from Marian Pahars, who otherwise was disappointing, as was James Beattie. Recently touted as an England possible, he played more like a striker heading for a call-up to Southampton reserves. Tranmere had Clint Hill carried off with an ankle injury but even without him the defence performed heroically around the veteran Richard Jobson. Merseyside's poor relations lacked attacking invention, though, and their best two chances were presented to Andy Parkinson via South ampton errors. First Jo Tessem's slip left the nippy striker free on goal but Paul Jones pulled off an instinctive save from the ensuing shot. Then a Richards error let in Parkinson again and only Claus Lundekvam's last-ditch tackle saved the day. And so to the replay. Hill is doubtful for Tranmere but Southampton's plight is worse. Matthew Oakley has joined an already large injury list, Dan Petrescu is Cup-tied, Tahar El Khalej is on international duty and Hoddle admits he will have to call up some youngsters. Poor old Tranmere. No one is helping them get their priorities right.  You've read the piece, now have your say. webTitle: Joint review finds council at cutting edge of good practice

fields.headline: Joint review finds council at cutting edge of good practice
fields.trailText: Kensington and Chelsea social services department provides high quality services that are well designed to meet service users' needs, according to a joint review report published today.
fields.body:
Kensington and Chelsea social services department provides high quality services that are well designed to meet service users' needs, according to a joint review report published today.

The report by the social services inspectorate and the Audit Commission found that 75% of users and carers consider Kensington and Chelsea's social services "good or excellent".

Key strengths included a commitment to multi-agency working, which has prevented exclusions from secondary schools, and a comprehensive human resources strategy that supports and develops staff at all levels.

The royal borough of Kensington and Chelsea's population is polarised between those wealthy enough to afford some of the most expensive property in the country and those dependent on benefits. It has one of highest social services budgets per capita in England and spends considerably more on social services than comparative authorities.

The joint review pointed to the authority's direction of change strategy as the main reason behind its success. The programme, which is led by senior managers, aims to shift the organisational culture towards clear and consistent principles and processes driven by service users' needs. Managers were praised for encouraging staff to develop evidence-based practice.

The review team also praised the authority's early assessment and intervention to help families in crisis, which had resulted in low numbers of children in care or on the child protection register. Its community care services responded more effectively to service users' needs by banding them together according to their level and complexity of needs.

Director of the joint review John Bolton said: "Kensington and Chelsea can congratulate themselves on the successful delivery of good quality social services which meet the requirements of local people. The effectiveness of social services is driven by the authority's preoccupation with developing the needs driven service across all areas."

However, the review team pointed to some areas where improvement was needed. They called on the authority to embed business planning into everyday practice, analyse the unmet needs of users to strengthen its commissioning arrangements, and iron out variations in practice through audits to identify their impact on users. They recommended more initiatives to empower users and carers and disseminate good practice.

But the report acknowledged that Kensington and Chelsea was "already at the vanguard of good practices in many areas".

"By adopting the recommendations of the review, the authority will protect its already solid base and ensure that it is among those social services departments with a national reputation for excellence," said Mr Bolton.

Kensington and Chelsea council leader Merrick Cockell said: "This has been a root and branch examination of the way we do things and we have come out of it with flying colours. It is a source of immense pride to the council that the social services we provide to our most vulnerable residents are so good.

"However, we will not rest here. There is much more we can do to raise the level of our services even higher."

webTitle: Italian jet set told to share their beaches

fields.headline: Italian jet set told to share their beaches
fields.trailText: A 10-year legal battle to prise open the Sbarcatello beach complex in Argentario, Tuscany reserved for residents of luxury villas has ended in a victory. Italy's highest court ruled that royals, tycoons, celebrities and British prime ministers can no longer seal off their favourite bits of sand.
fields.body:
Democracy washed over Italian beaches at the weekend when the rich and famous were ordered to open their secluded playgrounds to the rest of humanity.

Italy's highest court ruled that royals, tycoons, celebrities and British prime ministers can no longer seal off their favourite bits of sand.

A 10-year legal battle to prise open a Tuscan beach reserved for residents of luxury villas ended in a victory which set a precedent for the rest of the country.

The Sbarcatello complex in Argentario was told it must allow the public to slap on suncream alongside its usual guests - the Queen of the Netherlands, Borghese princes and film directors.

"No private property, for any motive, can deny access to the sea if that is the only way to reach it," the court of cassation said.

Italy's main environmental group, Legambiente, hailed the ruling as a landmark which would end the privatisation of the seaside.

Tony Blair's August 1999 holiday at another Tuscan resort, San Rossore, caused controversy when the local authorities closed off three miles of beach to ensure privacy and security.

Downing Street mollified protesters by getting the ban lifted.

Legambiente hopes the law will result in the private guards, fences, railings and walls which seal off some of Italy's most beautiful sands disappearing by summer. Top of its list are resorts at Capri and Portofino, where Europe's elite gather from May to September.

Commentators were jubilant that the moneyed clients of Sbarcatello would soon have to share their idyll. "They were all united, for years, in holding on to their little Eden far from outsiders. But now they are defeated," one said.

The tranquillity of private resorts is a world away from the bedlam of public beaches in peak season. Italians all tend to take their holidays in August, when more than 20m people scramble to the coast.

Last summer some towns drafted special beach police to maintain order as tempers frayed and fights broke out.

webTitle: Labour conference: key cash flow areas revealled

fields.headline: Party faithful given a taste of things to come
fields.standfirst:
Ministers reveal crime, health and child care as key areas where the cash will flow in a second term

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Ministers reveal crime, health and child care as key areas where the cash will flow in a second term.
fields.body:
Labour's three-day rally in Glasgow at the weekend effectively launched the party's election campaign with a string of policy announcements designed to reassure Labour activists and the country that it is ready for a second term.

Tony Blair and eight cabinet ministers set out plans for reforming public services, spreading prosperity and making the country a "more civilised place".

Mr Blair highlighted policy initiatives on drugs, unemployment and paternity leave.

Acknowledging that Labour still needs to do more on law and order, Mr Blair promised to create a register of hard drug dealers.

Based on an idea first set out by the Scottish MP Derek Brown, he said the courts would have powers to place on a register anyone leaving prison and liable to deal in drugs.

The register, which would not be available to the public, would help police keep track of suspects.

The idea will be included in a package of proposals to tackle crime which will be published during the next fortnight. The home secretary, Jack Straw, told the conference there would be new rights for crime victims. He said they would be kept informed of the progress of their case through the courts and provided with explanations about the key decisions affecting them.

He also promised to punish more effectively the 100,000 hard-core of persistent offenders "with sentences which both properly take account of their offending record and do more to reduce reoffending when they return to the community".

On the unemployed, Mr Blair promised changes on the New Deal programme. He said: "In future any jobless claimant will not just be expected to take work but also if they lack skills to take up a state offer to pay to improve their skills.

"As a condition of benefit we will establish basic skills tests for newly unemployed adults. We will pay for them to read, write and do basic maths".

The programme, in part modelled on the successful employment action zones, would be part of a wider drive to help the 7m adults with inadequate basic reading skills.

Mr Blair also promised that paternity leave would be paid by the state. Two weeks pay is the likely amount on offer and it could be set at the same level as maternity pay, which is £60.70 a week.

The proposal will be condemned as another regulatory burden by business, but employers will be relieved that Mr Blair has rejected proposals that mothers should be able to return to their former employment with a statutory right to part-time work.

In a separate speech the employment minister Tessa Jowell held out the prospect of a big increase in the provision of child care, admitting that at present there is only one place for every seven children aged under eight.

She also presaged a drive on pay equality, drawing on figures showing that between a quarter and half of the pay gap between men and women is caused by "employers' discrimination against women".

In a development which will lift the spirits of northern activists, John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, revealed that he had won the backing of Mr Blair to publish a green paper after the election setting out plans for elected regional assemblies in England. Mr Blair has been convinced that the regions can act as economic power houses and also raise, overall, British productivity.

At present the regional development agencies in England are monitored by non-statutory and unelected groups of councillors working in regional chambers. The green paper is likely to propose that referendums on elected assemblies should be triggered either by these chambers or by a petition from a fixed proportion of the electorate within each region.

He drew loud cheers when he said: "Regional chambers are a start to decentralisation in the English regions. Our next step must be to deepen regional accountability.

"I believe the time is right to take the next steps to publish a green paper on empowering our regions to strengthen the accountability of regional chambers, and where people vote for it to move to directly elected regional assemblies."

The move was welcomed by many northern councillors who will be crucial in getting out the core Labour vote at the coming election.

Throughout the weekend ministers went out of their way to promise greater freedom to local councillors. The chancellor, Gordon Brown, even held out the prospect of 150 councils being given greater freedom to spend money, so long as they negotiated with the Treasury on a common set of targets.

Efforts were also made to appease pensioners, many of whom were infuriated by the 75p rise in the state pension last year. Mr Prescott promised to equalise the age for concessionary fares, saying it would help an extra 1m people at 60 years of age.

The health secretary Alan Milburn also highlighted measures likely to please NHS workers. Besides offering extra cash and new targets to cut down health inequalities between poor and rich, he said it was time to "shift the centre of gravity to the NHS frontline".

He promised ward sisters would control ward budgets so that they would have "the power to stop payments to privately run cleaning firms which are failing to keep our hospitals clean".

He said that as services improved, so more devolution would take hold. The best hospitals would be free to use extra cash to pay bonuses to the best teams of staff. Poor services would get cash to improve them.

It was a consistent theme of ministers that after two years of tight spending controls at the start of Labour's first term, the benefits of extra cash were starting to flow.

Mr Blair told his audience that his government had matured in office and he was proud that there had been no breakdown in the relationship between the party and government that had disfigured previous Labour administrations.

 Debate Labour's record with Polly Toynbee and David Walker at 2pm today at theguardian.com

fields.headline: Postal votes 'can be crucial'
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Labour activists are being urged to combat the threat of a low turnout in the coming general election by exploiting new rules allowing millions of people to vote using postal ballots for the first time.
fields.body:
Labour activists are being urged to combat the threat of a low turnout in the coming general election by exploiting new rules allowing millions of people to vote using postal ballots for the first time.

The little-known rules, which came into force last Friday, were briefed to party activists during a series of behind-closed-doors training sessions at Labour's spring conference in Glasgow over the weekend.

Under rules passed in the Political Parties Act, voters will be entitled to a postal vote without having to meet complex qualification procedures.

Some Labour organisers believe it could boost turnout by as much as 2% in some areas.

Activists were told that if only one in six Labour voters in 1997 does not vote Labour this time, then 60 Labour seats will be lost and the party's majority cut by 120.

Senior party figures have for months been expressing concern over cynicism among the general electorate and apathy among party activists.

The postal polling drive follows a Home Office experiment during last spring's local elections, which showed that the most successful way to boost turnout was to ease all the restrictions on postal balloting.

Until now, postal votes have only been available if the voter is certain to be abroad or is ill. An applicant has to apply to their local council or returning officer. The postal ballot is then sent to the voter after all candidates have declared and the campaign is underway.

webTitle: Analysis: UK bank balance is healthy

fields.headline: Bank balance is healthy
fields.standfirst:
This is the first of five pieces in the Analysis slot looking in detail at Labour's performance: economics

Special report: election countdown
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: This is the first of five pieces in the Analysis slot looking in detail at Labour's performance: economics.
fields.body:
Of course things got better on the economic front but was it Labour's luck or Brownian judgment? The answer is probably 60% of the former and 40% Mr Stability. The son of the manse swore repeatedly on the bible of neo-liberalism while he set out to achieve a more equal society by stealth. He certainly covered his tracks.

Labour took office on a rising curve and the good news has, largely, continued. Gordon Brown and Tony Blair did not ruffle the golden goose. The 20th century association between Labour and economic crisis was at last broken. At 75% the employment rate is now pushing towards the highest level ever recorded. By the end of last year the Labour Force survey said fewer than 1.5m people were out of work; the count of those claiming social benefits now shows under 1m.

We are all now better off. For every £100 of retail spending on the eve of the 1997 election, consumers have £114, households some £45bn more in total. Under Labour the economy grew by 2.6% a year on average, compared with the Tories' 2% during 1979-1997, which of course includes two downturns. Under Labour the ranks of higher-rate income tax payers swelled by 100,000. Some got a lot more to pay tax on: salaries of chief executives of FTSE 100 companies improved from £463,00 in 1998-1999 to £490,000 a year later.

Labour promised price inflation at 2.5% a year. It undershot. Annual inflation is now below 1% on some measures. But inflation had been on target prior to the election. Did operational independence for the Bank of England make such a big difference?

Old skeletons have not stopped rattling away in the Treasury's closet. Productivity is still well below those allegedly bloated welfare states France and Germany. A strong pound cheapened imports so it took the chancellor a while to express concern about sterling's appreciation - by some 20% against the euro between January 1999 and last autumn. This helped the trade deficit grow though few seemed to worry. Those that did noted how the UK balance of payments was financed by volatile inflows as the ratio of UK long-term assets to liabilities deteriorated.

Labour showed no wish to push the UK to a higher position in the league table of government size; we remain well under France and Germany but above Japan and the US. Mr Brown said size did not matter. What did was whether the state created conditions for business success. Longbridge (then Llanwern) symbolised business failure. Yet if the board of BMW decided to relocate what right had third way ministers to demur? The Blairites wanted to move the UK hop, skip and jump into the internet age; the trouble was a lot of Labour voters, let alone productivity gains, depend on manufacturing still.

Mr Brown got new money in. Business taxes were worth 3.5% of GDP in 1998-99 but 3.9% in 2001-2002, not bad in a world where globalisation is supposed to forbid one-country hits on the private sector. There was cash, too, from an act of old-fashioned socialist expropriation, the windfall tax on the utilities. Labour deprivileged marriage, made company cars dearer, house purchase a little harder (by cutting mortgage tax relief), penalised motorists and smokers. It pushed money towards working families, pensioners and, marginally, helped drinkers.

Looked at in the round, this was a government which asked no fundamental questions about the functioning of the economic system or its fairness. In an ageing Britain, Labour upheld the Thatcherite settlement on provision for old age - it is basically up to individuals. Financial markets have been buoyant and no one has worried much. But things may not always get better and in retrospect the government's silence over the fate of Equitable Life - a straw in the wind? - may appear ominous.

 Tomorrow: did things get fairer?

Do you think things got better? Polly Toynbee and David Walker will be online today at 2pm on the Guardian network to discuss their book. You can post messages and questions now at theguardian.com/labour
