There was cash, too, from an act of old-fashioned socialist expropriation, the windfall tax on the utilities. Labour deprivileged marriage, made company cars dearer, house purchase a little harder (by cutting mortgage tax relief), penalised motorists and smokers. It pushed money towards working families, pensioners and, marginally, helped drinkers. Looked at in the round, this was a government which asked no fundamental questions about the functioning of the economic system or its fairness. In an ageing Britain, Labour upheld the Thatcherite settlement on provision for old age - it is basically up to individuals. Financial markets have been buoyant and no one has worried much. But things may not always get better and in retrospect the government's silence over the fate of Equitable Life - a straw in the wind? - may appear ominous.  Tomorrow: did things get fairer? Do you think things got better? Polly Toynbee and David Walker will be online today at 2pm on the Guardian network to discuss their book. fields.standfirst:
In the first extract from their book, Polly Toynbee and David Walker assess Labour's performance
Extract two: social justice
Extract three: environment
Extract four: crime
Extract five: health

fields.trailText: Well, did they? Yes. The economy boomed, unemployment plummeted, inflation too, debt was repaid, virtually everyone got richer.
fields.body:
Well, did they? Yes. The economy boomed, unemployment plummeted, inflation too, debt was repaid, virtually everyone got richer. Poor pensioners and poor children saw a sharp increase in the support they get from the state; primary schools and hospitals improved: most of the things that government affects got measurably better.

All that and some socialism, too. Labour came to power promising almost nothing, getting its disillusion in first with a paltry five easy pledges and a risibly timid campaign song (Things Can Only Get Better). The tactic worked so well that later radicalism barely registered. Who ever imagined New Labour would make a pledge Keir Hardie would have blenched at? The party's founder promised the minimum wage - implemented in April 1999 - but not the abolition of child poverty. Who ever thought New Labour would end pensioner poverty in four years? (Those promises are even more radical considering the definitions of poverty used are proportions of earnings at large: as earnings rise so must benefits.)

If the message was muffled, it is because the Blair government has been so ambivalent about what it stands for that it did not dare trumpet these successes, for fear the Daily Mail might hear. It was socialism by stealth and limited, for this was done by distribution of new wealth, never taxed directly away from the better off.

Early on Tony Blair said he would fail if he did not leave a fairer society behind. The gap between rich and poor has not lessened - the distribution of wealth has probably got even more skewed - yet the lot of the poor has improved more sharply than at any time since the founding of the welfare state. A quarter of the 4m poor children have been lifted out of poverty. Weekly income for the poorest pensioners will have risen in April from £68.80 in 1997 to £92.15.

The basic state pension will be up for rich and poor alike by £5 plus the £200 fuel allowance. The working families' tax credit now helps 1m poor working families, none now living on less than £214 a week. Income support for children rose by 72% in real terms, child benefit for all by 25%. In April every household with children where earnings are under £40,000 gets £520 a year instead of the old married couples' allowance of £285.

Yet curiously none of this is the story Labour tells about itself. For this has also been a deeply conservative government, dogmatically attached to private finance and privatisation, for the tube and air traffic control. On the same side of the ledger Jack Straw pushed the population in prison up by 6,000 at a time crime has been falling and no more criminals were being caught. Asylum seekers were ritually abused (though few got sent back). There was pandering to Murdoch and the Mail, who still kicked them in the teeth.

Labour, the neo-conservative party, promised no rise in income tax. It even cut the basic rate by 1%, perpetuating the Tory myth that voters can have low tax and good public services. Labour talked rights and responsibilities but no one breathed a word about the obligation on the rich or business to contribute more as wealth soared, while capital gains tax was cut and inheritance tax withered to virtually nil.

How people rate the Blair government depends critically on their view of its first two years, when Labour accepted the Tories' punitive spending plans, lone parent cuts and all. This delayed the rolling out of Labour's best projects, action on the 2,000 worst housing estates, better treatment of young offenders, Sure Start for babies and a national programme for childcare. The spending pledge postponed improvements in health and education, which in turn led to public disappointment.

But was that severe early restraint necessary? Even as the crowds were still celebrating on May 2 1997, inside No 10 the Blairites were reining in expectation, damping down excitement. They never quite believed in their victory, fearing the vanquished Tory foe would still rise from its grave. Full of folk memories of City panic on Harold Wilson's arrival in power, they feared a run on the pound, a flight of capital, spiralling inflation, all the Labour ghosts. Remember, too, that in spring 1997 the economy was predicted to turn down by October: the Bank of England pondered only whether it would be a hard or soft landing. In the event nothing happened. So with hindsight, it is easy now to see the first two years as a sorry waste. But who could have guessed then that the coffers would overflow?

But now the money is in there can be no excuse for timidity in a second term. Labour's fearfulness postponed a decision on the euro that could have been taken at a gallop in the flush of their election victory. Yet Tony Blair was brave over Kosovo when he did the right thing for its own sake. On Labour's watch the world took a few stumbling steps towards greater mutual responsibility for human rights and human welfare: perhaps the very facility with which Labour resorted to the language of rights was itself progress. Labour led in cutting third world debt. Arms sales continued but at least more transparently than anywhere else, with details and destinations of shipments published for the first time.

Constitutional reform brought representative government to the nations of the UK, the routing of old ermines from the Lords and a mayor and assembly for London. Devolution was badly done by a leader loath to let go, but done it was. Nothing much was done about the Commons. The promised strong draught of freedom of information was watered down as Labour ministers succumbed to a bad case of executive-mindedness. No coherent constitutional template was formed and critical questions of public sector morale and organisation dodged - which Labour will regret if it gets another term. Proportional representation for Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland and European parliament elections sparked no enthusiasm for electoral reform at Westminster. The Blair vision of realigning the parties through PR, so making the 21st century safe for progressive government, got nowhere.

So what is the final tally? If money in the pocket measures a government's success, the prosperous have prospered but so have the poor. If it is public confidence in the state and the services it supplies, then those two years of Tory spending were an error, which is being compounded by Labour's refusal to tax more. On present policies, there will never be enough to raise UK provision to European standards.

As we trawled through departments examining what Labour did, we were puzzled by how a government famous for glossy annual reports and permanent spin had failed to communicate so much of what it was really up to. This has been a remarkably busy government. But unless a policy becomes a battle, a scandal or a joke it vanishes into the ether, virtually unreported. Our book ignores the Westminster soap opera in favour of hard evidence on change accomplished, outcomes measured. On that basis we have to conclude it has been a good government, blessed with fortunate circumstance. Had Labour been less afraid of its own shadow, less in thrall to a dead Thatcherite past, how much better it could have been - and might yet be.

Extracted from Did Things Get Better? by Polly Toynbee and David Walker published by Penguin Books on 22 February at £6.99.

webTitle: Party cash plea puts Irvine in the frame

fields.headline: Party cash plea puts Irvine in the frame
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: February 19 2001: The row over the lord chancellor's letter to senior lawyers soliciting money at a fund-raising dinner to help secure a second term for Labour has brought to a head a dispute over the conflict between his roles as politician and head of the judiciary.
fields.body:
The row over the lord chancellor's letter to senior lawyers soliciting money at a fund-raising dinner to help secure a second term for Labour has brought to a head a dispute over the conflict between his roles as politician and head of the judiciary.

There is much disquiet among judges and lawyers that so powerful a figure as Lord Irvine of Lairg should also head the judiciary, a body whose independence from politics is seen as crucial to democracy.

Every lord chancellor flouts the doctrine of the separation of powers - that judges, the executive and the legislature should be separate - every day of his working life. He straddles all three, as head of the judiciary, a senior cabinet minister, and speaker of the House of Lords.

The anomaly has become more stark since Derry Irvine took over the role. No other lord chancellor in recent times has been so close to the prime minister.

The contrast is particularly striking with the previous lord chancellor, Lord Mackay. He was a non-political law lord who had spent years as a senior judge when Margaret Thatcher asked him to take the job.

As lord chancellor, Lord Irvine has the right to sit in the highest court in the land, the House of Lords, as the presiding judge, and to choose the cases he sits on. He has exercised the right several times, even though his only previous experience was as a part-time judge.

Several of the law lords who sit with him have privately expressed unease about his role in their court.

Since the Human Rights Act came into force last October, however, the type of case he can sit on has been limited by the need to ensure that litigants get "an independent and impartial tribunal". He has been challenged by lawyers for proposing to sit on cases in which the government had an interest.

The prominent QC Anthony Scrivener, said: "Now if I end up attacking the government and if I end up before the lord chancellor in the House of Lords, I shall say I want him off, I don't want him to sit, thank you very much. In the old days I wouldn't have turned a hair. With Mackay I wouldn't have bothered. Now I would."

Lord Irvine relishes the power he wields in all three arenas - he once famously likened himself to Cardinal Wolsey - and is determined to keep his feet firmly planted in all three camps.

He has turned a deaf ear to those who have been urging him to give up the secret system by which he appoints judges, and to set up a judicial appointments commission using modern selection methods to vet candidates.

It is the huge power of patronage the lord chancellor exercises in judicial appointments and in promoting lawyers to the coveted rank of QC which has landed him in trouble this time. A lawyer keen to win "silk", might not want to risk binning a letter addressed "Dear John" and signed "Yours ever, Derry".

Robert Stevens, master of Pembroke College, Oxford, and author of a historical study of the lord chancellor's office, said he could not recollect any previous lord chancellor pressing lawyers for party contributions. He said: "This shows the difficulty of having a politician as head of the judiciary. Perhaps it is time to split the various functions of the lord chancellor."

Another QC, a Labour supporter who was at the dinner and gave money, said: "The lord chancellor wears a number of hats.

"This is a hat too far and a begging bowl too far. I can see it was a stupid thing to have done. He's compromised himself. People will think they have to give because of his patronage."

fields.headline: Irvine's judgment has gone awry
fields.standfirst:
Canvassing for political donations is not appropriate behaviour for a lord chancellor, writes legal correspondent Clare Dyer, and this anachronistically powerful office needs to be checked

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: February 19 2001: Canvassing for political donations is not appropriate behaviour for a lord chancellor, writes legal correspondent Clare Dyer, and this anachronistically powerful office needs to be checked.
fields.body:
Derry Irvine deserves credit for two achievements which would never have happened had the Tories won the last election. The first was the Human Rights Act. It was ostensibly the home secretary's bill but Jack Straw was never particularly keen on it; Irvine's determination pushed it through. The second achievement was to curb the huge sums QCs were pocketing from the legal aid fund - way in excess of the earnings of any other professionals paid from public funds.

But this lord chancellor's abiding weakness is for power and the trappings of power. The overblown redecoration of his flat in the Houses of Parliament, with its £300 rolls of reproduction Pugin wallpaper and its large statues on MDF plinths, summed up the man who once famously compared himself to Cardinal Wolsey.

The role of the lord chancellor is a constitutional anomaly. It offends against the separation of powers - the rule that in a democracy, parliament, the government and the judiciary must be separate. The lord chancellor embodies all three roles, as a cabinet minister, head of the judiciary and the country's most senior judge, and speaker of the House of Lords.

In the past this affront to democracy has been accepted because the lord chancellor of the day adopted a resolutely non-political role, however political he had been before taking office.

Lord Hailsham, who as an MP had run for leadership of the Conservative party, put himself above politics when he became lord chancellor. The last lord chancellor, Lord Mackay of Clashfern, had been a senior judge before Mrs Thatcher offered him the job. No one could imagine either canvassing for party political contributions from lawyers, whose careers can be made or broken by the Lord Chancellor's patronage, as Lord Irvine has done.

The lord chancellor wears at least one hat too many. It's time for him to give up his stranglehold over the system of appointing judges. The system is too secret and unaccountable, with success too dependent on "who you know."

In the US, Canada, South Africa, Ireland, Israel and many European countries, judicial appointments commissions made up of judges, lawyers, lay people and members of the executive and legislature recommend candidates for judgeships using modern and transparent selection methods.

Before this Lord Chancellor got his bottom on the woolsack, Labour supported such a commission. Now that the new Human Rights Act requires judges to take much more political decisions, we need one more than ever.

webTitle: Campbell hits back at 'bog standard' critics

fields.headline: Campbell hits back at 'bog standard' critics
fields.standfirst:
Dispute over school slur

Special report: New Labour in power
Education site
fields.trailText: The prime minister's press spokesman, Alistair Campbell, yesterday hit back at his critics and defended his reference last week to secondary schools as being "bog standard comprehensives".
fields.body:
The prime minister's press spokesman, Alistair Campbell, yesterday hit back at his critics and defended his reference last week to secondary schools as being "bog standard comprehensives".

He was speaking after the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, and the education secretary, David Blunkett, both used their conference speeches to attack the phrase.

Mr Campbell's remarks had infuriated both teachers and Labour councillors.

In his conference speech Mr Prescott said: "Let's have more substance and less spin. Let's have more talk about specialisation and high standards. And less talk about bog standard policies."

Mr Blunkett told the delegates that it was a phrase which he, himself, would never have used.

Mr Campbell said yesterday he didn't "spin". "You get facts and the occasional opinion."

He did not, he said, see Mr Prescott's remarks in terms of a dressing down, however.

Mr Campbell and Mr Prescott are normally very close; it is possible that he would have been notified of Mr Prescott's attack in advance.

It is the third time in recent weeks, however, that Mr Campbell has come under criticism for mishandling key events. Some have claimed he acted hastily in the effective dismissal of the former Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson.

The cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson, also directed him to tone down his attacks on Tory policy.

 An on-line service promising to cut the hassle of dealing with government is launched today by Downing Street. The ukonline.gov.uk website is based on key moments in people's lives and offers help, from learning to drive, to having a baby or moving home. But critics claim the venture could also be used to distribute government propaganda, giving the Downing Street spin machine a vehicle to publish its own news service.

He was speaking after the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, and the education secretary, David Blunkett, both used their conference speeches to attack the phrase. fields.headline: Cradle to grave website fails to deliver
fields.standfirst: The government's new 'citizen portal' has more style than substance, writes Simon Jeffery
fields.trailText: The government's new 'citizen portal' has more style than substance, writes Simon Jeffery.
fields.body:
Life's a bitch, so the saying goes, and then you die. UK online, the government's new "citizen portal", certainly has the last base covered. If you ever need to notify the authorities of a recent bereavement, plan your funeral or make a will, this site will help.

As for the rest of life's traumas, they are all there too. If you want to learn how to drive (remember those first test nerves), move house or deal with crime UK online has the necessary advice. Notably, there is nothing on what to do if you have been put on a six-month waiting list to see an NHS consultant but that is perhaps to be expected.

You probably did not know you needed this information, and you probably never will. UK online's major fault (it has many, but this will have to satisfy us for now) is that rather than being targeted at the average citizen's needs it acts more as an umbrella site for the government's ever expanding internet presence.

For some reason, UK online cannot give you information on its own pages - instead it links you to a relevant section on another government department or agency website. This introduces you to some marvellous quirks (would you have ever imagined the Office of Fair Trading contains most of the information on death?) but is a little frustrating and smacks somewhat of inter-departmental squabbles among the Whitehall webmasters.

UK online, you can imagine, probably made a lot of sense to its civil service developers but, with its many links, may prove a little bewildering to users.

If we have an idea why UK online was set up it is not clear why you would use it. Quite why you would turn to the government, as opposed to friends, family and the medical profession, for information on having a baby (yes, this really is a cradle to grave operation) may be beyond the average citizen. Ditto going on holiday, another of UK online's "life episodes".

UK online has potential but, as a project, it is unfinished. Programme director Bob Evans wants to allow users to register a birth or apply for driving licence online. You can imagine that one day we may vote on a similar site.

But, for now, it has little to draw you in and nothing to hold you. The newsroom, for example, links directly to Downing Street and is filled with government good news. This is not a comprehensive citizen's guide nor a yellow pages of government services.

The first page you come to asks for some personal information - such as which part of the UK you want information on and in what language you want to read it - so it will be easier for you to make subsequent visits. Part of me cannot help feeling that is a little optimistic.

webTitle: Twelve dead in Brazil prison riots

fields.headline: Twelve dead in Brazil prison riots
fields.standfirst: Negotiations in Sao Paulo have secured the release of thousands of hostages held in South America's largest jail
fields.trailText: Negotiations in Sao Paulo have secure the release of thousands of hostages held in South America's largest jail.
fields.body:
A siege in which 12 prisoners were killed and nearly 8,000 people taken hostage after riots enveloped Carandiru jail in Sao Paulo, Brazil and spread to more than 28 other prisons looks to be over.

After a day of negotiations the prisoners have reached an agreement with the authorities to end their uprising and release the hostages, military police said.

"The visitors are leaving and employees are being freed," Nagashi Furukawa, state secretary of prison administration, said in a televised interview.

The inmates were protesting at the transfer of 10 prisoner leaders belonging to a major Rio de Janeiro crime gang said to exert considerable influence in the jail.

Rioting started during visiting hours. Armed with revolvers and grenades, prisoners took over the jail a block at a time.

An estimated 72 prison guards and more than 7,900 visitors - including 1,700 children - were inside when the rebellion started. Many of them were family members who stayed voluntarily.

"It was a carefully planned operation, by an organization that exerts its influence over inmates in other prisons," said Marco Vinicio Petreluzzi, Sao Paulo's public security secretary.

"The uprising was clearly the organization's way of getting back at us for the transfer of the 10."

Police attempted to take Carandiru back yesterday but had occupied only a small part of the jail by nightfall. Television footage shot from a helicopter showed police advancing slowly over rooftops and through the massive prison's courtyards.

Shots from a helicopter showed what appeared to be trails of blood running across one courtyard.

A bloody operation to quell a similar uprising in 1992 at Carandiru left at least 111 inmates dead.

Late last night 20 hostages were released and bused out of the prison, local media reported. A rebel leader, identified only as Roberto, said he expected the hostages to be released today.

Similar revolts spread to 28 other prisons across Sao Paulo state.

The 10 prison leaders were transferred on Friday after authorities at the jail raided their cells and found stockpiles of ammunition, knives and cell phones.

Riots and violence in the country's overcrowded jails are common. Many observers say the government is losing its grip on the prison system.

Jornal da Tarde
Radio Jovem Pan AM

fields.headline: Industry Standard cuts more jobs
fields.trailText: 5pm: Internet business magazine the Industry Standard Europe is expected to confirm more redundancies, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Internet business magazine the Industry Standard Europe has put the brakes on hiring new staff amid rumours of further job cuts in the US and a reassessment of international expansion.

Confirmation of redundancies, which will add to the 36 employees who were laid off in January, is expected tomorrow.

According to well-placed sources, some 65 employees from a total of 400, including 15 from editorial, are to be axed in order to cope with the sharp decline in ad revenues.

A Standard spokeswoman in the London office declined to comment, redirecting all enquiries to the company's head office in San Francisco.

The 60 or so staff in the recently established European headquarters in London are not thought to be affected by the latest cull.

However, a new recruit who was due to start attThe Industry Standard Europe today was told at the weekend that there was no longer a job for him.

The turn of fortune for the Standard has mirrored that of the dot.com industry it covers.

Only four months ago the magazine made its grand entry into the UK with a pyrotechnics and laser display at a swanky restaurant.

It was widely rumoured at the time that a total of £40m had been allocated for international expansion.

Advertising agencies were pulled in for a £5m UK launch campaign, and handsomely paid journalists were recruited.

However, rumours persist that the Industry Standard Europe is not meeting circulation targets, despite widespread distribution in WH Smith and a low price point of £1.95.

webTitle: Leeds FC offers WAP phone package

fields.headline: Leeds FC offers WAP phone package
fields.trailText: 5.30pm: Leeds United FC is to offer fans a club-specific WAP mobile phone package, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Leeds United fans will have the chance to bet on their club's football matches and other sporting events, receive club news and buy merchandise through a new WAP mobile phone service.

Leeds is to offer a club-specific WAP mobile phone package through a deal with mobile phone operator BTCellnet and WAP software and service developer WAP Integrators.

The move is likely to be replicated by other sports clubs.

Leeds is offering its 1.7 million fans a free Siemens handset, free BTCellnet connection and one month's free line rental when they sign up for a 12-month contract.

The cost of the monthly contract has not yet been decided.

As well as betting and gaming via the handset, fans will be able to play football quizzes and lotteries and catch up on club and football news, including statistics and history.

A "push" service, for fans who cannot watch a Leeds United game, will inform them on a real-time basis via SMS messaging when the team scores, wins a penalty or corner.

The service will also offer email and online chat facilities, and exclusive purchasing opportunities via the phone for club tickets and merchandise.

WAP Integrators believes the potential earnings from this type of deal are significant.

In addition to the betting, revenues will accrue from SMS, location services, quizzes and lotteries.

The club's directors believe there are 50,000 ardent fans who will be keen to have the service.

It will be promoted through the club's official shop, mailings to the supporter database and in match programmes.

The betting service will be trialled initially with approximately 100 Leeds United supporters before going out to a wider audience.

The concept is highly applicable to other sporting and leisure communities.

WAP Integrators will target football clubs in the Premier and Nationwide leagues once the concept has been tested with Leeds United.

The company will also be targeting European and Latin American clubs as well as other mainstream sports, such as rugby union and Superleague clubs.

fields.headline: The Terrorism Act
fields.standfirst: The Prevention of Terrorism Act 1973 has been superseded, as of this morning,   by a new and much more draconian piece of legislation directed at   international militant groups. Derek Brown explains
fields.trailText: The Prevention of Terrorism Act 1973 has been superseded, as of this morning, by a new and much more draconian piece of legislation directed at international militant groups. Derek Brown explains.
fields.body:
Why do we need new anti-terror laws?
The government believes that Britain is being used as a haven by groups intent on subverting the international order by violence. Among them are radical Islamist organisations, shadowy European revolutionary cells, and an assortment of liberation armies from the developing world. The old Prevention of Terrorism Act specifically targeted Irish militant groups.

What new powers will the government have?
The Home Secretary will be able to proscribe organisations, making membership or support of them illegal. The list starts with 14 groups, all Irish. It is likely to expand rapidly, though the Home Office says that ministers have yet to decide which groups will be added.

They must have some idea?
The organisations most mentioned are mostly Islamist ones. They include the al-Qaida movement headed by Osama bin Laden in Afghanistan, which is dedicated to the establishment of strict Islamist states around the world. Then there is Hizbollah in Lebanon, the Armed Islamic Group in Algeria, Al-Gama'at al-Islamiyya in Egypt, and a clutch of Palestinian armed groups, some Islamist and some secular.

Is it an anti-Arab thing?
The militant groups say it is, and have issued bellicose warnings that the legislation could make Britain a target. In fact, the net is likely to spread far beyond the Arab and Islamic world. Other groups likely to be targeted include the November 17 ultra-marxist cell in Greece, the Tamil Tiger liberation army in Sri Lanka, and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Columbia (FARC).

Is it simply a matter of banning such groups?
Far from it. Once an organisation is proscribed, it will be illegal to belong to it, support it financially, or even to be present at a meeting of three people or more if one of those people is a member.

Is the Act restricted to those groups which commit crimes here?
No. It will be an offence to incite, or call for, militant acts abroad. Jack Straw, the Home Secretary, says the government is determined that the UK will not be used as a base "for the planning and preparation of terrorism here or abroad".

How is terrorism defined?
It used to be, roughly speaking, violence with political motivation. From now on the definition will include anyone serving a "political, religious or ideological" cause, who uses violence or the threat of violence against people or property.

But terrorism still has to involve violence?
The new Act has an interesting new IT-age dimension. It targets so-called cyber-terrorists who hack into computer networks to undermine governments or threaten lives.

Who is in favour of the Act?
Our government and governments everywhere, both repressive and otherwise. Egypt, under threat from the Muslim Brotherhood, is very keen for Britain to clamp down on alleged conspirators here. Sri Lanka takes a similar view. The USA also appproves - the State Department maintains a list of nearly 40 organisations it deems to be subversive.

And who is against?
Militant groups, of course, hate it. So do civil libertarians, who are aghast at the sweeping powers given to ministers and officials. They point out that had the new Act been in force a little more than a decade ago, supporters of Nelson Mandela in Britain could have been defined as terrorists.

fields.headline: Charities concerned over commissioner's powers
fields.trailText: The new Welsh children's commissioner, Peter Clarke, could face legal challenges unless he gets new powers, leading charities in Wales have warned. Maggie Murray reports
fields.body:
The new Welsh children's commissioner, Peter Clarke, could face legal challenges unless he gets new powers, leading charities in Wales have warned.

The warning follows a meeting between leading children's charities in the principality and their legal advisers, and comes just days before Mr Clarke is due to take up his appointment on 1 March.

Charities are concerned that any comment he makes on issues involving children but outside his jurisdiction could be legally challenged. This could cover all non-devolved matters. For instance, if children were in young offender institutions, which come under the Home Office, then the commissioner might not be able to comment on their welfare. And, at the moment, he will only be able to comment informally on court cases that might be open to a legal challenge.

One of the charities concerned with the legal oversight is NSPCC Cymru. "The government has given assurances that the commissioner would be able to make informal comment outside his remit as currently contained in the [children's commissioner for Wales] bill," policy adviser Sara Reid said.

"But we have taken legal advice and this is incorrect because the commissioner could be legally challenged if he made comments during the course of his investigations where he had no formal mandate. Relying on the goodwill of the government is unsatisfactory and it is vital that the commissioner is given the correct legal powers to do his job effectively.

"The best time to clarify the extent of the commissioner's responsibilities is now, during the passage of the bill."

Mr Clarke, who was appointed as the first children's commissioner in the UK last the autumn, said: "Until the bill has gone through I don't know exactly what powers I will have, but obviously I am concerned that no child in Wales should be excluded from being helped by what I might be able to do for them."

He added: "There are, though, wide powers already contained within the bill and if we begin with what is contained in the bill then I don't see any reason why it would not be possible to campaign for a wider remit. If I feel I need more powers to do an effective job for the children of Wales then I will be saying so loud and clear."

webTitle: British-US strikes 'followed escalation in Iraqi attacks'

fields.headline: British-US strikes 'followed escalation in Iraqi attacks'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Downing Street today strongly defended Friday's bombing raid on Baghdad with the disclosure that British and American aircraft came under attack more than 22 times in January.
fields.body:
Downing Street today strongly defended Friday's bombing raid on Baghdad with the disclosure that British and American aircraft came under attack more than 22 times in January.

The figure, higher than for the whole of the year 2000, reflected a broader intensification of Iraqi offensive activity since the New Year, a spokesman said.

It is believed to be linked to Baghdad's acquisition of a new fibre optic aircraft detection system, which was targeted in Friday's air strikes.

The strikes have led to a torrent of international condemnation, headed by the Arab League, Russia, China and France.

Baghdad said two civilians died in the raids which, said Britain and the US, were necessary to defend the safety of Allied air crew patrolling no-fly zones in the north and south of the country.

Last year, Allied planes took action on 34 occasions in the northern no-fly zone and 44 in the south. Downing Street said this showed there was no increase in the frequency of Allied responses in 2001.

"The action was directed exclusively against military facilities comprising elements of the Iraqi integrated air defence system," the spokesman said.

"We make no apologies for carrying out this action, as we believe it was the right thing to do."

This morning, Labour MP George Galloway renewed his attack on the government's stance toward Iraq, describing its defence of the raids as a "pitiful excuse".

Speaking during a hastily arranged visit to Baghdad, the Glasgow Kelvin MP said: "It would be laughable if it were not so tragic.

"It is the most pitiful excuse for attacking somebody's country that I have heard in my lifetime. If the policy is so good, how come only Britain and the US are doing it?"

Mr Galloway, a long-standing critic of Britain's policy on Iraq and UN sanctions against Saddam Hussein's regime, today visited the hospital in the capital where people wounded during the raids were being treated.

He claimed three civilians had died and seven others were still in hospital following the bombings, including a 12-year-old boy and a mother with her two children.

"It was very distressing. Burning hot steel spinning around civilian streets does a lot of damage," he said.

"The action was directed exclusively against military facilities comprising elements of the Iraqi integrated air defence system," the spokesman said. "We make no apologies for carrying out this action, as we believe it was the right thing to do." This morning, Labour MP George Galloway renewed his attack on the government's stance toward Iraq, describing its defence of the raids as a "pitiful excuse". Speaking during a hastily arranged visit to Baghdad, the Glasgow Kelvin MP said: "It would be laughable if it were not so tragic. "It is the most pitiful excuse for attacking somebody's country that I have heard in my lifetime. If the policy is so good, how come only Britain and the US are doing it?" Mr Galloway, a long-standing critic of Britain's policy on Iraq and UN sanctions against Saddam Hussein's regime, today visited the hospital in the capital where people wounded during the raids were being treated. He claimed three civilians had died and seven others were still in hospital following the bombings, including a 12-year-old boy and a mother with her two children. "It was very distressing. Burning hot steel spinning around civilian streets does a lot of damage," he said. webTitle: John Patterson on this week's US movies

fields.headline: Death warmed up
fields.standfirst: John Patterson despairs at this week's US movies - a lame vehicle for Chris Rock and a laughable Keavu Reeves weepie
fields.trailText: John Patterson despairs at this week's US movies - a lame vehicle for Chris Rock and a laughable Keavu Reeves weepie
fields.body:
February in Hollywood is the annual equivalent of bin-night, when the studios throw out the trash they think nobody with a brain is ever likely to want. And it has certainly been a dumpster of a month so far. First there was Valentine, which cried out for a stake through its heart, then Hannibal and Saving Silverman, both of which were better left for dead. Instead they were smeared across 3,000 screens nationwide.

This weekend, in the place of trash, we got Hollywood's version of recycling. I always understood this was a process whereby rubbish was reconfigured into something usable, but movie-makers seem to think it's a reverse-alchemical process for turning gold into base metal. There were two new releases - Down to Earth and Sweet November - and both were dime-store remakes of only marginally better movies.

There were high hopes for Down to Earth, the debut star vehicle for comedian Chris Rock. Rock joined the cast of Saturday Night Live the same season as Adam Sandler, Chris Farley, Rob Schneider and David Spade, with whom he shared a cramped office. All of them put Rock in their own SNL spinoff movies but it has taken him nearly seven years to get his own name above the title. Meanwhile, he has increased his reputation with The Chris Rock Show on HBO and two blistering stand-up specials. The first of them, Bring the Pain, marked the first time a young, hip, black American male had expressed his detailed contempt for some of the idiocies of gangsta-rap culture.

Down to Earth was nothing like as funny or harsh as Bring the Pain, and it is hard to imagine what Rock saw in this project about a black comedian who is called to heaven 44 years too early, then returns to earth in the body of a 55-year-old white capitalist pig. Which brings us back to recycling. Down to Earth is the umpteenth remake of the 1941 comedy Here Comes Mr Jordan, and this version comes courtesy of the people who gave us American Pie. Most assume that it is just a remake of 1978's Heaven Can Wait - whose writers, Warren Beatty and Elaine May, are credited as source material. Here Comes Mr Jordan was based on a play by Harry Segall called Halfway to Heaven, and was so popular that it spawned a rash of wartime imitators. There was A Guy Named Joe (boringly remade by Spielberg as Always), The Horn Blows at Midnight, and Jordan's own musical semi-sequel, called - well, fancy that - Down to Earth. Add Powell and Pressburger's superficially similar A Matter of Life and Death and you've got one well-trodden stairway to heaven.

Is the bumbling, shapeless Heaven Can Wait worth remaking? If I want Warren in his Julie Christie period and Julie in her perm period I'll take the mighty mighty McCabe and Mrs Miller any day. Down to Earth certainly does nothing to invigorate the material, which originally flourished in the more god-fearing world war two era when heaven was on a lot more people's minds than it is now.

Sweet November, on the other hand, brought hell right to the front of my mind. It is a remake of a 1968 weepie of the same title with the unlikely starring duo of Sandy Dennis (a byword for irritatingly "kooky") and Anthony Newley. This time the roles are taken by Charlize Theron and Keanu Reeves. She's a free spirit (you can tell by all the cartwheels she does) who lives with a different man for successive 30-day periods, then sets them free after showing them how great life really is. Of course Keanu's businessman falls for her, but then she catches one of those photogenic terminal diseases that wastes free spirits away but leaves no outward trace. Theron goes through the cutesy motions with some efficiency, but Keanu is all adrift. He can do clear and simple - as in Point Break and The Matrix - but deep and complex defeat him. In Sweet November he looks quite lost playing the yuppie who regains his soul but loses the love of his life. In the auditorium, meanwhile, the audience is losing its collective lunch, as it prays for an end to Hollywood recycling - or regurgitation - and inwardly howls, "Roll on, March!"

fields.headline: Birt ally quits BBC
fields.trailText: 4.15pm: Margaret Salmon, one of Lord Birt's closest allies is leaving her £230,000-a-year job at the BBC, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
One of Lord Birt's closest allies, Margaret Salmon, is leaving the BBC where she held a £230,000-a-year job.

Ms Salmon, 53, was head of BBC resources the unit responsible for studio hire and outside broadcasts.

A spokesman said she had decided to take "early retirement".

Ms Salmon was a close colleague of Lord Birt during his years as director-general of the BBC.

She was responsible for implementing some of his most unpopular policies.

"She had a difficult time with staff, axing thousands of jobs and introducing the reviled producer choice for Birt," said one colleague.

Ms Salmon's departure follows the exit of two other senior executives who were close to Lord Birt - head of policy Patricia Hodgson and news chief Tony Hall.

Today, Lord Birt's successor Greg Dyke said Ms Salmon had planned to retire in 1999 but had been persuaded to stay for another two years.

"I've enjoyed working with Margaret for the past year," said Mr Dyke.

"She has done a great job in getting the business into a position where we expect it will make its first profits next year," he added.

She said: "Working for the BBC for 10 years as director of personnel and chief executive of resources has been a tremenduous privilege.

"My personnel years involved supporting colleagues through some ecxciting times and I am pleased as I leave resources the business in such good shape to support the BBC in future."

Ms Salmon's appointment as head of resources was greeted with surprise two years ago.

Many believed she was being promoted as a reward for her loyalty to the BBC chief.

However, she won the support of staff unions, who had clashed heavily with her predecessor Rod Lynch over his suspected privatisation ambitions.

Under his stewardship, the main BBC TV studios were available to all comers.

These included businesses who wanted to entertain corporate clients on sets such as that for Noel Edmonds' House Party.

In a reverse of Mr Lynch's policy, Ms Salmon reintegrated resources into the BBC and, in the process, reduced the number of staff working under her from 6,000 to 2,000.

webTitle: Top teams enjoy a one-goal weekend

fields.headline: Top teams enjoy a one-goal weekend
fields.trailText: Until the 69th minute of their match against Lecce yesterday, Roma's Valentine's week was looking a bit like Vanessa Feltz's belly: ie. somewhat deflated. With no Totti, little in the way of scoring opportunities, and the painful defeat against Liverpool still stinging the mind like a lost love, there was nothing for the Stadio Olimpico crowd to get excited about.
fields.body:
Until the 69th minute of their match against Lecce yesterday, Roma's Valentine's week was looking a bit like Vanessa Feltz's belly: ie. somewhat deflated. With no Totti, little in the way of scoring opportunities, and the painful defeat against Liverpool still stinging the mind like a lost love, there was nothing for the Stadio Olimpico crowd to get excited about.

But then up popped Argentine international Walter Samuel - now the second most expensive defender in the world after Rio Ferdinand - to head his first goal for the club from two yards out. Cue wild, serotonin-releasing celebrations from Samuel and most of the 60,000 crowd. Suddenly Roma started playing like Serie A leaders again.

Samuel's goal proved to be enough as Roma held on for a 1-0 win, but no one should be fooled. For most of the first-half, the Giallorossi were as lifeless as their fans, who staged a 15-minute silent protest at the start of the match in protest at the Bologna police, whom they blame for putting a Roma supporter in a coma during their game their last weekend.

"It was very difficult to get straight into the match today after the Uefa Cup tie, above all against aggressive, hostile opponents like Lecce," admitted Capello afterwards. "In the first half-an-hour we didn't play because we were tired after the match against Liverpool. However, we played well in the second half and after we took the lead we created more space and played well on the counter-attack."

Meanwhile, the club should receive further good news later today. Francesco Totti, who last week accused the club of screwing him over - "I feel like Roma are making fun of me. I feel the urge to leave. It's not a matter of money but respect" - has settled his differences with president Franco Sensi and will sign a new £25m five-year deal this afternoon. Judging by their lacklustre performances in the last two games without him, Totti is worth every penny.

Juventus and Lazio's late, late shows

The first signs of spring were in the air in Italy this weekend. So it is perhaps appropriate that Alessandro Del Piero - again a second-half substitute - is beginning to show encouraging signs of recovering from his two-year footballing hibernation following his knee ligament injury.

With less than ten minutes to go, Juventus's trip to bottom-placed Bari seemed to be fizzling out into a 0-0 draw, but Del Piero had other ideas. After picking up the ball just inside the Bari half he then skipped past three defenders, sold Moroccan defender Rachid Neqrouz an exquisite dummy, and beat Belgian goalkeeper Jean-Francois Gillet with a delicate chip from an impossibly tight angle to give Juve a 1-0 win.

It was Del Piero's first game since his father died of cancer in midweek, and the goal was a fitting tribute.

Under-strength Lazio also left it late before squeezing their way to an undeserved 1-0 away at Perugia. Missing Dino Baggio, Pavel Nedved, Sinisa Mihajlovic and Hernan Crespo, Dino Zoff brought in Fabrizio Ravanelli up front and Roberto Baronio in midfield. But the two were largely anonymous as Perugia, inspired by Fabio Liverani, dominated the game.

But the home side couldn't score. And in the 89th minute they were pick-pocketed by Diego Simeone, whose deflected chip from the edge of was palmed into his own net by goalkeeper Andrea Mazzantini. The result gives Lazio their fifth straight away victory in the league - a club record.

After the match, Perugia coach Serse Cosmi was an angry man, describing the referee's performance as "unbelievable".

"There were lots of strange episodes in the Lazio area," he said. "I saw a lot of fouls but the referee didn't see anything at all.

"We didn't deserve to lose," Cosmi continued. "On the contrary, I think that we didn't even deserve to draw! But, as the match in the game at the Olimpico showed, we've been very unlucky against Lazio this season."

And Cosmi even found time to dismiss Lazio's prospects of retaining the Scudetto. "I don't think Lazio are in form," he blasted. "If I was Zoff I'd be quite worried about the future. I think that if their target is the title, then Perugia may as well aim for that as well."

Zoff decided not to be drawn into a slanging match - probably wise, considering Cosmi looks like a nightclub bouncer and possesses the biggest neck in all of football - and instead gave Perugia credit for their performance.

"I admit that Perugia played a terrific match and gave us troubles, especially in the first half," he said. "However we were forced to play with four substitutes. Naturally they lacked confidence, so we suffered as a result."

The best of the rest

Italy's hooliganism problem is growing. Two policemen were injured by fireworks during Atalanta's match against Vicenza - one had his finger blown off and another suffered a slash in his leg. Unfortunately, fourth-placed Atalanta were unable to produce similar fireworks on the pitch. Nicola Ventola scored first for Atalanta before Vincenzo Sommese grabbed an equaliser 17 minutes from time to earn the visitors a 1-1 draw.

Expect Atalanta's Champions League berth to come under increasing pressure from fifth-placed Parma. Their impressive run of form under new coach Renzo Uliveieri continued with a 3-0 home win against Brescia, thanks to second-half goals from Patrick Mboma, Sergio Conceicao and Junior.

Meanwhile, both Milan clubs continue to struggle. Relegation-threatened Napoli beat Internazionale 1-0 thanks to a 53rd minute Matuzalem Da Silva strike - a result which left Inter coach Marco Tardelli struggling for an explanation.

"We are a strange team," he admitted. "I'm angry with my players. "Tonight we could have reached a place near the Champions' League zone but we usually fail in these situations.

And AC Milan didn't fare much better at home to Bologna. After going 2-0 ahead through two goals from Andrei Shevchenko, Milan succumbed to a second-half Bologna barrage. Giacomo Cipriani (2) and Beppe Signori looked like giving the visitors their first away win over Milan since 1974 - but deep into injury time Luigi Sala grabbed an undeserving equaliser, leaving Bologna coach Francesco Guidolin as sick as the proverbial parrot.

"We threw it away," he said. "We played much better than Milan and even after conceding two goals against the run of play we showed all that was necessary to come back and then take the lead.

"After the two consecutive home defeats we really needed a win but this draw means nothing. Football can be so cruel sometimes."

Words that many managers will be echoing after this weekend's games.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: IDM seals deal with e-command
fields.trailText: The Institute of Direct Marketing is teaming up with networking specialists e-command to improve direct marketing on the internet, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
A deal to improve direct marketing through the internet has been brokered by The Institute of Direct Marketing.

The IDM, which has a membership of over 5,500 direct marketeers, is teaming up with e-command.co.uk, a new media networking organisation with 300 e-commerce members.

The deal aims to improve the relationship between the traditional direct marketing industry and newer web counterparts by encouraging networking, knowledge-sharing and training between the groups.

IDM bosses believe many e-commerce sites could have saved themselves from obscurity had they employed traditional direct marketing skills as an integrated part of their promotional campaigns.

"Take Boo.com, for example," says an IDM spokeswoman. "It spent millions on an ad campaign to drive users to its site but did nothing with the data it captured when users got there. The fundamentals of direct marketing could help e-commerce companies move forward."

"This partnership means each group can continue to grow independently and at the same time benefit from the many initiatives undertaken by the other. We are delighted with the alliance because it introduces even more e-commerce professionals to the IDM," said IDM managing director Professor Derek Holder.

E-command.co.uk co-founder Sharon Smith added: "This partnership means we can ensure our members receive the best possible direct and interactive marketing training to build on the knowledge base they acquire at our evening seminars."

Last month IDM announced a similar strategic relationship with Phoenix Network, formerly known as e-women, an organisation for women in e-commerce, which also forms a council of the Direct Marketing Association.

Both agreements mean preferential rates and treatment for each organisation's members when making use of the other's events.

fields.headline: Express to close investigations unit
fields.trailText: 5pm: The Express is dismantling its four-strong investigations unit, in a bid to cut operating costs, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Express is dismantling its four-strong investigations unit, in a bid to cut operating costs.

Jonathan Calvert, Michael Gillard, David Connett and Lucy Johnston were brought over from the Observer under the former editor Rosie Boycott, who wanted to make the paper a credible mid-market paper of the Left.

They have now have been told Express Newspapers can no longer afford to justify a team dedicated to investigative journalism - by its nature a costly, long-term investment.

The four journalists have been told they will be given jobs elsewhere in Express Newspapers.

It is thought they will all go to the Sunday Express.

"It was part of the drive to take the Express to a higher level of the market," said an insider.

"They were saying they wanted it to be somewhere between the Telegraph and the Mail, a kind of 'broadloid' for thinking people.

"But I think there's no doubt an investigations unit is an expensive luxury as far as the new management is concerned."

Jonathan Calvert, Michael Gillard, David Connett and Lucy Johnston were brought over from the Observer under the former editor Rosie Boycott, who wanted to make the paper a credible mid-market paper of the Left. They have now have been told Express Newspapers can no longer afford to justify a team dedicated to investigative journalism - by its nature a costly, long-term investment. The four journalists have been told they will be given jobs elsewhere in Express Newspapers. It is thought they will all go to the Sunday Express. "It was part of the drive to take the Express to a higher level of the market," said an insider. "They were saying they wanted it to be somewhere between the Telegraph and the Mail, a kind of 'broadloid' for thinking people. "But I think there's no doubt an investigations unit is an expensive luxury as far as the new management is concerned."

fields.headline: UK adspend tops £8bn
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: UK adspend increased 5.5% last year, topping the £8bn mark for the first time, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
UK advertising expenditure increased by 5.5% in the 12 months to December last year to top the £8bn mark for the first time.

The figures, released today by media buying agency CIA, suggest the much talked about slowdown in advertising may not be as pronounced as previously thought.

But car manufacturers such as Rover and Vauxhall and food companies, traditionally the biggest advertisers, are spending less.

Expenditure on advertising for food products fell by 4.7%, while car companies spent a worrying 6.6% less than in 1999.

"We seem to be seeing a move away from traditional FMCG advertising spend to niche markets such as the computer sector or entertainment and media," said David Fletcher, vice-chairman of CIA.

The biggest growth sector was computer advertising, where spending increased by 35%, closely followed by finance which rose 25%.

Advertisers are allocating a larger proportion of their budget to press advertising at the expense of more costly TV adverts.

Expenditure on press reached £3.1bn last year, compared with £3.8bn for TV spend.

And radio advertising continues to grow, up 4.8% on 1999 to £555m.

webTitle: Feature: Profile of architect Luis Barragan

fields.headline: Cowboy builder
fields.standfirst: Cool fountains, shaded courtyards in uplifting colours - everything the Mexican Luis Barragan designed was touched with magic, says  Jonathan Glancey
fields.trailText: Cool fountains, shaded courtyards in uplifting colours - everything the Mexican Luis Barragan designed was touched with magic, says Jonathan Glancey.
fields.body:
The spirit of the Mexican Luis Barragan (1902-88) broods gently over the world of modern European architecture. Now and then its presence is felt - when an architect adds a sudden burst of warm colour to brighten up the otherwise essentially cool, neutral aesthetic of much of today's European design.

Among buildings designed over the past decade alone, the delightful houses that John Pawson and Claudio Silvestrin built for a German art dealer in Majorca and Seth Stein for himself in Knightsbridge owe more than a little to Barragan. So, too, does some of the work of the inspired Japanese architect Tadao Ando. Barragan's name is hallowed - and deservedly so. His work, celebrated in a new exhibition at London's Design Museum, reminds architects worldwide that the best architecture has spirit and soul.

That soul is present in every post-1945 Barragan project: his own house and studio (Tacubaya, 1947), the San Cristobal stud farm (Los Clubes, 1968), the chapel of the Capuchinas Sacramentarias del Purismo Corazon de Maria (1955), all in and around Mexico City. It is even present in the astonishing abstract eruption of the Satellite City tower (1957), a public artwork on a scintillating scale alongside the Queretaro highway.

Each building, garden or artwork lifts the spirit. The life-enhancing chapel is achingly beautiful inside. Yet, like so many Barragan buildings, it is ultra-modern, while realised in the simplest materials - in this case adobe, timber and limewash. When Barragan uses the strictest rules of geometry, it feels as if Mies van der Rohe has come out on holiday to Mexico, knocked back a few tequilas, relaxed, coated his steel-framed buildings in thick mud walls and then painted them pink.

These two names are not linked by chance. Barragan, raised on a ranch near Mazamitra, Guadalajara, was educated by Marists and Jesuits before training as an engineer. After graduating in 1924, he decided to become an architect. He taught himself partly by setting off on a highly personalised grand tour of Europe and north Africa. Although profoundly moved by the Moorish Alhambra in Granada, Spain, and the mud architecture of north Africa, he was equally impressed by lectures he attended in Paris given by Le Corbusier and by some of the best early Modern movement architecture.

I'm not sure if he ever saw it in the flesh, so to speak, but Mies van der Rohe's German pavilion, built for the 1929 Barcelona World Fair, must have been a significant influence. When, as at the breathtaking San Cristobal stud farm where he kept his own horses, Barragan plays with elemental geometric forms he seems to be arriving at the same point as Mies did at Barcelona, but under an even harder sun.

Both architects, Prussian and Mexican, understood the mollifying play of water when set closely against the clean lines of modern buildings. Both, whatever Mies might have said in public, remained Catholics. Both proved that spirituality and modern architecture could inhabit the same abstract realm.

Where they differed was in the plans of their buildings: where Mies became the champion of the open-plan, of indeterminate space, Barragan's houses, especially those he built in his property-developing days in the 1930s and 1940s, were based around individual rooms. Tradition tugged at Barragan's sensibilities all his life: he was, at heart, a horseman, a gentleman rancher. He was never a Modern iconoclast or utopian dreamer as were so many of his European contemporaries.

Barragan was normally a generous man. When he was asked to rebuild and extend a convent in Tlalplan not far from his own home, he paid for the extra work needed to give the resident nuns a special design far and above what they had expected. The result was a sensual, spiritual place influenced by the Court of the Myrtles at the Alhambra.

Just as the Moors sought to create oases mediated by rich and subtle architecture in north Africa and southern Spain, so Barragan aimed to re-create echoes of the Garden of Eden in many of his projects. Aside from the Alhambra, he was much taken by the French gardens of artist Ferdinand Bac in Provence, and particularly by the Les Columbiers near Menton.

The essential architecture of Barragan, in its mature post-1945 phase, is a very particular brand of Mies and Le Corbusier-influenced European modernism, with a touch of north Africa, the Alhambra and the sunny gardens of Ferdinand Bac. The use of gloriously touchy-feely local materials, plus a generous use of water ("In fountains," he liked to say, "silence sings") and colour, completes the picture.

"Any work of architecture that does not express serenity is a mistake," said Barragan, when accepting the Pritzker prize for architecture in 1980. He went on to remind his audience of the other words that ought to matter. These were not "orthogonal", "postmodern", "net-to-gross" or "neoprene", but "spellbound", "magic", "enchantment", "intimacy" and "amazement". It is essential, he said, for architects to "see in such a way that [their] vision is not overpowered by rational analysis".

Barragan's are buildings that don't disappoint. But don't, having seen the Design Museum show, imagine that a charter flight to Mexico will find you in a world designed according to Barragan. If not exactly a prophet without honour in his own country, Barragan still cuts a lone figure in Mexico as elsewhere: so many architects and clients must want to overcome "rational analysis", but the danger of going the way of colourful kitsch and over-sentimentality is always there. Invoking the spirit of Luis Barragan is much harder than it looks.

· Luis Barragan: the Quiet Revolution is at the Design Museum, London SE1 (020-7940 8790), from March 9 to July 8.

webTitle: Government launches 'cradle to grave' site for citizens

fields.headline: Government launches 'cradle to grave' site for citizens
fields.standfirst:
A new UK portal claims to provide information on everything from birth to bereavement

More net news
fields.trailText:
A new UK portal claims to provide information on everything from birth to bereavement.
More net news
fields.body:
The UK government has relaunched its main citizen web site today with a set of services designed to make it easier to deal with the government during key life events.

The government promised that the UK Online portal will cut bureaucracy by allowing people round-the-clock, direct access to information about "cradle to grave" services.

The site - which was launched in a test format in December and has attracted 123,000 visitors a day - is centred around six "life episodes", such as having a baby, dealing with bereavement and learning to drive.

Bob Evans, the programme director for UK Online, admitted that at the moment users cannot truly conduct business with the government online, but he hopes to change that soon. He wants to allow users to register a birth or apply for driving licence online, for example.

"Now that we have the infrastructure in place, I'd like to roll out two departmental services a month from the middle of the year," he said.

Cabinet office minister Ian McCartney said: "This web site is a key part of our £1bn drive to get all government services online. It's turning government on its head - ensuring convenient and accessible services organised around people's needs."

The UK Online portal has also been redesigned to cater for the partially sighted. Mr Evans hopes to add digital television, WAP and public kiosk services soon.

fields.headline: Lawyers round on Irvine
fields.standfirst:
Lawyers round on Irvine in fundraising row

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, was castigated for "stupidity" and "abuse of power" by Labour-supporting QCs yesterday over a letter he signed asking them to give at least £200 each at a fund-raising dinner to help secure a second term for Labour.
fields.body:
The lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, was castigated for "stupidity" and "abuse of power" by Labour-supporting QCs yesterday over a letter he signed asking them to give at least £200 each at a fund-raising dinner to help secure a second term for Labour.

But lawyers across the political spectrum drew back from endorsing the demand made by Michael Howard QC, the former Tory home secretary, that Lord Irvine's act of "fundamental corruption" required his instant resignation from Tony Blair's cabinet.

"Not the way to behave, but not a resignation matter," said one former Conservative government law officer.

He reflected widespread dismay that a man in Lord Irvine's position should lay himself open to complaints that he has abused his "heavy powers of patronage" over the appointment of judges and QCs.

Another prominent QC, Anthony Scrivener, who gave Labour £6,000 in the past - and was tipped as a potential lord chancellor - but is now disillusioned by its policies, accused Lord Irvine of throwing away the centuries-old impartiality of his office.

Mr Scrivener said: "I cannot think how anyone in their right mind could have thought it right. He has thrown away the impartiality of the lord chancellor, which everybody has been able to maintain for hundreds of years."

But other lawyers said many recipients of Lord Irvine's invitation to a West End dinner did not stand to suffer or benefit in any way from his attitude.

The offending letter, on Labour party (not Whitehall) notepaper, was sent to senior barristers whom the lord chancellor is empowered to make QCs or judges, as well to leading solicitors, whose body the Law Society is in conflict with him over legal aid reforms.

The letter was an invitation to a fund-raising dinner on February 7 hosted by Lord Irvine at the Atlantic Bar and Grill in central London. The guest of honour was the prime minister's wife, Cherie Booth QC, and the attorney general, Lord Williams of Mostyn, was the guest speaker.

The event has been held annually for the past three years, Lord Irvine's letter said. "There is no ticket price this year. We will, however, be making an appeal on the evening for the Labour party's general election fund.

"The minimum amount you will be invited to pledge is £200 per person, but we know that many of you will take this opportunity to make a significant contribution to party funds in order to ensure a second term." The letter was signed "Yours ever, Derry."

A Labour-supporting QC who attended the dinner and gave a donation but asked not to be named said: "I can see it was a stupid thing to have done. He has compromised himself." A Tory QC said: "Typical of the man, he is lacking in common sense. I am sure he didn't mean to alarm people, but there will be lawyers who think their future depends on keeping the lord chancellor sweet."

Mr Scrivener said he had voted Labour in 1997 and had given £6,000 to the party at a fund-raising dinner - "the standard rate we were asked to provide." It had been solicited by "a very attractive girl" rather than the lord chancellor, he recalled.

But he was disillusioned by Labour's legal policy, including restriction of trial by jury, and might not vote at the next election. "The European Court of Human Rights was already looking at the position of the lord chancellor. They say 'how can you have a politician running the show?' We've always said 'you can in fact because the custom has been that the lord chancellor has always been independent'. And there he is throwing away his independence in one letter."

Labour party officials joined Downing Street in insisting that Mr Blair's first boss in legal chambers had done nothing wrong. He had not been told how much anyone attending the dinner actually donated to the party.

"I don't think it's a secret to anybody that Derry Irvine is a prominent member of, and supporter of, the Labour government. Therefore him hosting a fund-raising dinner for the Labour party doesn't strike me as newsworthy. A Labour lord chancellor hosting a fund-raising dinner is no different from a Labour prime minister hosting one," said Mr Blair's spokesman, Alastair Campbell.

But a Labour-supporting QC who did not attend the dinner called it an abuse of power. "If the Labour party is saying the lord chancellor won't be influenced in choosing judges and QCs, why use him to solicit funds from lawyers. Why wasn't it the home secretary or the prime minister?"

The row highlights the difficulty of balancing the lord chancellor's conflicting roles as head of the independent judiciary, with responsibility for judicial appointments, with his actively-political role in cabinet and committees.

Lord Mackay, the last Tory lord chancellor, was unpolitical. Lord Hailsham, whom he succeeded was highly partisan, though not in that job, his friends said yesterday. Mr Howard, a successful planning QC, called it a "fundamental corruption of the office of lord chancellor" which justified his removal.

fields.headline: Calls for Irvine's resignation
fields.standfirst:
The lord chancellor's Tory opponents say his fundraising efforts for Labour are an abuse of power

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Lord Irvine's Tory opponents say his fundraising efforts for Labour are an abuse of power.
fields.body:
Lord Irvine, the lord chancellor, is facing demands for his resignation after it was revealed he had lobbied lawyers at a fundraising dinner for Labour Party donations.

Opponents in the Tory party have accused Lord Irvine, who is a close friend of the prime minister, Tony Blair, of abusing a traditionally neutral office for party political gain.

Others have called for his office to be reformed to prevent such conflicts of interest.

The lord chancellor is the head of the judiciary, Britain's most senior judge and responsible for appointing new judges from the lawyers' ranks. Many of those he lobbied could be potential candidates.

Michael Howard, the former home secretary, said Lord Irvine's fund-raising activities were "a fundamental corruption" of the office of lord chancellor and demanded his resignation.

"This is the man who appoints QCs, who appoints judges, and he writes a letter to the very people who are candidates for those positions saying: 'Come to this dinner, you don't need to pay anything but you are expected to contribute at least £200 to the Labour Party'," he said.

Tory MP Michael Fabricant, a member of the Commons home affairs select committee, said he would urge the committee to hold an inquiry into the matter.

"The idea that someone who appoints judges ... should now be trawling for party funds is reminiscent of the worst days of the Clinton White House," he said.

Downing Street said Lord Irving had done nothing wrong and maintained that the row was contrived.

The prime minister's official spokesman said it was no secret that Irvine was a Labour supporter, "therefore hosting a fundraising dinner for the Labour party is not terribly newsworthy".

Liberal Democrat peer Lord Lester said the lord chancellor's role should be reformed, something he claimed Lord Irvine supported before taking office.

"When he was in Opposition he was in favour of changing the system but while in office he has held on to his empire.

"It says in the Bible that no man should serve two masters. The lord chancellor serves two if not three ... and he cannot go on wearing all these different hats," he said.

fields.trailText: There is rare unanimity in the regional press about the Anglo-American air strikes on Iraq: they are universally condemned, but for widely differing reasons.
fields.body:
There is rare unanimity in the regional press about the Anglo-American air strikes on Iraq: they are universally condemned, but for widely differing reasons.

As usual, the Arab papers heavily rely on western agency reports, but are following the political fall-out of the raids closely. The Bahrain Tribune, for example, has picked up agency reports of dissent in the Labour party over the airstrikes on Iraq: "Prime minister Tony Blair came under pressure from within his Labour party yesterday for Britain's participation in air raids around the Iraqi capital of Baghdad. Labour deputy Tony Benn described the air strikes as a "terrorist" attack and called for parliament to be recalled to discuss the issue. There could have been a revolt within the party, if MPs had not been on holiday, Clive Soley, a Labour member, told the Independent on Sunday."

The paper also gives prominence to a column by Susan Cornwell of Reuters, analysing the Anglo-American special relationship: "US President George W Bush and British prime minister Tony Blair have never met. But they have already launched air strikes against Iraq together in a joint military action that should help break the ice when they finally shake hands in Washington this week. The US-British attack on radar stations near Baghdad on Friday speaks volumes about the long-term 'special relationship' linking Washington and London, even when their leaders are strangers and come from opposite sides of the ideological fence."

In Dubai, the Gulf News has some interesting online opinion polls, showing that its readers strongly oppose the air strikes, and are against the continued deployment of western troops in the region.

The Jordan Times devotes a lot of space to parliamentary condemnation of the air strikes: "Prime minister Ali Abul Ragheb on Sunday strongly criticised the US-UK air strikes against Iraq and said such acts will instigate unrest in the region and threaten its stability and security During the ordinary session of parliament, MPs had harsh criticism for the latest strikes on Iraq, which left two dead, including an 18-year-old woman, and more than 20 wounded.

"They urged the Arab and international communities to end the sanctions against Baghdad, imposed after Iraq's 1990 invasion of Kuwait. The lawmakers also criticised the double standards the US adopts in dealing with the Arabs while it turns a blind eye to Israel's disregard of international laws. Some even called for the cancellation of the 1994 Jordan-Israel peace treaty."

In the United Arab Emirates, the Khaleej Times picked up on the Iraqi press reports (strictly controlled by the regime) of new raids: "The Iraqi press denounced US president George W Bush as a 'dwarf' and a criminal for ordering air strikes around Baghdad. 'This criminal will fare no better against Iraq than his father ' said the Babel newspaper run by President Saddam Hussein's elder son, Uday."

In Israel, the air strikes are also being criticised - but from quite another perspective. The Jerusalem Post urges the Bush administration to consider something rather more radical - the 'liberation' of Iraq. It criticises those who would abandon as discredited, the long-running sanctions campaign against Saddam Hussein: "Such defeatism is dead wrong, and if followed will inevitably result not only in a re-energized Saddam but growing radicalising forces in the entire region. Iraqi officials are already beginning to make menacing noises toward Kuwait, not to mention the many bellicose threats against Israel and the US, just to give a small taste of things to come...

"Ultimately, President Bush's policy toward Iraq will determine whether he plans to continue a "policy" of fudging and denial raised to level of a high art, or be a leader who will demonstrate that the West is not powerless against weak but brutal local bullies like Saddam Hussein. The litmus test is not what happens with sanctions, but whether the US leads the way in supporting the Iraqi people against a hated and dangerous regime."

Tel Aviv daily Ha'aretz reports the government's reassurance to Israelis that they have nothing to fear from Iraq: "'Israeli citizens have no cause for concern,' [prime minister Ehud] Barak said adding that there was no need for any special security measures. He said Israel would keep a close watch on developments in the Gulf and would remain in contact with the United States for updates."
