webTitle: Stan too much of a man

fields.headline: Stan too much of a man
fields.trailText: Only three weeks in, and Stan Collymore's already in trouble with his new paymasters. Sid Lowe reports on the weekend action.
fields.body:
Stan Collymore has a new personal best: just three weeks at Real Oviedo and he's already in trouble with the boss. Radi Antic axed his latest signing from the squad that travelled to Zaragoza on Sunday, accusing him of lacking fitness.

"Stan's been left out of the squad because he's a long way from the fitness level he should be at," Antic explained, apparently unaware whose job it is to organise training. "I haven't been happy with his performances so far, and he needs to prove he's better than that". But just as the hacks were gleefully penning yet another football obituary for the Brummie bad boy, Antic insisted that Stan still has a future at the club, claiming: "He's a great asset for us".

Despite Collymore's absence, something truly amazing happened on Sunday - Oviedo scored. It was the 33rd minute when the ball fell to French centre back Federic Danjou, who emphatically smashed home the glory goal (OK, OK, he kneed it over the line from a few yards) - Oviedo's first away all season.

Typical: like the L2 that runs from calle Uría to the home of Grisú C.F. in Cerdeño, oventenses wait months for one and two turn up at the same time - Jamie Fernández got another twenty minutes from full time

Not that it made any difference - Radi Antic's side might have scored two, but they conceded five. Yet again Juan Esnaider was Zaragoza's inspiration - he created one and scored two (including a superb second). No wonder the club's trying to make his move from Juve permanent.

Real Oviedo's defeat takes them perilously close to the danger zone after both Numancia and Real Sociedad won at the weekend.

Sociedad boss John Benjamin was furious with his side's performance, despite winning 2-1. "I didn't recognise my players out there," he said. "Today was the least effort we've put in since I've been here and, weirdly, the first time we've won."

Time to stop trying, then? Perhaps not - la Real had more than a little help from an Espanyol side apparently desperate to gift them the points, and referee Bueno Grimal also seemed to be in on the conspiracy. An own goal from Sergio González set John Benjamin's boys on their way, and Oscar de Paula scored the winner from the spot after a shocking dive from Aitor Rekarte - which was outside the box anyway - somehow impressed the ref.

Numancia weren't much better in beating Malaga 3-2, their winner coming from a Ruben Navarro penalty in the dying moments.

Real roll on

There are those people - cynics and liars, the lot of them - who think that I've been sabotaging the Marca website. Last week, Steve McManaman found his way onto the site's Quinta del Buitre/Raúl Madrid "dream team". And this week, following Madrid's superb 3-2 win against Lazio in the Champions League, Madrid fans voted Macca their side's most on-form player, ahead of Ivan Helguera, Luis Figo and Roberto Carlos.

At the bottom of the list was Iker Casillas, whose shocking blunder against Lazio was his third balls-up in consecutive games. And poor Iker felt it, too. Tears running down his cheeks, he was inconsolable after the Lazio match, despite the best efforts of Aitor Karanka, Fernando Hierro and, oddly enough, the press - who rather than give the teenage keeper a justified slating, reminded him that he is in good company, including Zubizarreta, Busquets and David "Sheaman".

So Casillas must have felt at least a twinge of sympathy this weekend as he watched Racing Santander keeper José Ceballos's outrageous howler hand an uninspiring (and Macca-less) Real Madrid all three points at the Bernabéu.

With the three points in the bag (just), Real's players trotted off happily enough. And they left the Bernabéu happier yet, having seen Barcelona fall eleven points behind with a 3-2 defeat at the hands of Deportivo La Coruña in the Nou Camp. A bit short-sighted perhaps, with Depor just four points behind and Real Madrid travelling to the Riazor next weekend.

Only the Man in the Moustache seemed to realise as much. He admitted before the weekend's games that he'd have rather see Barça win than Depor, and he's since said he'd sooner beat Javier Irureta's side this weekend than Serra Ferrer's the following week.

Deportivo break Nou Camp duck

Depor went 1-0 up in the sixth minute through Djalminha, but Barça were certainly the better side in the first half, with Luis Enrique flying on the right side of midfield. And they soon got their reward with Rivaldo scoring a penalty and Luis Enrique adding a second with a fine header.

It was all to no avail, though. Víctor scored two superb second-half goals for Depor to clinch their first ever win at the Nou Camp. His dramatic injury-time winner proved once again that Javier Irureta is the king of cunning free-kicks - a short ball fooled the Barça wall, which comically tried to shuffle sideways like a bunch of red-necked yokels at a line-dancing competition, and Víctor smashed in an unstoppable shot.

Víctor then dropped to his knees and prayed. Afterwards he revealed that he had been "deeply affected" by news of an accident on Friday which had killed Spanish cyclist Ricardo Otxoa and left his brother Javier in a coma. Víctor, who admitted to having barely slept, dedicated his goals to the brothers who ride for Kelme. "It was very emotional," said Víctor, "I had loads of things swimming round in my mind and had spoken to lots of friends during the week". "One even told me I was going to score the winner." he revealed. "I'm going to ask him for his lottery numbers this week".

There were emotions of a different kind in the Barça dressing room. Manu Petit didn't appreciate being asked to warm up only to watch Gerard and Dani get sent on instead. Throwing his boots down, Petit - who still hasn't fulfilled his promise to shoot comedy keeper Richard Dutruel - tried to storm off but was persuaded (not for the first time this season) to stay on the bench and fester instead.

Petit's not alone, either. The Dutch old guard have lost the privileged position they held under Van Gaal and rumours abound of clashes between "Generalísimo" Lorenzo Serra Ferrer (a ridiculously harsh title given its connotations in Spain) and de Boer, Zenden and Patrick Kluivert.

Serra Ferrer, whose only successful signing has been Marc Overmars, is becoming ever more unpopular and looks unlikely to be in the hotseat next season. As if to emphasise the point, Barça director Ángel Fernández offered that old favourite - the insincere vote of confidence: "We still have confidence in Serra Ferrer, but results dictate things".

With Fabio Capello already turning the job down (apparently he'd rather lose against Liverpool) and the rumours surrounding Héctor Cúper subsiding, one name looms large. Even larger - if that's possible - than it has done for the last five years. Yep, Johan Cruyff could be back - if, that is, he can bury his differences (which include legal action) with the club and its president, Joan Gaspart.

Aimar impresses again

Barcelona might look for a new boss even sooner if they slip out of the Champions League positions, and that's certainly a possibility now. Pablo Aimar impressed again (and scored) as Valencia beat Las Palmas 2-0 to go above Barça into third. And Villarreal and Mallorca are also closing in (both are two points behind) after wins against Valladolid (2-1) and Athletic Bilbao (1-0) respectively.

Below them lie Rayo Vallecano and Alavés, whose midweek Uefa Cup excitements were quickly forgotten in dull encounters - Alavés beat Osasuna 1-0, while Rayo drew 1-1 against Celta in Vigo.

But while Lorenzo Serra Ferrer might not have the top job pretty soon, another opening is on the cards - the Catalan giants have just opened the first of thirty FC Barcelona petrol stations at L'Estartit in Gerona. "Pump 4? That'll be 7,000 pesetas please, sir".

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Disability chic, Hollywood style
fields.standfirst: It's long been held in Hollywood that as soon as you play someone with a disability, you're half way to an Oscar (think Dustin Hoffman in Rainman). In Wait Until Dark, released on video this week, Audrey Hepburn is blind (naturally, it got her a Best Actress nomination), leading us to ponder on some of the most blatant examples of disability chic since Morrissey donned a hearing aid during the early days of The Smiths.
fields.trailText:
Forrest Gump (1994)
Directed by Robert Zemeckis. Starring Tom Hanks.
fields.body:
Forrest Gump (1994)
Directed by Robert Zemeckis. Starring Tom Hanks.

Has a more depressingly cynical film ever been made? Hanks trades on his good-guy, Jimmy Stewart reputation while we struggle to keep down the bile during this simpleton-through-history Zelig-alike. The character's retardation helps him end up mixing with the great and the good, which could be a metaphor for the political process, but isn't anything like that subversive.

The Idiots (1998)
Directed by Lars von Trier. Starring Jens Albinus, Louise Hassing.

In your youth, you may have impersonated Joey Deacon, Blue Peter's cerebral palsy victim, but weren't you constantly being told by weary adults that making fun of Joey was WRONG? Now it seems, it was ART. Lars von Trier probably wasn't fully informed on the Deacon phenomenon, but this story of middle-class professionals releasing their "inner idiot" is either deeply offensive or very liberating, depending on your sensibilities. If you need to know, the players act mentally disabled in order to spark reactions between members of the group and from those they encounter. Made during von Trier's Dogma 95 days ("natural film making"), this isn't easy viewing, but it does have some of the most graphic, if brief, sex scenes in a mainstream film, so you might find it worth the effort.

Scent of a Woman (1992)
Directed by Martin Brest. Starring Al Pacino, Chris O'Donnell.

Pacino is wildly over the top as blind Lieutenant Colonel Frank Slade, a man who knows the meaning of the word irascible and is prepared to prove it - but, hey, the women seem to like it. All this proves is that in Hollywood films a disability can give you licence to act in the most selfish of ways and people will forgive you. The odd thing is that Pacino is paired with Chris O'Donnell, a man so forgettable that a wet flannel could seem overbearing alongside him.

My Left Foot (1989)
Directed by Jim Sheridan. Starring Daniel Day-Lewis, Ray McAnally.

Worth mentioning not just for Day-Lewis's outstanding performance as Christy Brown, cerebral palsy victim, but also for his devotion to duty. Apparently he kept in his wheelchair all day during filming and insisted on remaining in character. This meant he had to be fed by crew members, while still talking in Brown's contorted voice. Could he not have taken Olivier's advice to Hoffman when the method man was trying to get into character and "try acting, dear boy"? But his efforts were worth it as it's a powerful film with an equally strong performance from Brenda Fricker.

Whatever Happened to Baby Jane? (1962)
Directed by Robert Aldrich. Starring Bette Davis, Joan Crawford.

An ageing child star (Davis) indulges her psychotic tendencies over her fading movie star sister, mysteriously crippled in a car crash. It's a triumph of bad make-up, a bitchfest for Davis and one layered with so many biographical overtones for the two principals (only Sunset Boulevard rivals it on that score) that you end up slumping back in your seat and reminding yourself "it's only a movie." As everyone knows, "moguls" told the filmmakers, "We wouldn't give two dimes for those old broads." A judgement wildly out of kilter with the film's reception.

webTitle: Beacon scheme facing a dim future

fields.headline: Beacon scheme facing a dim future
fields.trailText: The local government and regions minister, Hilary Armstrong, is being asked to brighten up the beacon council scheme by offering greater financial freedoms to make it more attractive to local authorities. By Dermott Calpin
fields.body:
The local government and regions minister, Hilary Armstrong, is being asked to brighten up the beacon council scheme by offering greater financial freedoms to make it more attractive to local authorities.

The influential beacon council advisory panel, which is made up of leading local government, trade union and business leaders, has called for the introduction of new "whole-council beacons" and says local authorities should be offered more freedom from government control.

There is real concern that the beacon council scheme - which is designed to celebrate excellence in local service delivery - attracted only 179 applications from 123 local authorities this year compared with a total of 269 applications from 211 councils in its first year of operation.

Ministers and the advisory panel had hoped that they could attract more entries by increasing the number of service areas covered by the beacon awards from seven to 11 but the result has been doubly disappointing with a sharp fall in entries in just the second year of the scheme.

Both the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions and the Improvement and Development Agency have launched an evaluation of the effectiveness of the beacon awards, which was originally seen as one way of allowing councils greater financial autonomy in setting business rates and council tax levels.

So far beacons have only proved popular among county councils with 76% applying for awards this year, but the advisory panel says local government would welcome a clear statement on the future of the scheme "including the introduction of whole-council beacons and the availability of additional freedoms and flexibilities".

Many local government leaders believe that the beacon scheme has been bypassed by the development of new-style local public service agreements. They also point out that councils are already subject to several inspection regimes and able to highlight service improvements through a range of schemes that includes charter marks and other awards.

The advisory panel, which is chaired by Lord Filkin, has close links with the best value inspectorate forum. It has stressed the value of the beacon scheme "as a tool for service improvement under best value" and is urging councils to take part in the nationwide programme of workshops and open days to promote best practice.

It suggest that ministers should do more to meet the costs of bidding for beacon status which could be £80,000 or more for some authorities, and it argues that this may help attract more applications, especially from many of the smaller district councils.

In its report on the second year of the scheme it also acknowledged that there are limits to the value of beacon status and says: "Quite clearly excellence in local government is not restricted to those councils we are recommending for beacon status. In some cases the panel found shining examples of good practice which for a variety of reasons we were unable to put forward with a recommendation usually because the council had not met the test of good overall performance. We are very anxious to ensure that such examples are not lost."

A total of 39 local authorities have been awarded beacon council status - with Camden, Croydon, Knowsley and Nottingham each gaining the award in two service areas - this compared with 33 beacon awards to 42 councils for the first year of the scheme.

The final selection of awards also dismayed the London councils of Barnet, Brent, Newham and Merton which had been recommended for beacon status by the advisory committee but this was blocked by ministers because of critical reports from the best value inspection service and the social services inspectorate.

webTitle: Derek Malcolm at the Berlin Film Festival

fields.headline: Derek Malcolm at the Berlin Film Festival
fields.standfirst: The two top awards for the controversial Intimacy and the failure to honour Emma Thompson for her powerful performance in Wit were the main talking points at the end of the Berlin Film Festival
fields.trailText: The two top awards for the controversial Intimacy and the failure to honour Emma Thompson for her powerful performance in Wit were the main talking points at the end of the Berlin Film Festival
fields.body:
Berlin's huge film festival - more films than Cannes and Hollywood stars by the bucketful - celebrated its 51st year with a jury decision that was roundly castigated by the assembled press. The Golden Bear went to Patrice Chereau's Intimacy, a Franco-Italian co-production made in London and culled from Hanif Kureishi's autobiographical novel of the same name. Not only that, but the Best Actress award went to the Australian actress Kerry Fox, the lead with Mark Rylance in the film.

This was a considerable shock since it was generally thought that Steven Soderbergh's Oscar-nominated Traffic would win the main award as the best of the big American movies on view, and that British actress Emma Thompson deserved the Best Actress award for a magnificent performance in Mike Nichols' Wit, an adaptation of an American play in which she plays a successful academic taken to hospital with terminal ovarian cancer.

Intimacy split its audiences, if not the jury, into two parts - the larger of which thought this tale of sexual obsession was both portentous and unsatisfactory. It's the story of two married people who meet each Wednesday for sex, scarcely speaking to each other and forming no kind of relationship other than in bed. One of them (Rylance) has left his wife and children and the other (Fox) is an actress with a loquacious taxi-driver husband (Timothy Spall).

Gradually, however, the man gets intrigued by his sexual partner and decides to attempt to discover something about her. Then the fun begins, since the taxi driver is not best pleased by what he finds out and the woman herself wants to give up the relationship. The moral of the film clearly is that sex alone is not enough - fairly obvious, in fact. But done with this intensity it's at least capable of forging a tale of amour fou to be remembered.

Unfortunately, this is a French director's film which means that the screenplay, written by Chereau himself with an accomplice and not by Kureishi, sits oddly on its English setting. Added to that, the sex, which includes an unsimulated fellatio sequence for the first time in an openly commercial film, gets boringly repetitive. You can't have much sympathy for anyone in the picture except perhaps the taxi driver whom Spall paints with all his familiar near-to-caricature skill.

Traffic, however, was not totally ignored. Benicio Del Toro rightly won the Best Actor award for his performance in a film that at least proves that Hollywood isn't totally bereft of anything but obvious talent these days. Wit, however, was, and most people couldn't understand why.

This clever and moving adaptation of Margaret Edson's prize-winning play gave Thompson the chance, in her first film part for three years, to give a stunning performance as a woman whose whole life has been a success until she is forced to confront failure for the first time. Told by her doctors that the only hope is the heaviest dose of chemotherapy, she decides to take the chance and suffers accordingly.

Added to that, she also faces the members of an American medical establishment who, in order not to involve themselves emotionally, deliberately distance themselves from their patients, and it is left to the black nurse (Audra MacDonald, also very good) and her old tutor (Eileen Atkins) to help her through the final stages.

Such a film, made for Home Box Office, the American television channel, is not an easy one to look at since it makes very few of the usual compromises and refuses a feelgood ending. But Thompson's often humorous performance - she helped to write the screenplay with Nichols - leavens it a little. And anyway such acting, put completely to the service of the material and in no sense a star turn, is very rare indeed.

Elsewhere, the festival, which finally said farewell to Moritz de Hadeln, its director for some 20 years, and a controversial figure since he is half Swiss and half English, unleashed upon us so many films in each of its three sections that it proved impossible to see more than a tenth of them.

One of the most popular films in the competition was Italian for Beginners, the first Danish Dogma film to be directed by a woman. Lone Sherfig's film adheres to most of the Dogma rules, such as no artifical light, hand-held cameras (and no sex during the shooting), but does so with enough skill to make its watchers scarcely notice the difference between this and an ordinary production.

It's a light-hearted piece about a group of Danes from a dreary Copenhagen suburb who go to Italian classes and get romantically mixed up with each other. But its skill lies not in its effervescence but in the natural characterisation and unaffected acting. The film received a rousing reception from both the critical audience and the general public. The International Critics Jury gave the film its prize for the competition and even the main jury admitted its charm by according Italian for Beginners its minor Jury Prize.

As usual, the East, always given a good showing in Berlin, also came into the reckoning. Wang Xiaoshuai's Beijing Bicycle, a sympathetic and skilful Chinese film about the travails of a courier from the countryside in the big city, won the Grand Jury Prize, virtually the second best award in the festival, and, more surprisingly, the Best Director prize went to Lin Cheng-sheng for his work on Betelnut Beauty, a rather meandering Taiwanese film about young people growing up in Taipeh.

Some of the best films were shown in the Forum and Panorama sections. The Forum, also under new management next year since Ulrich and Erika Grigor, who built this radical section up from nothing, are also retiring, produced several outstanding documentaries and bravely included 10 features from Vietnam which had never been seen in Europe before. Most of them were not exactly masterpieces. But one, The Scent of Guavas, certainly deserved the considerable praise it gathered.

In all, the Berlin programme, now housed in the most modern and luxurious cinemas on the festival circuit, and blessed with enough money to expand even further, could be called a qualified success this year. There were just enough good movies to suggest that world cinema isn't yet totally defeated by the money and star-power of Hollywood, if not quite enough to give that much hope that America will cease to be the be-all and end-all of commercial film-making. Next stop Cannes in May, where hope also springs eternal.

fields.headline: Robinson may quit UK
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: Weakest Link host Anne Robinson says she may quit the UK if her quiz show takes off in the United States.
fields.body:
Weakest Link host Anne Robinson says she may quit the UK if her show takes off in the United States.

The star has signed a deal to present a US version of the show, which could make her as much as £15 million if it becomes a major hit.

She told celebrity magazine Heat she would consider heading across the Atlantic on a more permanent basis if the success of the show depended on it.

"I'm happy to do whatever is required," said the 57-year-old presenter, when asked if she would be prepared to move.

And Robinson added she would be happy to buy a place in the US if need be: "I'm always happy to spend money. I'm Mrs Spend."

However, she was realistic about her chances of making it big with the new audience.

"They might say, 'She's rubbish, send her back on the banana boat'. It's pretty rare for a British presenter to make it over there.

"Tracey Ullman I suppose, David Frost ... Mrs Thatcher. I think if it takes off it will be due to American's fascination with English accents and English attitudes. It certainly won't be down to my age and beauty."

The star, who is leaving BBC1's Watchdog because of her new commitments, said she was getting plenty of fan mail from admirers of her dominatrix image in the Weakest Link.

"It took me a while to realise it was turning some people on. And the gay clubs like it, apparently. They show it in the corner," she said.

"I don't know why. The nuns at my convent boarding school would be horrified."

fields.headline: Guilty until proven innocent
fields.standfirst: The redefined Terrorism Act targets environmental activists as well as armed extremists and reverses the burden of proof, says Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.trailText: The redefined Terrorism Act targets environmental activists as well as armed extremists and reverses the burden of proof, says Richard Norton-Taylor.
fields.body:
From today there will be hundreds, perhaps even thousands more "terrorist suspects" in Britain.

As John Wadham, director of Liberty, the civil rights group, has pointed out, under the new Terrorism Act, protesters and activists, with no interest in overthrowing the state or harming the general public, could find themselves falling under the Act's expanded definition of terrorism.

Under the Act it is a criminal offence to possess any "article" or "information", including photographs, in circumstances which give rise to a "reasonable suspicion" they would be used for "terrorist" purposes - a clause which has serious implications, not least for journalists.

The Act reverses the burden of proof - it will be up to the accused to prove their innocence, in other words, to prove a negative.

That is not all. The definition of terrorism in the bill includes "the use or threat, for the purpose of advancing a political, religious, or ideological cause, of action which involves serious violence against any person or property". This could embrace not only armed extremists but also environmental activists attacking GM crops.

For the first time, the term "terrorism" will apply to domestic groups which can be proscribed by the home secretary. It will be an offence to "provide money or other property" which may be used "for the purposes of terrorism" and not tell the police when you suspect others of doing so.

It will be a criminal offence to speak at the same meeting as someone from a proscribed organisation.

This will have the peculiar result of making it a criminal offence to oppose such an organisation. The meeting could be of no more than three people, private or public. It could be an informal gathering or a discussion in a pub.

The Act also introduces a criminal offence of "incitement" - an offence which could catch, for example, anyone calling for the overthrow of undemocratic regimes abroad. It would have caught Nelson Mandela and other ANC leaders who supported armed struggle against the apartheid regime in South Africa.

The Act gives the police an array of sweeping new powers and in effect sets up a parallel criminal justice system wide open to abuse and far beyond the provisions of the Police and Criminal Evidence Act. It gives them stop and search powers on the basis of "expediency" and of "suspicion", not of committing any offence, but of being connected, or potentially connected, to the bill's vague description of "terrorism".

The Act, says Wadham, "creates a two-tier system - in which people suspected of a criminal act for moral or political reasons will have less rights than someone who commits a similar crime for reasons of lust, greed or viciousness".

By concentrating on motivation, it includes activity which the vast majority of the public would not regard as terrorism, while excluding gangs of racketeers or drug-runners, for example, engaged in serious criminal activities.

fields.headline: Thieves disrupt cable TV services
fields.trailText: 1pm: When thieves stole equipment from Telewest's centre, customers in Essex and Kent were left without services, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Cable TV customers in Essex and Kent were left without internet and interactive services on Friday after thieves broke into Telewest's Basildon network centre and stole crucial equipment.

More than 2,000 high-speed blueyonder internet customers were affected for almost 24 hours.

Some 44,000 digital subscribers were unable to access interactive services until noon on Saturday.

In all, 23 servers were either stolen or damaged when the network hub was ransacked in the early hours of Friday morning.

A spokesman for Telewest refused to say how much damage had been done or give an estimate for the value of the equipment taken.

He insisted there was a "good level of security" and that a full investigation had been launched to ascertain how the break-in happened.

"We managed to bring in equipment from other network centres to get the services up and running as quickly as possible," said the spokesman.

fields.headline: New Media Markets
fields.standfirst: Publication date: February 16
fields.trailText: February 16: The Kirch Group's plan to sell live rights to the 2002 World Cup to UK pay-TV operators may come to nothing.
fields.body:
The controversial plan by the Kirch Group to sell on exclusive live rights to the 2002 football World Cup to pay-television operators in the UK may come to nothing.

The Italian government appears to have made a deal with the opposition to have rules for digital terrestrial television introduction brought before parliament before the upcoming general election.

British Sky Broadcasting is carrying out tests of a "sidecar" box that connects to its existing Sky Digital set-top boxes. It provides services delivered over telephone lines via an ADSL modem.

BSkyB may not switch off the analogue signals of its three Sky Sports channels at the end of June.

The BBC is working on a digital terrestrial set-top box that would offer at least all the free-to-air channels as well as high-speed internet access.

fields.headline: Egg's losses increase
fields.trailText: 9.45am: The cracks are widening at online pioneer Egg, after the internet-only bank reported increased losses, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The cracks are widening at online pioneer Egg, after the internet-only bank reported increased losses.

Egg has struggled to prove that web-based banking can work and has failed to make an advantage of the "first mover" status it acquired when it launched three years ago.

Despite adding insurance, mortgages and joint credit-card ventures to its services, Egg today reported a full-year pre-tax loss of £155.3m, up from £149.7m in 1999.

However, Egg emphasised its customer base had soared from 790,000 to 1.35m, while the UK is falling further in love with the net.

"A recent study by MORI estimates 23 million people will be online by the middle of 2001 and 14 million are expecting to use a new technology product for the first time," said Paul Gratton, chief executive of Egg.

Egg has gained a high profile with an off-the-wall advertising campaign, which drew a series of complaints from the public.

People claimed the commercials, which featured a man jumping into bed with a customer, were sinister.

However, analysts were looking for a more old-fashioned approach to business in the results, and they got it with a statement about the company's timescale for reaching profitability.

Egg said it would reach profit by the end of 2001 and will seek continental partners for an aggressive expansion into Europe.

"We fully intend to become a global business," said Mr Gratton.

"We are exploring commercial partnerships with a number of significant European businesses."

Rival operations such as Co-op's Smile and Abbey National's Cahoot have stolen some of Egg's thunder.

However, Egg is growing fast - it added 100,000 customers in 2001.

"We have the strength of proposition, speed of delivery and stamina of management team to ensure Egg will be a winner in the digital economy," said Mr Gratton.

People claimed the commercials, which featured a man jumping into bed with a customer, were sinister. However, analysts were looking for a more old-fashioned approach to business in the results, and they got it with a statement about the company's timescale for reaching profitability. Egg said it would reach profit by the end of 2001 and will seek continental partners for an aggressive expansion into Europe. "We fully intend to become a global business," said Mr Gratton. "We are exploring commercial partnerships with a number of significant European businesses." Rival operations such as Co-op's Smile and Abbey National's Cahoot have stolen some of Egg's thunder. However, Egg is growing fast - it added 100,000 customers in 2001. "We have the strength of proposition, speed of delivery and stamina of management team to ensure Egg will be a winner in the digital economy," said Mr Gratton.

webTitle: Fight for top BBC news jobs

fields.headline: Fight for top BBC news jobs
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Senior BBC editors are preparing to battle for the top jobs at some of the highest-profile news programmes, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
Senior BBC editors are sharpening their knives as they prepare to battle for the top jobs at some of the highest-profile news programmes.

A game of musical chairs was signalled at the weekend with the appointment of an insider to succeed Tony Hall as director of news. Mr Hall is leaving to become chief executive of the Royal Opera House.

The editorship of the Six O'Clock News is up for grabs, and the Newsnight editor has indicated that she wants to move on.

The developments will be watched closely by Westminster: the BBC is already under scrutiny over its coverage of Europe. It is also under commercial pressure with head-to-head competition at 10pm from ITV, the increasing strength of Sky News and the arrival of a new 24-hour news channel from ITN.

There are a number of certain and potential vacancies. Mr Hall is to be replaced by his deputy, Richard Sambrook, thus leaving the post of deputy director vacant for an internal promotion.

The editorship of BBC 1's Six O'Clock News will be free after the election when its present boss, Mark Popescu, goes to the 10pm bulletin; Newsnight's editor, Sian Kevill, has expressed a desire to move; and it is possible that Rod Liddle, editor of Radio 4's Today programme, will want a new challenge.

There is also a senior vacancy at the BBC's rolling news channel, News 24, after Richard Porter was promoted to edit the BBC's recently relaunched Breakfast programme.

It is certain that the successor to Mr Popescu at the Six O'Clock News will be an insider. The frontrunners are Jay Hunt, editor of the One O'Clock News, and Chris Rybczynski, who is in charge of BBC television's weekend news coverage.

The Today programme will go through another transition with the expected departure of the veteran presenter Sue Macgregor. Her replacement is almost certain to be Sarah Montague.

fields.headline: Best of Both Worlds comes off worse
fields.trailText: 1.45pm TV overnights: BBC1's Best of Both Worlds failed to dent the ratings of London's Burning last night, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BBC1's latest Sunday evening drama, Best of Both Worlds, failed to dent the ratings of ITV's London's Burning last night.

The long running ITV fire-service drama was watched by 10m, while Best of Both Worlds managed only 5.3m, according to unofficial overnights.

The BBC drama, written by acclaimed Cracker scriptman Paul Abbott, centred on the woes of an air stewardess with husbands in both London and Bologna.

The protagonist is played by rising star Alice Evans.

But the first instalment of a three-part drama mustered just a 21% share, yet again demonstrating the stranglehold ITV has on Sunday night family viewing.

London's Burning clinched a 41% share between 9pm and 10pm.

Viewing figures for the long-runnng ITV drama were up 300,000 week on week.

The Sunday night schedules also played host to that rare beast, a home-grown Channel 5 drama.

Hotel - which went out over 90 minutes from 9pm - starred Paul McGann, Art Malik and Lee Majors in a tale of incompetent terrorists who take the US president hostage in a suburban English hotel.

It notched up a respectable 1.2m viewers and a 5% share.

Channel 4 also scored last night with the terrestrial premiere of controversial Las Vegas lap-dance extravaganza Showgirls from 10pm.

The movie gained 2.4m viewers and a 21% share.

webTitle: Trinity reviews strategy with talks to shed ISP

fields.headline: Trinity reviews strategy with talks to shed ISP
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Unlimited Money
More net news
fields.trailText: Trinity Mirror is understood to have held preliminary discussions for the sale of ic24, the newspaper publishing group's internet service provider.
fields.body:
Trinity Mirror is understood to have held preliminary discussions for the sale of ic24, the newspaper publishing group's internet service provider.

The talks are part of a wider strategic review at the company, formed from the merger of regional newspaper firm Trinity and the Mirror Group 18 months ago.

Trinity Mirror's magazines and exhibitions division has also been identified as a potential candidate for sale.

Insiders stressed that no firm decisions had been taken on ic24 but acknowledged that the City has been looking for a disposal. "The future of the ISP is under scrutiny," said one. "The group is looking at what the next logical step is."

Trinity Mirror would retain its network of websites and is still committed to spending the £150m outlined in March last year at the height of the internet boom. The sites include 13 regional portals leveraging the network of regional newspapers, icSport, icChoice and icShowbiz.

The service provider has 670,000 subscribers but some executives at the group feel it has now served its purpose in establishing the portals business. A likely buyer would be a telecoms firm acquiring the traffic.

Trinity Mirror's other online assets include sportinglife.com and totalbet.com. Analysts are becoming increasingly concerned that Trinity Mirror is a company lacking a strategy - the chief reason for the poor record of its share price which continues to trade at a significant discount to its peers.

The company is also facing the threats of a softening advertising market and a rise in newsprint costs.

At least one analyst has suggested the Sunday People might not have a future within the group, although two approaches for the tabloid newspaper over the past 12 months have been turned down.

Philip Graf, group chief executive, announced in September that he intended to step back from the the day-to-day running of the group to focus on broader issues, appointing Joe Sinyor to run the newspapers.

fields.headline: London Fashion Week
fields.standfirst: As London Fashion Week sashays its way into the media spotlights, here's our guide to the best sites on the annual cavalcade of elegance, audacity and downright stupidity
fields.trailText: As London Fashion Week sashays its way into the media spotlights, here's our guide to the best sites on the annual cavalcade of elegance, audacity and downright stupidity.
fields.body:
1. Another week, another fashion show - sandwiched between the New York and Milan extravaganzas comes the UK's very own turn on the catwalk.

2. London Fashion Week, which began yesterday, is where British designers such as Alexander McQueen get to parade their latest creations.

3. And very interesting they are too. At a previous show Hussein Chalayan wowed the world with a coffee table that turned into a skirt.

4. In the words of the British fashion council: "London has a unique position on the international catwalk circuit with its mix of new avant-garde designers and elegant classics."

5. But sometimes the models are themselves the stars. Can you believe it was only a year ago that multi-talented Victoria Beckham did a turn for designer Maria Grachvogel, proving to her critics she cannot only sing but also wear clothes and walk?

6. London, however, is still the junior of rival shows in New York, Paris and Milan.

7. In those fashion capitals, the couture kings show off their nicely cut new collections and big name designers, such as Stella McCartney, are lured to the big name fashion houses.

8. Another difference is money. There is none of that euro nonsense here, you know. British designer Russell Sage yesterday plastered his clothes with £20 notes.

9. "Why London?" you may ask. Information gleaned from the organisers' own website would appear to suggest that this biannual descent of Marlboro Light smoking fashionistas is punishment for Hoxton, the Queen, gastro pubs and Jude Law.

10. But there is no need to worry - whole swathes of the capital are still resolutely unfashionable. Residents or visitors wanting to find them should avoid the following (London Fashion Week approved) list of bars, clubs and restaurants.

fields.headline: Australia's Maggie Thatcher
fields.standfirst: Pauline Hanson blends anti-establishment politics with compelling personal delivery, says Patrick Barkham, but the potential of her One Nation party is not yet clear
fields.trailText: Pauline Hanson's blends anti-establishment politics with compelling personal delivery, says Patrick Barkham, but the potential of her One Nation party is not yet clear.
fields.body:
"I've been a small business woman most of my life. I knew what it was like to run my business where at the end of the week I had to pay the bills and what was left was mine. The trouble is these politicians have never been in small business, they don't know what it's like to have to provide for your family."

It could be 20 years ago, and Margaret Thatcher eulogising her early life in a Grantham greengrocers. But it is 2001, and it's Pauline Hanson, the controversial former fish and chip shop owner and leader of Australia's One Nation party, talking about why her country's politicians "have no regard for the average Aussie out there".

Hanson doesn't wield a handbag, but there are striking stylistic similarities between her and Lady Thatcher. As Thatcher was "Maggie", Hanson is "Pauline": charismatic, direct and very personal. Every issue is personalised; her life is a crusade against the doubters who want to destroy her.

"Politics is a dirty game," she recently told the Guardian. "Since One Nation has been on the scene there's been a concerted effort by the major political parties and big business cartels to get rid of One Nation, to destroy me. But I think Australians believe that I'm honest, dedicated, that I love my country and I do care about their future and the future of my children and grandchildren."

As Thatcher was, Hanson is an anti-politician, claiming to be pitched against the establishment. Thatcher boasted of dismantling the post-war consensus; Hanson seeks to destroy Australia's Liberal-Labor consensus, which has facilitated deregulation and economic rationalism for the last 15 years.

In policy terms, there are clear differences. One Nation, opposed to Asian immigration, foreign aid, and Aboriginal welfare support, is a few notches further right of Thatcher. Hanson's opposition to globalised free markets and hatred of big business "cartels" is in complete contrast to Thatcherite neoliberalism.

But, like Thatcher, Hanson has the media bedazzled. Even those who profess disgust take a rabbit-in-the-headlights approach to covering her every shimmy in the latest lurid floral halterneck dress. One tabloid has taken to heading stories about One Nation with a little graphic saying: "The Power of Pauline".

Margaret Thatcher, of course, was in power. How significant is Hanson? Pollsters admit voters are backwards about coming forwards in favour of Hanson. Recent polls that put One Nation on 4% were underestimating its support. The party is really backed by a healthy 15% or so in the vast expanses of rural Australia.

While this will win Ms Hanson a seat in Australia's senate in the federal election later this year, One Nation only won three seats in western Australia's upper house and none in its lower chamber ten days ago. After last weekend's Queensland election, the party stands to win three seats in the state's 89-member chamber.

There is real disenchantment in the bush with John Howard's conservative coalition government, particularly over petrol prices, the 10% goods and services tax (GST), and more amorphous grievances against globalisation and geographical alienation from the decision-making hub in Canberra.

One Nation is profiting from this, but so is the Green party, who convincingly out-polled Hanson in western Australia and won six upper house seats. And the chief beneficiary is the Labor party.

As the University of Queensland's Paul Reynolds says, the real story of the two state elections in western Australia and Queensland has been a giant swing away from Australia's conservative Liberal and National parties to Labor. "There's been an orthodox if exaggerated swing across the pendulum from one major party to another and on the way through a minor force [One Nation] has picked up a bit of sting. It's not a dealignment, it's a realignment as conservative voters have moved to Labor," he said.

That is not to write off Pauline Hanson. Dr Reynolds says there has been a clever shift in what One Nation are talking about. "Three years ago it was all about welfare bludgers, Aborigines getting too much, Asians coming and taking our jobs, and all that crazy racist economics. What we're hearing now is much less of that stuff."

"In the Queensland campaign, Hanson made only one speech where she talked about Indonesia and 'how dare we send money to them when they burn our flag'. The rest was to send a message to Howard over petrol prices and GST. It was a much more focused domestic politics protest situation."

One-person parties are notoriously volatile. However, if Hanson is able to steer clear of the rows and scandals which nearly sunk her a year ago (and there are fresh reports that the director of public prosecutions is investigating One Nation's misuse of A$4.3m [£1.6m] in electoral commission funding), her voice could yet be a powerful one.

But it appears that Labor is going to be the chief beneficiary of rural discontent at the next election. Whether Pauline Hanson lives to fight on in floral prints for another day will depend on how effectively a Labor administration then cleans up the image of Canberra and addresses the anxieties of Australia's rural voters.

fields.headline: Express circulation chief joins rival
fields.trailText:
12.30pm: Express Newspapers circulation director Nigel Lomas is joining News International, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Feb 14: Express puts Woolfenden on gardening leave
fields.body:
Express Newspapers circulation director Nigel Lomas is joining News International as supply chain manager.

Ian Jackson, director of sales and circulation for News International, confirmed Mr Lomas was coming on board.

"Nigel's got an enormous amount of experience, particularly on the wholesale side," said Mr Jackson.

Mr Lomas' departure is the second from the Express sales and circulation departments in a week.

Last week, Paul Woolfenden, the paper's commercial director, went on gardening leave amid reports his salary was too high for Express owner Northern & Shell.

Meanwhile, the Express reported sales figures of below 1m at the most recent newspaper ABCs.

fields.headline: Coca-Cola promotes Harland
fields.trailText: 12pm: Coca-Cola has elected a former PR chief of its UK operations to be a vice-president of the company, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Coca-Cola has elected a former PR chief of its UK operations to be a vice-president of the company.

Robert Harland, director of international public affairs, has been appointed vice-president as Coke emphasises the importance of communications within the company.

Coke recently hired US vice-president Dick Cheney's PR chief, Dirk Vande Beek, to the newly created position of vice-president of public relations.

Mr Harland, 54, is responsible for managing communications between the company's corporate organisation and the operating groups throughout the world.

In his 28 years with Coca-Cola, Mr Harland has helped establish and expand the external affairs function in Asia, the middle east and Asia Pacific.

Mr Harland joined the company in 1973 as public relations manager for the Coca-Cola Corporation in the UK.

He moved to Hong Kong in 1978 to establish the external affairs function throughout the Asia region.

In 1988, he was appointed vice-president and director of external affairs for the former Pacific Group.

webTitle: Sarah Payne suspect held in custody

fields.headline: Sarah Payne suspect held in custody
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.body:
The man accused of kidnapping and murdering eight-year-old Sarah Payne was remanded in custody when he appeared in court today.

Roy William Whiting, 42, was remanded until May 18 by Judge Richard Brown at the hearing in Lewes crown court.

Whiting, formerly resident in Littlehampton, who was wearing black jeans and a grey T-shirt, smiled and yawned through much of the 10-minute hearing. He spoke only to confirm his name.

Sarah Payne's parents, Sara and Michael, were present. Mrs Payne stared at Whiting throughout the 10-minute hearing.

The court heard from Sue Lumbard, for the prosecution, that due to the "nature and complexity of the case", it would take several weeks to serve papers on the defence.

The court was packed with family and friends of Sarah, many of whom were wearing badges bearing her picture and the words "For Sarah". The jury box was opened to accommodate more than 20 reporters.

Outside, police officers stopped the traffic in Lewes high street as Sarah's family left the court, surrounded by cameramen. They said nothing.

A date for a plea and directions hearing will be set when the case returns to Lewes crown court.

fields.headline: Emap prepares teen title
fields.trailText: 12pm: Emap Elan has confirmed speculation that it is working on plans for a new, high-profile teen magazine, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Emap Elan has confirmed speculation that it is working on plans for a new, high-profile teen magazine.

Barry McIlheney, chief executive of the Emap Elan network, confirmed Emap has asked More editor Marina Gask to develop plans for a magazine for teenagers.

"It seems this is a market which, more than any other, celebrates newness," Mr McIlheney said.

"There hasn't been a big launch into this space for several years and our strategy would be to launch a title in the next 12 to 18 months."

He added the magazine would be a "noisier, more aggressive launch" than anything that had appeared in this market over the past four years.

The biggest selling teen magazines have sold astronomically well, with Attic Futura's Sugar peaking at over 420,000.

But last week's ABCs reported big falls for teen titles, with the once popular pop-based magazines the worst hit.

The BBC's Top of the Pops crashed 21.6%, while Emap's Smash Hits fell 11.5%.

But Mr McIlheney said Emap was unworried by the downward trend.

He believes "lifestyle-based" teen magazines like Sugar, Bliss and J17 have a better chance of surviving the the fads of teenage publishing.

Pop-based magazine publishers say the vacuum in the pop world caused by the demise of the Spice Girls and All Saints is the main reason for the slump.

Meanwhile, he confirmed Emap was looking at developing a celebrity title for older female readers, following the success of Heat.

He said the plans were still at "back of a fag packet" stage.

webTitle: Vivir con la amenaza de ser expulsado

fields.headline: Vivir con la amenaza de ser expulsado
fields.standfirst: Thousands of immigrants in Spain have been left with no rights, thanks to a new law that allows illegal immigrants to be sent back home within 48 hours. Eulàlia Furriol asks what young people think
fields.trailText: "Había un hombre que llegó a Barcelona hace veinticinco años. Los primeros años pedía papeles para ser legal, pero después se cansó de intentarlo. Trabajaba de barrendero en un mercado. Hace unos días fue la policía al mercado y lo mandó de vuelta a Marruecos", explica el joven inmigrante Joumad.
fields.body:
"Había un hombre que llegó a Barcelona hace veinticinco años. Los primeros años pedía papeles para ser legal, pero después se cansó de intentarlo. Trabajaba de barrendero en un mercado. Hace unos días fue la policía al mercado y lo mandó de vuelta a Marruecos", explica el joven inmigrante Joumad.

Desde finales de enero la ley española permite expulsar en cuarenta y ocho horas a los inmigrantes ilegales o sin papeles en el país. Y trabajar sin permiso es, con la nueva ley, una infracción grave. Miles de inmigrantes en España viven ahora con la amenaza de la expulsión.

Sonia, Joumad y José estudian en la escuela Miquel Tarradell, de Barcelona. Un setenta por ciento de los estudiantes de esta escuela son inmigrantes. María José enseña español a inmigrantes en Algeciras.

¿Crees que la inmigración es un problema para España?

María José (Tiene 16 años y es de Algeciras): Sí, porque existen prejuicios. La gente dice que quitan empleo, que ensucian las calles... Compañeras de clase hablan de la invasión de los "moros". A ellos no les gusta la palabra "moro", sino marroquí o árabe. Algeciras es una ciudad de paso de los inmigrantes que cruzan el estrecho con pateras desde Marruecos. Por eso desde hace dos años soy voluntaria de Andalucía Acoge. Algunos se aprovechan de nosotros, pero otros realmente lo necesitan.

José (Tiene 15 años y es de Barcelona): La gente cree que los de fuera harán algo malo. Pero la mayoría de inmigrantes no crean problemas. Pagan justos por pecadores.

Sonia (Tiene 15 años y es de India. Llegó a Barcelona hace tres años): El problema es para los que llegan sin papeles.

¿Qué opinión tienes de la nueva Ley de Extranjería?

María José: Hasta ahora los inmigrantes primero buscaban trabajo y después pedían los papeles. Ahora ya no es posible.

Joumad (Tiene 17 años y es de Marruecos): Para tener papeles necesitas trabajo, y para tener trabajo necesitas papeles. Es un pez que se muerde la cola.

Sonia: Hay inmigrantes que viven aquí desde hace años y no les dan papeles. La nueva ley les obliga a volver a sus países, pero no quieren.

Por eso han empezado una huelga de hambre. Para los inmigrantes jóvenes es muy difícil volver. Es difícil adaptarse a la vida y a la escuela de sus países.

¿Los inmigrantes ilegales son los esclavos de hoy?

María José: La nueva ley hace más fácil la explotación de los ilegales. Y también son esclavos de las mafias de sus compatriotas. Les engañan con promesas de trabajo. Los mafiosos se pasean por Algeciras con unos coches y móviles impresionantes.

Sonia: Conozco gente que no tiene papeles y trabaja. Pero cobran casi la mitad que los demás, porque son ilegales. En cambio, inmigrantes de otros países de Europa han pedido papeles en España y les han dado. Y los que viven y trabajan aquí desde hace años se han quedado sin. Esto es injusto.

Joumad: Hasta hace seis meses yo no tenía papeles. En la escuela no es importante tener o no tener papeles. Pero si acabas la escuela y no tienes papeles tampoco tienes certificado escolar. Esto sí es un problema.

Cada día hay inmigrantes que se juegan la vida en las pateras. ¿Qué se debe hacer?

María José: Hace dos semanas encontré un grupo de once inmigrantes que acababa de llegar. Decían: "¡Luchar tanto por llegar a un país donde odian a los negros!" Las fronteras deberían estar más abiertas.

Joumad: No dejar entrar a más personas hasta que los ilegales en España tengan todos papeles.

José: Un mundo igual para todos. Un mundo sin visados ni residencias.

Sonia: Dar papeles a todos. Lo ideal sería que la gente no tuviera que emigrar.

Glosario/glossary

aprovecharse de to take advantage of or to exploit

un barrendero street cleaner
una ciudad de paso a city used as a place of transit

engañar to mislead
jugarse la vida to risk oneÕs life

un móvil mobile (phone)

pagan justos por pecadores the innocent pay for the guilty
una patera small boat

un pez que se muerde la cola a vicious circle

tener o no tener papeles to be a legal or an illegal immigrant

webTitle: Three Britons dead in Tasmanian bus crash

fields.headline: Three Britons dead in Tasmanian bus crash
fields.standfirst:
Emergency number: 020 70080218
Local police: 0061 362302677
fields.trailText: Three British holidaymakers died after a tourist bus carrying 18 passengers plunged off a Tasmanian mountainside last night, killing four and injuring 14 others.
fields.body:
Three British holidaymakers died after a tourist bus carrying 18 passengers plunged off a Tasmanian mountainside last night, killing four and injuring 14 others.

Two men and two women died, and six people were critically injured, after the bus toppled 33 metres down a steep embankment in Cradle Mountain national park. Judy Franklin, a British woman from the Cambridge area, has been named as one of the dead.

The bus had stopped to let another vehicle pass on a narrow gravel road when part of the ledge crumbled.

The vehicle rolled down the slope, flipped on to its roof and came to rest against a pine tree.

The passengers included tourists from the United States, New Zealand and Australia.

Eight of the injured were released from hospital yesterday.

They had been on a night time wildlife tour organised by Cradle Mountain Lodge, where they were staying.

Peter Hazelwood, a spokesman for Hobart police, said: "It has been a terrible event. In my 12 years here nothing like this has ever happened.

"The victims were on a tour and out looking for possums and other famous species from around here. It is something people come far and wide to look for."

He added: "It happened in the middle of the night and we have had all the police lights flashing around and an awful job seeing what we were doing. We also had the helicopter out to take the injured to the North West regional hospital."

Rod Stendrup, Cradle Mountain Lodge's manager, said: "It is very distressing.

"It is a close-knit community up here and it has hit our staff very hard, and for those people up here for a couple of days it has had a terrible impact.

"It is quite a narrow section of road and it drops off very sharply. That was the problem."

Accident investigators are trying to establish the cause of the accident, which occurred at 10.15pm local time.

fields.headline: The special relationship is becoming a special burden
fields.standfirst:
Bush needs more partners than just the UK, says Peter Preston

Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Bush needs more partners than just the UK.
fields.body:
The White House does something decisive about Iraq and what happens? Hark, you can hear the voices rising. Listen to "the sniping, carping, bitching, the predictable editorial comments". Watch the apostles of "cynical liberalism" get down to their corrosive business again. And that was George Bush Sr railing at his critics 10 years ago. It seems that nothing changes.

A bestial Saddam Hussein still rules Iraq. Dick Cheney and General Colin Powell still sit around an American cabinet table, the civilian more virulently hawkish, the soldier more timorous about risking his men. Another President Bush frowns and sucks his thumb. Another young British prime minister snaps faithfully to attention. Here we go again.

And yet, on examination, everything is not the same; and we ought to chronicle the differences. Saddam is 10 years older - and visibly sicker. Every dictator, in the end, runs out of rope as his national guardsmen and mobster pals ponder their next allegiances. "Predictable" editorialists should watch their adjectives. Events may soon hand young George a victory which eluded old George. There will be a crude, familial relish to that moment when it comes.

But other, profounder things have altered, too. First, the belief in a new world order which saw an international coalition of forces voyage to the Gulf and a UN, freed from cold war stasis, sanction action. The Yanks and the Brits are the last ones left in the air over Baghdad. They have no wider support; they are outside the law; they are the remnants of the old gang just plugging and zapping along. Unless world order resides solely in Downing Street and the Oval Office, we are making no progress.

What has a decade of economic blockade achieved? Nothing, except the death by starvation and disease of millions of Iraqi peasants. Have no-fly zones saved the Kurds in the north or the Shias in the south? A thousand miserable Kurdish refugees, beached on the French Riviera, would seem to think not. Is the Arab world more stable and peaceful for our beneficences? Go beat your head on Jerusalem's Wailing Wall. A fresh generation of fighters - radicalised by the TV pictures they see of dead kids in Baghdad or Gaza - is taking over. There are other eventual rulers of "terrorist states" waiting in line, and we are helping to make them what they are.

Old president George, however tetchy he grew under fire, deserves clear credit. He was right, in March 1991, to decide that Saddam must be expelled from Kuwait. He was right to insist that no negotiating fudge could forgive this aggression. Of course the oil made intervention more self-serving than it would have been in, say, the Congo, but the world beyond America guzzles gas as well. And, whatever Dick Cheney may believe, Bush was right to stop the carnage when he did. The cost of visible slaughter had simply grown too great.

What was wrong - inevitable, but wrong - was the way that this half-victory turned to domestic politicking and froze into intellectual immobility. Saddam became a satanic totem in a personalised standoff, the man who could be given no quarter and no fresh thought. He could be bombed by a successor president in an impeachment jam. (A missile a day keeps Gallup pollsters at bay). He could be bombed by a new president wanting to show his mettle.

As he was demonised, though, his shadow grew longer. Military machines and lapdog defence contractors used him and his like to burnish their budgets. So Son of Star Wars arises with the son of George.

The difficulty here, the root of all difficulty, is not rooted in cynicism, however. Examine what George W Bush says and reckon that, for the most part he believes it and speaks for most his nation's citizens. "Our world, shaped by American courage, power and wisdom, today echoes with American ideals. We won a victory not just for a country, but for a vision: a vision of freedom and individual dignity. For us, this is a time of unrivalled military power, economic promise and cultural influence. It is, in Franklin Roosevelt's phrase, 'the peace of overwhelming victory'. Our noble challenge [now] is to turn these years of influence into decades of peace."

But what, once the rhetoric of his most magisterial pre-election speech on foreign affairs had ended, was the first pre-condition he cited? "Building a durable peace," he said, "will require strong alliances." It would, in sum, require a meeting of minds and a pooling of interests. And the devilish difficulty, as he looks around the globe this morning, is that "strong" alliances grow weaker.

The Tony Blair who turns up in Washington this week seeking his own pre-election moment in the sun, is the only one left (bar Ariel Sharon) playing inflexible friend. The rest of Europe grows restive; Russia and China scowl; Japan and India frown; the Middle East is in anxious uproar. That isn't just because Saddam got zapped this time with (as opposed to without) publicity: it is because America, with power but too little wisdom, has begun to see its "ideals" and "cultural influence" as the only shows in town. There's no strength to alliances built that way.

Inevitably, this week, British commentators writing in British newspapers will bang on about the "special relationship" and Mr Blair's anxiety (like the anxiety of his predecessors) to play governor of the 51st state, always there, always agreeable. That, bobbing back and forth between Brussels and Washington, is our self-appointed "special" role and special cross. But what shrieks to be on the agenda now is more than PR spin. Blair needs to be the interpreter of Europe to America, not the bearer of mere messages back.

The better agenda was conveniently laid out last month in a policy brief - A Transatlantic New Deal - for the Foreign Policy Centre. What is the "burden sharing" that the US bangs on about? Is it troops and firepower alone or overseas development assistance? EU countries give $27bn a year to overseas projects: the US gives $9bn (just 0.1% of GDP to the ODA). Is it curbing greenhouse gases and global warming?

The plain fact is that there is already far more sharing of the global burden than George W (or his Pentagon) realise. The future fact is that - interpreted beyond mere missile counts - better balances and partnerships are there for the building. But partnerships only come between free and equal partners. What the new boy in the White House and his ancient advisers need to realise is that a partnership which excludes everyone but London and Tel Aviv is no partnership at all. What Tony Blair needs to realise is that standing mutely by his man is a recipe for strife - and for another Saddam, and another, waiting to strike.

There are other eventual rulers of "terrorist states" waiting in line, and we are helping to make them what they are. Old president George, however tetchy he grew under fire, deserves clear credit. He was right, in March 1991, to decide that Saddam must be expelled from Kuwait. He was right to insist that no negotiating fudge could forgive this aggression. Of course the oil made intervention more self-serving than it would have been in, say, the Congo, but the world beyond America guzzles gas as well. And, whatever Dick Cheney may believe, Bush was right to stop the carnage when he did. The cost of visible slaughter had simply grown too great. What was wrong - inevitable, but wrong - was the way that this half-victory turned to domestic politicking and froze into intellectual immobility. Saddam became a satanic totem in a personalised standoff, the man who could be given no quarter and no fresh thought. He could be bombed by a successor president in an impeachment jam. (A missile a day keeps Gallup pollsters at bay). He could be bombed by a new president wanting to show his mettle. As he was demonised, though, his shadow grew longer. Military machines and lapdog defence contractors used him and his like to burnish their budgets. So Son of Star Wars arises with the son of George. The difficulty here, the root of all difficulty, is not rooted in cynicism, however. Examine what George W Bush says and reckon that, for the most part he believes it and speaks for most his nation's citizens. "Our world, shaped by American courage, power and wisdom, today echoes with American ideals. We won a victory not just for a country, but for a vision: a vision of freedom and individual dignity. For us, this is a time of unrivalled military power, economic promise and cultural influence. It is, in Franklin Roosevelt's phrase, 'the peace of overwhelming victory'. Our noble challenge [now] is to turn these years of influence into decades of peace." But what, once the rhetoric of his most magisterial pre-election speech on foreign affairs had ended, was the first pre-condition he cited? "Building a durable peace," he said, "will require strong alliances." It would, in sum, require a meeting of minds and a pooling of interests. And the devilish difficulty, as he looks around the globe this morning, is that "strong" alliances grow weaker. The Tony Blair who turns up in Washington this week seeking his own pre-election moment in the sun, is the only one left (bar Ariel Sharon) playing inflexible friend. The rest of Europe grows restive; Russia and China scowl; Japan and India frown; the Middle East is in anxious uproar. That isn't just because Saddam got zapped this time with (as opposed to without) publicity: it is because America, with power but too little wisdom, has begun to see its "ideals" and "cultural influence" as the only shows in town. There's no strength to alliances built that way. Inevitably, this week, British commentators writing in British newspapers will bang on about the "special relationship" and Mr Blair's anxiety (like the anxiety of his predecessors) to play governor of the 51st state, always there, always agreeable. That, bobbing back and forth between Brussels and Washington, is our self-appointed "special" role and special cross. But what shrieks to be on the agenda now is more than PR spin. Blair needs to be the interpreter of Europe to America, not the bearer of mere messages back. The better agenda was conveniently laid out last month in a policy brief - A Transatlantic New Deal - for the Foreign Policy Centre. What is the "burden sharing" that the US bangs on about? Is it troops and firepower alone or overseas development assistance? EU countries give $27bn a year to overseas projects: the US gives $9bn (just 0.1% of GDP to the ODA). Is it curbing greenhouse gases and global warming? The plain fact is that there is already far more sharing of the global burden than George W (or his Pentagon) realise. The future fact is that - interpreted beyond mere missile counts - better balances and partnerships are there for the building. But partnerships only come between free and equal partners. What the new boy in the White House and his ancient advisers need to realise is that a partnership which excludes everyone but London and Tel Aviv is no partnership at all. What Tony Blair needs to realise is that standing mutely by his man is a recipe for strife - and for another Saddam, and another, waiting to strike. peter.preston@theguardian.com

webTitle: Letters: government proposals for state schools

fields.headline: Your helpful suggestions for re-educating Trevor
fields.trailText: The article by Trevor Phillips (Well done, sir, February 17), full of specious argument as it is, gets nowhere near justifying the government's plan to divide our comprehensive schools into haves and have nots.
fields.body:
The article by Trevor Phillips (Well done, sir, February 17), full of specious argument as it is, gets nowhere near justifying the government's plan to divide our comprehensive schools into haves and have nots.

In Worcestershire, the education authority is committed to parity of excellence for all of its comprehensive schools. How do Trevor Phillips or David Blunkett think that giving half of these schools special status will be of benefit to the communities of Worcestershire? Providing specialist schools in large urban areas might work in that parents can take advantage of the choices offered. But in many rural areas the only real choice is the one local school. This seems to be yet another education policy made up by civil servants and ministers who think that what might be appropriate in London will be good for the rest of the country as well.

Parents will see the schools with "special status" as being better, for that is surely the purpose of the exercise. The corollary is that the remaining schools will be worse. It will only take a short time before non-specialist schools achieve the same status as secondary moderns.
Neil Holmes
Bromsgrove, Worcs

 More New Labour doublethink, or just old-fashioned toadying? If Trevor Phillips seriously believes Blunkett's "masterstroke" will not lead to a two-tier system can he explain which diverse (but equal?) range of schools would be best for his family: the schools given specialist status and extra resources or those without? Jonny Stott
Worthing
jstott@classicfm.net

 Trevor Phillips is rash to praise the multicultural potential of church schools. In the early 1970s, when I was eight, we moved to North London, and my parents sent me to the local school which happened to be C of E. There, as one of a handful of Jewish children, I quickly learned about religious chauvinism, and particularly anti-semitism: from the constant playground taunts of other children that teachers I appealed to for help cursorily dismissed (taunts that became stones outside the school gates); from the visiting vicar's references at assembly to Jewish complicity in Jesus Christ's death; from the scriptural focus of constant RE; and from the sharp tellings off I received for refusing to say the Lord's Prayer.

Within six months, I announced that I would not participate in RE or attend school assemblies, and eventually my parents, citing distress, appealed to the LEA to move me to a local secular school a short distance away.

From conversations with others, I don't believe my experience was in any way unusual. Consequently, I remain very sceptical about the capacity of church and other faith schools to create the inclusive, heterogenous communities Trevor Phillips and others seek.
Prof Davina Cooper
Keele University
d.cooper@law.keele.ac.uk

fields.headline: Cinderellas of the payroll ball
fields.standfirst: Charities should be celebrating the government's support for payroll giving, but many smaller causes are missing out, says Roger Kojecky
fields.trailText: Charities should be celebrating the government's support for payroll giving, but many smaller causes are missing out, says Roger Kojecky.
fields.body:
The government's campaign in support of payroll giving ought to be good news for all charities. With the Treasury adding 10% to donations for a three-year trial period, all the ingredients are there for a party, but many charities, especially smaller local causes, are getting crowded out.

Employers, of course, are the primary audience. Some have dormant schemes, which their employees are not aware of. Many smaller firms have never established payroll giving, and the campaign sets out to inform them how easy to administer it can be. The objective is to double the amount of money given by employees to £60m by 2003, and to increase access to the scheme from one in five to one in three employees.

Enter the professional fundraising organisations (PFOs). These specialists can organise programmes with the employer to promote the scheme and recruit donors. It's a fact of life that donations are much more likely to be triggered by face-to-face requests than by written communications. PFOs send in canvassers who, if they are lucky, spend two or three minutes with interested employees. In that time, they can only talk about a handful of good causes. Big national charities are much more likely to be mentioned than small local ones.

The theory, enthusiastically communicated by the Treasury's campaign, assumes that PFOs are a one-stop shop. No need for employees to deal with numerous local charities. The charities have only to pay a PFO to find donors for them and then they, too, are saved time knocking on the doors of employers. Moreover, the PFOs collectively, together with the payroll giving agencies that process donations, are assumed to provide a fully functioning channel for the swelling volume of national donations. The theory, however, is badly flawed.

PFOs are profit-making concerns with small staffs and a number of part-time canvassers on their books. There are only nine of them on the Treasury's national list, of which one is reported to be barely functioning - letters and phone calls from a client charity have gone unanswered since May 2000.

Moreover, charities applying to be promoted by PFOs are, as a rule, turned away - unless they are already an established brand and sure to attract immediate interest during canvassing. The campaign that was designed to open the floodgates for cash-strapped charitable organisations discourages, in effect, direct contact between charities and employers. The PFO channel turns out to be a closed door.

If the campaign ever goes to a second phase, its implied model should be altered to admit, or commend, alternatives to the PFO bottleneck. Local initiatives between employers and charities can be productive - employee community investment committees, for example, could take on a payroll giving push. Many local and national charities are willing to assist employers to promote payroll giving.

There is also a need for some fresh thinking about the channel. If there is to be equity in the access of local charities to employers, an intermediary entity may need to be set up, possibly with a self-regulatory function.

Meanwhile, there are few restrictions in a useful non-profit website operation at smartchange, which promises to deliver charities' details to corporate intranets. And more charities might consider what they could achieve through a well-resourced consortium with marketing muscle.

 Roger Kojecky is consultant to a central London charity working with homeless people.
