webTitle: Rights groups voice concern about anti-terrorist laws

fields.headline: Rights groups voice concern about anti-terrorist laws
fields.trailText: New anti-terror laws which target groups using Britain as a base for terrorist acts abroad come into force today, but civil rights groups are worried the law could be used to stifle legitimate protest.
fields.body:
New anti-terror laws which target groups using Britain as a base for terrorist acts abroad come into force today, but civil rights groups are worried the law could be used to stifle legitimate protest.

Radical Islamic groups such as Hamas and Hizbullah could be outlawed under the Terrorism Act, which replaces the Prevention of Terrorism Act 1973. Cyber-terrorists who hack into computers to undermine governments or threaten lives are also targeted.

The act allows ministers to add groups to a list of proscribed organisations, which currently includes Irish terror groups such as the IRA and the Ulster Volunteer Force. Groups which could be banned include the Tamil Tigers of Sri Lanka, the Kurdistan People's Party (PKK) of Turkey and the Palestinian Islamic Jihad.

Once an organisation is on the list, it is illegal to be a member of the group, support it financially, display its emblems or share a platform with a member at a meeting of three or more people.

Home secretary Jack Straw said the new legislation strengthened civil liberties and increased police powers to clamp down on terrorism. He denied that moves to outlaw groups using Britain as a base for terrorist action abroad could be seen as anti-Islamic, saying he was one of the government's leading campaigners against "Islamophobia".

Although he would not say which particular groups could be proscribed under the new powers, he insisted that they would not be used to silence all protest.

One reason for introducing the new law was to strengthen the position of individuals by making the law comply with the new Human Rights Act, he said.

The Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, Simon Hughes, said his party had serious reservations about some parts of the legislation.

Most worrying was the wide definition of terrorism, which he believed could easily be used to stifle legitimate protest. He said that trade union leaders calling for a strike at a hospital could be caught by the legislation.

The leader of the Muslim parliament, Ghayasauddin Siddiqui, said many British Asians would feel intimidated by the new laws. He added that Pakistanis campaigning for self-determination in Kashmir would feel they were being discriminated against, for example.

fields.headline: Parkinson outshines Popstars
fields.trailText: 11.30am TV overnights: It took the return of Michael Parkinson to remove the shine from Popstars' ratings, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
It took the return of the old charmer himself, Michael Parkinson, to finally remove the shine from Popstars' ratings.

The hit ITV show's ratings dropped by almost 2m viewers when up against the BBC chatshow king.

Mr Parkinson opened a 10-week run of his evergreen chatshow with an all-female guest line-up of Tracey Ullman, Denise Lewis and Dolly Parton, between 9.05pm and 10.50pm.

Parkinson had 6.8m viewers and a 29% share, according to unofficial overnights

Last week, in the same BBC1 slot, a Jonathan Creek repeat managed just 4.7m viewers.

Popstars ran between 9.15pm and 10pm on ITV and looked back at the events of January, when the tabloids began to run stories about the five band members' private lives.

The reality show slipped a little from the stellar-ratings of the previous two Saturdays, posting 7.9m viewers and a 34% share.

The week before, at 7.30pm on Saturday night, Popstars had pulled in 9.7m - two in five viewers.

BBC2 again won the weekly Saturday night nostalgia battle with Channel 4.

The BBC's I Love 1984 attracted nearly three times as many viewers as Top Ten Eighties Soul between 9.15pm and 10.50pm.

I Love 1984, hosted by Frankie Goes to Hollywood singer Holly Johnson, had 3.1m and a 15% share.

Channel 4's archive-fest pulled in just 1.1m.

Following on at 10.50pm, BBC2's repeated John Hughes bratpack movie the Breakfast Club proved more popular than the 101 Rent Boys documentary on Channel 4.

The Breakfast Club had 1.6m viewers and a 14% share from 10.50pm to 12.20am.

Channel 4's 101 Rent Boys, which focused on the male prostitutes plying their trade on LA's Santa Monica Boulevard, had 1.1m between 10.50 and 11.50pm.

fields.headline: Patriotism is order of the day
fields.standfirst:
London Fashion Week opens with traditional wools, tweeds, and pounds sterling

Special report: London Fashion Week 2001
fields.trailText: London Fashion Week opens with traditional wools, tweeds, and pounds sterling.
fields.body:
London Fashion Week began yesterday, if not exactly with a bang, then with a defiant statement of Britishness. After the typical sleek commerciality of last week's fashion week in New York, London kicked off with catwalks strewn with unusual takes on traditional British fabrics.

Tweeds and wools were very much the order of the day at designer Ronit Zilkha's show, whose collection opened the week. Russell Sage went even further in his take on traditional British fashion: his clothes employed everything from Victorian antique fabrics to spirals of overlaid £50 and £20 notes.

Such patriotism could well be what London Fashion Week needs this season. Within the past two months it has lost designers Hussein Chalayan to financial problems, and Luella Bartley to next week's Milan fashion week. The loss of these more tempting carrots to the international fashion press has caused many anxious PRs and British Fashion Council members to wonder if London has, for the moment, lost its fashion allure.

These annual concerns will no doubt prove unfounded. Certainly there is plenty to look forward to this week, and still some big names - notably, the reliably attention-grabbing Alexander McQueen - to give London some column inches in the international fashion press.

But what London Fashion Week really needs this season is its own, distinctive sense of identity to compensate for some of the gaping holes in the schedule. So perhaps giving his collection such a British feel, not to mention a very British theme, was more than mere whim on Russell Sage's part.

His collection, entitled Russell Sage is History, was he said, "an examination of the intrinsic value of fashion". This examination was most obvious in the clothes made from money, such as a sweet little shift dress composed of £20 and £50 notes, and a silk jacket with circles of money at the shoulders. The non-monetary clothes provided a parade through the fabrics and the history of British fashion: one of the first outfits, a blouse and a pair of shorts, was composed of a Victorian chair cover and Victorian silks and brocades. The models wore little booties with side buttons which were reminiscent of those worn by (male) Elizabethan courtiers.

As the show progressed, the fabrics became lighter as they moved forward in time, such as the childlike pair of white cotton shorts decorated with floral embroidery from the 1930s. Even the seating plan for last year's British Fashion Awards was used as an underskirt. But the only real attempt here at being contemporary came courtesy of the soundtrack. Recent interviews with various designers were heavily and unrecognisably slowed down, treating the audience to bitchy comments about to day's new guard, such as Tom Ford, Stella McCartney and the state of the House of Givenchy. A true taste of the state of international fashion today, in a very British show.

fields.headline: IPC readies technology launch
fields.trailText: 8.30am: IPC is moving into the technology market with a fortnightly internet and web magazine codename Project Spider, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
IPC has confirmed speculation it is to venture into the technology market for the first time, with a fortnightly internet and web magazine codenamed Project Spider.

The move comes as technology and computing titles across the board have reported depressing ABC circulation figures for the second half of 2000.

And on Friday technology publisher Future Network announced it was to cut 350 jobs worldwide.

"The information needs of the home internet user are not being met," said Sylvia Auton, managing director of IPC's Country and Leisure Media group.

IPC said it believed that the market for a magazine targeted at internet users in the 25-50 age group is as large as 7m.

Project Spider is to be edited by Jim Lennox, the former editor of Computeractive.

The Project Spider magazine will have an initial print run of 250,000.

Mr Lennox rebuffed suggestions that Project Spider could fall prey to the same market conditions that caused the Future Network magazine Project Click to be scrapped before launch.

He said Project Spider was launching into a "completely different market" from Computeractive and Future's Project Click.

He also said that Project Spider was likely to target more female readers.

Technology and computing magazines have been badly hit in the latest ABCs, with many titles reporting double-digit circulation drops.

fields.standfirst: Plus: Debra Messing to be Woody's girl; Val Kilmer sizes up fairground chilller
fields.trailText: Plus: Debra Messing to be Woody's girl; Val Kilmer sizes up fairground chilller
fields.body:
 Jennifer Jason Leigh is the latest star name to sign on for The Road to Perdition, the next film from American beauty director Sam Mendes. The film showcases Tom Hanks as a Prohibition-era assassin who embarks on a mission of vengeance when his family are murdered. The bad news for Jennifer is that she is down to play the role of Hanks's wife: expect a few lines of dialogue around the breakfast table and then a grisly death scene about twenty minutes into the picture. The Road to Perdition also stars Jude Law (as a rival assassin) and Tom Sizemore (as Al Capone) and will boast a cameo appearance from Paul Newman.

 Rising star Debra Messing is to join an ensemble cast that includes Helen Hunt, Charlize Theron and Dan Aykroyd in the new Woody Allen picture The Curse of the Jade Scorpion. Messing, who will play the role of Allen's girlfriend, also had a small part in the film-maker's unloved 1998 satire Celebrity.

 Desperately seeking a hit to reverse his fortunes, troubled actor Val Kilmer is in negotiations to star in The Princess of Paradise Park opposite Jim Caviezel, star of Frequency and The Thin Red Line. Kilmer and Caviezel will play brothers who inherit a delapidated carousel from their grandfather which is haunted by the ghost of their dead sister.

fields.headline: E-district suspends chief executive
fields.trailText: 11.30am: The entertainment dotcom has suspended its chief executive after finding serious accounting flaws, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Online entertainment company e-district.net has sensationally suspended its chief executive after discovering serious accounting flaws at the fledgling dotcom.

In a brief statement to the stock exchange, the e-district board said it had suspended Steve Laitman after finding the reported numbers for registered users, page impressions and revenues for last year had been "substantially overstated".

The company, which floated last March, offers online interactive games that enable users to play against each other from different locations.

One of its most popular attractions is the chance to adopt a Tamagochi-style cyberpet.

"It is not clear over what period of time this overstatement has occurred but it could include all of 2000.

"The board is not aware of any misappropriation of funds," e-district said in the statement.

The company's board has also requested that e-district shares be suspended on the AIM index.

E-district provides interactive entertainment via the internet and digital television.

It also runs the Leisuredistrict interactive games service for 16- to 35-year-olds.

The company reported a half-year loss of £0.6m in October last year, with 2.1m registered users and 273m page impressions a month.

E-district has already been criticised for its belief it can generate revenues almost entirely from online advertising.

This approach has left it exposed to the overall downturn in the UK advertising market.

fields.headline: The Rumour Mill
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours would encourage you to give £200 to the Labour Party. And then give you a promotion
fields.trailText: The Mirror reckon that Steve Bruce is the "surprise candidate" to take over from Gerry Francis at QPR. The paper claims the former Huddersfield boss is the board's favourite to fill the Loftus Road vacancy. The Daily Star, meanwhile, still tip Dave Bassett for the job, while the Daily Mail believe Graham Rix will get it.
fields.body:
The Mirror reckon that Steve Bruce is the "surprise candidate" to take over from Gerry Francis at QPR. The paper claims the former Huddersfield boss is the board's favourite to fill the Loftus Road vacancy. The Daily Star, meanwhile, still tip Dave Bassett for the job, while the Daily Mail believe Graham Rix will get it.

In another R's rumour, the Daily Mail reports that David Ginola could be a surprise transfer target for the First Division club.

With John Gregory having gone on a European tour, Teamtalk speculate that the Villa boss could be set to move for PSV Eindhoven captain Mark van Bommel. The 23-year-old has had an impressive season in the PSV midfield, an area Gregory wants to strengthen at the Villa. "We still need strengthening," Gregory said this weekend, "and in an ideal world we would be able to bring in someone before next Saturday's game at Derby."

West Ham's on-loan defender Hannu Tihinen could move on to Middlesbrough, according to Teamtalk. The Finnish international's loan spell at Upton Park ends this week, but Harry Redknapp is unwilling to fork out £3m to sign him permanently. Boro have taken note of Tihinen's impressive form, however, and could move for him instead.

Crystal Palace will attempt to sign former Manchester United striker Erik Nevland this week, according to Planet Football. The Norwegian, now playing for Viking Stavanger, impressed Alan Smith at a recent tournament in La Manga.

fields.trailText:
From: "Personalize, NIKE iD" nikeid_personalize@nike.com
To: "Jonah H. Peretti" peretti@media.mit.edu
Subject: RE: Your NIKE iD order o16468000
fields.body:
From: "Personalize, NIKE iD" nikeid_personalize@nike.com
To: "Jonah H. Peretti" peretti@media.mit.edu
Subject: RE: Your NIKE iD order o16468000

Your NIKE iD order was cancelled for one or more of the following reasons.

1) Your Personal iD contains another party's trademark or other intellectual property.

2) Your Personal iD contains the name of an athlete or team we do not have the legal right to use.

3) Your Personal iD was left blank. Did you not want any personalization?

4) Your Personal iD contains profanity or inappropriate slang, and besides, your mother would slap us.

If you wish to reorder your NIKE iD product with a new personalization Please visit us again at www.nike.com

Thank you, NIKE iD

From: "Jonah H. Peretti" peretti@media.mit.edu
To: "Personalize, NIKE iD" nikeid_personalize@nike.com
Subject: RE: Your NIKE iD order o16468000

Greetings,

My order was canceled but my personal NIKE iD does not violate any of the criteria outlined in your message. The Personal iD on my custom ZOOM XC USA running shoes was the word "sweatshop."

Sweatshop is not: 1) another's party's trademark, 2) the name of an athlete, 3) blank, or 4) profanity.

I choose the iD because I wanted to remember the toil and labor of the children that made my shoes. Could you please ship them to me immediately.

Thanks and Happy New Year, Jonah Peretti

From: "Personalize, NIKE iD" nikeid_personalize@nike.com
To: "Jonah H. Peretti" peretti@media.mit.edu
Subject: RE: Your NIKE iD order o16468000

Dear NIKE iD Customer,

Your NIKE iD order was cancelled because the iD you have chosen contains, as stated in the previous e-mail correspondence, "inappropriate slang".

If you wish to reorder your NIKE iD product with a new personalization Please visit us again at www.nike.com

Thank you, NIKE iD

From: "Jonah H. Peretti" peretti@media.mit.edu
To: "Personalize, NIKE iD" nikeid_personalize@nike.com
Subject: RE: Your NIKE iD order o16468000

Dear NIKE iD,

Thank you for your quick response to my inquiry about my custom ZOOM XC USA running shoes. Although I commend you for your prompt customer service, I disagree with the claim that my personal iD was inappropriate slang. After consulting Webster's Dictionary, I discovered that "sweatshop" is in fact part of standard English, and not slang. The word means: "a shop or factory in which workers are employed for long hours at low wages and under unhealthy conditions" and its origin dates from 1892. So my personal iD does meet the criteria detailed in your first email.

Your website advertises that the NIKE iD program is "about freedom to choose and freedom to express who you are." I share Nike's love of freedom and personal expression. The site also says that "If you want it done right...build it yourself." I was thrilled to be able to build my own shoes, and my personal iD was offered as a small token of appreciation for the sweatshop workers poised to help me realize my vision. I hope that you will value my freedom of expression and reconsider your decision to reject my order.

Thank you, Jonah Peretti

From: "Personalize, NIKE iD" nikeid_personalize@nike.com
To: "Jonah H. Peretti" peretti@media.mit.edu
Subject: RE: Your NIKE iD order o16468000

Dear NIKE iD Customer,

Regarding the rules for personalization it also states on the NIKE iD web site that "Nike reserves the right to cancel any Personal iD up to 24 hours after it has been submitted".

In addition it further explains: "While we honor most personal iDs, we cannot honor every one. Some may be (or contain) others trademarks, or the names of certain professional sports teams, athletes or celebrities that Nike does not have the right to use. Others may contain material that we consider inappropriate or simply do not want to place on our products.

Unfortunately, at times this obliges us to decline personal iDs that may otherwise seem unobjectionable. In any event, we will let you know if we decline your personal iD, and we will offer you the chance to submit another."

With these rules in mind we cannot accept your order as submitted. If you wish to reorder your NIKE iD product with a new personalization please visit us again at www.nike.com

Thank you, NIKE iD

From: "Jonah H. Peretti" peretti@media.mit.edu
To: "Personalize, NIKE iD" nikeid_personalize@nike.com
Subject: RE: Your NIKE iD order o16468000

Dear NIKE iD,

Thank you for the time and energy you have spent on my request. I have decided to order the shoes with a different iD, but I would like to make one small request. Could you please send me a color snapshot of the ten-year-old Vietnamese girl who makes my shoes?

Thanks, Jonah Peretti

(no response)

webTitle: In brief: Hannibal stays at number one in US

fields.headline: Hannibal stays at number one in US
fields.standfirst: Plus: Funding for biopic with Depp and Clooney falls through; four hospitalised after accident on Four Feathers set
fields.trailText: Plus: Funding for biopic with Depp and Clooney falls through; four hospitalised after accident on Four Feathers set
fields.body:
 Hannibal reigned supreme at the US box office for the second weekend running, pulling in a hefty $30m (£20.7m) in the three day period from Friday to Sunday. Its closest competitors were miles behind: the Heaven Can Wait remake Down to Earth, starring comic Chris Rock, debuted in second place with $17.5m (£12m) and the kids romp Recess: School's Out came in third with $10.8 (£7.45m), just ahead of the Keanu Reeves weepie Sweet November on $10.5m (£7.24m). Boosted by its Oscar nominations and a wider release Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon soared up to fifth place on the chart. Nothing, though, came close to disturbing Ridley Scott's polished horror-thriller, which has eased passed the $100m (£69m) mark after only ten days on general release.

 Funding for a new film starring Johnny Depp and George Clooney has fallen through at the eleventh hour, leaving the project in limbo. Based on the autobiography of Gong Show host Chuck Barris, Confessions of a Dangerous Mind was to have starred Depp as a TV compere who doubles as a CIA operative and Clooney as the organisation's recruiting agent. But backers Renaissance Films have failed to come up with the required budget of $35m (£24.15m). The film, which was to have been directed by Bryan (X-Men) Singer, was due to have started filming next month, immediately after Clooney completed work on Steven Soderbergh's Ocean's Eleven.

 Production on The Four Feathers, starring Kate Hudson and Heath Ledger, was halted over the weekend after a horse accident injured six extras and an animal handler on the film's set at London's Greenwich Naval College. A production statement revealed that four crew members had been hospitalised, while the other three were treated at the scene. Fans of the Oscar-nominated actress will be relieved to know that Ms Hudson was not on set at the time. As a result, the Almost Famous star did not even require so much as a band aid.

fields.headline: Dr Martens kicks off spring advertising blitz
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Dr Martens is to launch an advertising campaign in April to include guerrilla marketing techniques, reports Julia Day
fields.body:
Dr Martens is gearing up to launch a new advertising campaign in April that will include guerrilla marketing techniques.

The 40-year-old boot brand owned by Northamptonshire company R Griggs appointed advertising agency Mustoe Merriman Herring Levy to its account 18 months ago.

But MMHL new business director Damian Horner said the new campaign was the first big push the agency has created for the brand.

Mr Horner added that previous work has been of a more tactical nature.

In April Dr Martens will take over Covent Garden underground station for the whole month, with blanket advertising on poster sites.

The brand's flagship London store is situated in the heart of Covent Garden.

Exposure, the PR agency appointed to the brand's account in September, will launch a guerrilla marketing campaign in and around Covent Garden.

Email viral marketing is also believed to form another strand of the brand's new marketing push.

A print advertising campaign by MMHL will run in style press magazines including The Face and iD.

R Griggs has also appointed PR agency DLA Upstream to handle its corporate, financial and political affairs.

The £6.25m Dr Martens international media account was moved out of Manning Gottlieb Media and into Starcom Motive last June without a pitch.

fields.headline: Kashmir clashes continue
fields.standfirst: With the state's unilateral ceasefire set to expire on February 26, the cycle of violence and protest shows no sign of abating, says Luke Harding
fields.trailText: With the state's unilateral ceasefire due to expire on February 26, the cycle of violence and protest shows no sign of abating, says Luke Harding in New Delhi.
fields.body:
Jalil Ahmad Shah was not a militant. Of this his family are certain. But four days ago Shah, who ran a medical shop in the Kashmiri town of Haigam, mysteriously disappeared.

His mother, four sisters and brothers grew increasingly anxious. Eventually word reached them that he had been arrested by Indian security forces. Their uncertain wait continued.

The army then announced that Shah was dead - and said he had been killed in an "encounter" in the deep and soundless forests which surround the town. Shah was a top commander in the Harakat-ul Jihad-e-Islami, a Pakistan-based militant group, they added.

Shah's mother admits that he supported the Jammu and Kashmir Liberation Front - a non-violent separatist group opposed to Indian rule in Kashmir. But she denies - adamantly and mournfully - that her son had ever taken up arms.

There is nothing particularly remarkable about the manner of Shah's death. He was merely the latest victim of a practice which has become so commonplace in Kashmir that it goes almost unremarked in India itself: extra-judicial killing.

Since 1989 Muslim guerrillas have been waging a war against the Indian presence in the state: a war in which more than 30,000 people - civilians, guerrillas, Indian army and policemen - have died.

The guerrillas are supported by Islamic fundamentalists in Pakistan, who want Kashmir incorporated into Pakistan as part of a larger Islamic state.

Since Partition, when Pakistan was created as a separate homeland for India's Muslims, India has never stopped claiming the Muslim-dominated valley for itself. Some half a million Indian troops are now stationed in the valley to keep the insurgency at bay.

While there is no doubt that many of those who are killed by the Indian army in Kashmir are "foreign mercenaries", many others - like Jalil Ahmad Shah - are not. It is merely convenient to term them so.

The day after Shah's mysterious death, thousands of local Muslims gathered in Haigam, north of Kashmir's summer capital Srinagar, to protest. The protesters blocked the national highway. They were confronted by an army patrol.

According to a local Indian police officer who was there, the army then "went berserk" and started firing indiscriminately.

Five villagers were shot dead on the spot, including two women. The officer, Kursheed Khan, who has filed a formal complaint, only survived the massacre because he was pushed out of the way by one of the villagers, who took the bullets instead.

The army has expressed regret over last Thursday's deaths and has vowed to investigate. "I give you my solemn word that those of my men who are blameworthy will be brought to book and dealt with according to the law," the Indian army's 15 Corps chief John Ray Mukherjee said yesterday (Sun).

But the army's track record of punishing those responsible for extra-judicial killings is a poor one. No one has yet been held accountable, for example, for the murder of five Muslims who were killed and then mutilated after being accused of carrying out a massacre at Chitisinghpura in Kashmir last March, when 35 Sikhs were killed during President Clinton's visit to India.

No inquiry is being carried out into the death two weeks ago of the owner of a car used during a militant attack on Srinagar airport. The army says the owner, who was taken into custody, was shot "while trying to escape".

All this while India's prime minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee decides whether to extend his unilateral ceasefire in Kashmir, in place since November.

The ceasefire is due to expire on February 26. The Indian government last night postponed a crucial meeting to discuss the issue. Mr Vajpayee is said to be in favour of extension, though his position remains equivocal.

"Violence in Kashmir has not ebbed. We thought Pakistan would be able to rein back the terrorists but it has failed," he said last week.

But India's hawkish home minister, together with the government's Hindu nationalist supporters, are said to be against any extension. They point to the fact that militants have killed at least 16 people, including 11 policeman, in recent months.

In Kashmir, meanwhile, the interminable cycle of violence and protest continues, with running clashes in Srinagar between police and protestors.

More such protests, and more such killings, can be expected in the coming weeks.

fields.bodyText: Jalil Ahmad Shah was not a militant. Of this his family are certain. But four days ago Shah, who ran a medical shop in the Kashmiri town of Haigam, mysteriously disappeared. His mother, four sisters and brothers grew increasingly anxious. Eventually word reached them that he had been arrested by Indian security forces. Their uncertain wait continued. The army then announced that Shah was dead - and said he had been killed in an "encounter" in the deep and soundless forests which surround the town. Shah was a top commander in the Harakat-ul Jihad-e-Islami, a Pakistan-based militant group, they added. Shah's mother admits that he supported the Jammu and Kashmir Liberation Front - a non-violent separatist group opposed to Indian rule in Kashmir. webTitle: Intimacy triumphs at Berlin Film Festival

fields.headline: Intimacy triumphs at Berlin Film Festival
fields.trailText: Patrice Chereau's controversial film version of Hanif Kureishi's novel took the festival's top prize despite facing accusations that it is self-consciously sexually explicit
fields.body:
Intimacy, a controversial portrait of adultery, beat heavy favourite Traffic to take the Silver Bear award for best film at the Berlin Film Festival last night. The film's female lead Kerry Fox won the best actress award, while the Oscar-nominated Traffic player Benicio del Toro was named best actor.

"You can imagine how beautiful this is for me," said Intimacy director Patrice Chereau upon accepting the festival's premiere award. All week, the French film-maker had been forced to defend his picture from charges that it is self-consciously provocative and explicit. At one stage the director became so exasperated at a press conference that he refused to answer any more questions over the film's sexual content. Based on the novel by Hanif Kureishi, the film stars Fox as a bored housewife who embarks on a tragic affair with a London bartender (Mark Rylance). Primarily set in a shabby London flat, the film's centrepiece is an unbroken 35-minute sex scene.

The other big winners at the Berlin Film Festival were Taiwanese film-maker Lin Cheng-sheng who took the best director award for his movie Betelnut Beauty and Hollywood legend Kirk Douglas who was presented with the Golden Bear lifetime achievement award. Now aged 84 and hampered by a stroke that he suffered five years ago, Douglas took the stage to accept his award in person. In a brief interview, he said that he was more proud of his political activism than his movies but said he would still leap at the chance of working with Steven Soderbergh (who cast Kirk's son Michael in Traffic). "I have learned one thing in life," Douglas told the assembled throng. "Never, never give up."

webTitle: Drug company's legal battle puts price savings at risk

fields.headline: Drug company's legal battle puts price savings at risk
fields.trailText: Supplies of cheaper prescription medicines that save the NHS more than £80m a year are threatened by a legal battle between a German-based multinational drug company and the European commission, the Consumers' Association (CA) warns today.
fields.body:
Supplies of cheaper prescription medicines that save the NHS more than £80m a year are threatened by a legal battle between a German-based multinational drug company and the European commission, the Consumers' Association (CA) warns today.

Victory for Bayer would end the whole practice of parallel trade in drugs in the EU.

Manufacturers sell products at different prices to different EU countries. But some "parallel" distributors buy drugs from wholesalers in countries with relatively low prices and re-sell them in countries at a level that undercuts the higher prices of the same products supplied directly by the manufacturers.

The row over the trade that helps the NHS control its annual £5.5bn drugs budget comes as companies are also under heavy fire from aid agencies for charging too much in developing countries.

Bayer has so far successfully fought through the courts a £1.9m fine levied by the commission in 1996 for trying to prevent the parallel trade of the heart drug Adalat into Britain. The commission and a German group of parallel traders have now taken the case to the European court of justice.

Douglas Macarthur, of the European Association of Euro Pharmaceutical Companies, said, in CA's consumer policy review, that parallel trade posed no danger to safety since the drugs had the same active ingredients as the branded drugs and they were administered in the same way, as well as being made by the same manufacturers.

"Parallel trade means increased competition which can also generate substantial savings," he said.

Clare Mackay, editor of the review, said the trade acted as an informal price control and a brake on monopolistic practices by multinationals.

"The EU, and member countries, support parallel trading in this field," she said. "It means that discounted pharmaceutical products can enter the market, reducing overall drugs budgets for member states. Diversion of sales from one EU country to another has not led to the industry cutting back on research and development, nor has it meant that a market for counterfeit or substandard products has been created."

 All NHS patients should pay the first £60 of their annual prescription bill, with better off people paying up to £120 a year, said Ian Senior, an analyst for the Adam Smith Institute thinktank. This would help to provide an extra £2.2bn for the annual medicines budget and bring an end to the postcode lottery approach to rationing expensive new treatments, he added.

webTitle: C4 swipes rally rights from BBC

fields.headline: C4 swipes rally rights from BBC
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Channel 4 has snatched the World Rally Championship UK TV rights from the BBC in a £20m three-year deal, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 4 has snatched the World Rally Championship UK TV rights from the BBC in a £20m three-year deal.

The broadcaster has secured exclusive live and highlights coverage of the premier rally competition, starting in 2002.

Channel 4's £20m investment will cover the cost of buying the rights, plus production and marketing costs.

Two years ago, Channel 4 swiped the rights to England's home cricket tests from the BBC.

Channel 4 went on to win numerous awards for its new approach to covering the sport.

"Just as we have with cricket, we aim to give the viewers a greater understanding and appreciation of rallying - the techniques, tactics and sheer nerve required to become the best driver in the world," said David Kerr, Channel 4 editor of sport.

Channel 4 chief executive Michael Jackson added: "The World Rally Championship has always been a thrilling and hugely popular event.

"However, new technology means we can now transform the coverage of this classic sport and make it accessible to a wider audience."

The World Rally Championship has 14 rounds, culminating in the British leg, the Rally of Great Britain.

Channel 4's coverage will be produced by Chrysalis Television, which makes World Rally programming for international distribution.

Chrysalis is also involved in the production of ITV's formula one programming, through the MACh1 joint venture.

Channel 4 was awarded the rights contract by World Rally Championship rights holder International Sportsworld Communicators.

ISC was recently bought by David Richards from formula one boss Bernie Ecclestone.

"Channel 4's plans include wide-ranging joint marketing initiatives," said Mr Richards.

"I am certain that as we develop the programme offering, they will become a benchmark by which other broadcasters are judged."

webTitle: Bruno Brookes vows never to return

fields.headline: 'My DJ days are over' vows Bruno Brookes
fields.standfirst: Feb 19: I'm a crap DJ now
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Former BBC Radio 1 DJ Bruno Brookes has vowed never to go back into the studio, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Former BBC Radio 1 DJ Bruno Brookes has vowed never to go back into the studio.

In an interview published in Media Guardian this morning Mr Brookes, now managing director of internet radio outfit Storm Digital Broadcasting, insisted his DJ days are over and that nothing would get him back behind the turntables.

"The number of times I've been asked by our programme director to do a show - and I will not. I won't go anywhere near that studio now. I'm a crap DJ now," he said.

Mr Brookes, whose company runs internet radio station StormLive, is also glad to be out of the public eye.

"Being in the limelight can be a pain in the arse. I don't care if people recognise me anymore. It's not what turns me on anymore," he said.

Mr Brookes said he prefered to stay behind the scenes and is amazed that his contemporaries, the likes of Tony Blackburn, Jimmy Young and Alan "Fluff" Freeman, can still spin the wheels of steel.

"I find it amazing that they can still carry on doing radio and that they've still got sparkle. No disrespect, but I knew all along I was not going to end up like that. Good luck to you guys, I couldn't do it," he added.

webTitle: Blair wants register of drug dealers

fields.headline: Blair wants register of drug dealers
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday increased the political momentum towards the next general election with a speech to the Labour party's spring conference which heralded a crack down on drug dealers and offered a new deal for working fathers.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday increased the political momentum towards the next general election with a speech to the Labour party's spring conference which heralded a crack down on drug dealers and offered a new deal for working fathers.

In a call to arms to 3,000 party activists in Glasgow, the prime minister claimed New Labour had grown up in office and that Britain was on the brink of "the biggest progressive political advance for a century".

With one eye on election day - which many political observers believe will fall on May 3 - he called on party workers to go out to the country with heads held high, spelling out the message of the government's successes.

"Whenever this fight comes, go into it with confidence, go into it knowing we have won the intellectual and political debate in this country," he said.

As if to kickstart activists he gave them a series of new policies to sell to families, the unemployed and announced a further crackdown on crime.

Eyecatching among the raft of measures was a drugs register that all convicted dealers will be forced to sign.

Like the paedophile register, it would be open only to police. Anyone freed from jail and liable to deal in drugs would go on the register so that unusual bank transactions and changes of address could be monitored.

Mr Blair revealed further "next steps" manifesto policies, including paid paternity leave, likely to be worth £62 for two weeks. The proposal was attacked as a new burden on business by the Institute of Directors, but Labour insisted the reform is an example of how investment in human capital will increase British productivity in the long term.

Mr Blair also promised to extend his "tough love" welfare reforms by making unemployment benefit conditional on the unemployed not just taking up a general training scheme but also attending reading, writing and basic maths courses. More than seven million adults are estimated to lack basic literary skills.

Mr Blair also effectively ruled out generalised tax cuts in the March budget saying he wanted tax breaks that help children, "whatever the position of their parents".

He said: "I believe in marriage but I also believe that the widow or the single mother whose husband has deserted her cannot be discriminated against for something not their fault." Senior Labour MPs left Glasgow predicting a commons majority of more than 100 with some urging Mr Blair to call the election in April. Privately some senior Labour ministers favour a four-week campaign, rather than the expected three, believing it will expose the tensions in Conservative ranks.

Much of Mr Blair's speech was devoted to energising a rank and file that has often respected, rather than loved the government. He told them: "I take pride in the fact that this is the first Labour government in history where the party in the country and in government have stayed together and seen this thing through together."

People had joined Labour to change society and "no longer to pass resolutions across the corners of a room at one another".

He urged the conference to realise "this could indeed be the 21st century of progressive politics". All over the world, he claimed, policies of economy and society were no longer in conflict. Social justice, as well as investment in human capital were now what drove economies forward. "Show that we believe in ourselves and then I tell you this country will show confidence in us."

Mr Blair derided William Hague as the "only political leader in history who has his opinions delivered to him by the paper boy. We are the practical party, the others now are the ideologues and extremists that have atrophied and gone off to the right."

Last night the Conservatives branded the paternity leave measure as a "transparent election ploy" because no introduction date has been announced, adding that it will create a "red tape burden" for small businesses.

The TUC welcomed the announcement saying: "We welcome it and obviously hope it happens sooner rather than later."

The move would bring Britain in line with many other European nations that have statutory paternity leave. In Austria new fathers enjoy 10 days paid paternity leave. Fathers in Belgium get three days fully-paid leave in the private sector and four in the public sector.

Tory trade and industry spokesman David Heathcoat-Amory said: "The government is holding out the prospect of goodies without confirming a date for legislation.

"If this move follows past practice, the associated burden of paperwork and red tape burden will, in practice, fall on business, in particular small firms."
fields.bodyText: Tony Blair yesterday increased the political momentum towards the next general election with a speech to the Labour party's spring conference which heralded a crack down on drug dealers and offered a new deal for working fathers. In a call to arms to 3,000 party activists in Glasgow, the prime minister claimed New Labour had grown up in office and that Britain was on the brink of "the biggest progressive political advance for a century". With one eye on election day - which many political observers believe will fall on May 3 - he called on party workers to go out to the country with heads held high, spelling out the message of the government's successes. "Whenever this fight comes, go into it with confidence, go into it knowing we have won the intellectual and political debate in this country," he said. As if to kickstart activists he gave them a series of new policies to sell to families, the unemployed and announced a further crackdown on crime. Eyecatching among the raft of measures was a drugs register that all convicted dealers will be forced to sign. Like the paedophile register, it would be open only to police. Anyone freed from jail and liable to deal in drugs would go on the register so that unusual bank transactions and changes of address could be monitored. Mr Blair revealed further "next steps" manifesto policies, including paid paternity leave, likely to be worth £62 for two weeks. The proposal was attacked as a new burden on business by the Institute of Directors, but Labour insisted the reform is an example of how investment in human capital will increase British productivity in the long term. Mr Blair also promised to extend his "tough love" welfare reforms by making unemployment benefit conditional on the unemployed not just taking up a general training scheme but also attending reading, writing and basic maths courses. More than seven million adults are estimated to lack basic literary skills. Mr Blair also effectively ruled out generalised tax cuts in the March budget saying he wanted tax breaks that help children, "whatever the position of their parents". He said: "I believe in marriage but I also believe that the widow or the single mother whose husband has deserted her cannot be discriminated against for something not their fault." fields.headline: Tony and William log off
fields.standfirst:
As Labour plays down its plans to fight the next election in cyberspace, Matthew Tempest shows how all British parties can learn the lessons of US political campaigning on the internet
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: As Labour plays down its plans to fight the next election in cyberspace, Matthew Tempest shows how all British parties can learn the lessons of US political campaigning on the internet
fields.body:
For a contest that was supposed to herald online political campaigning, the US presidential election was more like a return to the industrial revolution. Its enduring images were of mechanical machines counting pile after pile of disputed ballot papers and pregnant chads.

But before the dark days of Florida, the US did offer web evangelists a taste of future elections. And since the US is five years ahead of the world with anything web-related, the results are being studied by party strategists in the UK.

Both Democrats and Republicans invested heavily in web campaigning during the election. But a survey by America's e-Voter institute - a non-partisan company promoting the use of the internet as a political tool for campaigning and analysis - found that their investment yielded disappointing results. Gore's adverts enticed Republican supporters to vote for Bush, and vice versa: 60% of Democrats who saw online adverts for Bush voted for Gore.

From the industry's point of view, the only good news was that swing voters who identified themselves as Democrats were 18% more likely to vote for Gore once they had seen an online advert. The same figure for swing voters who identified themselves as Republicans was 4%.

The survey tracked 40,000 customers of Juno Online Services, a free ISP in the US that required users to allow their surfing habits to be tracked, from June to November 2000. Participants registered their sympathies before the study began and their exposure to advertising was then monitored, and voting behaviour tracked after the election.

The apparent adverse reaction threw Labour's Millbank appratchiks into a tizzy two weeks ago as they rushed to deny reports that they would abandon a top-secret internet advertising blitz.

But Dennis Kavanagh, professor of politics and communication studies at Liverpool University, believes they have had a rethink.

"The Labour party was intending to use this general election as a prototype for five years' time where we really could see some proactive marketing on the web," he says. "That's now on the back burner as strategists realise that these ads, especially the pop-up-style ones, are very potent but need to be handled with care because people find them irritating."

That view is partially borne out by the latest findings from Forrester Internet User Monitor, which shows that 51% of British net users object to pop-up banners or internet advertising. American online strategist Steve Clift, who runs Web, White and Blue - a consortium of American political portals - believes much of the time and effort of website designers was misguided and that a simple email list was often the best form of online campaigning.

He says: "The key element is to register email details and create an electronic loop of information. The Gore website was beautiful to look at and very features-rich, whereas the Bush site was more message-orientated with a 2m sign-up target for emails."

Clift's own research shows that while just 15% of the American online public visited a political site, 50% sent or received a political email. That fact is not lost on Conservative Central Office, which last week launched a William Hague audio-email urging supporters to save the pound - and forward the email.

Labour denies shelving its internet campaign (the official line being that since no details of what it had planned had been released, no change of direction had taken place) and is now keen to play up a policy of letting webmasters put "Labour party sign up email" boxes on their sites. A spokesman for its election strategy team says:

"It's something we've been studying carefully for years. There are so many styles of internet advertising - banners on non-political websites, pop-ups, email lists, click through, region-specific ads - but you have the same dilemmas in the new medium as you do in the old. You know what they say, 'In advertising, half the money you spend is wasted, it's a question of which half.' The main website is a fantastic resource for getting your message across unmediated by the press and broadcasters, and for telling constituencies exactly what cuts the Tories are planning in their home town. We would be silly not to enlarge it in the years to come - especially if you look at projected rates of growth and penetration."

David Walter, head of communications and chief strategist for the Liberal Democrats, agrees: "For the LibDems, everything has to come back to finances. We don't get the £5m cheques the larger parties pick up, and so our resources will be concentrated on our internet site, both as a point of reference for voters on policy issues, and for selling ourselves through pro-active campaigns, such as the petition currently running to save our tube at www.save thetube.org. That's proved hugely successful and also gives us a database of emails to contact."

But the dangers of unsolicited emails have already alarmed planners at Conservative Central Office, although they didn't stop their Save the Pound email. The party's chief internet planner, Jonathan French, says:

"There are inherent dangers in an unabridged or unedited email list, attractive as it may be in terms of the number of subscribers. So far as other forms of proactive advertising are concerned, let's just say we are ruling nothing out."

One element the Tories may pinch from their Republican soulmates is the Bush site's online tax calculator, which allowed wavering voters to work out how much they saved under George W's tax-cutting manifesto. The big question facing all three parties will, however, be how to finance these campaigns. Not only would none of the major parties put a figure on their internet budget, but the rules regarding electoral spending have just been redrawn. Last week saw the unveiling of the six new electoral commissioners who will limit what parties can spend on campaign advertising. But privately the commissioners admit they do not know how spending on internet advertising will be audited.

One said: "A party website does not count as campaign spend because people visit it unsolicited. However, a mass email to 400,000 subscribers should be registered, but how do you measure the cost of an email? It's not as simple as auditing 400,000 first class stamps."

It will also be an offence for the first time to solicit a donation of greater than £200 from a person not registered on the UK electoral roll - tricky if the money comes from someone donating online from an email address.

Since the Commission will only be auditing the accounts retrospectively, party strategists are hoping to draw up an informal cross-party memorandum of understanding to ensure that all parties adhere to the same rules - but don't hold your breath. As Dr Stephen Coleman, director of the e-democracy programme at the Hansard Society, warns:

"The big issue of the election after this will be breaches of campaign spending. The parties have barely thought this through, from the simple fact that MPs will have to take down their personal websites as soon as an election is called, to buying up bogus websites and the costs of companies which create partisan links to the parties." Creative accounting - always a part of election campaigns - will surely spread to the net.

 Matthew Tempest is a politics reporter

fields.headline: My New Media
fields.standfirst: Lewis Bronze
fields.trailText: Lewis Bronze
fields.body:
Favourite websites?

Streetmap.co.uk. It's the most fantastic free resource. The speed, coverage and searchability are brilliant, but I think it stinks as a business model. I'd pay to subscribe to that service! Another is chiswick4.com, a local community website which is great for restaurant reviews and local issues. It's interesting and a bit more scandalous than reading the local paper. People get to say stuff that could never be printed.

Last online purchase?

A book for my wife from Amazon. Prior to that it was two bottles of malt whisky from Berry Brothers.

Most recent technological faux pas?

I completely failed to understand the recent advertising campaign for mobile phones: the adverts on bus shelters which showed text messages. I think they were aimed at teenagers, and I simply couldn't understand what they were saying. It all made me feel very old.

Ever been in a chat room?

Yes. I've been in investment and technology chat rooms on Yahoo! but they didn't really work for me. I didn't learn as much from live interaction as from reading email postings on bulletin boards.

Main news source on the web?

FT.com, sportinglife.com and a newsletter from the US called the Education Economy Newsletter which covers deals in educational IT.

Most useful site on the web?

Google search engine is the most incredible invention. There's nothing else like it. It makes all other search engines look pathetic.

Which site is least likely to succeed? I

think Lastminute.com must be very vulnerable. The functionality of the site is poor and so are the offers. The concept of lastminute was a great idea, but in reality it's flawed.

Time spent on the web?

About an hour a day, in bite-size portions.

Least useful site on the web?

An awful lot of them are by media companies. I think that broadcasters have been slow and arrogant about the web, and a lot of their sites reflect that. They are too ponderous. The one thing that has helped change that perception was the success of the Big Brother website, because it was so central to the narrative.

Do you use a screensaver?

I use one created by our own company.

Most irritating thing about web?

Slowness, download delays and broken links. Also, video on the web has got a long way to go.

Do you still bother with old media?

Yes, the whole lot, all the time.

 Lewis Bronze is CEO of espresso.co.uk

fields.headline: 'I'm a crap DJ now'
fields.standfirst: He's not interested in getting back on the airwaves and the fame game leaves him cold.  Amy Vickers on an ex-Radio 1 golden boy who nowadays gets his kicks from digital radio
fields.trailText: He's not interested in getting back on the airwaves and the fame game leaves him cold. Amy Vickers on an ex-Radio 1 golden boy who nowadays gets his kicks from digital radio
fields.body:
Remember Bruno Brookes: the former Radio 1 DJ who, for much of the 80s, was as widely recognised as many of the popstars of the time? But one minute he was Radio 1's hottest property, the next he was off the airwaves and disappearing in to obscurity.

Ten years on from his Radio 1 heyday, most people will only be familiar with him because his name has been raked through the mud by his ex-girlfriend, the publicity-paramour Anthea Turner, who decided to tell the world that their relationship was no bed of roses.

Brookes is understandably bitter, but shrugs off the chance to get even (in this interview at least). "The public made their own mind up about that one. It's best to leave it in the past," he says, unable to resist adding: "And I haven't seen her in the media since." Perhaps he is smiling inwardly when he says this, but his expression never changes from dead-pan business Bruno; the serious Bruno who now runs a digital broadcast company which employs 40 people.

We meet at his London office in swanky New Bond Street, where the walls are plastered with platinum records and the latest in technology sits around begging to be played with. I recognise him straight away. He's the same diminutive, button nosed, clean shaven man that I grew up with. The only difference is a well-fed waistline and a receding hairline, framed by a halo of inch-long hair where once sat his trademark bouffant.

First things first, he says, I have to smoke a rollup. He seems to like the fact that previous profiles of him have always kicked off with reference to his Golden Virginia habit. We then get down to the business of the interview. He tells me about his internet radio station, StormLive, and his growing business empire, Storm Digital Music, that he hopes to float on the stock market later this year.

Bruno (real name Trevor) comes from the Smashy and Nicey days of Radio 1; the old-school fraternity which counts Tony Blackburn, Peter Powell, Gary Davies, Dave Lee Travis and Simon Bates among its paid-up members. They were the glory days of Radio 1, days that have never been seen since.

It must have been something of a comedown.

Brookes laughs off this suggestion - he doesn't care if people don't recognise him. "Being in the limelight can be a pain in the arse," he says. "It's not what turns me on anymore. What turns me on now is getting results in a different way."

When he left London for Berkshire after his unceremonious departure from Radio 1, Brookes began his show Bruno at the Mill House and kitted out the whole house with microphones - even in the toilet and bedroom - so he could move around while presenting it. Each week, he broadcast 14 shows on Emap's regional radio stations.

Eventually, the business outgrew the house so he moved into studios at Newbury, and expanded into broadcast training and design. He'd already come across the internet a few years before, and it had got him thinking of ways to take the business online.

Like most entrepreneurial tales, Storm came from an idea on a napkin in a restaurant. It was early 1999 and, with three music industry friends, he mapped out his future: radio across all emerging platforms.

Brookes is now the managing director of Storm Digital Broadcasting, a role that seems to satisfy him. "I get a serious buzz out of taking this forward but there's never enough hours in every day at the moment," he says. He also presents a weekly fishing show on Sky Sports.

The core of Storm's current strategy is to partner with other companies, such as portals, to bring a ready-made audience to the StormLive station. It is distributed on, among others, Freeserve, Sky Digital, MyKindaplace.com and Newsoftheworld.com.

The next step is to expand into new territories. He's firming up plans to roll out Storm Sweden and move into India and South Africa. Plans are also in place to start selling licensed music by digital download.

Another direction is to develop Reality Radio, Brookes' take on Reality TV. Installing moviecams into StormLive's studios was the first step, he says, but he's not very forthcoming with further details.

"That would be giving the game away," he says, "If I talk about it I'll give ideas away and the shareholders will rip me apart. It's premature to say what they are, all I can say is it's 'where marketing meets media'."

Brookes is also unwilling to talk about the number of listeners his new station has attracted. Three times I ask for the figures, only for my question to be neatly evaded: "We will let you know at the end of the month when we get our audit through. At the moment I don't know myself." Unlikely, but then he's being guarded, playing the shrewd businessman, and all will be revealed when it suits the company.

Brookes plays the role well. He speaks in the latest techno-jargon and comes across as a man who actually understands what he's talking about. He's excited about 3G and what it can mean for digital radio; he's watching Japanese mobile operator NTT DoCoMo, and he follows market developments on ADSL and unmetered access.

Very early on in his career, even when he was still at Radio 1, Brookes recognised that he wasn't going to be a DJ forever and began thinking of other ways of taking his life forward. "To not start educating myself would have been a mistake. No disrespect, but I knew all along I was not going to end up like Tony Blackburn or Fluff. They didn't have anything else to fall back on."

"Thank God we've moved forward," says Brookes. He's also glad that radio is no longer just about FM and AM frequencies. "Radio, to me, has become a little bit format-oriented. But new technologies open it all up." It's at this point he throws in Storm's tagline: "Different not Dangerous. The future has no frequency." I hastily change the subject.

What does he think of radio in the UK? "There's some great radio in this country, but there's also some bloody bad radio." What's his relationship like with that other Radio 1 DJ turned media entrepreneur, Peter Powell? "We're both busy blokes. It's mostly media bullshit between me and Peter. One thing's for certain, though, Worldpop [Powell's music website] should carry Stormlive. Peter, call me..."

The impression I leave Storm with is that Bruno Brookes is incredibly driven to achieve his ambition: to build a big broadcasting company. The only thing he won't do for his company, however, is go back into the studio - despite being asked many times by Storm's programme director to do a show. "I won't go anywhere near that studio," he says, adding quite resolutely, "I'm a crap DJ now."

The core of Storm's current strategy is to partner with other companies, such as portals, to bring a ready-made audience to the StormLive station. It is distributed on, among others, Freeserve, Sky Digital, MyKindaplace.com and Newsoftheworld.com. The next step is to expand into new territories. He's firming up plans to roll out Storm Sweden and move into India and South Africa. Plans are also in place to start selling licensed music by digital download. Another direction is to develop Reality Radio, Brookes' take on Reality TV. Installing moviecams into StormLive's studios was the first step, he says, but he's not very forthcoming with further details. "That would be giving the game away," he says, "If I talk about it I'll give ideas away and the shareholders will rip me apart. It's premature to say what they are, all I can say is it's 'where marketing meets media'." Brookes is also unwilling to talk about the number of listeners his new station has attracted. Three times I ask for the figures, only for my question to be neatly evaded: "We will let you know at the end of the month when we get our audit through. At the moment I don't know myself." Unlikely, but then he's being guarded, playing the shrewd businessman, and all will be revealed when it suits the company. Brookes plays the role well. He speaks in the latest techno-jargon and comes across as a man who actually understands what he's talking about. He's excited about 3G and what it can mean for digital radio; he's watching Japanese mobile operator NTT DoCoMo, and he follows market developments on ADSL and unmetered access. Very early on in his career, even when he was still at Radio 1, Brookes recognised that he wasn't going to be a DJ forever and began thinking of other ways of taking his life forward. "To not start educating myself would have been a mistake. No disrespect, but I knew all along I was not going to end up like Tony Blackburn or Fluff. They didn't have anything else to fall back on." "Thank God we've moved forward," says Brookes. He's also glad that radio is no longer just about FM and AM frequencies. "Radio, to me, has become a little bit format-oriented. But new technologies open it all up." It's at this point he throws in Storm's tagline: "Different not Dangerous. The future has no frequency." I hastily change the subject. What does he think of radio in the UK? "There's some great radio in this country, but there's also some bloody bad radio." What's his relationship like with that other Radio 1 DJ turned media entrepreneur, Peter Powell? "We're both busy blokes. It's mostly media bullshit between me and Peter. One thing's for certain, though, Worldpop [Powell's music website] should carry Stormlive. Peter, call me..." The impression I leave Storm with is that Bruno Brookes is incredibly driven to achieve his ambition: to build a big broadcasting company. The only thing he won't do for his company, however, is go back into the studio - despite being asked many times by Storm's programme director to do a show. "I won't go anywhere near that studio," he says, adding quite resolutely, "I'm a crap DJ now."

fields.headline: Media monitor
fields.standfirst: by John Kampfner
fields.trailText: by John Kampfner
fields.body:
The first task of an opposition is to get headlines; the second is to get good headlines. This past week is a prime example of the Conservatives achieving more of the former than the latter.

At a time when the media are unusually receptive to policy announcements (for most of the political cycle, they prefer personalities), this should be a golden opportunity for William Hague. The month started well enough, with the pledge to abolish tax on savings for all but the wealthiest. Commentators saw the measure as popular, and the strategy behind it - of appealing to the lower and middle-income earner, and the slightly older voter - as sensible.

The potential in the "grey vote" is huge. So when last year the Tories promised to get rid of Gordon Brown's "gimmicks" - winter allowances and free TV licences for the over-75s - and put them on the basic pension they slapped themselves on the back. Trouble was, they recently discovered that pensioners actually liked them, and a u-turn was required.

The question was when? Fridays are usually a good bet - deadlines are earlier, papers carry less news, political teams are not at full strength. In mid-afternoon on February 9, Central Office faxed offices at Westminster a press release by David Willetts (shadow social security, chief policy "wonker" and now, chief manifesto writer). In the small print of an otherwise unremarkable document was the inference that pension policy was changing.

The Independent put it on its front page; others covered it, but generally the Tories got away quite lightly. It was a clever operation, because on Sunday, Hague and Michael Portillo were on the airwaves publicising a better news story on pensions - the raising of allowances, and extra help for the over-75s. So by Monday, things weren't looking too bad, especially as the Sun carried an opinion piece asking if the Tories had "finally got their policy act together".

Others remained to be convinced. In Tuesday's Independent, Don Macintyre suggested that Hague's refusal to panic in the face of irredeemably awful poll figures was beginning to seem a bit strange. The latest Gallup survey in the Telegraph showed that while Labour's standing on morality had plummeted, the Conservatives were not seen as any better - bad news for the government, worse news for an opposition desperate to make headway.

On Wednesday, the Daily Mail, of all places, produced a long piece explaining how the Britain of Blair and Brown now had the lowest inflation across the EU; several papers carried follow-ups to a Daily Mirror investigation into a charitable trust for Hague's speeches that the party had not registered with the charity commission. The Times despairingly wondered in a leader whether the Tories would sort out their policy mess and ditch their "headlines today, headaches tomorrow" approach.

Most annoying to Tory spinners were two news stories that day: the Times, on its front, suggested Hague was trying to drop the pledge he made last September, at the start of the petrol crisis, to cut 3p off the price of a litre, while the Independent's Paul Waugh wrote one of those "knives are out for . . ." splashes, quoting senior Tories as speculating about the number of seats Hague would need to gain at the election to survive as leader.

Both stories were officially rubbished, but neither was easy to deal with. The line on petrol became the vague "whatever Brown does at the budget, we will trump him". As for the leadership contest, that is one of those perennial stories that cannot be proved or disproved. The Mail's Ephraim Hardcastle diary on Thursday speculated that the main suspect for Waugh's story was Robbie Gibb, who left Central Office after being told he couldn't become Portillo's adviser. Waugh denies that Gibb was the informant, saying he had three sources, one of which was a member of the shadow cabinet.

Senior Tories agree that Hague's only salvation was ever going to come from a stream of good stories, and a consistent stream of bad copy for Labour. That is not happening. Just to rub it in, Thursday saw one of those splash headlines to make any Tory weep - and especially in the house journal, the Telegraph. Citing the inflation and unemployment figures, it said, simply: "Things can't get better for Blair."

fields.headline: Three-in-a-bed is standard procedure
fields.trailText: When Tom Brokaw, the prime-time anchor of NBC News, breaks a story due to appear on the front page of the next day's Washington Post, few people bat an eyelid in America.
fields.body:
When Tom Brokaw, the prime-time anchor of NBC News, breaks a story due to appear on the front page of the next day's Washington Post, few people bat an eyelid in America.

Alliances between print, television and online media have become so common in the US that the occasional use of the early evening news - or an online partner - to sell a newspaper story has become a common, if not standard, procedure.

Increasing consolidation has led to more and more alliances in spite of the death of some of the online news organisations themselves. Just last week, Yahoo! and the New York Times paired up, with the newspaper's stories joining those from Reuters, AP, ABC news, Inside.com, and others displayed on the portal.

One of the broadest and most established partnerships is that between the Washington Post, which decided to let NBC broadcast a scoop on the Clinton furniture, and MSNBC, the internet and television joint venture between Microsoft, the software company, and NBC. The alliance also highlights some of the successes and failures of such cross-company collaborations.

When it was announced in November 1999, the scope of the venture surprised many in the industry. The deal gave the Washington Post, which owns the venerable daily as well as Newsweek, a direct line to both the television channel and MSNBC.com.

At first glance, the most obvious success has been MSNBC.com, which is America's leading online news source, according to research group Media Metrix. Some 10.1m unique users log on to the news service every month.

Although it is impossible to quantify the impact of improved coverage on online audience figures, Merrill Brown, the editor of MSNBC.com, says that having the news and analysis of the Washington Post and Newsweek helped enormously. He says that the long-running election saga made the year-old relationship much more intense: "It made us more intimate, although not necessarily on a daily basis."

Editors from the Post and Newsweek send their newslists to Brown, and attend the twice-daily news conference calls at MSNBC.

The integration between MSNBC.com and Newsweek was designed to be much deeper than that with the flagship daily. Under the terms of the alliance, Newsweek effectively handed over the operation of its website to the technical people at MSNBC. Click on to Newsweek.com and you go to an MSNBC-branded site.

Details of the revenue implications for this part of the alliance are not likely to be revealed until June, at the end of the joint venture's fiscal year. However, there has already been a fairly high level of editorial cooperation.

In spite of the obvious conflicts that could arise, both appear very happy with the way things are going. "There's a level of integration which is really unprecedented," says Brown. "We are them and they are us."

Mark Whitaker, Newsweek editor, also says he is pleased with the way things are working out. He says his staff like the extra coverage they get by offering stories to MSNBC. The magazine now competes for space on the website's home page in the same way its own features department does.

The relationship with the Washington Post has been less extensive. There have been a dozen or more stories such as the furniture scoop which the venerable daily was happy to leak before the printing presses started to roll.

Concerns over the demands of the television camera in the newsroom still exist, however, although with so many other US papers doing the same thing they are diminishing. The paper's editors are also still chary about itemising scoops in their daily meetings with MSNBC.

The Post - which unlike its sister magazine does aim to be a leading online source of news and information - uses video provided by MSNBC on its home page.

B ut there have been none of the collaborative ventures that mark the Newsweek venture, both on the editorial and business side. The salesforce at Newsweek, for example, will use the MSNBC link to sell joint space.

Some analysts have suggested that the departure of Marc Teren as head of the Washington Post's internet subsidiary a few months after the alliance was signed slowed things down a little. It appears more likely, however, that the nature of the newspaper itself kept the relationship relatively limited to the extension of its audience and the use of some technical know-how.

The Post has moved much further than many US papers, and certainly further than any in the UK, towards partnering with other media outlets. Its collaboration intensified as a result of a news event rather than for financial reasons, suggest that alliances are here to stay. At least, until the urge to merge comes back into fashion.

webTitle: ITN hires Holt for news post

fields.headline: ITN hires Holt for news post
fields.trailText: 8.30am: News Direct's Steve Holt has been given the new role of executive editor for ITN World News, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Steve Holt, who was brought over from one of America's most successful news stations to head News Direct 97.3FM in 1999, has been given the new role of executive editor for ITN World News.

Mr Holt, a former news director at New York station 1010WINS, which pioneered rolling radio news, was the launch manager of the ITN rolling news service on News Direct.

He will work with ITN marketing director David Robinson and Richard Tait in developing ITN World News, the ITN service sold to the US's PBS network that has made a star out of presenter Daljit Dhaliwal.

Stuart Thomas, editor of LBC 1152AM, will take over as editor of News Direct.

The two stations are owned by London News Radio, in which ITN is a major shareholder.

Mr Holt's move follows reports that News Direct was forced to make a u-turn on a strategy that would have seen it replacing live programming with a feed from ITN News Channel overnight and at weekends.

It is understood that the plans were shelved following objections from the Radio Authority.

An ITN spokesman denied Mr Holt had been moved as a result of the change in strategy at News Direct on substituting the News Channel feed for live programmes.

"With Steve's knowledge and experience, he is by far the best candidate to take on this role in what is a major area of growth for ITN," he said.
