webTitle: US sights turn to Iraqi oil lifeline

fields.headline: US sights turn to Iraqi oil lifeline
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Foreign policy analysts in the US said the air strikes on Iraqi radar installations around Baghdad had, by suppressing the immediate threat to allied aircraft, given the new administration a breathing space to decide how to fulfil George Bush's campaign promise to "get tougher" with Saddam Hussein's regime.
fields.body:
Foreign policy analysts in the US said the air strikes on Iraqi radar installations around Baghdad had, by suppressing the immediate threat to allied aircraft, given the new administration a breathing space to decide how to fulfil George Bush's campaign promise to "get tougher" with Saddam Hussein's regime.

But with Iraqi opposition groups as weak as ever and the raft of sanctions springing new leaks with every passing day, it is clear there will be no easy way to break the 10-year deadlock with Baghdad.

US defence officials said that US and British pilots patrolling the no-fly zones had noticed a sharp increase in anti-aircraft fire in the past six weeks.

On average last year, the Iraqis fired one surface-to-air missile at coalition planes a month. This year they had already fired 13, and there had been a significant increase in anti-aircraft shells.

Furthermore, an increasing number of near-misses suggested that the Iraqis' aim was improving.

"It was really only a matter of time before they got lucky, and one of our pilots was shot down. It was not a sustainable situation," a Pentagon official said.

The air strikes reflected an increasing reliance on a new generation of long-range precision-guided air-to-ground missiles, the AGM-130 and the navy's AGM-154A, which allow US planes to hit distant targets without exposing themselves to close anti-aircraft fire.

Shooting down an allied pilot would be a public relations triumph for President Saddam in the Arab world, where he is portraying himself as a bastion of resistance to Israel and the US.

It would also push the US administration into fulfiling its election pledge to "do something" about Saddam sooner before it had agreed on a feasible policy.

Mr Bush's foreign policy team is currently pursuing two main policy tracks.

The secretary of state, Colin Powell, favours tightening the use of sanctions, and his first foreign trip at the end of this week is to be a tour of the Middle East, in an attempt to persuade other Arab states to help enforce the UN restrictions on the export of Iraqi oil.

The embargo is showing increasing signs of wear. Walid Khadduri, editor of the Middle East Economic Survey, estimates that Iraq is selling more than 400,000 barrels of oil a day outside the UN oil-for-food programme, of which 150,000 barrels are passing through a Syrian pipeline reopened in November with Iraqi help.

The Iraqi regime is pocketing more than $1bn (£700m) a year from the smuggling, and is raising more money by imposing a surcharge of 25 to 30 cents a barrel on oil traders handling Iraq's legal exports under the oil-for-food programme.

Mr Powell is due to visit Syria and plans to raise US concern about the pipeline, but it will be hard to persuade Damascus to comply, after the collapse of Israeli-Syrian peace talks and the election in Israel of Ariel Sharon, who is reviled in the Arab world.

The other policy track being explored is increasing support for Iraqi resistance groups, in the hope of undermining President Saddam's regime from within Iraq.

The policy is most fiercely advocated by the new defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, and his deputy, Paul Wolfowitz, who were behind the 1998 Iraq Liberation Act, earmarking $97m (£67m) in aid, mostly for the Iraqi National Congress (INC) coalition.

Very little of it was disbursed by the Clinton administration, which had little confidence in the faction-ridden opposition movement.

On Friday, while the bombing raid was under way, the INC leader, Ahmed Chalabi, was meeting Edward Walker, the assistant secretary of state for Near East affairs.

Mr Chalabi said later that he had been given the green light to spend more than $30m, much of it for operations inside Iraq.

But most Iraq analysts believe the aid is of mainly symbolic importance and have serious doubts about the effectiveness of the INC and other opposition groups.

webTitle: Leader: Iraq raid sheds worrying light on Mr Bush

fields.headline: This man is dangerous
fields.standfirst:
Iraq raid sheds worrying light on Mr Bush

Special report: Iraq
Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: The escalation of US military pressure on Iraq is in many ways more worrying for Britain than it is for Saddam Hussein. Every bomb that falls strengthens the Iraqi dictator's claim to pan-Arab leadership in defiance of a supposedly hostile western imperialism.
fields.body:
The escalation of US military pressure on Iraq is in many ways more worrying for Britain than it is for Saddam Hussein. Every bomb that falls strengthens the Iraqi dictator's claim to pan-Arab leadership in defiance of a supposedly hostile western imperialism. Every long-range cruise or "stand-off" air-launched missile merely emphasises Washington's fear of sustaining casualties or losing hostages in an unwinnable war fought at a safe distance. Saddam knows very well that a large-scale land invasion of Iraq by allied ground troops like that begun and halted in 1991, the only sure way to unseat him, is no longer feasible. How amusing he must find current US talk of funding and infiltrating Iraqi opposition groups more accustomed to sipping coffee in well-appointed London apartments. Every raid increases the discomfort of Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, squirmingly reluctant hosts to the allied planes. Far from reminding Saddam of his enemies' power and resolve, every sortie reminds a watching world of America's bankrupt policy of bombs and sanctions.

All of which is deeply worrying for Britain given its uniquely close association with this US policy which many European allies, as well as Russia and China, fiercely oppose. Tony Blair says he acted to defend RAF pilots against an increased threat in the no-fly zones. But, legally speaking, their presence there has no specific UN or other authorisation. Robin Cook says Britain has a humanitarian mission to protect the southern Shia and the Kurds against Saddam's depredations. But this justification relates to the situation 10 years ago. Saddam suppressed the Shia long ago; and the biggest threat to the Kurds is the Turks (and other Kurds). The government has a duty to protect our armed forces. But it has an equal duty not to put them in harm's way unnecessarily. Paradoxically, Britain recently warned the US that the no-fly zone patrols were becoming unacceptably hazardous, even pointless. But instead of taking the rational course and ending them, George Bush decided to use new, secretly agreed rules of engagement to expand them.

The resulting, highly escalatory attacks on targets near Baghdad cannot be supported as a matter of law or common sense. They do absolutely nothing to help end Saddam's undoubtedly dangerous tyranny. They diminish the chances that imminent UN talks with Iraq on a resumption of weapons inspections will succeed. They will do nothing to curb the rampant oil smuggling upon which Saddam is once again growing strong. They undermine the US secretary of state, Colin Powell, who may have hoped to rally support for less indiscriminately punitive, arms-focused sanctions during his Middle East visit this week. They increase tension and instability in a region already reeling from the Palestinian intifada and Ariel Sharon's triumph in Israel. Oddly, the attacks did not target chemical and biological weapons facilities that the US says Saddam is rebuilding. Since the proliferation of such mass terror weapons is America's principal stated security concern, why were these alleged factories not bombed? That at least would have been understandable.

Worrying for Britain, too, is what this irresponsible action says about the insecure, aggressive mindset of the new administration in Washington. In a sense Mr Bush was testing Mr Blair's loyalty, sucking him back into a conflict he has no mandate to fight. When the two men meet for the first time later this week, the president is likely to want more oaths of fealty, seeking British acquiescence in his globally destabilising missile defence plans, for example, in his intention to disengage in the Balkans and in his apparent belief that Nato has a right of veto over the EU's military aspirations. Increasingly, this domineering American security agenda does not serve Britain's interests, nor that of Britain's European partners. This latest episode in Iraq starkly demonstrates that. Seeking to be special friends with Mr Bush is all very well. But not at any price, Mr Blair. This American president is dangerous.

fields.headline: Jeans genie
fields.standfirst: In the tradition of Flat Eric and Nick Kamen, Levi's is set to knock 'em dead again with its latest trend-setting jeans advert.  Belinda Archer  on a campaign with a new twist
fields.trailText: In the tradition of Flat Eric and Nick Kamen, Levi's is set to knock 'em dead again with its latest trend-setting jeans advert. Belinda Archer on a campaign with a new twist
fields.body:
This Thursday, Levi's unveils its latest advertising campaign - the third burst of activity to back the groovy new "twisted" Engineered Jeans. Typically for a brand which made a fortune through its ads in the 80s, the TV work is visually striking, set to a funky soundtrack and by one of the hottest directors around, Frank Budgen. And at £5m it is the most expensively post-produced campaign Levi's has ever made.

But despite the money, the great look and the kicking track, the crux of the ad is in the final frame. In the last split-second the camera focuses fleetingly on a hairy gonk, sporting his own, mini Engineered Jeans, dangling from the rear-view mirror of a car. This creature, my friends, is Twisted Boy and, believe me, he is going to be big.

From later this week he will have his own website and online game, will feature on in-store promotional material and will be the subject of a comprehensive viral campaign. Surfers in possession of a closely-guarded password will be able to log on, play about with his twisty limbs - developing the creative idea from the commercial - and watch him jig about to various tracks. To get the password punters will have to be one of a tight circle of opinion-leaders who have already been sent a mystery email (a j-peg of a limb, in fact) incorporating the website address and key word. The eagle-eyed will also be able to spot the microsite address written on a wall somewhere in the actual commercial itself.

Other activity is planned for our new friend, but the fact that Levi's, the gold standard in knock-em-dead TV executions, is turning to the internet to extend the impact of its advertising reflects a key trend among advertisers for using the web to give their commercials extra clout.

In December, John West Salmon had a minimal airing of a TV spot featuring a John West worker fighting a bear for a salmon. This tiny spend was magnified by the ad being sent round virally, cropping up in Asia and Australasia and other far-flung markets. Lowe Lintas' "belly" spot for Reebok, depicting a giant inflated belly hotly pursuing a jogger, has similarly been spun off onto the web, featuring on Reebok's official website but also being emailed to 100 key target-group consumers. Nike has also experimented with inviting viewers to vote for the ending of several TV commercials on its website, while Budweiser's whassup has so far triggered 38 unofficial spoofs that are still being emailed around the globe.

Websites which focus on advertising are doing much to fan the flames of this trend, in particular the increasingly popular US site adcritic.com which showcases worldwide TV commercials and enables people to download them and send them on.

Gwyn Jones, managing director of Bartle Bogle Hegarty, the Levi's ad agency, says: "Media is fragmenting so much now and delivering an audience is so much harder. It is simply not enough to do a Nick Kamen and have exposure in one channel - you've got to cut through more than that, so your digital strategy is key: you've got to engage them on the internet too."

The jeanswear giant has, of course, dabbled with the net before: think of the phenomenon that was Flat Eric in 1999. Eric was launched on the web a few weeks before the TV campaign began. But Twisted Boy is a more subtle and sophisticated concept, being just one, digital element of a much larger campaign that embraces traditional posters (starring top models Liberty Ross and Tyson Ballou, no less), plus press and cinema.

In short, viral emailing is becoming the new word of mouth - the 21st century equivalent of getting your advertising slogan repeated down the pub - and advertisers are all trying to harness this new potential for the benefit of their own brands. But not all TV campaigns readily lend themselves to such development.

Jeremy Bowles, deputy managing director of Lowe Lintas, Reebok's agency, cautions: "A lot of people think about doing viral marketing but you can't do anything if the idea isn't good enough, otherwise people won't pass it on. And they have to feel rewarded by it, or else they will be irritated and it will backfire."

In many ways the internet serves as an acid test of how successful a TV ad has been in engaging its audience: the extent to which people take it up and play with it themselves is an indicator of the ad's impact. With whassup, for example, consumers enthusiastically created their own versions, from a Northern "ey-up" spoof to a version featuring rabbis exchanging shaloms and a posh variation in which toffee-nosed actors sipped cups of tea instead of downing Buds.

Jones adds: "On the web the test is simply 'do people send it on?'. The intention with Levi's is not to extend its presence online - it's about the pass-on ability of what we've created."

Many advertisers are actively using the internet as an extension of their TV work, but others are having it done for them - something which can be beneficial but involves losing creative control.

Kate Howe, the deputy managing director of John West's agency Leo Burnett, says: "Our ad actually gained a life for itself around the world. We didn't set out to spread it virally, it just happened, but it is good that the ad in totality is being spread. Spoofs can be good, and imitation is a form of flattery, although we would rather control the creative integrity of the brand ourselves."

But do these internet spin-offs really aid awareness and drive sales, or do they simply serve to entertain a tiny minority of folk (adfolk even) who plainly have time on their hands to fool around with such things?

Michele Norman, in-house PR manager for Budweiser, is happy. She says: "The unofficial whassup spoofs made us seem innovative and creative among our target audience. They built awareness and brand image, as well as adding huge value in terms of column inches to our initial TV campaign. We achieved the highest ever awareness among beer brands last year, according to Millward Brown."

Jones agrees that it's all about "creating fame".

"When you get people to cross-refer between different media, you build a currency for something way beyond the actual campaign," he says. "Twisted Boy will work digitally to reinforce the product message of Engineered Jeans displayed in the rest of the campaign."

It is perhaps a little ironic that while some will no doubt appreciate the ambitious new Levi's campaign for its hefty media spend and state-of-the-art special effects, it might become best known for a little hairy gonk. But that's advertising, and without the surrounding lavish TV campaign Twisted Boy simply could not exist.

webTitle: Raid shows Bush-Blair bond on Iraq

fields.headline: Raid shows Bush-Blair bond on Iraq
fields.standfirst:
The bombing of Baghdad The rules of engagement get tougher, and the controversy intensifies

Special report: Iraq
Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The rules of engagement get tougher, and the controversy intensifies.
fields.body:
Friday night's air strikes on targets near Baghdad were cleared by Tony Blair and George Bush after requests from military commanders increasingly worried by the threat to their aircraft posed by new Iraqi radar and missile systems, defence sources said yesterday.

The RAF and the US air force were concerned at what they saw as heightened risks for their pilots. Whether there is a legal basis for the no-fly zones from which the US and Britain have barred Iraqi planes since the Gulf war ended in 1991 was not an issue for them, but is a matter of controversy for the politicians.

British ministers argue that the zones are being maintained for humanitarian reasons - to reduce the ability of the Iraqi regime to attack its opponents among the Shia in the south and the Kurds in the north.

The air forces sought political clearance to act after registering serious threats from Iraq's new integrated air defence system, coordinated by fibre optic communications and bolstered by a growing number of SA-6 surface-to-air missiles supplied - according to intelligence sources - by Serbia and Ukraine.

British Tornado jets cannot fly as high as US F-15 aircraft, nor are their defence systems as good. That no Tornado had been shot down, British defence sources said yesterday, was a combination of "skill and luck".

Requests to change the rules of engagement to allow British and US aircraft to bomb military targets whether or not they were inside the no-fly zone were made early this year by British and American commanders frustrated at restrictions imposed by the Clinton administration.

The military's argument is that Iraqi installations exercising command and control for the zones can be located beyond the zone boundaries which were set by Britain and the US at the suggestion of the former prime minister John Major.

President Bush is believed to have discussed these requests at a special White House meeting on Iraq earlier this month. They were almost certainly discussed at a meeting two weeks ago in Munich between Donald Rumsfeld, the defence secretary, and Geoff Hoon, his British counterpart, and taken up by Robin Cook in Washington last week.

But defence sources insist that the timing of the raids was a military decision. Eight RAF aircraft were involved and were given just one target, in the southern no-fly zone.

The RAF is not equipped with US "stand-off" weapons which enable pilots to fire their weapons farther from the target.

British Paveway laser-targeted bombs were used in Friday night's attack, which involved four Tornado bombers, two Tornado defence support aircraft, and two VC-10 tankers.

British defence sources expressed surprise at the response to the raids, suggesting that it had been hyped up by the media with shots of the Baghdad skyline lit up by anti-aircraft fire.

Their reaction perhaps can be explained by the fact that this is generally a "forgotten war", though British aircraft have dropped well over 100 bombs on ground installations where Iraqi targeting equipment has locked on to the western patrol aircraft. The 10-year US-British operation has cost taxpayers more than £900m.

Contrary to claims yesterday by the government - including Brian Wilson, the new Foreign Office minister responsible for Iraq - the no-fly zones are not sanctioned by any UN security council resolution.

The British and US governments justify them by referring to security council resolution 688 of April 1991, which condemned "the repression of the Iraqi civilian population in many parts of Iraq [and] demands that Iraq ... immediately end this repression".

Few now believe the patrols serve any purpose in the south, the reason France gave in 1998 for stopping its air patrols.

Mr Hoon said at the weekend that in international law Britain was "perfectly entitled to deter aggression".

The Commons foreign affairs committee said last year that "at the very least, the doctrine of humanitarian intervention has a tenuous basis in current customary law", while the defence committee said: "The precise legal basis for the no-fly zones is controversial."

Mr Cook said yesterday that President Saddam had not given up his claim to Kuwait or wish to get weapons of mass destruction.

But the no-fly zones were not imposed to deter these threats.

Turkey, from where US and British aircraft patrol the northern zone but which also conducts attacks on Kurds, was one of many countries to criticise the latest raids.

fields.headline: Media Monkey's Diary
fields.body:
 Due to overwhelming public demand, a couple more headlines from our list purporting to be from the Melbourne Herald Sun. An Australian correspondent informs us this is a training exercise run by the Herald Sun compiled from headlines from all over the world. The final five are: "Police Begin Campaign to Run Down Jaywalkers"; "Drunks Get Nine Months in Violin Case"; "Iraqi Head Seeks Arms"; and that old chestnut: "Is There a Ring of Debris around Uranus?"

 Mounted on to the cover of March's Cosmopolitan magazine, the essential Bedside Book of Kinky Sex seems to be proving very popular. After an initial mailout of two copies to the ITV Lunchtime News desk, Cosmo assistants have been struggling to keep up with those follow-up requests for more copies. Rushing over to help, Monkey found they'd sent a grand total of 10 so far. No need for those newshounds to panic, though, Cosmo is happy to keep sending them over to Gray's Inn Road.

 Monkey always enjoys Mushy Green's "scenes from the life of a radio producer" column in the Independent. How well we remember the one about BBC news values which appeared on February 1. The one that began: "Have you noticed an awful lot about Peter Mandelson in the news recently?" So it was with great delight last week that Monkey discovered Mr Green had written the same column all over again. What other explanation could there be for its return?

 A tale of woe from Scotland. Jimmy Reid, a veteran columnist on the Herald, recently wrote a piece questioning the handling of an investigation into financial mismanagement on the part of the Northern Ireland secretary, John Reid. Jimmy's piece, which was spiked by the Herald for some reason, eventually found its way on to the Guardian's comment pages. A move which must surely be unconnected to the fact that Jimmy has now been sacked by the Herald.

 Still north of the border, Monkey's man in a kilt writes that the nation's testosterone-fuelled hacks were appalled by Jean Rafferty's condemnation of their habits and prejudices in Friday's Times: "hard, macho males" was one of the nicer comments. Now the hacks are fighting back. A new organisation is being launched next month with a sumptuous dinner at the Scotch Whisky Association HQ in Edinburgh. Its title? Men in Journalism. The poor dears.

 It was no accident that Carlton chose to stage its Crossroads launch at one of the more elegant hotels in London, the Conran- refitted Great Eastern - the swanky surroundings clearly sending a message that the motel days are over. It was inevitable then that something would go wrong: cue Tony Adams, aka the now-greying former lothario Adam Chance, who declared during press questions that "I feel like I'm on the bridge of the Titanic". Just as well David Liddiment was not in the room at the time.

 Stunned as Monkey was to read on Friday that the BBC is to rescue the Dome with the Tussaud's Group, it might go some way to explaining this memo we found in the Broadcasting House bins, entitled "That BBC Dome line-up in full". Apparently we can look forward to such attractions as the management board roller coaster: one minute you're up, one minute you're down, next thing you know you've lost your lunch - and that chauffeur driven car! Or ye olde worlde BBC: see how people lived when millionsused to watch it; marvel at the corkscrew on the boardroom table and the full drinks cabinet; sit and watch a genuinely funny sitcom; and then ride in an authentic chauffeur driven car (see above). webTitle: No contest in the battle for Arab hearts and minds

fields.headline: No contest in the battle for Arab hearts and minds
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Iraq
Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: In the Middle East, Saddam Hussein appeared to have won the public relations battle yesterday in the aftermath of the US-British air strikes on radar stations around Baghdad.
fields.byline: Brian Whitaker and Suzanne Goldenberg  in Jerusalem
fields.body:
In the Middle East, Saddam Hussein appeared to have won the public relations battle yesterday in the aftermath of the US-British air strikes on radar stations around Baghdad.

Western arguments that the attacks were necessary to protect patrols in the no-fly zones have cut little ice with Arab leaders or the public, allowing President Saddam Hussein once again to portray himself as victim rather than aggressor.

Egypt described the strikes as "a serious negative step" which endangered Iraq's "safety and sovereignty" and could not be justified.

In 1991 Egypt provided troops for the international coalition against Iraq's occupation of Kuwait and helped to ensure that other Arab countries supported the effort.

The Egyptian foreign minister, Amr Moussa, said Friday's attack could undermine talks on resuming weapons inspections and lifting UN sanctions on Iraq. The talks are due to begin on February 26.

In the West Bank, hundreds of Palestinians took to the streets within minutes of the air strikes, and television reported protests in Ramallah, Tulkaram, Qalqiliya and other towns.

In the four-month uprising, Saddam Hussein has been held up as a heroic figure for Palestinians. He has sent payments of $10,000 (about £7,000) to the families of every "martyr" and $1,000 to those wounded by Israeli gunfire.

At the weekend, some analysts predicted that the attack near Baghdad could ratchet up the rhetoric of war, feeding into the tense situation that has seen the uprising in the West Bank and Gaza intensify since the election of the hardline Ariel Sharon as Israel's prime minister. Iraq launched 39 Scud missiles at Israel during the 1990-91 Gulf war, but yesterday official Israeli reaction to the attack was relatively muted.

The outgoing prime minister, Ehud Barak, said: "Israel need not take any steps at the current stage." Reports said Israel had no prior notice.

Arab citizens in Israel protested against the US and British air strikes in front of the US consulate in Jerusalem. Placards read: "From Baghdad to Gaza, we are all one people."

Syria, Qatar, Jordan, Yemen and Algeria also criticised or condemned the attack.

Jordan's foreign minister, Abdulilah al-Khatib, was quoted by the state news agency, Petra, as saying that the western-imposed no-fly zones in Iraq were illegal.

"Jordan has always rejected the use of force and violation of the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Iraq and always calls for an end to all acts that take place outside the framework of UN resolutions," he said.

Yemen described the raids as "a dangerous development that threatens the security and stability of the Gulf region" which violated UN resolutions.

Several Iraqi opposition groups joined the chorus of criticism. Libeid Abbawi of the Damascus-based Iraqi Communist party said the air strikes "would never help our people in their struggle against the dictatorship but would rather foment Arab feelings against the United States".

Kuwait and Saudi Arabia, the Arab countries with most to fear from Iraq and which provide the US and Britain with facilities for patrolling the southern no-fly zone, made no immediate comment.

Meanwhile, a prominent Saudi businessman, Abdul-Aziz Mohammed al-Rafidi, complained: "Bush has uncovered his ugly face and all the hate and spite he has for the Arabs."

In Baghdad, one of the official newspapers, al-Qadissiya, declared that the reason for the attack was Iraq's support for the Palestinian uprising against Israel.

But while state-run TV showed homes and shops said to have been damaged in the raids, protests in the Iraqi capital were curiously small: more than 2,000 people, including the deputy foreign minister, Nabil Najim, protested in central Baghdad and at least 1,000 others gathered across the city near the offices of the ruling al-Baath party.

"This dangerous aggression shows how much the Americans and Britons hate Iraqis and do not respect any international law," Mr Najim told the crowd.

fields.headline: Why God needs good PR
fields.standfirst: Once the churches could rock the nation's breakfast tables. Yet today,  Stephen Bates  laments, their news is reduced to whispers and 'no comment'
fields.trailText: Once the churches could rock the nation's breakfast tables. Yet today, Stephen Bates laments, their news is reduced to whispers and 'no comment'
fields.body:
The new year has dawned quietly on the religious front. We specialist correspondents have been left, if not exactly down on our knees, at least twiddling our thumbs waiting for the service to begin.

Last week, the increasingly eccentric Catholic Herald found a way of filling its meagre pages in a quiet season. It handed space to Daniel Johnson, son of Mail columnist Paul, to moan about why, oh why, the Catholic hierarchy is so bad with the press. The Mail reckons it has done two religious stories in six months and, now that there are only three religious affairs correspondents in the national dailies, some of us are beginning to wonder whether we might soon be shut down like a row of redundant inner-city churches.

Even the Times's assiduous Ruth Gledhill, long pined after from afar by lonely clerics everywhere, has taken to concentrating on her ballroom dancing career, her personalised website and her fantasy share portfolio in the columns of her paper. The Church Times's media columnist, Andrew Brown, has devoted successive columns to the decline of religious news and Clifford Longley, 30 years correspondent for the Times and then the Telegraph, fulminates in the specialist publication Priests and People that it is all the churches' fault.

It wasn't always thus. Time was when the Church of England could rock the breakfast tables of the nation: when my old Oxford tutor Gary Bennett penned his anonymous Crockford's preface and then committed suicide, when the ex-Bishop of Durham chose to open his mouth on any subject whatsoever or when the Church of England was twisting itself in knots over women's ordination. Today we're reduced to sitting like crows on a fence waiting for the Pope to die or the Archbishop of Canterbury to throw in the towel.

But if there are currently no great doctrinal differences, there is a sense that the two old Christian churches are also happy not to draw attention to themselves. Far from preaching the Good News in the secular press, they would rather not speak at all. And if you have a story, don't look to them for help.

The Catholic media office is excellent - its genial former head, Father Kieran Conry, is rumoured to be heading straight for a bishopric, a fate not given to many press officers. But the advisers surrounding Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, archbishop of Westminster, have proved themselves lamentable. When, fresh from the obscurity of a rural diocese, he was last summer thrust into the spotlight by allegations that he had not taken firm enough action years before against a priest accused of child abuse, his press team patently did not know how to cope.

They were spotted in a confused huddle wondering whether, if they said nothing for a few hours, the whole thing would go away. In the end it was the archbishop who took the decision that he must go on the lunchtime news to answer his critics.

Better his openness and apologies, though, than the Archbishop of Cardiff's attempt to bluster out the storm over his appointment of not one but two paedophiles - one his press officer - in his own diocese. With Catholic priests being sent down for paedophilia at the rate of one every four months, the church should have worked out its crisis strategy by now. Any other organisation would have done.

The Church of England, by contrast, seems to have adopted an alternative approach. Beneath a veneer of apparent openness, it has learned the least impressive skills of New Labour spin doctors. Under the Rev Bill Beaver, an American former PR executive who saw the light before becoming the C of E's director of communications, it favours a manipulative, whispering style.

When official figures showed church attendances declining for the first time below 1m, it initially decided not to publish them, then insisted that, because ordinations were rising, the press should be talking up its success, and finally decided to alter the way attendance statistics are compiled. Meanwhile, Archbishop Carey's new press officer, Arun Kataria, a bureaucrat with no apparent media training or aptitude, apparently thinks that "no comment" is as far as he is authorised to go.

When he organised a briefing before Carey's recent trip to Nigeria a few weeks ago, he felt unable to say even off the record that the archbishop would be raising the issue of Muslim persecution of Christians. He left one correspondent - yes, it was me - fuming at the incompetence of a missed opportunity to show his boss in an unusually determined light. Yet surely he must know, by such fruits ye shall know them. I hope it's not left to a church spokesman to announce the second coming.

 Stephen Bates is the Guardian's religious affairs correspondent.

fields.headline: Binge-drinking: Britain's new epidemic
fields.standfirst: Alarm at role of alcohol in deaths, violence, crime and accidents
fields.trailText: Alarm at role of alcohol in deaths, violence, crime and accidents.
fields.body:
Death rates from alcohol-related liver disease rose by nearly half in a decade in the United Kingdom, according to World Health Organisation advisers worried by the binge-drinking epidemic in parts of Europe.

In England and Wales alone, 33,000 people a year are dying from drink-induced causes, including ill-health, road crashes, violence, alcohol poisoning and other accidents.

The advisers report that as many as one in eight deaths among young men across western Europe is related to drink and condemn the "little bit does you good" health messages of recent years - saying moderate drinking only helps middle-aged and older people, if any one at all.

Tougher advertising rules and higher taxation may be needed to curb consumption, according to papers prepared for a WHO conference opening in Stockholm today. It is being attended by representatives from 51 European countries.

These comments reinforce many concerns voiced recently by British doctors worried by a rise in drinking among women, their growing need for hospital treatment for chronic liver disease, and the wider after-work and binge-drinking culture to which young Britons appear increasingly addicted.

Overall consumption in the UK has remained fairly constant - with a 1% drop in 10 years - compared with many European neighbours and drink-driving laws have helped bring significant falls in deaths from road accidents.

Deaths from cirrhosis and other liver problems - which caused about eight deaths per 100,000 people in 1998, 47% more than in 1988 - are still low compared with most countries. But the rate of increase is worrying and only exceeded by former Eastern bloc states.

In addition, a quarter of all people arrested are drunk and half of all violent crime, two-thirds of suicide attempts and 75% of assaults are committed by people under the influence of alcohol.

The WHO figures measure consumption in terms of pure alcohol per litre per person, when in reality beers usually range from around 3.5% to 6% alcohol by volume, wines between 10.5% and 13%, and spirits around 40%. The average Briton consumes 7.5 litres a year of alcohol.

The WHO is also suspicious about the unrecorded levels of consumption, which may in places such as Hungary be bigger than official figures. But it believes even EU countries such as Austria, France, Italy and Sweden may have slightly higher levels than recorded.

Overall alcohol-related deaths among 15- to 29-year-olds will be presented in four main groups of countries by WHO officials. Those for Britain, EU partners and other more developed European states, suggest one in eight male and one in 12 female deaths are drink-related. But in a group including Russia, Ukraine, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, the drink-related toll is one in three male and one in eight female deaths - across the whole of Europe, it is one in four male deaths in the age group.

There is mounting concern too about drinking among children.

Britain, with few abstainers even in its adult population, is notable for the low numbers of adolescents who have never tried a drink. Well under 10% of 13-year-olds say they have never had alcohol. In addition, one in seven English boys aged 11, one in four Welsh boys of 13 and around a half of 15-year-old boys in England and Wales drink wine, spirit or beer once a week, putting them among the highest youthful consumers in Europe.

Cees Goos, WHO regional adviser for alcohol, drugs and tobacco, said: "We are receiving signals from all across the region that many young people are turning to alcohol as a drug. There is an increase in high-risk drinking, such as binge-drinking and drunkenness."

The regime of voluntary advertising and sponsorship codes, which Britain relies on to a greater extent than many other countries, is being increasingly called into question by the advisers and voluntary or ganisations. They are concerned at marketing ploys used by such drink giants as Carlsberg and Budweiser during the 1998 World Cup which link drink to sport. The pressure for change is already demonstrated by football's Premier League, which is desperately trying to find a non-alcohol sponsor to replace Carling.

There is also concern that the non-stop hedonistic party culture promoted in centres like Ibiza, Spain, Ayia Napa, Cyprus, and Ios in Greece - made easier to attend for young Britons by cheap holiday deals - is storing up trouble.

Griffith Edwards, of the Institute of Psychiatry, London, among the authors of the WHO papers, said: "Within stable and saturated markets, the main role of advertisements is to ensure that old consumers are replaced by new ones and that educational messages do not diminish alcohol consumption... Through its messages, it maintains the social desirability of drinking, overshadows the risk of alcohol use to individual and public health, and contradicts prevention initiatives. These indirect effects alone are sufficient to justify the need to control the volume and content of alcohol advertising."

He said evidence from countries that ban spirit advertising suggested they had 16% lower alcohol consumption than countries with no bans and those with bans on beer and wine advertising had 11% lower alcohol consumption than those with bans only on spirit advertising.

The benefits of drinking to protect against heart disease "if they exist, are likely to be limited to men over 40 years of age and to post-menopausal women and are not population-wide".

The alcohol industry in Britain operates codes meant to stop advertisements suggesting alcohol enhances masculinity or femininity, and insists advertising is to increase brand awareness not consumption. Many other countries ban or restrict advertising - although there are not even voluntary arrangements in Greece, Hungary and Romania.

Junior health minister Gisela Stuart is attending the conference that will not be forcing new moves on WHO members.

The Department of Health, which will publish its own plans to tackle alcohol abuse this summer, said: "It is not so much advertising as drinking patterns we want to tackle." This would include new measures to tackle under-age drinking and buying of alcohol.

Europe under the influence

Belgium
6% of workers have drink problem; 40% of violent crime and vandalism linked to alcohol

Denmark
Drink-related deaths doubled 1970 -94 despite national consumption stagnating since 1983

Finland
Nearly half male and one in five female suicides involve alcohol abusers

France
40% of fatal traffic accidents - 4,000 deaths a year - and overall 43,000 deaths, 9% of total, linked to drink in 1997

Germany
2.7m people between 19 and 69 misuse alcohol. Alcohol-related mortality estimated at 40,000 a year

Hungary
Cirrhosis among men rose from 19 per 100,000 in 1970 to 208.8 in 1994

Norway
80% of crimes of violence, 60% of rapes, arson and vandalism committed under influence

Poland
1,446 fatal alcohol poisonings in 1996

Russia
40% of men and 17% of women suffer from alcoholism

Spain
25% of domestic violence drink-related

Sweden
87% of attempted suicides attributed to alcohol in 1992

United Kingdom
50% of violent crime, 65% of attempted suicides linked to alcohol; 33,000 deaths a year linked to drink in England and Wales alone

He said evidence from countries that ban spirit advertising suggested they had 16% lower alcohol consumption than countries with no bans and those with bans on beer and wine advertising had 11% lower alcohol consumption than those with bans only on spirit advertising. The benefits of drinking to protect against heart disease "if they exist, are likely to be limited to men over 40 years of age and to post-menopausal women and are not population-wide". Junior health minister Gisela Stuart is attending the conference that will not be forcing new moves on WHO members. The Department of Health, which will publish its own plans to tackle alcohol abuse this summer, said: "It is not so much advertising as drinking patterns we want to tackle." This would include new measures to tackle under-age drinking and buying of alcohol. fields.headline: Stations take self-control
fields.standfirst: The commercial TV stations are to be given self-regulation, but where was the debate?  Maggie Brown  looks at opposition to the ITC's move
fields.trailText: The commercial TV stations are to be given self-regulation, but where was the debate? Maggie Brown looks at opposition to the ITC's move
fields.body:
Thanks to the News at Ten dispute, broadcasting regulation has become a key consumer issue. Which is why more debate is needed on the independent television commission's radical decision to "step back" its method of holding ITV, Channel 5 and Channel 4 to their public service commitments.

Instead of the annual performance review, backed up by detailed box ticking on what has been screened, there are to be rolling annual statements, written by the licence holders and channels. They will assess themselves against their statements.

So will ITV become self-critical and confess in future to running too many derivative dramas, and pledge the South Bank Show at 10pm? Would Channel 4 have sent cameras to the Kumbh Mela if its weak religious programming had not been exposed by the ITC's annual reports? Don't bet on it.

The switch to programme policy statements is proposed in the communications white paper, on which public consultation concluded last week. But the speed of the ITC's response is causing gasps.

The ITC's proposals emerged in public on January 16, when its chief executive, Patricia Hodgson, told a London conference of consumer bodies that "this year we will introduce a system of asking our licensees to volunteer and report annually on their public service commitments".

She met scepticism. "Out of control," said one highly-respected consumer lobbyist. Another former BBC executive observed that the BBC's ex-director of policy and planning was imposing the kind of annual review system John Birt had given the corporation, and it was hardly comforting.

Paddy Coulter, director of the International Broadcasting Trust, says: "We have all had experience of the BBC's annual statement of promises, they get briefer and blander. There have to be detailed requirements, real practical impediments, posts in the ground, to stop a drift in the current ferocious climate." As he points out there are fewer programmes about international affairs now than 10 years ago: how can a weaker system make things better?

Behind the scenes, each of the 15 ITV regional licence holders is currently writing six-page statements on its (regional) commitments. ITV Network is writing another one containing its national programme promises. These will be published in March, and replace the system which has existed since 1993 - the one which forced ITV to bring back News at Ten.

It seems that the ITC wants everything cut and dried, before opposition mobilises. Despite the billing of the new statements as "an experiment" they are the template for the future. As Jocelyn Hay, chair of Voice of the Listener and Viewer, asks: "Why so fast before the consultation process on the white paper is even complete?"

Last week at the European Media Forum, Hodgson provided more detail of her flexible approach to change. Broadcasting "was not a heritage industry". The ITC would keep self-regulation honest by quantifying public service where possible, backed up by a range of research, including longer term programme trends.

Will the system defend vulnerable programme areas and be able to do something to correct drift at a point when a unified ITV Network is being encouraged? Common sense suggests ITV is unlikely to lay out its best ideas for the year ahead and aspirations for the next for competitors to pinch. And the network itself is uncertain: does it keep records and open itself up to inspection when asked?

Those writing the ITV statements say that mandatory programmes, such as news and current affairs, children's and religion, will have a clear weekly minimum. Beyond that, those considered vulnerable - arts, adult education, documentaries and social action - will form part of a simpler table to ensure diversity. "To be perfectly honest, haggling is going on. We've not reached a final agreement," said an ITV source.

The lists of required programmes are being "pared down to the core" said another. And for high profile popular areas including sport, entertainment and drama, there will be no targets set, because it is assumed that ITV will carry on producing them until the cows come home. A second table will set out regional output, per franchise. But these broadcast commitments cannot be harmonised.

The hope, overall, is that the changes will produce a more dynamic network. The fear, of course, is that the quirks and diversity of British television will be jeopardised.

fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst: Richard Whish
fields.trailText: Richard Whish
fields.body:
Radio:

I put on the Today programme at 6.30 am. If its John Humphrys or Sue MacGregor after half an hour I'm so annoyed, I go to Radio 3. There is too much attacking of everyone. I never listen to commercial radio.

Newspapers:

On weekdays I always buy my Financial Times from Ian, the newsagent in Cleveland Square. The FT gives a special voucher scheme to impoverished academics, so it's 45p instead of 85p. I have to read it, there are always three or four big competition issues daily. It has very good arts and opera reviews, but to my great frustration, no proper sports pages. I always read the Economist: it fits on the handlebars of the exercise bike at the gym. At weekends I buy the Guardian, and read it cover to cover to catch up on the week, it's pretty good. On Sundays I read the Observer.

Television:

Most television is absolute rubbish. Stupidly, I subscribed to Sky a month ago, it is just 10 times the rubbish! I try to follow Indian culture. I've been every year since 1986, and I also feed my knowledge with India Today [a weekly digest]. I devoutly follow EastEnders, the one relaxing part of the day, though a fourth episode is a terrible mistake, they'll run out of ideas. At 10pm, if I watch the news, it will be on the BBC. The one news that is streets ahead is Channel 4, but it's too early for me. Newsnight? Can't stand it, it's a disgrace, all about the cult of Paxman.

New media:

I don't use the internet outside of work: when you're researching in front of a computer 12 hours a day, that is quite enough.

 Richard Whish, professor of law at King's College, London, is the competition law expert conducting a review of the BBC's fair trading guidelines and policy.

fields.headline: Doubts over Iraq air strikes
fields.standfirst:
MPs express anger at raids as legality is questioned

Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: The government's insistence that the US and British air strikes against Iraq are justified under international law is less firmly endorsed in Whitehall than ministers admit publicly, informed sources said last night.
fields.body:
The government's insistence that the US and British air strikes against Iraq are justified under international law is less firmly endorsed in Whitehall than ministers admit publicly, informed sources said last night.

Private doubts about the legal basis of the no-fly zones over Iraq resurfaced as angry Labour MPs, MEPs and union leaders gave Tony Blair clear signals that they will be much more sceptical about intimate military cooperation with Washington now that a Republican administration is back in power - even though a general election is just weeks away.

In public Mr Blair and his senior colleagues argue that the threat to the west from "rogue states" such as Iraq is real and leaves Britain and the US "perfectly entitled to deter aggression" as the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, put it.

Allied arguments have cut little ice around the world as Arab leaders united in opposition to the air strikes and allowed the Iraqi president, Saddam Hussein, to portray himself as victim rather than aggressor.

Under the Tories, successive legal advisers, including Lord Williams of Mostyn, the attorney-general, have reassured ministers that the no-fly zones are sanctioned by international law.

However authoritative sources said last night: "They are less confident in private."

Labour's rank and file is also more sceptical. Bill Morris, leader of the Transport and General Workers' Union, and Glenys Kinnock MEP expressed doubts about Friday night's bombings and the 10-year policy of sanctions which have failed to bring President Saddam to heel.

George Galloway, the arabist Labour MP, flew to Baghdad and likened Friday's attack to "Hitler marching into Czechoslovakia" in 1939.

"What the British and American governments are doing is reckless, lawless and murderous. If they are not already working for Saddam Hussein then they might as well be because for every bomb that is dropped, Saddam is getting stronger," the Glasgow Kelvin MP said.

More than 2,000 people - including Iraq's deputy foreign minister, Nabil Najim - protested against the bombings in Baghdad and at least 1,000 other protesters gathered near the offices of the ruling al-Ba'ath party.

"This dangerous aggression shows how much the Americans and Britons hate Iraqis and do not respect any international law," Mr Najim told the demonstrators. "This aggression must be condemned."

Mr Blair and the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, led a platoon of ministers in defending the US-UK action as necessary to protect their air sorties from anti-aircraft attack by President Saddam's forces - and thereby to save the Kurds of northern Iraq and the southern Shi'ites from his murderous revenge.

That is the legal basis which ministers invoke when challenged: the right under international law to intervene to prevent a humanitarian catastrophe such as the use of chemical weapons to kill 5,000 Kurdish villagers in the 1980s when the west still tilted towards President Saddam in his war with Iran.

But, the no-fly zones are not specifically sanctioned by any UN security council resolution. Four days before Mr Blair flies into Washington to meet President George Bush, it emerged that Friday's air strikes were cleared by both leaders after requests from military commanders, the RAF as much as the USAF.

fields.headline: A message from Heat: watch out for lamp-posts
fields.standfirst: A year ago, Heat nearly closed. Last week it showed a circulation rise of 137%. Why? Editor  Mark Frith  tells all
fields.trailText: A year ago, Heat nearly closed. Last week it showed a circulation rise of 137%. Why? Editor Mark Frith tells all
fields.body:
Heat's little bit of good news at the end of last week - sales up to 172,000, an increase of 137% year-on-year, the biggest increase for any UK newsstand magazine - came at the end of a two-year period packed with more drama than most of the TV shows we write about.

It's at this point in a magazine's history, when the clouds are lifting, that editors are asked to talk about their title's success. The editor will jump at the chance of talking about how the unusual sales curve was the plan all along and how they were just waiting for the rest of the world to catch up with their genius. I won't be doing that. Cos I'd be lying. It's been hell. No, really.

Two years ago today Emap put a new magazine out on the shelves of Britain's newsagents. For the next week most of those magazines stayed there - many in the industry reckoned they were actually nailed to those shelves.

Post-mortems went on behind the scenes. There were too many words in it. It was too serious. There weren't enough pictures. It was too intense. It was too old. Something had to change.

A poor-selling weekly is the easiest way for a publishing company to lose money. Lots of it. Production and distribution costs are so high that if you're not pulling in mega numbers you're running at a severe loss. Conversely, if you're doing well, the rewards are huge - bigger than any mag, even the big thick glossies. We wanted to be in the latter category, please. A year ago we weren't.

It's no exclusive that Heat nearly closed. For a while we were the story. We very boldly said from the off that we were aiming for a settle-down figure of 100,000. We had to, about six months after launch, admit we weren't doing anything like that (the figure was more like 65,000). Even the Daily Mirror said we were about to close.

Now, 24 months from launch and it's a different tale - a student with a preposterous beard who sings Britney Spears songs in an over-the-top manner is on the cover and people seem to be buying it. I'm not telling you what our secret is, because every magazine has to look at their own market situation and come up with their own. Every magazine's way out of it will be different. But what we can say is that Heat's method involved a brilliant, loyal team working hard every single day, a management team that has allowed me, as boss for the last year, to do my job in peace (it's all about trust) and an MD and editor-in-chief who have been nothing short of inspirational (if the editorial team are in opposition to the management you're buggered sooner or later). But mostly it's about knowing what the reader really wants week in week out. Every editor will tell you there's no bigger thrill than seeing people reading it on buses, raving about it to their friends, talking about it on the radio, writing about us in the papers. Over the past 12 months I genuinely believe we've had more of all of that than any other magazine in Britain.

The very best moment of my last 12 months happened while I was walking down New Oxford Street last week. It was a Tuesday and the new issue had just come out. A woman was on her way to work, smoking a fag and reading our transcript of Ali G's hilarious interview with Posh and Becks. I watched her walking along the street smoking and laughing. I also watched helplessly as she walked into a lamp-post. It was at that point that I realised the magazine had become everything we wanted it to be. An unputdownable, sexy, glamorous, must-read. We had become for her - and many like her - utterly irresistible. This year we'd like to think Heat will be causing a lot more people to walk into lamp-posts. We can only apologise in advance.

fields.headline: Mad about celebs
fields.standfirst: The latest ABC figures for magazines show rough rides for the girls' market and more losses for women's glossies. But which of the celebrity titles now rules supreme? By  John Dugdale
fields.trailText: The latest ABC figures for magazines show rough rides for the girls' market and more losses for women's glossies. But which of the celebrity titles now rules supreme? By John Dugdale
fields.body:
Are magazine publishers mad? Looking at the latest six-monthly average sales figures, it seems the only feasible explanatory hypothesis. Take, for example, the girls' market, where most editors will have spent the whole night after the ABC stats came out sobbing into their Robbie Williams duvets. A few titles are up, but the vast majority are down - from market leader Sugar's 1.90% year-on-year loss to Live & Kicking's horrendous 29.80% drop, largely attributable to the decline in the Saturday morning show it's linked to.

Reasons for the slump are not hard to find: the pop scene is dull, with clone boy bands giving way to clones of clones of clones, and there's a limit to the number of Steps or Britney covers any girl will splash out on; but above all teenagers and tweenagers are spending an increasing amount of time online, finding the kind of celebrity gossip, features and personal experience pieces that mags can provide, alongside the chat rooms and opportunities to meet boys they can't.

The number of defectors to the net is bound to increase, and common sense would suggest this is a sector to steer clear of if you're planning a new launch. Yet last year the BBC brought out the teen title Star, the recent debut of Mad About Boys created as big a sensation as the first girl in the playground with a bra, and CosmoGirl! and Elle Girl are both due to arrive this year. Bonkers or what?

Seemingly equally demented are publishers eager to add even more titles to the women's monthly sector, described as "mature" and "congested" for about as long as anyone can remember. For the umpteenth period in succession, sales are generally down, with good results for Company and Elle the only significant exceptions; otherwise publishers are reduced to hailing zero change as success "in a very competitive market" and tiny gains as triumphs. The "Full up" sign is there for all to see, you'd imagine. Nevertheless, the BBC's Eve and IPC's resuscitated Nova wedged themselves into the crush during 2000, Time Warner premiered In Style last week, and Condé Nast's Glamour will shortly follow. Nurse!

And yet. And yet. The possible method in their madness can be discerned if you look at the women's weekly sector, where stale old-style mags with titles beginning with the word 'Woman' have been in decline since at least the 1980s, as elderly readers - wondering on foul wintry mornings whether they feel up to tottering to the newsagent for their copy of Woman's Own - vote with their Zimmer frames. Publishers could easily have looked at the relentlessly dropping ABC figures and stayed well away from the sector. They didn't, though. They saw opportunities. First came the German invasion led by Take a Break and Bella, then magazines such as Now (up 20% in the latest figures) combined tabloid stories with better pictures.

Above all, the success of Hello! and OK! revitalised the whole sector, and their impact has spread well beyond it. Without their demonstration of an endless public appetite for celebs, it's hard to imagine publishers nerving themselves to launch such titles as Star, In Style and Heat, all centred on the lifestyles of the rich and famous.

Up by a flabbergasting 137.60%, Heat (see box opposite) was far and away the stand-out performer in the July-Dec 2000 ABCs, and its owner Emap had other reasons to be cheerful. FHM, which once looked to have peaked, put on 2% and at 716,679 retains its place in the top 10 of all titles ranked by the number of copies "actively purchased" (ie not the result of club membership, etc). Elle added 6.80%, almost identical to its year-on-year gain in the previous period, and It's Bliss, up 4.30%, was one of the few teen titles to post gains.

But Smash Hits, down 8.20%, fell victim to the slump in pop-based titles, and of the sinking Wagadon titles acquired by Emap, only the Face (up 8.20%) has recovered. Death Row surely beckons for Arena (down 21.30 to a meagre 37,080); and it's surprising that the publisher which last year deleted Select and Minx has not already put Sky (down 35.20%) out of its misery. Also sliding are the once-healthy women's title Red (down 14%) and teen mag J-17 (13%), suffering double-digit decline for the second consecutive period.

IPC had a bit of a stinker, hit by demoralising losses in such prestige titles as Marie Claire (down 11%) and Loaded (5.40%), with further whopping drops at men's mag Later (22.40%) and women's glossies Woman's Journal (14.80%), Essentials (10.50%) and Woman and Home (8.70%). Attempts to reboot NME have so far been in vain, and if it continues to lose 8.20% of its readership every six months it could be heading for the same rock graveyard as its former stablemate Melody Maker. Nova debuted with 75,142, said to be "on target with launch expectations".

Besides Now's performance, IPC could take some consolation from TV and Satellite Week (up 22.40%) and What's On TV's loss of only 2.30% - far from contemptible in a volatile listings sector recently reinforced by Bauer's 732,259-selling TV Choice - which preserves its position as the No 1 actively purchased title with a monstrous ABC of 1,701,064.

But this goodish news was offset by grim figures from TV Times, which shed 12.90% of its circulation. Its longstanding rival Radio Times (down 5.40%) also drooped, scarcely improving the glum mood at BBC Worldwide. The Beeb's magazines were the worst hit by girls getting bored by pop, with Top of the Pops chasing Live and Kicking downwards in losing 17.20%.

Condé Nast experienced mixed fortunes, achieving significant rises at Condé Nast Traveller (19.70%) and Vanity Fair (8%), but falls at Tatler (3.60%) and GQ (1.40%). As did National Magazines, where the outstanding result was Company's 8% gain, strikingly reversing the previous period's 4.80% year-on-year loss. The slippage at Marie Claire meant that NatMags' Cosmopolitan was able to extend its lead at the head of the sector despite itself losing 2%.

Less welcome results came in the publisher's Home and Lifestyle Group, where its former Gruner & Jahr titles were hit by the distribution dispute which has caused their absence from the shelves of Tesco: Best fell by 9%, Prima by 6%. And still haemorrhaging readers with an unstaunchability suggesting haemophilia is Esquire, doggedly pursuing its "keep your tits in for the lads" policy of eschewing the pin-ups used by other men's mags as reader bait.

With the babe-free monthly plummeting 40% to 61,271, NatMags' gloss that Esquire is "creating a totally new men's market where others are now beginning to follow" should win every PR award going in the "innova tion in spinning pants" category. And it drew from editor Peter Howarth's old foe James Brown - whose film title Hotdog posted a "very respectable" debut ABC of 39,247 - the comment that "if Howarth was the captain of the Titanic, he'd be saying 'We may be drowning, but look at the fantastic views of underwater life'".

You will naturally want to know whether OK! beat Hello! in the gripping and increasingly bitter contest in which the two celebrity titles vie for supremacy, with OK! on top this time last year but Hello! regaining the lead six months ago. And the answer is some much-needed good news for Northern & Shell boss Richard Desmond.

A period in which Desmond acquired the cross-promotional muscle of the Express titles and spent £1m on photos of the Michael Douglas/Catherine Zeta-Jones wedding - triggering a feral courtroom battle over Hello!'s spoiler snaps - saw his OK! boost its circulation by 6.20% to 586,176. With Hello! up only 1.50%, new editor Phil Hall now has an 84,000 deficit to make up.

fields.bodyText: Are magazine publishers mad? Looking at the latest six-monthly average sales figures, it seems the only feasible explanatory hypothesis. Take, for example, the girls' market, where most editors will have spent the whole night after the ABC stats came out sobbing into their Robbie Williams duvets. A few titles are up, but the vast majority are down - from market leader Sugar's 1.90% year-on-year loss to Live & Kicking's horrendous 29.80% drop, largely attributable to the decline in the Saturday morning show it's linked to. Reasons for the slump are not hard to find: the pop scene is dull, with clone boy bands giving way to clones of clones of clones, and there's a limit to the number of Steps or Britney covers any girl will splash out on; but above all teenagers and tweenagers are spending an increasing amount of time online, finding the kind of celebrity gossip, features and personal experience pieces that mags can provide, alongside the chat rooms and opportunities to meet boys they can't. The number of defectors to the net is bound to increase, and common sense would suggest this is a sector to steer clear of if you're planning a new launch. fields.headline: Pink panthers or paper tigers?
fields.trailText: Newspapers cannot afford to stand still, whatever their place in the sales league table. They must either respond quickly to the demands of the market or, more usually, innovate to stimulate the market's previously unconscious appetite.
fields.body:
Newspapers cannot afford to stand still, whatever their place in the sales league table. They must either respond quickly to the demands of the market or, more usually, innovate to stimulate the market's previously unconscious appetite.

This phenomenon of permanent revolution is nowhere more obvious just now than at Britain's two pink papers, the Financial Times and Sunday Business. Both are engaged, for very different reasons and in different ways, in strategies aimed at winning a larger audience.

The FT, which makes handsome profits for its owners, Pearson, has made huge strides by internationalising itself, selling in the US, continental Europe and Asia. Last month those three foreign issues accounted for almost 62% of its total sale of 478,000, and virtually all of the paper's 43,000 year-on-year increase.

Its British circulation, at 180,000, has been fairly static for some time, but the FT's editor, Richard Lambert, is not prepared to let that situation persist, and there are signs that new initiatives are beginning to pay dividends.

He is aiming to win steady, incremental growth through a range of editorial changes and additions, such as the enterprising Creative Business supplement on Tuesdays, the beefed-up Saturday issue with its two magazines, a broadening of the agenda on the comment and analysis pages and a push to win circulation in Scotland.

These diverse measures, along with the building up of staff abroad, illustrate the way in which the FT is happy to do battle on several fronts at the same time.

But the paper is still careful with its money. When a Swedish company launched Business arm in Scotland, the FT dummied up what Lambert calls "a cheeky, cheerful tabloid" to compete head on. Then, unconvinced of its real worth, it dropped the idea in favour of raising its visibility north of the border by boosting its bureau in Edinburgh.

That commitment to an investment in people, in journalists and therefore in journalism, is what sets the FT apart from the cost-cutting so prevalent in many other papers.

It now has 400 staff journalists, including some 60 foreign correspondents, and a further 30 "super stringers". In addition, there are 114 journalists attached to its successful website, ft.com, many of whom also contribute to the paper. The web workers have been incorporated into the heart of the print operation.

It is clear that Lambert and the editor of the UK edition, Philip Stevens, believe that the FT must now appeal beyond its strictly financial niche market, to those engaged in public policy for instance.

On Saturdays, the FT's best- selling day by a good margin, there is also material in the magazines, How To Spend It and The Business, which attracts an audience far beyond the stereotypical City gent in pin-stripes.

This need to offer more has struck a chord with the faltering Sunday Business too, which has cost its owners, the Barclay brothers, a considerable sum over the last couple of years (see main piece, left). With its successful launch editor, Jeff Randall, moving on to the BBC, the new editor, Nils Pratley, is taking over at a difficult moment in the paper's history.

A relaunch planned for the middle of next month is crucial to the paper's very existence. It will boast a 64-page glossy magazine, which will feature three lengthy articles and incorporate some of the material - restaurant reviews, motoring, food and drink - which used to appear in the second section of the paper.

This will allow a big revamp of that section, with the inclusion of what Pratley calls "relentlessly upmarket" personal finance pages, a major analytical article on the front page and a real innovation on the back: a column about sports spread betting.

T he main paper will stay roughly the same, though there will be an extra page of comment and analysis, and an attempt to relieve the City diet on the front with economic and personal finance stories. Pratley says: "We have an extraordinary reputation and respect in the City, but we need to convert that into increased sales." Pratley and his publisher, Andrew Neil, see the problem in the same terms as the FT: they must broaden the appeal of their paper.

What is so interesting about this movement at both titles is the recognition that even a niche market as well-heeled as the City, with its abundant advertising spend and rabid interest in its own affairs, is not enough to sustain a paper.

The FT's history, going back to its post-war days under Brendan Bracken, has been one long - and wholly understandable - saga of gradually broadening its agenda in order to build sales. It has worked for the FT, but the jury is still out for Sunday Business. Can it really build a big enough audience from a low starting point?
