fields.headline: It'll cost you...
fields.standfirst: After a year turning round the Scotsman, Andrew Neil is descending on Sunday Business. Which can only mean one thing for the Barclay brothers - dipping into their pockets. Again. And again.  Paul Murphy  and  David Teather  add up the price of ambition
fields.trailText: After a year turning round the Scotsman, Andrew Neil is descending on Sunday Business. Which can only mean one thing for the Barclay brothers - dipping into their pockets. Again. And again. Paul Murphy and David Teather add up the price of ambition
fields.body:
Given his girth, Andrew Neil has a remarkable ability to pat himself on the back. He was at it again earlier this month at the Dorchester on London's Park Lane, at a party to celebrate the circulation of the Scotsman bursting through 100,000 for the first time.

There was an air of bewilderment around the room, filled with senior staff from across the Press Holdings newspaper group where Neil carries the title of publisher-in-chief - a newspaper business owned by the Monaco-based Barclay family, which spans Sunday Business and Scotland on Sunday, as well as the Scotsman. This bewilderment had little to do with the extraordinary fact that Neil was celebrating the Scotsman's supposed success in a fussy, expensive London hotel - several hundred miles from the grittily competitive world of Scottish publishing.

It was concern over what Neil was actually saying which was causing a stir. Last year's relaunch of the Scotsman, accompanied by a slashing of its cover price and forced through despite a dramatic exodus of staff, had been an unqualified success, the publisher declared. Neil had rescued the Scotsman. And now that his job north of the border was done, the former Sunday Times editor was promising to devote "100%" of his time to Sunday Business.

This young newspaper, acquired by the Barclays three years earlier and relaunched by Neil's one-time News International colleague, Jeff Randall, had been an unqualified editorial success, Neil observed. Now it was his duty to turn it into a commercial success. In the past 12 months, sales of Sunday Business have fallen alarmingly by 33% to just 37,600 excluding bulks.

Nils Pratley, who succeeds Randall this week, is young and exceptionally well-versed in the black arts of City journalism, yet his colleagues doubt he has the stature or experience to stand up to the ebullient and over-bearing Neil.

On one side of the Dorchester room, a few Scotsman stalwarts were suppressing their titters. But across the room, the gloom was descending on the Sunday Business contingent. "It was napkin-biting stuff," recalls one of Neil's guests. "Here was a man who, having already poleaxed the paper's circulation, was now promising to ride to the rescue."

"When Andrew Neil starts saying this is the year of Sunday Business, then you start to worry. I don't envy Nils," added another.

Being financial journalists, those working on Sunday Business claim an ability to add up. They were also well aware that in his relatively short career as a businessman, Neil has only ever been associated with numbers which are big and red.

From time to time, at the Scotsman's office in Edinburgh and the London headquarters on High Holborn, Neil's senior editors sit back, tot up the money their publisher has lost their proprietor (Aidan Barclay, son of the reclusive Barclay twins) and quietly wonder just how Neil has managed to retain his job.

Getting an exact take on the losses run up by the Barclays in their bid to establish a newspaper empire is not easy. For a start, the umbrella newspaper company, Press Holdings, is based off-shore in Jersey and consolidated accounts are not public. But it is possible to burrow down through the individual publishing subsidiaries registered in Britain, an exercise which paints a financial picture of a potentially unstable group which is almost entirely reliant on cash injections and loans from the Barclays and their bankers.

The most eye-watering figures which come to light are those associated with the European, the Maxwell venture which the Barclays rescued in 1992 and where Neil took over stewardship in 1997 before eventually closing the publication down in late 1999 - despite promises of funding for at least five years. The Barclays pumped £74m into this particular piece of vanity hackery, which built up cumulative losses of £79m.

The Scotsman, purchased for £85m by the Barclays in 1995, has always looked a more healthy business proposition. With a reasonable history of profitability - by newspaper standards - the brothers had to loan the business only £4.3m by the end of 1999. But already profitability was slipping - from £6.9m to £5.8m that year at the Scotsman group.

Neil became publisher on July 1 1999 and from being a disengaged editor-in-chief he adopted a very hands-on role - taking a punishing attitude to costs, to show he had the ability to successfully manage a business. Budgets were slashed across the board.

Most importantly, promotional spend was curbed as was the print run. By the end of his first year, profitability at the papers was improving and Neil had proved his point - he had made the company commercially robust. The effect of the short term gain, however, was to destabilise the titles to the point where the sales had slumped to 72,000 and he was forced to cut the cover price to get the title back on its feet. That, as Neil himself points out, has cost the company up to £5m.

"No one really knows or asks hard questions about the finances. They only look at the circulation figures where he can happily, with the Scotsman, say that it is successful. But what does it cost to get there? Other people's money doesn't factor into it. He simply craves the attention and the accolades of his peers. He is financially illiterate in many ways," says one former executive.

Then there is Sunday Business Publishing, whose last filed accounts (for 1999) show accumulated losses of £19m. Including an associate company, Sunday Business Printing, filed accounts suggest that until 14 months ago, the Barclays had already pumped almost £26m into the paper.

Sunday Business is still haemorrhaging cash. Three years ago when Randall, armed with a serious chequebook, threw together a team of 36 financial journalists to re-invent a newspaper which had previously been treated with derision in the City, "break even" was projected to be reached when circulation hit 80,000. This figure was attained for one month, early last year, when a growing base of regular business readers was suddenly swelled by the excitement surrounding the short-lived dot.com boom.

This was fantastic news for Randall. It was widely believed that when Neil had hired Randall, the former Sunday Times city editor had been promised a £1m bonus if he could make the paper profitable within the three years.

But the euphoria was short-lived. Bizarrely, Neil, while wrapped up in the editorial antics at the Scotsman and busy slashing the cover price of his flagship publication north of the border, suddenly decided that the moment had arrived to double the cover price of Sunday Business. Aghast at the timing of the move, Randall and his team begged for an immediate round of marketing/advertising to support sales as the price of the paper jumped from 50p to £1.

Neil refused. Instead, he began to dismantle the countrywide distribution system painfully constructed over the previous two years and abandoned plans to print Sunday Business on the Scotsman's presses, so depriving the paper of a chance of targeting the important Scottish business community. As sales fell, the print run was slashed from 130,000 to 80,000.

With only a limited base of subscription sales, circulation collapsed as the paper disappeared from news-stands outside London and the south east. The latest figures, for January this year, show full-rate sales of just 37,600, topped up with 16,000 bulk sales, sold to hotels for a nominal sum.

Given that recent experience, the Sunday Business editorial team had little reason to feel any confidence in Neil's promise, delivered at the Dorchester, to pull them out of the mire. He had, after all, thrown them into trouble in the first place.

"Take a look at the strategic decision to double the price of Sunday Business - the sales fall through the floor," says one former Press Holdings executive. "And this is at the same time that he is more than halving the Scotsman cover price to get a 25% lift. But he doesn't think like that. There is no five-year plan in place, he is always thinking of how what he does will play in London to his peers."

Taking the established figures from the newspaper operations, and then guesstimating the as-yet unquantified losses from a string of aborted internet ventures which Neil had backed enthusiastically (mainly through a company called the Net Media Group, which has yet to file accounts with Companies House), senior figures at the group reckon the Barclays are so far wearing losses of about £120m racked up during Neil's tenure.

The Barclays, of course, can afford this sort of pain, having built a fortune in commercial property during the 1970s and 1980s. The family are traditionally long-term "value investors" - buying assets which are out of fashion, financing them through the hard times and then selling when they return to vogue. Their patience with their cash-consuming newspaper business fits with this financial model.

Press Holdings' newspaper assets clearly carry a certain value. The Scotsman and Scotland on Sunday, purchased for £85m six years ago, were together valued at £135m in 1998 by the directors, and then revalued at £170m a year later. But in doing so the directors were attributing a higher rating to the business than that currently placed on the Daily Mail group by the stock market. Neil says the Scotsman group is now worth more than £200m.

Putting a valuation on Sunday Business is more difficult, since the business has yet to prove itself as a viable commercial entity - some insiders suggest £50m. The Barclays are believed to have had approaches from both News International and Pearson, the publisher of the Financial Times. But any potential buyer will have been aware that the newspaper still required sustained investment. Any valuation discussed in the past will have been dramatically higher when circulation was above 80,000, than now, when the core readership has dwindled to little more than 30,000.

Throwing heavy money at a business whose revenues are falling fast requires real bravery and there are doubts over whether Aidan Barclay, to whom Neil reports, still has the stomach to deal with the losses his newspapers keep hitting him with.

Something of a relaunch is planned at Sunday Business next month, with a colour magazine being introduced. Rather than cranking up investment, cost-cutting on the editorial side at Sunday Business is expected in the short term - with Neil replicating his actions at the Scotsman.

At the same time, there has to be an assumption that Neil will avoid the editorial approach he adopted first at the European and then the Scotsman - adopting a broadly anti-European line with the former and loudly opposing Scottish devolution while running the latter. An anti-City stance by Sunday Business would, of course, put the paper out of business.

As for Neil's future as an effective chief executive, the jury is still out. He would only say on Friday: "We have a strong newspaper group here which is going forward."

"He must know that if this was a normal quoted company, shareholders would be baying for his blood," says one of his lieutenants. "Aidan, on the other hand, is prone to long periods of managerial neglect, punctuated by tantrums. Andrew, in truth, could go at any moment. But given the Barclays' pride and the depth of their pockets, just stating as much will probably extend his stewardship here."

Full disclosure
by Guy Adams

Andrew Neil was educated at his local Paisley Grammar School and Glasgow University. He graduated in 1971 with an MA in politics and economics and, after a brief stint at the Conservative Party's research department, landed a job onAlastair Burnet's Economist.

Cutting his teeth as a Northern Ireland reporter, Neil was the magazine's Westminster, labour and US correspondent before being given the UK editor's job in 1982. His subsequent appointment, a year later, as editor of the Sunday Times unnerved the Fleet Street establishment: Neil was just 34 and had no experience of working in newspapers.

He did, however, enjoy the affections of his boss and was instrumental in News International's secretive move to Wapping in 1986. Neil also became involved in News International's expansion. He launched Sky TV in 1988 and was its executive chairman until 1990. The network lost money for several years, but secured a dominant (and now highly profitable) position in the satellite market.

Neil left the Sunday Times in 1994 when Rupert Murdoch, uneasy at his editor's high-profile and prompted by a row with the Malaysian prime minister that threatened News Corp's Asian interests, moved him to New York to front a flagship current affairs show for Fox TV. After an unhappy six months, Neil walked out to become an author, columnist, broadcaster and political commentator.

In October 1996, shortly after his autobiography, Full Disclosure, was published, Neil was approached by the Barclay brothers to become editor in chief of European Press Holdings.
fields.bodyText: Given his girth, Andrew Neil has a remarkable ability to pat himself on the back. He was at it again earlier this month at the Dorchester on London's Park Lane, at a party to celebrate the circulation of the Scotsman bursting through 100,000 for the first time. There was an air of bewilderment around the room, filled with senior staff from across the Press Holdings newspaper group where Neil carries the title of publisher-in-chief - a newspaper business owned by the Monaco-based Barclay family, which spans Sunday Business and Scotland on Sunday, as well as the Scotsman. This bewilderment had little to do with the extraordinary fact that Neil was celebrating the Scotsman's supposed success in a fussy, expensive London hotel - several hundred miles from the grittily competitive world of Scottish publishing. It was concern over what Neil was actually saying which was causing a stir. Last year's relaunch of the Scotsman, accompanied by a slashing of its cover price and forced through despite a dramatic exodus of staff, had been an unqualified success, the publisher declared. Neil had rescued the Scotsman. And now that his job north of the border was done, the former Sunday Times editor was promising to devote "100%" of his time to Sunday Business. This young newspaper, acquired by the Barclays three years earlier and relaunched by Neil's one-time News International colleague, Jeff Randall, had been an unqualified editorial success, Neil observed. Now it was his duty to turn it into a commercial success. In the past 12 months, sales of Sunday Business have fallen alarmingly by 33% to just 37,600 excluding bulks. Nils Pratley, who succeeds Randall this week, is young and exceptionally well-versed in the black arts of City journalism, yet his colleagues doubt he has the stature or experience to stand up to the ebullient and over-bearing Neil. On one side of the Dorchester room, a few Scotsman stalwarts were suppressing their titters. But across the room, the gloom was descending on the Sunday Business contingent. "It was napkin-biting stuff," recalls one of Neil's guests. "Here was a man who, having already poleaxed the paper's circulation, was now promising to ride to the rescue." "When Andrew Neil starts saying this is the year of Sunday Business, then you start to worry. I don't envy Nils," added another. Being financial journalists, those working on Sunday Business claim an ability to add up. They were also well aware that in his relatively short career as a businessman, Neil has only ever been associated with numbers which are big and red. From time to time, at the Scotsman's office in Edinburgh and the London headquarters on High Holborn, Neil's senior editors sit back, tot up the money their publisher has lost their proprietor (Aidan Barclay, son of the reclusive Barclay twins) and quietly wonder just how Neil has managed to retain his job. Getting an exact take on the losses run up by the Barclays in their bid to establish a newspaper empire is not easy. For a start, the umbrella newspaper company, Press Holdings, is based off-shore in Jersey and consolidated accounts are not public. But it is possible to burrow down through the individual publishing subsidiaries registered in Britain, an exercise which paints a financial picture of a potentially unstable group which is almost entirely reliant on cash injections and loans from the Barclays and their bankers. The most eye-watering figures which come to light are those associated with the European, the Maxwell venture which the Barclays rescued in 1992 and where Neil took over stewardship in 1997 before eventually closing the publication down in late 1999 - despite promises of funding for at least five years. The Barclays pumped £74m into this particular piece of vanity hackery, which built up cumulative losses of £79m. The Scotsman, purchased for £85m by the Barclays in 1995, has always looked a more healthy business proposition. With a reasonable history of profitability - by newspaper standards - the brothers had to loan the business only £4.3m by the end of 1999. But already profitability was slipping - from £6.9m to £5.8m that year at the Scotsman group. Neil became publisher on July 1 1999 and from being a disengaged editor-in-chief he adopted a very hands-on role - taking a punishing attitude to costs, to show he had the ability to successfully manage a business. Budgets were slashed across the board. Most importantly, promotional spend was curbed as was the print run. By the end of his first year, profitability at the papers was improving and Neil had proved his point - he had made the company commercially robust. The effect of the short term gain, however, was to destabilise the titles to the point where the sales had slumped to 72,000 and he was forced to cut the cover price to get the title back on its feet. That, as Neil himself points out, has cost the company up to £5m. "No one really knows or asks hard questions about the finances. They only look at the circulation figures where he can happily, with the Scotsman, say that it is successful. But what does it cost to get there? Other people's money doesn't factor into it. He simply craves the attention and the accolades of his peers. He is financially illiterate in many ways," says one former executive. Then there is Sunday Business Publishing, whose last filed accounts (for 1999) show accumulated losses of £19m. Including an associate company, Sunday Business Printing, filed accounts suggest that until 14 months ago, the Barclays had already pumped almost £26m into the paper. Sunday Business is still haemorrhaging cash. Three years ago when Randall, armed with a serious chequebook, threw together a team of 36 financial journalists to re-invent a newspaper which had previously been treated with derision in the City, "break even" was projected to be reached when circulation hit 80,000. This figure was attained for one month, early last year, when a growing base of regular business readers was suddenly swelled by the excitement surrounding the short-lived dot.com boom. This was fantastic news for Randall. It was widely believed that when Neil had hired Randall, the former Sunday Times city editor had been promised a £1m bonus if he could make the paper profitable within the three years. But the euphoria was short-lived. Bizarrely, Neil, while wrapped up in the editorial antics at the Scotsman and busy slashing the cover price of his flagship publication north of the border, suddenly decided that the moment had arrived to double the cover price of Sunday Business. Aghast at the timing of the move, Randall and his team begged for an immediate round of marketing/advertising to support sales as the price of the paper jumped from 50p to £1. Neil refused. Instead, he began to dismantle the countrywide distribution system painfully constructed over the previous two years and abandoned plans to print Sunday Business on the Scotsman's presses, so depriving the paper of a chance of targeting the important Scottish business community. As sales fell, the print run was slashed from 130,000 to 80,000. With only a limited base of subscription sales, circulation collapsed as the paper disappeared from news-stands outside London and the south east. The latest figures, for January this year, show full-rate sales of just 37,600, topped up with 16,000 bulk sales, sold to hotels for a nominal sum. Given that recent experience, the Sunday Business editorial team had little reason to feel any confidence in Neil's promise, delivered at the Dorchester, to pull them out of the mire. He had, after all, thrown them into trouble in the first place. "Take a look at the strategic decision to double the price of Sunday Business - the sales fall through the floor," says one former Press Holdings executive. "And this is at the same time that he is more than halving the Scotsman cover price to get a 25% lift. But he doesn't think like that. There is no five-year plan in place, he is always thinking of how what he does will play in London to his peers." Taking the established figures from the newspaper operations, and then guesstimating the as-yet unquantified losses from a string of aborted internet ventures which Neil had backed enthusiastically (mainly through a company called the Net Media Group, which has yet to file accounts with Companies House), senior figures at the group reckon the Barclays are so far wearing losses of about £120m racked up during Neil's tenure. The Barclays, of course, can afford this sort of pain, having built a fortune in commercial property during the 1970s and 1980s. The family are traditionally long-term "value investors" - buying assets which are out of fashion, financing them through the hard times and then selling when they return to vogue. Their patience with their cash-consuming newspaper business fits with this financial model. Press Holdings' newspaper assets clearly carry a certain value. The Scotsman and Scotland on Sunday, purchased for £85m six years ago, were together valued at £135m in 1998 by the directors, and then revalued at £170m a year later. But in doing so the directors were attributing a higher rating to the business than that currently placed on the Daily Mail group by the stock market. Neil says the Scotsman group is now worth more than £200m. Putting a valuation on Sunday Business is more difficult, since the business has yet to prove itself as a viable commercial entity - some insiders suggest £50m. The Barclays are believed to have had approaches from both News International and Pearson, the publisher of the Financial Times. But any potential buyer will have been aware that the newspaper still required sustained investment. Any valuation discussed in the past will have been dramatically higher when circulation was above 80,000, than now, when the core readership has dwindled to little more than 30,000. Throwing heavy money at a business whose revenues are falling fast requires real bravery and there are doubts over whether Aidan Barclay, to whom Neil reports, still has the stomach to deal with the losses his newspapers keep hitting him with. Something of a relaunch is planned at Sunday Business next month, with a colour magazine being introduced. Rather than cranking up investment, cost-cutting on the editorial side at Sunday Business is expected in the short term - with Neil replicating his actions at the Scotsman. At the same time, there has to be an assumption that Neil will avoid the editorial approach he adopted first at the European and then the Scotsman - adopting a broadly anti-European line with the former and loudly opposing Scottish devolution while running the latter. An anti-City stance by Sunday Business would, of course, put the paper out of business. As for Neil's future as an effective chief executive, the jury is still out. He would only say on Friday: "We have a strong newspaper group here which is going forward." "He must know that if this was a normal quoted company, shareholders would be baying for his blood," says one of his lieutenants. "Aidan, on the other hand, is prone to long periods of managerial neglect, punctuated by tantrums. Andrew, in truth, could go at any moment. But given the Barclays' pride and the depth of their pockets, just stating as much will probably extend his stewardship here." fields.headline: Earthlings beware
fields.standfirst: They're aliens, they're rude and they're coming to capture your children in a new TV show starting today. Duncan Campbell reports on the invasion of the Butt-Ugly Martians
fields.trailText: They're aliens, they're rude and they're coming to capture your children in a new TV show starting today, reports Duncan Campbell.
fields.body:
When the Teletubbies arrived in the US, the perceived homosexuality of Tinky Winky led to outrage from the religious right and a debate about which cartoon characters in the past had been sending what subliminal messages to young impressionable viewers. Conservative America may be in for a bit of a shock, then, when they finally get to see Butt-Ugly Martians, the children's television programme which premieres on British television today and comes to the US later in the year.

The aesthetically challenged eponymous trio not only resort to farting to subdue their enemies but are proud to be called aliens. And the message of the new, heavily-promoted series aimed at four to-11-year-olds is that decent children welcome and hide aliens and battle against those who would seek to catch them.

While Teletubbies' creators never claimed to have an agenda of fighting homophobia, the Los Angeles-based producer of the new series, Bill Schultz, whose past work includes both The Simpsons and King of the Hill, reckons that the cartoon does have a responsibility to let children know that they are right to defend strangers and right to show tolerance.

Not that the Butt-Ugly Martians are coming with a heavy political agenda. Far from it. The hope of the team behind the 26-part series is to be the biggest thing in the children's television world since the Ninja Turtles. No related marketing or spin-off opportunity is being missed. Everything from cereal tie-ins to replica characters is being employed in the big sell. The promotional material describes the series as Ninja Turtles meets The Mask meets Toy Story meets Men in Black, clearly hoping to press as many buttons as it can between screen and toy shop. Since the Butt-Uglies are being launched in the middle of the internet age, they will come complete with their own websites.

The basic story is that the three Butt-Ugly Martians, B Bop-A-Luna, Do-Wah Diddy and 2-T-Fru-T have come to earth in 2053 with their dog, helpfully named Dog, at the behest of the wicked Emperor Bog to capture the planet. Having arrived, instead of enslaving the human race they become friends with three children, Mikey, Angela and Cedric, the first two white and the third black.

So that the Butt-Uglies, who are enjoying their time on earth, can convince Emperor Bog that their mission is going according to plan, the three children help them mock up scenes which are sent back to Mars to reassure headquarters that the occupation is under way and victory is imminent. In fact, the trio are stuffing their faces with junk and watching television just like normal children.

Emperor Bog is assisted by the evil, one-eyed Dr Damage who is clearly English and sounds remarkably like the late Kenneth Williams, right down to his fruity, nasal vowels, fulfilling the rule of American film-making that an English person always plays the sadistic bastard - Hannibal, The Patriot etc. The pacing is fast, the animation of a standard to be expected from someone with Schultz's background.

The original idea by Gary Selvaggio has been developed by an LA-based Welshman, Mike Young, of Super Ted fame, and the Just Group in Derbyshire, of Pinky and Perky fame, hence its premiere in the United Kingdom. The USA, Canada, Germany, Spain, France and a host of other countries have bought it already and the next few weeks will tell whether or not it really is another Ninja phenomenon.

Supervising is Schultz, who came to LA as a songwriter but found himself working as the animation producer for The Simpsons and King of the Hill, as well as on the animated version of The Mask and Mighty Max. His childhood television influences included, he said, everything from The Man from UNCLE to The Brady Bunch and Gilligan's Island. Clearly a busy man, he is also supervising another four Cartoon Network series including the new Sheep in the Big City.

"Certainly the Simpsons have opened things up," says Schultz on the subject of what is now seen as acceptable on television - farting and the like. But while The Simpsons has an adult audience in mind, the Butt-Uglies are very much aimed at young children with the possibility that some sci-fi teenagers and adults may appreciate the undertones and the humour.

There has already been some murmuring in the US about the term "butt", says Schultz, but none from Britain, which he thinks is generally much more relaxed about such things: "Over here the sensibilities are different."

Schultz has four children himself, and says the team behind the show wanted to get a message of tolerance across without being patronising. So it's no surprise that Stoat Muldoon, the Alien Hunter, is portrayed as a self-important buffoon, albeit one with his own cable television show and website.

By coincidence, Stoat's warning to people to look out for aliens - "they are everywhere ... hiding in public restrooms" - comes just as vigilante groups in the southern states are issuing the same sort of warnings about a different kind of alien. Muldoon warns that "they want our homes" and suggests that "all aliens make disgusting digestive noises", which is presumably going to endear them even more to their target viewers.

The decision two years ago by the conservative Reverend Jerry Falwell's magazine, the National Liberty Journal, to issue a "parent alert" about Tinky Winky and his handbag, helped create an even larger audience for the show in the States, although Tinky had already been outed in the Washington Post and elsewhere.

However, Schultz is aware that what will bring success is one of those imponderables that cannot be bought, even with the piles of promotional pounds, dollars and francs about to be thrown at the show's opening. He says he will be "a student for life" on what actually catches the audience's attention, particularly that of the fastidious eight-year-old.

For the Butt-Uglies team, success will only truly have arrived if children run around shouting "let's get ugly" and singing the theme song, which Schultz, putting on his song-writer's straw hat, has composed: "We are the Martians, the Butt-Ugly Martians ... We don't want to conquer earth, we just want to fill our girth." If that works, a new world of cartoon characters will have established itself. If it doesn't, then presumably there will be no Butts.

Butt-Ugly Martians is on ITV at 4.05pm today.

fields.headline: Fools' gold?
fields.standfirst:
Now that Tony Blair has finally addressed the dreaded issue of the euro, the death of the pound is more than just a distant possibility. James Buchan examines sterling's chances of survival

Ask Keynes
Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Now that Tony Blair has finally addressed the dreaded issue of the euro, the death of the pound is more than just a distant possibility. James Buchan examines sterling's chances of survival.
fields.body:
For more than eight years, since sterling was so comprehensively expelled from the European system of fixed currency exchange rates in 1992, the British public has maintained a constructive indifference towards the euro on the rational ground that it had time to spare to think about it. That time is now up. The euro is camped on the British lawn.

At the European Union, an electronic calendar peels off the electronic days till January 1 2002. It is just 316 days until euro coins and notes become legal tender next New Year's Day. Not later than February 28 2002, the lira, the franc and the Deutschmark will be withdrawn from circulation.

A currency which has so far been a phantom to the 300m people in the 11 countries of the euro-zone, confined to the capital markets or as something to ignore on restaurant bills and bank statements, will enter daily life. The distribution of 10bn banknotes and thousands of tonnes of coins in time for Euro Day will be an operation rich in balls-up possibilities. If there is confusion, British travellers on the continent will surely be as confused as anybody.

In Britain itself, the euro has come down to earth. When Tony Blair announced in parliament that he would decide whether to put the euro to referendum in the first two years of the next parliament, he was telling no secrets. It was a statement of intent that ensures that the euro can now be processed through the political operations of this country, like regional devolution or school reform. With a general election expected in May, the euro will be one of the main issues of substance before the electorate.

Meanwhile, the European reprimand to Ireland last week revealed, for the first time, the vast political scope of the single currency. European finance ministers (including, I regret to say, the British) told the Irish government that it should not cut taxes and raise spending in its 2001 budget because that might lead to inflation and destabilise the euro.

Economic and monetary union since the Maastricht treaty in 1992 has been a story of coercion, threat and pointless bustle, but to tell the most successful economy in the union how to conduct its budgetary business is overdoing it. In its transition from an agricultural to a commercial economy, Ireland was bound to generate inflation. The continental economies should welcome a little inflation in Ireland to dull that sharp Irish competitive edge. The Irish economy is still far too small to have any influence on the external value of the euro.

Modern economies are hundred-billion-dollar engines fuelled by money. To manipulate them, governments can only increase or decrease the supply of money. They can raise or drop the cost of money through the rate of interest or take money from people through taxes or return it to them through rebates.

In 1999, the Irish government abandoned for all time its monetary sovereignty to the European central bank but still thought it could tax and spend as it pleased. Last week's events suggest that the proponents of European federation in Germany and the Benelux countries may get what they always wanted: the euro will slowly reduce national governments, at least in their economic activities, to ciphers.

For the first two years of its existence, the euro had no friends on the foreign exchange markets. Its supporters in Britain were consigned to a sulky silence. It is hard to promote a currency in the throes of falling 30% against the US dollar.

At the end of last year, the dollar began to drop and the euro to rise in response to steady economic growth in Europe and alarming signs of a slump in the US. As of last week, it was a suckers' rally. For the moment, the US is off the critical list. Bulls of the euro have lost so much money that they are very reluctant to accept the European economic story. The decision by the European central bank on Thursday not to follow the Anglo-Saxon central banks - the Federal Reserve and the Bank of England - into taking down market rates of interest was the last straw. The euro fell another 3% last week. It is even falling against the yen, the currency of the world's most troubled major economy.

The euro debate is beset by historical irony. Sterling, which has been on the slide since the early 1930s and on the skids since the early 1970s, is now back in business. The markets for long-term capital believe that inflation will be lower in the UK over the next 30 years than in euroland. (A loan to a borrower in sterling offers lower interest than the equivalent loan in Deutschmarks, but compensates the creditor by the greater apparent solidity of the principal.)

For the generation now on the threshold of middle age, who watched in agony while postwar Labour and Tory governments demolished sterling, the present stability of the pound is near miraculous. Eight and a half years of economic prosperity and currency stability is a short time in the life of a long-lived commercial nation such as Britain, but it is a good chunk of a lifetime. It has taken half a century to restore the prestige of sterling - just in time, it seems, to see it abolished.

For all Labour governments but that of Tony Blair, sterling has been a disaster. Ramsay MacDonald in 1931, Clement Attlee in 1947, Harold Wilson in 1967, James Callaghan in 1976: each presided over a sterling crisis. It was no wonder that the Labour party despaired of the damn thing.

On coming to power in 1997, Labour seemed to be saying: since we can't manage sterling, let's abolish it or give it to the Europeans to run. Instead, Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the Exchequer, gave the management of sterling to the Bank of England. It is hard to imagine Mr Brown saying at referendum time two years from now, "I made a mistake - Labour can't manage the UK economy and currency, nor can the Tories. We must let the continentals do it."

The chief complaint is that sterling is too strong against the euro. Yet a strong currency, as the Germans found from 1948 until they gave up the Deutschmark for the euro, is a powerful business discipline. As an official of the old German Bundesbank said to me in Frankfurt in 1990: "You British should try a strong currency - it's not as bad as it sounds."

For all the strength of the currency in which it prices its exports, the UK still managed to run a small surplus in its trade with euroland in the third quarter of last year (the last for which figures have been published). There may be something in the theory that currency depreciation was just a bolthole for unsuccessful managers.

In Britain, there are supporters of the single currency, but there are no enthusiasts. There are none of those shining young people you meet at the annual congresses of the German political parties, who tell you that the euro is a scheme of federation and will be good not just for Europe but for humanity in general.

Instead, the arguments for joining the euro have become tedious by repetition. By eliminating movements in individual currencies, a single currency lifts some of the fog from doing business so that goods and services should become cheaper and better. Creditors face no risk of their loans translating into less of their home currency, so rates of interest can fall, and thus the rate of profit to pay the interest. Investors are emboldened and employ more people, who will pay more taxes and receive less in benefits, so public finances improve.

At the end of the rainbow, the conversion of the European Union into a true common market will ensure that the power and wealth of individual states, at present dissipated, can combine into an entity more powerful than the US.

The political version of those arguments is Mr Brown's five tests of British suitability. Is the British economy converging on the continental? Will the euro aid economic flexibility? Will the euro be good, or at least not bad, for the City of London? Will the euro be good for employment? Is the euro likely to promote foreign investment in the UK? Those tests are not only quite arbitrary - an IMF report last month hinted that economic divergence would be a virtue in a currency union - they are also subjective. They will tell us only the opinion of the UK Treasury as to whether Britain can join the euro project, not whether it should.

In reality, economics is of no use in the matter of the euro. The euro referendum will confront the British public with the same question as the referendum on European community membership in 1975. Will this country be more secure and prosperous in closer political alliance with the chief nations of the continent? Or is it better off as it is? The answers belong in the realm not of economics, but of faith.

Unless by then Labour has, as the Tories did, crucified itself on the euro.

fields.bodyText: For more than eight years, since sterling was so comprehensively expelled from the European system of fixed currency exchange rates in 1992, the British public has maintained a constructive indifference towards the euro on the rational ground that it had time to spare to think about it. That time is now up. The euro is camped on the British lawn. At the European Union, an electronic calendar peels off the electronic days till January 1 2002. It is just 316 days until euro coins and notes become legal tender next New Year's Day. Not later than February 28 2002, the lira, the franc and the Deutschmark will be withdrawn from circulation. A currency which has so far been a phantom to the 300m people in the 11 countries of the euro-zone, confined to the capital markets or as something to ignore on restaurant bills and bank statements, will enter daily life. The distribution of 10bn banknotes and thousands of tonnes of coins in time for Euro Day will be an operation rich in balls-up possibilities. If there is confusion, British travellers on the continent will surely be as confused as anybody. In Britain itself, the euro has come down to earth. When Tony Blair announced in parliament that he would decide whether to put the euro to referendum in the first two years of the next parliament, he was telling no secrets. It was a statement of intent that ensures that the euro can now be processed through the political operations of this country, like regional devolution or school reform. With a general election expected in May, the euro will be one of the main issues of substance before the electorate. Meanwhile, the European reprimand to Ireland last week revealed, for the first time, the vast political scope of the single currency. European finance ministers (including, I regret to say, the British) told the Irish government that it should not cut taxes and raise spending in its 2001 budget because that might lead to inflation and destabilise the euro. Economic and monetary union since the Maastricht treaty in 1992 has been a story of coercion, threat and pointless bustle, but to tell the most successful economy in the union how to conduct its budgetary business is overdoing it. In its transition from an agricultural to a commercial economy, Ireland was bound to generate inflation. The continental economies should welcome a little inflation in Ireland to dull that sharp Irish competitive edge. The Irish economy is still far too small to have any influence on the external value of the euro. Modern economies are hundred-billion-dollar engines fuelled by money. To manipulate them, governments can only increase or decrease the supply of money. They can raise or drop the cost of money through the rate of interest or take money from people through taxes or return it to them through rebates. The markets for long-term capital believe that inflation will be lower in the UK over the next 30 years than in euroland. Eight and a half years of economic prosperity and currency stability is a short time in the life of a long-lived commercial nation such as Britain, but it is a good chunk of a lifetime. It has taken half a century to restore the prestige of sterling - just in time, it seems, to see it abolished. For all Labour governments but that of Tony Blair, sterling has been a disaster. Ramsay MacDonald in 1931, Clement Attlee in 1947, Harold Wilson in 1967, James Callaghan in 1976: each presided over a sterling crisis. It was no wonder that the Labour party despaired of the damn thing. On coming to power in 1997, Labour seemed to be saying: since we can't manage sterling, let's abolish it or give it to the Europeans to run. It is hard to imagine Mr Brown saying at referendum time two years from now, "I made a mistake - Labour can't manage the UK economy and currency, nor can the Tories. webTitle: What would Keynes make of the euro?

fields.headline: Ask Keynes
fields.standfirst:
Nicholas Fraser wonders what Britain's greatest economist would have made of it all

Fool's gold?
Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Nicholas Fraser wonders what Britain's greatest economist would have made of it all.
fields.body:
In 1922 the US journalist Walter Lippmann looked into the future and came close to a nervous breakdown. He realised that most of the things that were of concern for the citizens of a democracy were too technical to be easily understood. In particular, modern finance distressed him. The stock market was vaguely comprehensible to punters, but not so the web of connections that made up the international trading system - or indeed anything to do with the world economy. Aghast, Lippmann came near to repudiating his calling. How could one contemplate a functioning democracy in which the bulk of the populace were unable to understand such things?

The most discussed and least understood issue of our time is the euro. But it is possible to fathom the euro. Part of the effort involves exposure to the abstract utterances of the European Union. More fun, and more intellectually rewarding, is a crash course in the work of John Maynard Keynes via the 1,700-odd pages of Robert Skidelsky's extraordinary, definitive biography of the great man.

Keynes is remembered hazily as a British arch-pundit, responsible for one famous remark about the ideas of defunct economists lingering to plague us, and his memory is associated with the awful jargon of 1970s industrial disputes. Of course Keynes couldn't tell me what to think about the euro. (He died in 1946.) But in my relative ignorance I could at least learn a method from his example. As I made my way through the legion of 20th-century financial crises in which Keynes was often participant and pundit, I began to formulate a series of Keynes euro tests. Scribbling in margins, I began to mark Keynes con or pro, on a scale of one to 10.

The pound

Keynes struggled to fit sterling into the international system at a moment when British power was flagging. He would not have taken seriously the Tory notion that the British way of life was in some sense dependent on the pound. But like many members of the British mandarin liberal establishment, he also felt that there was no point in scrapping anything unless its replacement was assured.

He would never have assumed (like many of its opponents) that the euro was bound to be a flop. But he would have wanted to know whether other people would believe in it - if they didn't, he, too would have concluded that it could not last. Would he by now believe in the euro? I thought so, just. A six perhaps.

The European central bank

Many opponents of the euro focus on the lack of accountability implied by the existence of a central bank in Frankfurt. The bank, it is also argued, is too inflexible. In a recession it will not be capable of performing the sort of monkey business with public spending advocated by Keynes - all it can do is raise or lower interests and hope for the best. And it might be suggested that Keynes, who devoted much of his polemic to destroying the reputation of overfed central bankers, would not have warmed to the spectacle of large and unwieldy committees communicating through translators.

I had to take these objections seriously. Keynes did believe that money should be kept out of politics. But he also believed that clever people should be given the privilege of running financial policy. In the end I felt that the prospect of exercising such power through a European central bank would have appealed to Keynes. A four or a five, depending on how long and politely the bankers listened to him.

Europeans

I imagined this would prove to be Keynes' biggest stumbling block. He didn't trust French people, whom he saw as obsessed with gold, and still less the Belgians, whom he accused repeatedly of overstating war damage in order to claim excessive reparations. He would have intensely disliked the notion of a Europe with Brussels for its capital, and would have felt ill at ease in the outsize briar patch of EU regulation. For Keynes, civilisation began somewhere in the middle of the Channel.

But Keynes recalled with nostalgia the frontierless Europe of his youth. He would have been the first to acknowledge that Europe has changed, and for the better. A four or a five, depending on the quality of Italian wine.

The single market

Keynes's negative feelings about capitalism came from exposure to the hidebound aspects of the British manager class. He once lamented the fact that the US air force had not dropped bombs on every factory in the north of England "at an hour when the directors were sitting and no one else". Europeans (including British) were in his view excessively attached to where they came from. They dreaded economic change. A pan-European market would force them to alter their ways or, if that proved impossible, to move. The spectacle of immigrants, not armies, crossing the old frontiers of Europe in search of work would have appealed to him. Definitely a seven.

Now make up your mind

Keynes believed that economics, like history, was a plot we could feel free to tamper with in the hope of securing a better future. The more I read his work, the more I became convinced that the "dismal science" of economics, despite its addiction to graphs and formulae, is subject to the same worldly laws as any other human endeavour. Faced with the obligation to choose, Keynes would most likely have vacillated.

I could see him (like many rational sceptics) wanting to be in and out of the euro at the same time. Then I could see him resigned to accepting a system he didn't much like and then refusing it. No more than a grudging five here. As for the referendum itself, he would no doubt have raged against what he saw as the foolishness of requiring people to decide yes or no on complicated economic matters. Somehow, though, I feel he would be capable in the end of voting yes.

 Nicholas Fraser is the author of two books about contemporary Europe, the more recent being The Voice of Modern Hatred, published by Picador.

webTitle: G2: John Sutherland on David Baddiel

fields.headline: My fantasy don
fields.standfirst: Whenever Baddiel comes on the box, I can't help wondering what kind of don he would have made
fields.trailText: John Sutherland: Whenever Baddiel comes on the box, I can't help wondering what kind of don he would have made.
fields.body:
Baddiel-free zones are hard to come by nowadays. Choose your moment wrong and you can find the ubiquitous improvisatore on several channels simultaneously, doing a duo with Skinner or Bradshaw or talking the hind leg off some chat-show host.

At the last big American literary conference I went to, Elaine Showalter (no less) was sagely applauding his novel, Whatever Love Is, as a masterpiece of the Laddist genre to rank with High Fidelity. Bad-the-Lad receives the ultimate accolade of a full-page parody by Craig Brown in the latest Private Eye. What next? The Nobel prize for stand-up comedy?

I met Baddiel once. We shared a literary agent for a while and were introduced at her party. After a couple of desultory pleasantries he drifted off to more oxygenated waters ("is that Martin I see over there?"), leaving me with the other bottom-feeders and peanut munchers. I remember him; he won't remember me.

I envy Baddiel as one of those who got away. The ivory tower couldn't hold him. Now in his mid-to-late 30s, he took a double first at Cambridge in English. He then chose to pursue his graduate studies at UCL, where I work. We overlapped briefly. He was, I recall, writing a PhD thesis on Victorian sexuality and the little girl. An in-your-face subject. I never taught him. Those who did say he was extremely smart.

At some point in the early 90s, some four years into his postgraduate course, young Baddiel looked around him and decided on a career change. No more Doctor Dryasdust. And so came the partnership with Rob Newman, the Mary Whitehouse Experience (sofa comedy, "the new rock-and-roll"), Fantasy Football, the glory tune of Euro '96, and his latest forays into the unplanned and the unscripted - a genre for which I think we do not yet have a word (Baddielism?).

It's one of his running jokes that his mum is forever at her David to get married and go back to his PhD. The second is, I think, the less likely. Having negotiated seven-figure contracts, how could he ever return to the Trappist austerities and little triumphs of the academic life?

None the less, whenever he comes on the box (when doesn't he?) I can't help wondering what kind of don he would have made. A brilliant one, of course. I can see Professor Baddiel at the lectern in my mind's eye: rather shaggier (probably less shagging), tubbier, pebble-thick horn-rims (Sellotaped round the hinge), wearing the uniform shapeless pullover, ad-libbing lectures on the transgressive hermeneutics of the Alice books.

Students would have loved his daring excursions into sex, theory and the meaning of life. He, too, would have enjoyed listeners "almost" as clever as he, rather than those yobbish studio audiences for whom fart, porn and wank are the funniest words in the English language.

As a scholar, he would have shaken things up. An American, James Kincaid, eventually wrote what might have been Baddiel's monograph on the unhealthy Victorian fascination with little girls (Kincaid thought it was rather healthy). It provoked angry questions in parliament - the only work of literary criticism ever to do so, I think. What ripples Professor Baddiel would have made we'll never know. He left for bigger ponds.

I have this mind game, called Fantasy Dons. Suppose you had this English department - in some alternative universe university - staffed with media stars who had decided, perversely, to stick it out in the classroom. My team? AN Wilson (lecturing on Anglo Saxon - or ancient nose pickings, as my more irreverent colleagues call it), William Boyd (this semester lecturing on Evelyn Waugh), Alan Bennett (talking roundheads and Caroline verse), Germaine Greer (eunuch-lit), Andrew Motion (truly great poets) and Blake Morrison (docu-journalism).

You could throw in a couple of politicians: Robin Cook and Chris Smith. All embarked on graduate work (some, like Greer, Morrison and Smith, actually finished their theses). They must have felt what Dr Johnson calls "the strong contagion of the gown" and foreseen themselves as university teachers. Before reality set in.

In glum moments, I wonder if all the geniuses in my subject make the break; leaving us talentless Dobbins and Prufrocks to run the shop ("Do I dare, no I didn't"). I can't help noticing that the really clever students nowadays gravitate towards Monday's Media Guardian rather than Tuesday's Education. Who can blame them? Would you rather be me, or David Baddiel? Don't answer that.

webTitle: Comment: Saddam and Sharon - villains and heroes

fields.headline: Villains and heroes
fields.standfirst:
From Beirut, David Hirst sees the US accused of double standards on Saddam and Sharon

Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Israel has just elected a prime minister who, brought before the bar of international justice, would surely be judged a war criminal in the class of, say, Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb commander as firmly associated with the Srebrenica massacre as General Sharon was with that of Sabra and Shatila during the 1982 Israeli invasion of Lebanon.
fields.body:
Israel has just elected a prime minister who, brought before the bar of international justice, would surely be judged a war criminal in the class of, say, Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb commander as firmly associated with the Srebrenica massacre as General Sharon was with that of Sabra and Shatila during the 1982 Israeli invasion of Lebanon.

Sharon calls Yasser Arafat "a murderer and a liar" but, in the run-up to the elections, the liberal Israeli press copiously illustrated the deceit and sanguinary brutality which have been the twin pillars of his own career. One of his likely coalition partners, Avigdor Lieberman, has spoken of burning Beirut and bombing Tehran. Sharon's ideas on the furtherance of the peace process make a mockery of it. If any Israeli leader ever had the makings of a western villain, the destroyer of US interests in the region, it is surely he.

Yet, within a week of the emergence of this would-be villain as Israel's premier-elect, who do the Americans and British bomb? That old, familiar, that Arab, villain, Saddam Hussein. Of course, his crimes and atrocities are of an order that words can barely encompass. Keeping him from committing more is one thing, however. The motives and methods of those who, once again, have assigned themselves that task, and the regional context in which they do so, is something else.

The Americans and British say Friday's raid, the first on such a scale for more than two years, was necessitated by the upgrading of Saddam's defences and the increased threat that posed to their aircraft's routine forays over the "no-fly zones". Even if that argument is true, it has few takers in the Arab world.

For the Arabs, the raid is an escalation of the Anglo-American campaign against Saddam, with a far greater political import than a strictly military one. Coupled with the rise of Sharon, there could hardly have been a more blatant, a more richly symbolic, display of the double standards which, in their view, typify western, but especially American, treatment of those two zones of perennial Middle East crisis, the Arab-Israeli conflict on the one hand, Iraq and the Gulf on the other. It bodes ill for both.

Each crisis has its own origins and dynamics, but they are intrinsically connected. Saddam pioneered "linkage" when, immediately after his invasion of Kuwait in 1990, he offered to withdraw in return for an immediate, unconditional Israeli withdrawal from the occupied territories.

The offer was greeted with outrage in the west. But in due course "linkage" surreptitiously asserted itself. George Bush Sr promulgated a "new world order" whose cornerstone, in the Middle East, was to be a just and lasting Arab-Israeli settlement.

The US's Arab allies understood that, to achieve it, the US would back away from its historic pro-Israeli bias. "Bush," said President Mubarak at the time, "agrees with me that the Israelis must be pushed into a Palestine solution." Fairness and firmness in one crisis zone were to work wonders in the other.

But it was not to be. Both crises have festered and worsened. Saddam grows stronger and more assertive. The Arab-Israeli peace process has all but collapsed; violence and mutual hatred deepens.

And, with the ascent of Sharon, both have as their key players individuals who incarnate all that is most extreme, dangerous and destructive in the region.

webTitle: Air of disaster makes monkey of graduate

fields.headline: Air of disaster makes monkey of graduate
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: There may be a time and a place to admit that - despite an education at one of Britain's most esteemed universities - you are not sure whether Bach wrote a piece of music called Air on a G-String, Breeze in a Bikini, Waft in the Y-Fronts or Gust up a Gusset.
fields.body:
There may be a time and a place to admit that - despite an education at one of Britain's most esteemed universities - you are not sure whether Bach wrote a piece of music called Air on a G-String, Breeze in a Bikini, Waft in the Y-Fronts or Gust up a Gusset.

But under the glare of the spotlights and in the gaze of up to 10m viewers watching ITV's hit quiz show, Who Wants To Be A Millionaire, is definitely not one of them.

So sympathy battled with schadenfreude for control of the nation's psyche on Saturday when Michelle Simmonds, a 30-year-old hotel administrator from Bromham, Bedfordshire, and a graduate of St Andrews University, became only the third contestant in the show's history to leave with no money.

Ms Simmonds struggled with the first question, eventually choosing the right answer. But her luck was not to hold: she had to ask the audience in which city the Everton football team played, discovering that it was Liverpool but sacrificing one of her lifelines.

Another lifeline vanished as she phoned a friend to find out that the character played by Todd Carty in the TV soap EastEnders is called Mark Fowler.

Her £500 of accumulated prizemoney hung in the balance, however, as she addressed the £1,000 question: which word links a kind of mammal with an archbishop or high-ranking bishop? Ms Simmonds knew that the answer was not "carnivore" or "rodent". Unfortunately, she opted for "marsupial" instead of the correct answer, "primate".

"I'm gutted, but it's because I'm embarrassed, not because I'm upset not to have won any money," she said after the show.

The show's presenter, Chris Tarrant, rallied to her support yesterday, insisting that she was "certainly not stupid".

He added: "It's very daunting sitting in that seat and much harder than it looks from your armchair at home. I think I was more upset than she was. It was almost as nerve-wracking as watching someone win a million."

fields.headline: Reebok to launch drinks range
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Sportswear company Reebok is developing a range of drinks, reports Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Sportswear company Reebok is looking at extending its brand by developing a range of drinks.

Reebok International has signed a licensing deal with the Clearly Canadian Beverage Corporation to produce an "innovative" branded drink for the US, Canada and Caribbean markets.

The agreement lasts for nine years but CCBC would not give details of either the type of drink or the launch timescale.

The initiative fits in with Reebok's determination to capitalise on its reputation for quality sportswear by venturing into new business areas.

Last November it emerged the company was planning an assault on the European health and fitness club market and was looking at sites in Canary Wharf, London and other European capitals.

Reebok may well be planning to use its sports pedigree to target the fast-growing sports drink market dominated by brands such as Gatorade and Lucozade.

However, it is unlikely to launch a beer considering its TV advertising, which has highlighted the problems of giant beer bellies.

Rival sportswear firm Adidas has stretched its brand by launching a range of male grooming products.

Meanwhile Nike has set its stall on retail, opening a chain of the giant Nike Town outlets.

fields.headline: New Media Diary
fields.body:
 Amazon.co.uk finally got round to holding its staff Christmas party last week, two months after everyone had finally got the festivities out of their system. Coming just two weeks after the massive redundancies and cut-backs, staff were understandably sombre, particularly since the grapevine suggests further job cuts. Not even the salubrious Ascot racecourse surroundings could lift their spirits. Steve Frasier, the UK managing director, duly took to the stage to attempt to gee them up, only to end up leaving them feeling more dejected by the spin he put on the closure of the hub of Amazon's European operation in the Hague. One observer gave Diary the finer details: "The food was awful and the wine tasted like vinegar. Everyone looked and felt dejected because they were all forced to listen to his guff at a Christmas party in February in bloody Ascot on a Friday night." Staff would just like to extend their congratulations to Frasier for his impeccable timing.

 With senior Yahoo! executives jumping ship, its staff share-dumping sheet makes for interesting reading. The bets are on Heather Killen, senior vice-president of international, being the next to depart, following her aggressive shedding of options. Since April last year, Killen has reaped almost $70m from the sale of her staff options; last week's discharge alone added nearly $20m to her growing fortune. Nice. Let's face it, if you had millions in the bank would you really work your butt off to get Yahoo! through the forthcoming hard times? As they say at Yahoo!, go figure.

 Big it up for sharp thinking Mark McKeown, head of international content at Two Way TV, who dug himself out of a tricky situation last week. Faced with the conundrum of having to retrieve his only car keys from the house of a neighbour who had emigrated to Australia, after they were posted through the wrong letterbox, Mark did what any clever chap would do and broke down the door. No, seriously, he resorted to the ol' magnet on a string trick and hey presto, retrieved the key. No luck in retrieving the front of his stereo though (also posted through the letterbox) which will have to wait until the émigré returns.

 Speculation surrounds the sudden departure of Tim Jackson from American investment firm Carlyle. Fiendish gossips suggest he may be winging his way back to QXL (à la Steve Jobs returning to Apple), the company he started a few years back after being inspired by eBay. QXL is certainly not what it once was. Its shares are languishing at the 10p mark and not even Jackson, the Robin Hood of the internet, has the magic touch to perk up a company that analysts love to knock. Then again, the Steve Jobs-like move is just industry tittle-tattle and we all know how misinformed that can be.

 Amy Vickers is new media editor of mediatheguardian.com

fields.headline: Manics' anti-US preaching at Havana show brings Cuba to its feet
fields.trailText: Fidel Castro is not accustomed to being in the audience at the Teatro Karl Marx, the Havana auditorium where he once regaled spellbound citizens with speeches on revolutionary theory. But on Saturday night the 74-year-old maximum chieftook his seat among 5,000 rock fans to watch the Manic Street Preachers, the first major western artists to play a concert in Cuba for more than 20 years.
fields.body:
Fidel Castro is not accustomed to being in the audience at the Teatro Karl Marx, the Havana auditorium where he once regaled spellbound citizens with speeches on revolutionary theory. But on Saturday night the 74-year-old maximum chieftook his seat among 5,000 rock fans to watch the Manic Street Preachers, the first major western artists to play a concert in Cuba for more than 20 years.

He rose only for an ovation to the song Baby Elian - an anti-American tribute to Elian Gonzalez, the six-year-old victim last year of a tug-of-war between Havana and his relatives in the country the song calls "the devil's playground".

In a gesture the band said was "the greatest honour" of their lives, Castro went backstage for a chat before the 90-minute performance, which took place before a massive Cuban flag. Tickets cost the equivalent of 17p.

In 1979, the last time any big-name western musicians defied the US cultural and economic embargo of the island, Cubans with a taste for anything other than salsa and jazz had to make do with a visit from Billy Joel and Kris Kristofferson. For its part, Havana long condemned American and European rock and pop as decadent indulgences.

For the Manics, from Wales, Saturday's concert was an opportunity to take a stand against the commercialisation of popular culture.

"Cuba is an example that everything doesn't have to be Americanised," said the lead singer, James Dean Bradfield. Guitarist Nicky Wire insisted the visit was "not like a student Che Guevara sort of thing - it's just that Cuba for me is the last great symbol that really fights against the Americanisation of the world."

The visit had been negotiated thanks to the intervention of Neath MP Peter Hain, a Manics fan who first met the band during the campaign for a Welsh assembly and who used his contacts to convince the Cubans of their leftwing credentials. "They contacted me when I was at the Foreign Office and asked me whether I could help with a concert in Cuba," Mr Hain said yesterday.

But the distinction between acceptably radical western musicians and the rest seemed to be lost on young Cubans at the show. "It was really good," 20-year-old Michel Hernandez said."I hope this means more groups will come - like Oasis."

webTitle: NSPCC calls for young people's input about crime

fields.headline: NSPCC calls for young people's input about crime
fields.trailText: Children's charity the NSPCC has called for young people to be consulted about local crime reduction strategies to ensure they are safe in their own communities, after it found many schemes failed to address their fears. By David Batty
fields.body:
Children's charity the NSPCC has called for young people to be consulted about local crime reduction strategies to ensure they are safe in their own communities, after it found many schemes failed to address their fears.

The NSPCC carried out an audit of 89 crime and disorder strategies set up by the police and local authorities, which discovered that less than half (48%) involved child protection or victim support services.

Building Safer Communities for Children also found that just over a third (36%) of the strategies prioritised the increased safety of young people. Less than half (42%) prioritised children's fears, while only 11% tackled those fears.

Although 80% of strategies provide information on personal safety, health or citizenship information for young people, many concentrate exclusively on preventing young offending. This is despite the fact that children and young people are more likely to be the victims than the perpetrators of crime.

NSPCC chief executive Mary Marsh said: "This report shows that more action is needed to ensure that children and young people are safe in their communities and are consulted about their fears and needs."

The survey recommends that local authority partnerships should consult with young people of all ages and backgrounds, addressing their specific risks and fears. For example, while many strategies tackled hate crimes, such as racial and homophobic attacks, few were designed to help young people. Similarly only 36% of domestic violence initiatives were designed to help child victims.

Other recommendations included developing separate youth safety strategies, targeting schemes in areas where they are most at risk and appointing a co-ordinator to oversee crime reduction in the community.

Rob Hutchinson, chairman of the association of social services directors' children and families committee, said strategies were becoming more sophisticated and better at involving young people.

Mr Hutchinson, Portsmouth director of social services, said safe houses for children had been set up in the city after consulting local schools. "These are ordinary people's homes, which are regularly monitored by the police and social services, where children can go if they're in trouble or distress," he said.

The NSPCC report also identified several examples of good practice in local authority partnerships. Stockport council has established a corporate youth strategy to improve relations between young people and the police. This followed consultations in schools and youth groups, which found that young people were less likely to report crimes committed against them because they felt harassed by the police.

Steve Brown, manager of Stockport youth offending team, said: "We found they resented being moved on from bright areas at night, such as garages and shop windows, because they felt safe there. So we've tried to establish a greater tolerance between young people and adults by getting them to discuss their rights and responsibilities."

A spokesman for the Department for Education and Employment's children and young people's unit said the unit would be funding local partnerships to design crime reduction services for children and families.

"They should ensure play areas are safe and supervised, and provide special advisers to children in distress as a result of crime," he said.

Personal careers advisers on the DfEE's Connexions service, which will be piloted in April, would also be trained to deal with such issues, he added.

fields.headline: The mystery of the shrinking bank balance
fields.trailText: Michele Hanson: My mother wants to know what has happened to her life savings and how they're getting along, and she thinks, foolish innocent, that she can ring her local bank and someone will tell her.
fields.body:
Now that my mother is 94, with death lapping at her ankles, she is naturally getting into a bit of a flap over money and wills. She wants to know what has happened to her life savings and how they're getting along, and she thinks, foolish innocent, that she can ring her local bank and someone will tell her.

Oh ha ha! For starters the local branch doesn't even have its own phone number, only a central number. We phone, we wait, we press buttons, we get through, but all for nothing. They haven't the foggiest about investments. We must phone elsewhere - one number for ISAs, another for Tessas, another for these bonds, another for those bonds, until at last, exhausted and maddened by the phoning maze, my mother finds, tragically, that her savings are dwindling like a snowflake in a blast furnace.

How has this come about? When she moved here from Hove, her savings had to move with her, so we took advice, silly us, from the bank. But over the years, my mother has suspected that things were not going according to plan. So we wrote and told them what we wanted, but nothing happened. Why? Because they never received our letter, they swear it. And, deterred by the telephone nightmare, the monster queues in the local branch and the vicious, swarming traffic wardens who patrol around it, I have neglected to take my mother along there to investigate.

At last we are on their case. "Why has my mother's investment shrunk rather than grown over the years?" we ask. "Because you haven't left it in long enough," answers the bank cheerily.

Now the letters ISA are poison to us, we are in a molten fury and have arranged a meeting with a bevy of bank staff. Then we can give them a drubbing, tell them where to stick their ISAs, take out my mother's remaining pence, hide them under the mattress and never go near a bank again.

Meanwhile letters have been flooding in thanking my mother for buying more bonds. What bonds? She hasn't moved from her room or signed anything for weeks, and what could she buy them with anyway, now that the bank has left her with flumpence?

"Money makes money," my father used to say. Not if you put it in this bank, it doesn't.
