They haven't the foggiest about investments. We must phone elsewhere - one number for ISAs, another for Tessas, another for these bonds, another for those bonds, until at last, exhausted and maddened by the phoning maze, my mother finds, tragically, that her savings are dwindling like a snowflake in a blast furnace. How has this come about? When she moved here from Hove, her savings had to move with her, so we took advice, silly us, from the bank. But over the years, my mother has suspected that things were not going according to plan. So we wrote and told them what we wanted, but nothing happened. Why? Because they never received our letter, they swear it. And, deterred by the telephone nightmare, the monster queues in the local branch and the vicious, swarming traffic wardens who patrol around it, I have neglected to take my mother along there to investigate. At last we are on their case. "Why has my mother's investment shrunk rather than grown over the years?" we ask. "Because you haven't left it in long enough," answers the bank cheerily. Now the letters ISA are poison to us, we are in a molten fury and have arranged a meeting with a bevy of bank staff. Then we can give them a drubbing, tell them where to stick their ISAs, take out my mother's remaining pence, hide them under the mattress and never go near a bank again. Meanwhile letters have been flooding in thanking my mother for buying more bonds. What bonds? She hasn't moved from her room or signed anything for weeks, and what could she buy them with anyway, now that the bank has left her with flumpence? "Money makes money," my father used to say. Not if you put it in this bank, it doesn't.

webTitle: Comment: Tony Blair needs to kick the Ali habit

fields.headline: Tony Blair needs to kick the Ali habit
fields.standfirst:
Alastair Campbell's outburst last week was dangerous and boorish

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Alastair Campbell's outburst last week was dangerous and boorish.
fields.body:
Alastair Campbell will not willingly change his ways. Indeed Saturday's public rebuke - added by John Prescott and David Blunkett to the private criticisms which have bombarded the Labour leadership all week - may well provoke him into more excesses. He is that sort of man. Had he not been virtually out of control, he would not have spoken of "bog standard" comprehensive schools in the first place. So he will continue to damage the government's prospects and reputation until Tony Blair tells him to moderate his habits or go. The mystery is why the ultimatum is so delayed.

It is possible to argue that a second Labour victory is now so certain that there is no point in making a fuss every time that Campbell does or says something that reduces the next parliamentary majority by half a dozen seats. But Tony Blair is far too cautious to take re-election for granted. And he is sensible enough to know that success during the next five years - particularly in the Euro referendum - depends on the esteem in which he is held. Obvious reliance on Campbell can only diminish him.

Campbell has had a bad month. The cabinet secretary's complaint that he behaved in a way which was unbecoming to a civil servant was a matter of little consequence. It gave William Hague a moment's pleasure and we should not begrudge so small a consolation to a man who is in the terminal stage of his political career. The vicious briefing against Peter Mandelson - which kept the Hinduja affair on the boil when it should have been cooled down - was a major misjudgment. But half the cabinet was behaving in the same way. So it is hard to single out Campbell for censure - even though briefing against cabinet ministers is a bad habit for a Whitehall functionary to acquire.

Those incidents were just minor symptoms of the Campbell disease. A more virulent attack was diagnosed during the Downing Street meeting which ended Peter Mandelson's career. According to reports - confirmed, I am assured, by one of the participants - while the prime minister of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland agonised about the future of one of Her Majesty's principal secretaries of state, the Downing Street press secretary rushed in to complain about the time that the decision was taking. Then he sat, drumming his fingers on the table. If Bernard Ingham had behaved like that with Margaret Thatcher, she would have drummed his head against the wall.

Had Tony Blair reacted in the same way, he might have been spared the humiliation of pretending that he endorsed both the judgment and language of Campbell's "bog standard" comprehensive comment. Pretence it was. For the prime minister is no more a vulgarian than he is a socialist. Having taken so much trouble to reingratiate himself with teachers - in October he called them "the best in the world" - he must have been infuriated to realise that his work was being undone by one loutish phrase. By disowning the expression, Prescott and Blunkett have increased the embarrassment. They have done what Tony Blair seemed afraid to do.

During the last couple of days, I have tried to speak to Campbell in the hope that he would at lease explain the etymology of his boorish language. Was "bog standard" a phrase which suddenly came to mind, or was it carefully constructed to accommodate the lowest common denominator of politics? It certainly encouraged the Sun to support Labour's new education policy. But it also alienated several hundred thousand teachers who heroically work in the schools at which they believe the metaphor was directed. No doubt the press secretary helped the prime minister draft yesterday's speech. It warned against apathetic abstention. The general election turnout is in jeopardy less because of apathy than as a result of the New Labour crude insensitivity which Campbell represents.

Campbell - boorish behaviour apart - continually commits the sin for which no press officer can be forgiven. Instead of lurking in the background, he has become a celebrity in his own right. He has achieved that status by displaying characteristics which no civilised person would celebrate. But he only intensifies the problem. Since he did not return my calls, I can only speculate about his recent choice of language. But I put it down to the self-indulgent desire to represent himself as a member of the laddish tendency. There are no votes in that.

Unfortunately, although in his more brutal moments he may act independently of the prime minister, the prime minister is clearly not independent of him. Or so, at least it seems to the voting public. Indeed, the combination of the Campbell ego and media caricature has made Tony Blair look like his press secretary's prisoner. For his own sake, the prime minister needs to break out. The slogan for the campaign which precedes the general election should be Free the Downing Street One.

webTitle: G2: Mark Lawson reviews TV programmes

fields.headline: Gold rings glinting in the dung-heap
fields.standfirst: With blackly comic portraits of TV magicians, dissections of British sociology, and Freudian insights into Hitler, the week ahead is a tribute to the true diversity of British television
fields.trailText: With blackly comic portraits of TV magicians, dissections of British sociology, and Freudian insights into Hitler, the week ahead is a tribute to the true diversity of British television.
fields.body:
Among the historical developments considered in the first episode of BBC2's Middle Classes: Their Rise And Sprawl is the opening of the first department stores. Previously, shops had mainly served known customers, producing the goods from drawers.

The range of documentaries with which Middle Classes competes in its debut week reminds us of the way in which television is the department store of culture, encouraging us to pick up things we didn't know we wanted but which we take because we find them on the way to something else.

It would be an unusually catholic reader of books who got through in the same week a work of popular sociology, a biography of the magician Paul Daniels and a study of Hitler's sexuality and yet the keen viewer of factual television - the kind of person who mainly watches BBC2 and Channel 4 - is offered this selection of subjects in the space of a few days, as the schedules that premiere the Middle Classes also include When Louis Met Paul And Debbie, in which Louis Theroux spends time with Paul Daniels, and Nazi Women, a psychological assessment of Hitler through the females in his life.

There was once a television series called How Do They Do That? and, watching Louis Theroux's documentary profiles of celebrities, it occurs to you that they might be titled: Why Did They Do That? Unless Theroux is a systematic blackmailer who carries round a suitcase of pictures of famous people doing it with sheep, it's hard to see why people agree to be profiled by him.

Theroux seems drawn to slightly naff northern entertainers who hint at an inner weirdness or bleakness behind frenetic stage patter. Having kippered Sir Jimmy Savile last year, he has now won admission to Paul Daniels and his former assistant, Debbie McGee. His TV series cancelled by the BBC - news which Daniels claims to have heard first from a "dress designer at a party" - the magician is now living out a sitcom version of the opera scenes in Citizen Kane, funding Debbie's ambitions to be a choreographer with a national tour of her ballet company. The programme is given perfect dramatic shape when, with Debbie's dance tour struggling, Daniels is forced to take his wand out of storage, promoting his return with a painfully reluctant appearance on Ready, Steady, Cook.

McGee reveals in passing that wizards' female sidekicks are known as "box jumpers" because, like Peter Mandelson, they're always bouncing out of a cabinet. Theroux, ungainly and gauche, still gives the impression of someone who has unexpectedly jumped into the box. We haven't yet seen enough of him to know whether his manner - ingratiation mixed with stings - is natural or calculated, but it allows him questions and answers a Parkinson could never get. At one point Louis asks Debbie whether Paul kept his wig on in bed.

Confirming his memoir confession of having slept with 300 women in the past, Daniels, sullenly sucking a toffee in his dressing room before the TV comeback, mutters that his sexual liberty ended because of "herpes and Aids and all that". Theroux prompts: "And Debbie." Daniels' answer - "Oh, yeah. Debbie" - is the kind of thing that could get a magician cut in half by his box-jumper. Taken together, Theroux's studies of Savile and Daniels are the best accounts of the gnawing emptiness of the performer since John Osborne's The Entertainer.

Having viewed that programme with a delighted smirk, it's necessary to straighten the face for Middle Classes. But Rachel Bell's series is thoughtful and informed, smoothly mixing talking egg-heads with personal narratives to show how the obsessions of the modern middle classes - houses, shops, art galleries, their children's schooling - were spawned in Victorian times.

What's most impressive about Middle Classes is that it feels like fresh territory, a subject whose moment has come. In contrast, Channel 4's Nazi Women feels like an answer to the question, Is there anything about the second world war we haven't done yet? Investigating the possibility that Hitler's psychopathy was sexual, the series is guilty of backwards rationalisation, so that banalities are emphasised because of the person we're talking about. "The 16-year-old Hitler was obsessed by his self-image," it's revealed. Poor old Poland. If that was the root of Hitler's problem, there are going to be millions of adolescent boys invading it.

Yet, even if some of the choices are spoiled, it's good to have them. Aging magicians, English social history and Freudian biography, all between Monday and Friday. These swift shifts of subject and tone have been TV's blessing, but also its nemesis.

The strength of eclectic scheduling was that many viewers were introduced to subjects they would not have considered. The "hammocking" theory - difficult programmes hung between easy ones - lies deep in TV's history. But the effect was to lower the medium's reputation because the viewer was made aware of both the trash and the treasures. In contrast, the cinema or theatre-goer can, through careful selection of events, maintain the illusion that their art form maintains high standards.

But the variety of this week's factual films should be celebrated because the age of such strenuous diversity is ending. The future is targeted channels: biographies of Paul Daniels on Entertainment, the middle classes and Eva Braun on History. It's neater but also weaker, because the thrill of television is in its messiness, the gold rings glinting in the dung-heap.

 Middle Classes: Friday, 9pm, BBC2; Nazi Women: tonight, 9pm, Channel 4; When Louis Met Paul And Debbie: Tuesday, 9pm, BBC2.

webTitle: MPs cast doubt on legality of air strikes

fields.headline: MPs cast doubt on legality of air strikes
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Iraq
Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: The government's insistence that the US and British air strikes against Iraq are justified under international law is less firmly endorsed in Whitehall than ministers admit publicly, informed sources said last night.
fields.body:
The government's insistence that the US and British air strikes against Iraq are justified under international law is less firmly endorsed in Whitehall than ministers admit publicly, informed sources said last night.

Private doubts about the legal basis of the no-fly zones over Iraq resurfaced as angry Labour MPs, MEPs and union leaders gave Tony Blair clear signals that they will be much more sceptical about intimate military cooperation with Washington now that a Republican administration is back in power - even though a general election is just weeks away.

In public Mr Blair and his senior colleagues argue that the threat to the west from "rogue states" like Iraq is real and leave Britain and the US "perfectly entitled to deter aggression" as the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, put it.

Under the Tories, successive legal advisers, including Lord Williams of Mostyn, the attorney-general, have reassured ministers that the zones are sanctioned by international law.

However authoritative sources said last night: "They are less confident in private".

Labour's rank and file is also more sceptical. Bill Morris, leader of the TGWU union, and Glenys Kinnock MEP expressed doubts about Friday night's bombings and the 10-year policy of sanctions which have failed to bring Saddam Hussein to heel.

George Galloway, the arabist Labour MP, flew to Baghdad and likened Friday's attack to "Hitler marching into Czechoslovakia" in 1939.

"What the British and American governments are doing is reckless, lawless and murderous. If they are not already working for Saddam Hussein then they might as well be because for every bomb that is dropped, Saddam is getting stronger," the Glasgow Kelvin MP said.

More than 2,000 people - including Iraq's deputy foreign minister, Nabil Najim - protested against the bombings in Baghdad and at least 1,000 other protesters gathered near the offices of the ruling al-Ba'ath party.

"This dangerous aggression shows how much the Americans and Britons hate Iraqis and do not respect any international law," Mr Najim told the demonstrators. "This aggression must be condemned."

Only a handful of countries have joined that condemnation, said the foreign secretary, Robin Cook.

Mr Blair and Mr Cook led a platoon of ministers in defending the US-UK action as necessary to protect their air sorties from anti-aircraft attack by Saddam's forces - and thereby to save the Kurds of northern Iraq and the southern Shi'ites from his murderous revenge.

That is the legal basis which ministers invoke when challenged: the right under international law to intervene to prevent a humanitarian catastrophe like the use of chemical weapons to kill 5,000 Kurdish villagers in the 1980s when the west still tilted towards Saddam in his war with Iran.

It was also the legal basis used to justify the 1999 Kosovo intervention. But, the no-fly zones are not specifically sanctioned by any UN security council resolution. Four days before Mr Blair flies into Washington to meet President, George Bush, it emerged that Friday air strikes were cleared by both leaders after requests from military commanders, the RAF as much as the USAF.

They were increasingly worried about threats to their aircraft posed by new Iraqi radar and missile systems, defence sources explained. Their requests were passed up the chain of command and were focused on Iraq's new integrated air defence system, including a growing number of SA-6 surface-to-air missiles supplied, according to intelligence sources, by Serbia and Ukraine.

webTitle: Court could consign Fiji to apartheid

fields.headline: Court could consign Fiji to apartheid
fields.standfirst:
A case opens today that will decide if minority rights survive

Special report: the Fiji coup
fields.trailText: A groundbreaking constitutional case opens in Fiji today which will decide the legality of a regime widely criticised for quashing democracy and oppressing its ethnic Indian citizens after the coup by the businessman George Speight last year.
fields.body:
A groundbreaking constitutional case opens in Fiji today which will decide the legality of a regime widely criticised for quashing democracy and oppressing its ethnic Indian citizens after the coup by the businessman George Speight last year.

Two leading British barristers will battle it out in the courtroom in the capital, Suva, where the security forces are preparing for potential civil unrest when the court gives its ruling.

Nicholas Blake QC, a member of the recently formed Matrix Chambers in London, will represent the interim regime of Laisenia Qarase, put in power by the military and indigenous chiefs after the coup last May.

Geoffrey Robertson QC will act for an Indo-Fijian farmer, Chandrika Prasad, who took this interim government to court and won a ruling that its suspension of the constitution - which upheld the rights of the Indian minority as well as those of indigenous Fijians - was illegal.

On Mr Prasad's shoulders when he walks into the courtroom this morning is a case that could affect the stability of his country. But beyond that, undemocratic regimes across the world will be watching what steps the rest of the international community takes towards Fiji, should this ruling go against Mr Prasad.

If the constitution is overturned, international observers believe, it will herald apartheid-like conditions in a country with undeniable racial tensions. A new wave of Indian Fijians has already emigrated since the May coup.

One observer said the outcome would have "long-term and far-reaching signal effects, in the South Pacific and beyond, for government respect for the rule of law, human rights and the independence of the judiciary".

Some human rights activists in Britain have criticised the Matrix Chambers, in which Cherie Booth QC is a partner, for taking on a case which sets Fiji's unelected and racially biased interim regime against a poor sugar farmer.

The appeal has been described by Amnesty International as rattling the fundamentals of human rights, being a struggle between the rule of law and rule by force.

The Matrix Chambers described itself as one of the top human rights practices when it was formed last year. Its fee from the Fijian government for the task of challenging last year's decision upholding the multiracial constitution is estimated to be £100,000.

An Amnesty International spokesman said: "The fundamental principles of human rights and democracy will be on trial and this will be a landmark human rights case.

"Amnesty is concerned about the safety of Chandrika Prasad and hundreds of other Indo-Fijians, because of recent threats by coup supporters, should the administration's appeal be rejected by the courts."

The previous constitution was torn up after Mr Speight, a disgruntled Fijian business man, staged his coup on May 19 last year. He and his gang stormed the parliament building in Suva and took hostage dozens of MPs - including Fiji's first ethnic Indian prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, and his cabinet.

Campaigning to make indigenous Fijians paramount, he and his henchmen demanded the scrapping of the multiracial constitution and the dismissal of the democratically elected Mr Chaudhry The army agreed, temporarily took control, and put the interim administration in place.

The Indian Fijians, whose forebears were brought to the islands by British colonialists more than a century ago, make up 44% of the population, although 67,000 fled overseas after two coups in 1987. Indigenous Fijians make up 51%.

After the coup, the divisions between the ethnic groups worsened. Chandrika Prasad's family suffered a series of racist attacks and threats. His home was looted by coup rebels and their sympathisers.

Mr Prasad applied to the high court, saying his human rights had been violated, and a high court judge, Anthony Gates, ruled that the 1997 constitution was valid and the Qarase administration illegal.

The current government has said it will take no notice of that court judgment, but clearly expects trouble. Lieutenant-Colonel Henry Manulevu has warned that the army is ready to clamp down on any insurrection.

"There will be a lot of snap checkpoints and roadblocks," he said, adding that the army was aware of rumours that there would be disturbances when the hearing begins today.

A local democracy group, Fiji First, supported by trade unions and a number of non-governmental organisations, has called on workers to stay at home today in protest at the Mr Chaudhry's overthrow.

Last night Nick Martin, the chief executive of Matrix, defended the decision to take on the case.

"Matrix is a group of barristers who are all self-employed individuals. We have a commitment to represent governments and individuals on both sides of cases. We are committed to practice diversity."

The Fiji case original went to Clare Montgomery QC, of Matrix, who represented General Augusto Pinochet when Spain sought his extradition from Britain. Two leading British barristers will battle it out in the courtroom in the capital, Suva, where the security forces are preparing for potential civil unrest when the court gives its ruling. Nicholas Blake QC, a member of the recently formed Matrix Chambers in London, will represent the interim regime of Laisenia Qarase, put in power by the military and indigenous chiefs after the coup last May. Geoffrey Robertson QC will act for an Indo-Fijian farmer, Chandrika Prasad, who took this interim government to court and won a ruling that its suspension of the constitution - which upheld the rights of the Indian minority as well as those of indigenous Fijians - was illegal. If the constitution is overturned, international observers believe, it will herald apartheid-like conditions in a country with undeniable racial tensions. A new wave of Indian Fijians has already emigrated since the May coup. webTitle: US backs plan for Russia to import nuclear waste

fields.headline: US backs plan for Russia to import nuclear waste
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Environmentalists are due to protest in Moscow today against a change in Russian law to allow the importation of nuclear waste.
fields.body:
Environmentalists are due to protest in Moscow today against a change in Russian law to allow the importation of nuclear waste. The protest comes as a leaked document outlines US-backed plans for shipping spent nuclear fuel from eight Taiwanese reactors to Russia for disposal.

The lower house of parliament, the duma, is due to debate the second reading of a bill to end Russia's long-standing ban on the importation of nuclear waste.

Minatom, the state nuclear company sponsoring the bill, believes it can earn £15bn by importing waste from overseas.

The advanced stage of the plans became apparent at the weekend when a US energy department document was leaked to the anti-nuclear organisation Ecodefence in Moscow.

The report, "Foreign Spent Fuel Storage and Geologic Disposal in Russia", produced by the department and the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, outlines the plan for shipping Taiwanese nuclear waste to Russia.

The US involvement in the scheme stems from the control Washington exercises over nuclear proliferation. Spent fuel can be reprocessed and used for nuclear weapons, so, from the building of the first reactors in Taiwan, the US has insisted on controlling the disposal route for the nuclear waste if any of the material originated in America, as much of it does.

This has proved an embarrassment to Washington, since until now no country has been willing to take another's spent nuclear fuel, least of all America. But the Russians have long seen a business opportunity in the vast empty spaces of its eastern provinces.

In December 1998 the Russian nuclear minister, Yevgeny Adamov, wrote to the then US energy secretary, Bill Richardson, asking if the US would be interested in sending some of its high-level waste to Russia for storage or reprocessing.

At the time Mr Richardson replied that the US was not interested.

Information was eaked to the press that Minatom was holding talks with Germany and Switzerland regarding shipments of radioactive waste to Russia, but nothing appeared to come of this. To drum up support in Russia, Minatom said that provinces prepared to accept waste would get a share of the money.

The energy department report concerns the transportation of 7,500 tonnes of spent fuel from eight Taiwanese reactors. The fuel will be shipped by sea to the Russian far eastern ports of Vanino and Vladivostok and then by rail to Krasnoyarsk in Siberia.

It says the spent fuel must leave Taiwan for Russia in 2007, and will be stored until 2020, when a repository built near the Mayak nuclear reprocessing plant will start to operate.

Outlining the US's role as the main negotiator, the report says: "As a minimum, the US would have to enter into agreements with Taiwan and Russia that provide for successful implementation of the programme.

"This will involve many complex issues and interested government agencies as well as non-governmental organisations. Due to the unique aspects of the relationship between Taiwan and the US, the coordination of technical activities in this programme requires careful management."

This provoked a strong reaction from Vladimir Slivyak, co-chairman of Ecodefence, which released the document.

"The US energy department and the American nuclear industry are looking to set up an international radioactive toilet in Russia," he said.

"In polls 93,5% of Russians are strongly opposed to the nuclear waste import proposed by the Russian nuclear industry.

"It's not just a fight against nuclear waste import, but a fight for establishing democracy and strong civil society in Russia."

Environmental activists and the liberal party Yabloko are organising today's protest outside parliament.

The duma gave a first reading to the bill on December 21. The second reading is due on Thursday.

The Russian nuclear industry could earn an estimated $20bn (£13bn) over the next 10 years if the ban is lifted and it is allowed to import 20,000 tonnes of spent nuclear fuel from abroad, officials said.

But environmentalists claim that adding more to the 14,000 tonnes of Russian nuclear waste already stored near its nuclear reactors could bring an ecological disaster.

fields.headline: Worries over anti-smoking drug dismissed
fields.standfirst: Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: The government last night sought to reassure users of the new anti-smoking drug Zyban after it emerged that 18 Britons had died after taking it.
fields.body:
The government last night sought to reassure users of the new anti-smoking drug Zyban after it emerged that 18 Britons had died after taking it.

The deaths, among more than 270,000 people prescribed the drug, have all occurred over the eight months since the nicotine addiction treatment was launched in June last year.

The Department of Health is also believed to have received notice from GPs of 3,450 other patients suffering possible side-effects, including insomnia, chest pains, dry mouth, rashes, nausea and depression.

Officials said there would be continued close monitoring of Zyban's safety record, as already required through the reporting of suspected adverse reactions to new treatments, but gave no indication that extra measures were needed.

The manufacturers, GlaxoSmithKline, also insisted there was no indication the drug was unsafe and it could play a big part in reducing the 120,000-a-year death rates from smoking-related diseases in Britain.

Zyban seeks to regulate chemicals in the brain thought to be linked to nicotine addiction and its makers last night said that its main ingredient bupropion) was used in 5m anti-smoking treatments worldwide. It was also used in a different formula by 10m people, though not in Britain, as an antidepressant.

Advice by the government's medical controls agency (MCA) to doctors warns them not to prescribe it to patients with a record of seizures or epileptic fits, where there is thought to be a risk affecting one in every 1,000 patients.

It says the contribution of Zyban to any deaths is unproven and suspected reactions "are not necessarily caused by the drug and may relate to other factors such as nicotine withdrawal, other illnesses or other medicines taken concurrently".

The health department added yesterday: "It should be noted that patients may be required to stop smoking because of underlying diseases and these may well explain some of the reported deaths of patients taking Zyban."

Any widely prescribed drug would have a high number of reports from GPs about suspect reactions.

The Mail on Sunday yesterday reported that among the 18 who had died, four had heart attacks, two committed suicide, four died from brain disorders and one had acute asthma. A coroner in Sunderland last week referred to the MCA the case of Alan Ridley, a 46-year-old father of four, who died two days after starting a course of Zyban. An open verdict was recorded at the inquest.

GlaxoSmithKline said: "Zyban is generally well tolerated ... and there is no evidence of increased risk associated with the use of this medicine." The reports by GPs had raised no additional safety issues.

Manchester GP Chris Steele, who has prescribed the drug for 400 patients, said the 270,000 patients who had used Zyban by the end of December may now have risen to nearly a third of a million.

"These are people at high risk of serious events like heart attacks or strokes happening anyway because of smoking. Zyban is not a miracle cure but one in three users will stop smoking and still not be smoking in a year. That is twice as effective as a nicotine patch."

Patients on Zyban are usually prescribed one tablet for the first few days of their course and then go on to two tablets, but periods of treatment should not last more than nine weeks.

Dr Steele said: "If a patient is disturbed by any side-effects, I have reduced them from two tablets a day to one a day, and they have continued their course of medication."

webTitle: Blair wants register of drug dealers

fields.headline: Blair wants register of drug dealers
fields.standfirst:
Special report: election countdown
Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday increased the political momentum towards the next general election with a speech to the Labour party's spring conference which heralded a crack down on drug dealers and offered a new deal for working fathers.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday increased the political momentum towards the next general election with a speech to the Labour party's spring conference which heralded a crack down on drug dealers and offered a new deal for working fathers.

In a call to arms to 3,000 party activists in Glasgow, the prime minister claimed New Labour had grown up in office and that Britain was on the brink of "the biggest progressive political advance for a century".

With one eye on election day - which many political observers believe will fall on May 3 - he called on party workers to go out to the country with heads held high, spelling out the message of the government's successes.

"Whenever this fight comes, go into it with confidence, go into it knowing we have won the intellectual and political debate in this country," he said.

As if to kickstart activists he gave them a series of new policies to sell to families, the unemployed and announced a further crackdown on crime.

Eyecatching among the raft of measures was a drugs register which all convicted dealers will be forced to sign.

Like the paedophile register, it would be open only to police. Anyone freed from jail and liable to deal in drugs would go on the register so that unusual bank transactions and changes of address could be monitored.

Mr Blair revealed further "next steps" manifesto policies, including paid paternity leave, likely to be worth £62 for two weeks. The proposal was attacked as a new burden on business by the Institute of Directors, but Labour insisted the reform is an example of how investment in human capital will increase British productivity in the long term.

Mr Blair also promised to extend his "tough love" welfare reforms by making unemployment benefit conditional on the unemployed not just taking up a general training scheme but also attending reading, writing and basic maths courses. More than 7m adults are estimated to lack basic literary skills.

Mr Blair also effectively ruled out generalised tax cuts in the March budget saying he wanted tax breaks that help children, "whatever the position of their parents".

He said: "I believe in marriage but I also believe that the widow or the single mother whose husband has deserted her cannot be discriminated against for something not their fault." Senior Labour MPs left Glasgow predicting a commons majority of more than 100 with some urging Mr Blair to call the election in April. Privately some senior Labour ministers favour a four-week campaign, rather than the expected three, believing it will expose the tensions in Conservative ranks.

Much of Mr Blair's speech was devoted to energising a rank and file that has often respected, rather than loved the government. He told them: "I take pride in the fact that this is the first Labour government in history where the party in the country and in government have stayed together and seen this thing through together."

People had joined Labour to change society and "no longer to pass resolutions across the corners of a room at one another."

He urged the conference to realise "this could indeed be the 21st century of progressive politics". All over the world, he claimed, policies of economy and society were no longer in conflict. Social justice, as well as investment in human capital were now what drove economies forward. "Show that we believe in ourselves and then I tell you this country will show confidence in us."

Mr Blair derided William Hague as the "only political leader in history who has his opinions delivered to him by the paper boy. We are the practical party, the others now are the ideologues and extremists that have atrophied and gone off to the right."

Last night the Conservatives branded the paternity leave measure as a "transparent election ploy" because no introduction date has been announced, adding that it will create a "red tape burden" for small businesses.

The TUC welcomed the announcement saying: "We welcome it and obviously hope it happens sooner rather than later."

The move would bring Britain in line with many other European nations which have statutory paternity leave. In Austria new fathers enjoy 10 days paid paternity leave. Fathers in Belgium get three days fully-paid leave in the private sector and four in the public sector.

The announcement comes only days after Mr Blair met leaders of industry where he was pressed to reduce red tape which they claim is strangling business.

A British Chambers of Commerce spokesman said: "We feel it is somewhat schizophrenic of the government to be encouraging businesses to make productivity gains while at the same time creating barriers to such productivity gains."

Tory trade and industry spokesman David Heathcoat-Amory said: "The government is holding out the prospect of goodies without confirming a date for legislation.

"If this move follows past practice, the associated burden of paperwork and red tape burden will, in practice, fall on business, in particular small firms."

webTitle: Two women are questioned by Lawrence police

fields.headline: Two women are questioned by Lawrence police
fields.standfirst: Special report: Stephen Lawrence
fields.trailText: Detectives investigating the murder of Stephen Lawrence have ratcheted up the pressure on those they suspect have knowledge of the crime by arresting two women on suspicion of attempting to pervert the course of justice.
fields.body:
Detectives investigating the murder of Stephen Lawrence have ratcheted up the pressure on those they suspect have knowledge of the crime by arresting two women on suspicion of attempting to pervert the course of justice.

The arrests were made on Friday and followed dawn raids on two houses in south-east London, close to the scene where the black teenager was stabbed by a race hate gang on April 22, 1993.

Police believe the women, both 25, could hold crucial information about the identities of the gang.

Both women had previously been interviewed as witnesses and were arrested after detectives compared their statements to those made by other witnesses.

The two women were questioned at separate police stations and then released on bail until next month while detectives hunt for further evidence. Last week's arrests are the first major activity that has become public for almost a year by the Scotland Yard squad set up to solve one of the highest-profile murders in recent years. In March last year two men were arrested on suspicion of murder, but later released.

In a statement Scotland Yard said: "Information continues to come in to the investigation team eight years after the murder occurred. Witness appeals and intelligence gathering over the past year have proved very helpful to detectives.

"People who have not spoken to us previously are now coming forward. We would encourage anyone who does have information to come and see us before we come to see them."

Detectives are not ruling out more arrests as they seek to right some of the errors made by the first squad to handle the case.

fields.headline: Appeal for kidnap Briton
fields.standfirst: Rebel group suspected of holding engineer in Bangladesh
fields.trailText: Rebel group suspected of holding engineer in Bangladesh.
fields.body:
The father of a British engineer kidnapped and held to ransom in Bangladesh appealed yesterday to his captors to release him without harm.

"They may have political problems they want to address, but there's got to be a more peaceful way to do this," said Alfred Selby as he waited for the results of diplomatic efforts to free Tim, 28, who was seized at gunpoint on Friday. A spokesman for the British high commission in Dhaka said the kidnappers had demanded £1.2m for Mr Selby's freedom. He and two Danish citizens were in a group driving in the Chittagong hill tracts region in the south-east of Bangladesh.

The men were kidnapped at Guniapara, near Rangamati, about 240 miles from Dhaka, and security forces believe they have been taken into the jungle. Bangladeshi officials suspect a small group of former Shanti Bahini rebels, who opposed a 1997 peace deal with the government.

Mr Selby was in Bangladesh on a road surveying trip for the Danish company, Kampsax. He had been seconded to the company by his employers, Bratby, Ross and Silcocks, a firm of consultants based in Newcastle upon Tyne.

Another Briton, David Weston, and the group's Bangladeshi driver were also abducted but were later released unharmed.

A Foreign Office spokesman said yesterday that British and Danish officials had travelled to the area of the kidnap and were keeping close contact with Mr Selby's family. "We are doing everything we can in cooperation with the Danes and the Bangladeshi authorities to secure Mr Selby's release," he added.

Mr Selby's father, from Oldham, Greater Manchester, said he had been told that embassy staff were due to meet Bangladeshi ministers.

"Everybody is stressing the need for a peaceful resolution to the conflict," he said. "What they don't want is for soldiers to go in with all guns blazing... If I could speak to the kidnappers, I would ask them just to let him go."

Tim Selby's brother Jon added: "Tim has travelled all around the world and has been to Bangladesh once before, about two years ago. He has also worked in Armenia... so he is fairly worldly-wise about the dangers. But you cannot plan for anything like this. Knowing the sort of bloke he is, he wouldn't have walked in there with his eyes shut."

"They may have political problems they want to address, but there's got to be a more peaceful way to do this," said Alfred Selby as he waited for the results of diplomatic efforts to free Tim, 28, who was seized at gunpoint on Friday. A spokesman for the British high commission in Dhaka said the kidnappers had demanded £1.2m for Mr Selby's freedom. He and two Danish citizens were in a group driving in the Chittagong hill tracts region in the south-east of Bangladesh. The men were kidnapped at Guniapara, near Rangamati, about 240 miles from Dhaka, and security forces believe they have been taken into the jungle. Bangladeshi officials suspect a small group of former Shanti Bahini rebels, who opposed a 1997 peace deal with the government. Mr Selby was in Bangladesh on a road surveying trip for the Danish company, Kampsax. He had been seconded to the company by his employers, Bratby, Ross and Silcocks, a firm of consultants based in Newcastle upon Tyne. Another Briton, David Weston, and the group's Bangladeshi driver were also abducted but were later released unharmed. A Foreign Office spokesman said yesterday that British and Danish officials had travelled to the area of the kidnap and were keeping close contact with Mr Selby's family. "We are doing everything we can in cooperation with the Danes and the Bangladeshi authorities to secure Mr Selby's release," he added. Mr Selby's father, from Oldham, Greater Manchester, said he had been told that embassy staff were due to meet Bangladeshi ministers. "Everybody is stressing the need for a peaceful resolution to the conflict," he said. "What they don't want is for soldiers to go in with all guns blazing... If I could speak to the kidnappers, I would ask them just to let him go." Tim Selby's brother Jon added: "Tim has travelled all around the world and has been to Bangladesh once before, about two years ago. He has also worked in Armenia... so he is fairly worldly-wise about the dangers. But you cannot plan for anything like this. Knowing the sort of bloke he is, he wouldn't have walked in there with his eyes shut."

fields.headline: Railtrack 'nearly bankrupt'
fields.standfirst:
Plea for £2bn rescue draws accusation of incompetence

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack was last night said to be facing bankruptcy amid allegations by the rail industry regulator that it was incapable of managing its business.
fields.body:
Railtrack was last night said to be facing bankruptcy amid allegations by the rail industry regulator that it was incapable of managing its business.

The charge from the strategic rail authority (SRA) came as Railtrack confirmed that it had approached the government for an extra £2bn to ease its cash crisis, caused mainly by the increasingly heavy burden resulting from the Hatfield rail crash.

Senior sources in the authority, the government's strategy arm for the industry, said: "Railtrack is close to bankruptcy. It cannot survive as it is without the injection of further government money."

Sir Alastair Morton, the SRA's chairman, has ordered a halt to any further funding for rail maintenance because it is appalled at the way Railtrack is managing the network. His decision has been backed by the SRA's board.

He is arguing that Railtrack's funding should be separated into maintenance and enhancement, and that closer vigilance will have to be exercised by Railtrack on how it spends its money. Other companies may be brought in to carry out Railtrack work.

A senior industry source said that Railtrack could only get extra funding from the government or the rail regulator, but that either would have to come out of the same pot through the Treasury. Or Railtrack could be sold off to the international infrastructure company, Bechtel, if ministers were not prepared to take it back into state ownership.

The sources said the government still appeared reluctant to take any action against Railtrack until after the election. Ministers are relying on an imminent shake-up of the company, starting with the appointment of a new chairman by the end of the month.

One of the more radical changes being canvassed is a further realignment of the railway into the old divisions of British Rail. This, it is argued, might control the spread of subcontractors and help the train operating companies to run better services.

Railtrack's admission that the cost of modernising the east coast main line from London to Scotland could double from £1.9bn to £3.8bn has astonished both the SRA and ministers. Railtrack says it is only a feasibility study but it has stopped the SRA awarding a new franchise for the second fast mainline on the route.

Railtrack's continuing problems have obscured the increasingly difficult position of the SRA and its lack of leadership.

Failure by the SRA to come up with any strategy for the industry or to award new franchises is putting pressure on Sir Alastair and Mike Grant, his franchising director.

Both are at odds with the government on the award of the east coast franchise. The two final bidders are Great North Eastern Railway and Stagecoach-Virgin. Sir Richard Branson, Virgin's chairman, will seek a judicial review if his company loses the bid and it goes to GNER, the company favoured by Sir Alastair. Sir Richard says his bid is better value for money and would save the government £1.5bn.

Rail industry sources said last night that there could be resignations from the SRA which would be bad for the government in the lead up to the election.

Mr Grant's position, they say, is increasingly threatened.

webTitle: Guardian writers in line for awards

fields.headline: Guardian writers in line for awards
fields.trailText: Seven Guardian journalists have been nominated for this year's British Press Awards, the annual honours ceremony organised by the Press Gazette.
fields.body:
Seven Guardian journalists have been nominated for this year's British Press Awards, the annual honours ceremony organised by the Press Gazette.

 Critic of the year - Peter Bradshaw

 Online journalist - Amy Vickers

 Business journalist - Paul Murphy

 Feature writer - Maggie O'Kane

 Young journalist - Emma Brockes

 Columnist - Francis Wheen

Financial journalist - Jill Treanor

More than 80 judges will choose the final winners for the dinner on March 21.

The nominations come at a time of continued circulation growth for the Guardian. January's audited figures show the Guardian selling 410,152 copies a day - up nearly 6% month on month.

Full price sales for January 2001 represent 87.1% of the overall ABC figure, which is still comfortably the highest percentage of any broadsheet daily.

webTitle: Mugabe steps up assault on press and opposition leaders

fields.headline: Mugabe steps up assault on press and opposition leaders
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: The Zimbabwean government has intensified its assault on opposition and dissent with moves to bar the leading challenger to Robert Mugabe from the next presidential election, new threats to kill white farmers and the expulsion of two foreign journalists, including the BBC's correspondent.
fields.byline: Andrew Meldrum  in Harare and  Chris McGreal
fields.body:
The Zimbabwean government has intensified its assault on opposition and dissent with moves to bar the leading challenger to Robert Mugabe from the next presidential election, new threats to kill white farmers and the expulsion of two foreign journalists, including the BBC's correspondent.

The ruling Zanu-PF party is trying to block the popular opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, from running for president next year by bringing criminal charges designed to bar him from office. It is also packing the courts with compliant judges, unlikely to overturn any sentencing on appeal.

While Mr Tsvangirai's disqualification would be a blow to his party, the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), it could also prove highly destabilising, given the government's deep unpopularity and Zimbabwe's burgeoning economic crisis; economists warn that it will face a shortage of staple foods within six months.

Harare is also trying to limit the damage to its image overseas.

The information minister, Jonathon Moyo, said the government felt no obligation to abide by a Harare high court decision yesterday blocking the authorities from expelling Joseph Winter of the BBC, and Mercedes Sayagues, who works for the Guardian's sister paper in Johannesburg, the Mail and Guardian.

On another front, Zanu-PF is trying to force the leaders of the overwhelmingly white Commercial Farmers Union to resign, warning that more farmers will die if they do not side with the government.

The ruling party's main target, however, is Mr Tsvangirai. Last week he was belatedly charged with incitement to violence - five months after a speech in which he warned Mr Mugabe that if he did not go peaceably he could be removed by force.

The government claims that the MDC leader was advocating revolution. Mr Tsvangirai says he was just warning of the likely consequences of an increasingly unpopular president trying to cling on to power at all costs.

The MDC believes that the government waited to charge its leader because it was manipulating the courts to ensure that a conviction would be upheld on appeal.

Earlier this month, Zimbabwe's justice minister told the country's independent supreme court judges that their safety could not be guaranteed unless they resigned immediately. The chief justice bowed to the pressure and quit, but four other judges have refused to step down.

The MDC's legal affairs chief, David Coultard, sees a pattern in the recent events. "It's quite clearly part of a coordinated plan to make sure [Tsvangirai] is convicted and cannot run for president," he said. "If that happens Mugabe will go for an early election."

Intimidation has not been restricted to those in the courts and opposition figures, however. A group of men arrived on the doorstep of Mr Winter, the BBC reporter, at 2am yesterday, demanding to be allowed into his flat.

Other journalists arrived and scared them away and Mr Winter, his wife and child were given shelter by the British high commission, but their house was later ransacked.

webTitle: Arts: David Bailey's wonder and blunder

fields.headline: Wonders and blunders
fields.standfirst: 4. David Bailey
fields.trailText:
4. David Bailey
Wonder: St Pancras, London
Blunder: Millennium Dome
fields.body:
Wonder: St Pancras, London
Blunder: Millennium Dome

St Pancras station (with its hotel) is, for me, the most romantic building in the world. It continues to conjure up the same magic for me as it did when I was a kid. The Victorians were very clever in the way they built these wonderful gothic buildings which always seemed fresh and contemporary.

My favourite modern building is the Miho Museum in Japan, designed by IM Pei, architect of the Louvre pyramid. Pei got the permit to build on a slope in a nature reserve near Kyoto on condition he did not destroy the surrounding mountains. So he designed the museum to look like it has been made out of the slope itself. It houses a collection of art including a statue of Horus, supposedly taken from Tutankhamen's tomb, and the most impressive standing statue of Buddha I have seen. Pei's architecture is subtly detailed and doesn't overpower you. I think his work is the type of contemporary architecture most likely to last.

I hate all those 1950s churches with exposed bricks and bell towers. They look so ghastly and postmodern, like a hangover from Bauhaus. The small churches particularly look like they have been made from Formica or children's building blocks. I believe all design and architecture should be functional, but I hate a pseudo-functional style purely for show.

The Millennium Dome is another building I can't stand. I disliked the idea of it even before it started. It reminds me of the philosophy behind the Festival of Britain in the 1950s, the idea that Britain can make it, although at least the Festival of Britain resulted in some good architecture such as many of the buildings on the South Bank. The Dome should not have been built and I hate the implication that we must appeal to the lowest denominator in terms of taste. I don't think it is going to last very long.

 The Birth of the Cool, a retrospective of David Bailey's photographs, is at the Dean Gallery, Edinburgh (0131-624 6200).

webTitle: Women: Merope Mills on celebrity daughters

fields.headline: That's my girl
fields.standfirst: Last week, the papers were full of women with famous parents. Why? Because their parents are famous.  Merope Mills on the dilemma of being a celebrity daughter
fields.trailText: Last week, the papers were full of women with famous parents. Why? Because their parents are famous. Merope Mills on the dilemma of being a celebrity daughter.
fields.body:
"She wears it well. Whose daughter is this?" teased the Daily Mail on Friday, before revealing that the "eerily familiar" strut and bleached blonde hair of Kimberley Stewart had been inherited from her famous father, Rod. (His "Do you think I'm sexy?" signature tune was being played while Kimberley walked - just so the audience really got the message.)

Barely 24 hours earlier, Elizabeth Jagger had stepped out on the catwalk to popping flashbulbs, making it, among other places, to the front page of the Mirror, who described how "Mick's hippy chick" was following in the footsteps of her modelling mother, Jerry Hall.

There is little doubt that the children spawned by celebrities make for good reading. Publish a picture of parent and child and we can spot the similarities, pick away at their likenesses, compare their faces and identify their shared flaws. It didn't matter that Kate Hudson wasn't the lead in her debut movie, Almost Famous - she still got acres more press coverage than any of her co-stars. Everybody wanted a piece of the "golden child" of Goldie Hawn and stepdaughter of Kurt Russell so they could compare the "all-Californian glow and spry insouciance" she inherited from her mother.

Hudson may grow to regret the ease with which she sailed into the newspapers on the wind of her parents' successes when, a few more years/films into her acting career, she finds herself still being asked about whether mum and dad are proud of their little girl. It's not that Hudson isn't big enough and talented enough to stand on her own two feet (she has already been nominated for an Oscar for her efforts) but for women, finding a way out of the shadow of a successful parent is a struggle in itself.

Don't believe me? Take a look at the coverage of Baroness Jay of Paddington last week. Following her decision to leave the cabinet, the high-achieving, 61-year-old peer is still being defined as the daughter of prime minister James Callaghan, rather than the woman who, among other things, successfully presided over stage one of the reform of the second chamber of the Lords. It is ironic that, having demolished the hereditary principle in government, her own parentage is something she is never allowed to forget.

Maybe Dan Macmillan doesn't make for as good a picture as his on-off girlfriend Jade Jagger, but it is strange how he manages to appear in the papers in his capacity as a model and fashion designer, instead of being principally identified as the great-grandson of Harold Macmillan. Is it that Jade and her famous fashion friends (like Leah Wood - and let's not forget the suffix "Ronnie's daughter") make for better pictures? Or is it that our patriarchal society still finds it easier to believe that women cannot make it by themselves without a little nudge of help from mummy/daddy dearest?

The celebrity status of my own mother, the actor Valerie Leon, was a fraction of that of the Jaggers and Stewarts of this world, but it was still impossible not to grow up being determined, in other people's eyes, by what she did for a living. In the 60s she made a name for herself as the Hai Karate girl, before later taking roles in two James Bonds, six Carry On films and starring in the Hammer Horror flick Blood from the Mummy's Tomb.

At school, my classmates used to come in teasing: "I saw your mum in bed with Sean Connery last night. What does your dad think about that?" My father, as it happened, was entirely untroubled as he worked as a TV and film director himself. I got through this with a flush of mild embarrassment, but continually having to laugh it off got pretty tiresome over the years.

More galling was the inevitable question: "Are you going to be an actress like your mum?" In fact, it happened so much that in the end it seemed like the only viable career option for Valerie Leon's daughter. It was a reasonable suggestion, but I always found it funny that the same idea was never mooted for her son. My brother, who is 18 months older than me, laboured under the usual expectations of an older son, but he was never expected to grow up to be beautiful, glamorous and on TV.

If my brief love affair with the stage had lasted a lifetime, I'm pretty convinced I would have earned more money by taking a pound for every time someone said: "Don't you look like your mum?" than I would for the actual acting. For a while I did cherish a vague ambition to follow in my mother's footsteps, but one too many experiences with some unpalatable actors convinced me it wasn't my vocation.

There may even have been an inkling that I would not be able to replicate her success and I knew comparison would be inevitable. Several friends and boyfriends of mine used to joke: "Your mother's really beautiful ... What happened to you?" It wasn't that funny the first time and became less and less so the more I heard it.

If I had decided to become an actor like my mother, and succeeded, I doubt others would have judged that I got there on merit. Take the Dahl effect - passed down two generations from Roald to Tessa to her now notorious daughter Sophie. The unspoken suggestion lingers as to whether she would have made it as a size 14 model had she not had a famous second name. And would she? Conveniently, nobody can say. And inconveniently for Dahl, she will never be able to prove that she could to do it on her own.

For women growing up burdened with the assumptions of parental influence, there is an inevitable quandary to address before they even embark on one type of career. Do they exploit the contacts and connections of their famous parents - or take the tough route and go it alone? For my part, I remember feeling that people would assume my parents had helped me anyway so I might as well go ahead and use them. Which is why, before I decided to change career paths, I accepted my mother's offer of an introduction to her agent.

Hudson appears to have accepted the inevitability of inheriting her mother's mantle. She may have felt there was no point trying to do otherwise, which is why she didn't embargo journalists' inevitable questions about her family. A few Oscar nominations down the road, though, she might just want to call upon the woman's prerogative to change her mind.

webTitle: Left on course to reclaim Paris

fields.headline: Left on course to reclaim Paris
fields.standfirst: Local elections may herald the end of the Chirac era
fields.trailText: Local elections may herald the end of the Chirac era.
fields.body:
Dazed and divided, the French right is about to lose the biggest prize in next month's local elections. Paris town hall, a conservative bastion ruled for nearly 20 years by Jacques Chirac, seems sure to end up in Socialist hands for the first time in 130 years.

If the pollsters are right, as many as 15 districts will fall to the Socialists in the voting on March 11 and 18, a humiliating reverse for Mr Chirac's Gaullist RPR party and its allies, who until five years ago held all 20.

A leftwing victory would propel to the forefront of French politics an unassuming but determined local councillor called Bertrand Delanoe, who as mayor of Paris would become the first openly gay French politician to hold such a prominent office.

A local setback for the right could have serious consequences for the parliamentary and presidential elections due in the summer of next year, spelling disaster for the its ambitions on the national stage, and for Mr Chirac's plans to retain the presidency.

"All it needs is for Paris to fall to the left and everyone will instantly be talking about victory for the left in the parliamentary elections," Roman Paché, political director of the pollsters Louis Harris, said.

Socialist support has spread from the six north-eastern districts of Paris they won in 1995 to the wealthier south-east and even the bourgeois centre. To the surprise of many, the chic central and Left Bank districts of the 1st, 2nd, 4th, 5th and 6th arrondissements are among nine projected new strongholds.

If the right does lose, it will have itself to blame. A string of corruption scandals, many focused on Paris city hall - where Mr Chirac was mayor from 1977 to 1995 - has combined with deep party divisions to send voter confidence in the RPR and its UDF and DL allies plunging.

Prosecutors allege that for almost 20 years city hall was an RPR springboard to launch Mr Chirac at the presidency: party activists were paid from the public purse for non-existent jobs, and contracts were awarded only in return for kickbacks used to line RPR coffers.

The present mayor, Jean Tiberi, is heavily implicated in the financial scandals. Apparently in an attempt to wipe the slate clean, the RPR selected the former party chairman Philippe Séguin as its candidate.

Mr Tiberi is now running an aggressive independent campaign, splitting the right's vote. He accuses Mr Séguin of "copying" his programme, centred mainly on crime and security.

Mr Séguin, meanwhile, has confused voters and activists alike by opting to stand in the Socialist bastion of the 18th arrondissement, where he will be running against the interior minister, Daniel Vaillant.

Worse, he has put himself only fourth on the right's list rather than at the top - apparently on the grounds that if he cannot get elected as a councillor in the 18th, he does not deserve to be mayor. District councillors and mayors appoint the city mayor.

It is a strategy that does not seem to have been fully understood by the electorate. "It's completely stupid," said Paul, a shop owner in Monmartre in the 18th arrondissement. "It's just not logical if he wants to get himself elected mayor."

Mr Séguin has since refused to change tack and put himself at the head of the RPR's official list. For that at least he gets some credit.

"Going back on his decision would have made his strategy even less clear than it already is," Paul said, adding that in any case he would like to see "at long last, a Parisian as mayor".

Which is where Mr Delanoe comes in. While neither born nor bred in the capital - he moved there when he was 14 - he has been in Paris politics for 20 years.

His programme, which includes better policing, more green spaces, fewer cars and better public transport, is not radically different. But his commitment to the city, plus the fact that he plainly has no plans to use city hall as a launchpad for anything grander, appeal to Parisians.

Above all, he represents the cleanest possible break from the Chirac stranglehold on the city. One poll found that 43% of the Parisians who said they would vote for the Socialists would do so in protest at the RPR.

webTitle: G2: Pass notes on Russell Crowe

fields.headline: No: 1822
fields.standfirst: Russell Crowe
fields.trailText: Russell Crowe.
fields.body:
Age: 37.

Appearance: 30-odd Foot of Grunt.

Eh? It's the name of the movie star's rock band, but it describes how he appears in Gladiator just as well.

Ah. The sandal-clad epic. Which, in the tradition of overblown movies, looks set to carve up the opposition in next month's Academy awards. Russell - the Charlton Heston de nos jours - is tipped to win best actor.

Something to Crowe about. The last five years have seen the rugged Kiwi hellraiser rocket to stardom, after winning an Aussie Oscar for his role as a vicious Nazi thug in Romper Stomper.

Hard-hitting stuff. "I want to do movies that have a strong sense of purpose," says the star, "and work with people who have a vision."

Call his bluff. He was in The Quick and the Dead, with Sharon Stone.

Never heard of it. It quickly died.

So has Russell got a new film out? Indeed. Proof of Life, in which he stars as the lover of an adulterous wife played by America's sweetheart, Meg Ryan.

A tough assignment. "In order to get to true levels of sexuality," says the Hollywood bad boy, "you've got to be emotionally close to your co-star."

You don't mean...? After working with Russ, Ryan promptly divorced her husband of nine years, Dennis Quaid, and struck up Tinseltown's most talked-about affair of 2000 with the Antipodean beefcake.

Stone the Crowes! Riled by the press attention, Russell has sworn vengeance on "a certain group of parasites that have a constitutionally protected right to make a living out of sniffing through people's garbage".

Eek! That's us! Sharpen your sword! Buff up your breastplate!

So what's Proof of Life like? "Somewhat without lift," says one US critic.

Might this whole brouhaha, then, be a cleverly contrived publicity stunt to help market a mediocre movie? My publicist tells me to say: "No comment."

webTitle: Man's first four-legged friend was the undiscerning goat, research shows

fields.headline: Man's first four-legged friend was the undiscerning goat, research shows
fields.trailText: Man's first four-legged friend may have been the goat. It joined forces with humans about 10,000 years ago in the upland region of Iran and is, so far, the front-runner in the domestication stakes, according to Melinda Zeder of the Smithsonian Institution.
fields.body:
Man's first four-legged friend may have been the goat. It joined forces with humans about 10,000 years ago in the upland region of Iran and is, so far, the front-runner in the domestication stakes, according to Melinda Zeder of the Smithsonian Institution.

The goat had several attributes which made it an ideal candidate for domestication by tribes of hunter-gatherers in the Fertile Crescent that stretches from Turkey through the Lebanon and Syria to Iraq and Iran, said Dr Zeder, who sifted the archaeological evidence to arrive at the earliest date for goatherding so far.

Unlike the gazelle - auditioned by human hunters as a possible domestic animal at around the same time - the goat did not run away at great speed. Goats did not panic, she told the American Association for the Advancement of Science, and they did not mind living in a crowd. They had a social structure - a tendency to follow a dominant leader - that humans could use.

They would eat anything, and were not too choosy about sexual partners either. And there was something in it for the goats too, she said.

Humans chose the most docile billygoats to breed from, which meant that for the first time in their lives the weediest ones got all the females, rather than their aggressive, high-testosterone companions in the wild. "It's sort of like the revenge of the nerds," she said. Domestication tended to suit the interests of both humans and the creatures they tamed.

"What animals and plants get out of colluding with humans is the ability to outcompete wild competitors that don't enter this relationship and also to spread their distributions way beyond what they could do on their own," she said.

She analysed a huge collection of goat bones from Iran and Iraq, sorting the skeletal material according to age of death and sex. "That allows us to distinguish between hunters killing animals and herders raising animals," she said.

The birth of agriculture is a mystery slowly being solved by both genetic research and archaeology. As crops became domesticated, seeds got bigger and seed coats thinned, signs that plants were being tended rather than simply picked. Goat horns changed shape and became smaller, a sign that mating was decided by humans rather than by herd aggression.

Wheat and barley were first sown in the Fertile Crescent about 10,000 years ago. In the New World, the first crop was probably squash, 10,000 years ago, with maize being sown about 6,300 years ago.

Cattle were probably first domesticated in both the Fertile Crescent and in the Indus Valley, sheep in the Fertile Crescent and the Indo-Pakistan region and the pig in China.

The goat so far emerges as the first animal to be bred and used by humans. The dog however remains a candidate for the first companion, said Dr Zeder.

"It's not a livestock animal, it's more of a collaboration between dogs that hunt in packs and humans that hunt in packs," she said.

webTitle: French beat rest to long life

fields.headline: French beat rest to long life
fields.trailText: Most people will never get that telegram from the Queen. Most people will have to settle for a life expectancy of 85, according to American research.
fields.body:
Most people will never get that telegram from the Queen. Most people will have to settle for a life expectancy of 85, according to American research.

And they will have to wait a long time even for that, said Jay Olshansky of the University of Illinois at Chicago. At present rates, the French will get there first, he told the American Association for the Advancement of Science yesterday.

Babies born in France in 2033 can expect to live until 85. In Japan, that life expectancy will be reached in 2035 and in the US by 2182. He and colleagues report in the journal Science this week that they studied improving life expectancy between 1985 and 1995 and found that it would not reach 100 until the 22nd century in France and Japan, and not until the 26th century in the US.

Life expectancy during the 20th century in Europe and the US improved dramatically. American women could expect to live to 50 in 1900 and 79 in 1995. By the last decade, it was thought life expectancy would reach 100 in the 21st century.

But even after a decade of rapidly declining death rates, the chance of reaching a life expectancy of 90 had not altered appreciably. Future gains would be measured in months rather than years, said Prof Olshansky. "This is not surprising because life expectancy is very difficult to increase once it approaches 80. Adding decades to the lives of people who have lived to 70 is more difficult than adding decades to children who are dying of infectious diseases."

He added: "There are no lifestyle changes, surgical procedures, vitamins... or techniques available with the capacity to repeat the gains achieved in the 20th century."

fields.headline: Israeli court paroles murderer
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A Jewish settler who fired nine bullets into a bound and blindfolded Palestinian man walked free yesterday after Israel's supreme court reduced the life sentence he was serving for murder.
fields.body:
A Jewish settler who fired nine bullets into a bound and blindfolded Palestinian man walked free yesterday after Israel's supreme court reduced the life sentence he was serving for murder.

Yoram Skolnick was freed on parole after serving eight years of his term. He owes his release in part to the former Israeli president Ezer Weizman, who intervened twice to get his sentence reduced.

The 4-3 ruling overturned a petition brought by the Committee against Terror, which sought to cancel the parole board's decision to free Skolnick for good behaviour.

Skolnick was convicted of murdering Moussa Abu Sabha, 21, in 1993. Minutes before the killing Abu Sabha was overpowered and tied up by two Jewish settlers, one of whom he had stabbed. Skolnick, who arrived at the scene after hearing of the attack on a two-way radio, stood over him and opened fire with a machine-gun.

His wife, Sigalit, was jubilant at the decision. "Today they release so many terrorists, it can not be that they will leave in prison this holy Jew who is part of the nation of Israel," she told Army Radio.

The decision is bound to increase criticism that Israel's entire judicial apparatus, from the police to the attorney general's office, is infected with racial prejudice. Last month another Jewish settler was sentenced to six months community service and fined nearly £12,000 after clubbing to death an 11-year-old Palestinian who had been throwing stones.

"The message is almost a green light to hurt Palestinians," said Tomer Feffer, a spokesman for B'Tselem, an Israeli organisation which investigates human rights abuses in the occupied territories.

 A British citizen detained in Israel for six weeks on suspicion of being on a mission for the Lebanese guerrilla organisation Hizbullah has accused his jailors of torture. In a letter to the attorney general, Jehard Shuman said he was beaten, threatened with rape, and subjected to sleep deprivation and freezing cold showers.

fields.headline: Roger Hadley
fields.trailText: The guiding force throughout the life of Roger Hadley, who has died of cancer aged 69, was his concern for the powerlessness of the individual in large bureaucracies, which found expression in his involvement with co-ownership in industry.
fields.body:
The guiding force throughout the life of Roger Hadley, who has died of cancer aged 69, was his concern for the powerlessness of the individual in large bureaucracies, which found expression in his involvement with co-ownership in industry, and particularly in community-orientated and locally-managed social services. The emeritus professor of social administration at Lancaster University, he was best known as co-author of a series of books on the role of the state and social services that promoted the concept of decentralisation.

Born in East Hoathly, Sussex, Roger was brought up in Surrey: the atmosphere of freedom, kindness and humanity in his rural childhood home, and at Frensham Heights school, Farnham, contrasted greatly with what he was to find in the wider world - and it had a lasting effect on him.

Following national service, he took a BSc in economics at the London School of Economics (1952-55), and the focus of his concern developed from a belief in world government - as the way to world peace - to the sharper focus of people's lives in the workplace. He set about this with characteristic energy and enthusiasm, and, after graduation, worked for two years in factories in Britain, Canada and America, where workers' lack of fulfilment and feelings of powerlessness made a big impact on him.

He took a post-graduate diploma in industrial sociology (1957-59), and research for his doctorate on self- governing firms (1965-71) took him to the common-ownership firm Scott Bader Commonwealth, which he advised on personnel and training, writing several pamphlets about the benefits of industrial democracy.

In 1966, he became a lecturer in Professor Richard Titmuss's groundbreaking social administration department at the LSE, where he was first exposed to social service organisation and practice - to which his ideas on industrial organisation and democracy naturally transferred themselves.

In 1974, Roger was appointed to the chair of the newly-founded department of social admini- stration at Lancaster, where he pursued the idea of the "patch", or neighbourhood, approach to service provision, working with projects in social services departments in Normanton, East Sussex, Tyneside and Salford, which had moved away from centralised control.

During the 1980s, he co-authored a series of books and monographs which advocated the decentralisation of local authority social services, notably Going Local: Neighbourhood Social Services (1981), When Social Services Are Local (1984), Decentralising Social Services: A Model For Change (1984), A Community Social Worker Handbook (1987) and Creating A Responsive Public Service (1990). With Stephen Hatch, he wrote a wider critique of centralised services, Social Welfare And The Failure Of The State (1981).

In the 1990s, Roger argued against treating the provision of personal social services as if it was an economic market, whereby clients became "customers" and social workers had to produce "business plans", rather than ones rooted in human need. His riposte can be found in Care In Chaos (1996), written with Roger Clough. He was a member of the Wolfenden committee on voluntary organisations (1974-77) and the Barclay committee on the role and tasks of social workers (1981-82).

After retiring from Lancaster in 1996, he became an honorary professor at the University of Wales, Bangor, where he worked with the Centre for Social Policy Research and Development.

Roger was surprisingly shy about his other talents, which included being an accomplished pianist, singer, artist and photographer. After marrying his second wife, Clare Wenger, in 1986, he settled in Gwaenysgor, north Wales. Characteristically, he set about learning Welsh and completed a guide to local walks as well as a history of the village.

Clare survives him, as do three stepsons, and a son and a daughter from his first marriage.

webTitle: Victory for Labor in the Australian election

fields.headline: One Nation revival seals Queensland victory for Labor
fields.trailText: The Australian Labor party was re-elected by a landslide in Queensland on Saturday as the mainstream conservative parties collapsed under pressure from the rightwing One Nation party.
fields.body:
The Australian Labor party was re-elected by a landslide in Queensland on Saturday as the mainstream conservative parties collapsed under pressure from the rightwing One Nation party.

It won an estimated 69 of the state parliament's 89 seats, overcoming last year's vote-rigging scandal which prompted the premier, Peter Beattie, to call the election.

If the 10.4% swing to Labor in Queensland is repeated in the the federal elections due by November, Labor will easily regain power from John Howard's conservative coaltion of Liberal and National parties, and One Nation's leader, Pauline Hanson, could win a much-coveted senate seat.
