webTitle: Alien cells may cause arthritis in women

fields.headline: Alien cells may cause arthritis in women
fields.trailText: Women could be 10 times more likely than men to suffer from rheumatoid arthritis, lupus, multiple sclerosis and other autoimmune diseases because they carry alien tissues in their bloodstreams - cells from their children and mothers.
fields.body:
Women could be 10 times more likely than men to suffer from rheumatoid arthritis, lupus, multiple sclerosis and other autoimmune diseases because they carry alien tissues in their bloodstreams - cells from their children and mothers.

Lee Nelson of the University of Washington told the American Association for the Advancement of Science in San Francisco that even 30 years after the birth of a son, male foetal cells could be detected in a woman's blood stream at levels of one in a million.

The presence of these alien cells could indirectly affect the mother's immune system. Immune systems work by detecting and attacking invading cells - bacteria, viruses and so on. Sometimes, immune systems attack their own host, to cause scleroderma, multiple sclerosis and up to 100 other diseases. Autoimmune diseases are among the top 10 killers of women under the age of 65.

"Traditionally, autoimmune diseases are described as your cells attacking your own healthy tissue," she said. "Our findings raise the question as to whether some autoimmune diseases are not entirely autoimmune, whether they actually have a component that is non-self. It's really an entirely new paradigm."

Her research began with rheumatoid arthritis, which goes into remission when women are pregnant but returns after delivery. Immunologists have been interested for decades in why babies aren't rejected after conception, in the way that transplanted organs are rejected by the immune system. But the invasion by a "stranger" turned out to last far longer than nine months.

"In women who have had, for example, a son, you can look 10, 20 or 30 years later at a drop of blood, and find a male cell in there. Similarly you would find cells from a daughter. It's just a little easier to track a male cell in a woman," Dr Nelson said. "The basic theme is that pregnancy is an immunologic event, it is not just a change in hormones, it's actually exposure to a being who is half yours, because half the genes come from the father."

Some of the mother's cells went into the child as well. There were other ways of acquiring a "stranger" within - from a blood transfusion, from a twin, and even from a twin you never knew you had, because many pregnancies began as twins, with one of them lost at a very early stage.

"Probably those cells have a beneficial, neutral or detrimental function depending on what particular relationships there are of the genes that help you determine what is self, what is other," said Dr Nelson. It could explain why women had more autoimmune disease than men, because there were more chances of carrying alien immune system cells.

These were a set of genes on the sixth chromosome, essential to distinguishing self and non-self, called the human leukocyte antigens, or HLA genes. Knowledge of how these genes work could help scientists think of widely different illnesses as stemming from one source. It could also explain why some diseases retreated during pregnancy, and then became better or worse afterwards. It might also explain why one twin might have the disease, but another did not. One child would develop multiple sclerosis, but his or her identical twin had only one chance in 20 of developing the same disease

"It's a fascinating area and it will give us, hopefully, a whole new way of treating these diseases because we can target those cells," she said.

One of the first targets for new kinds of treatment could be scleroderma, which affects about 14 in a million worldwide - mostly mothers. It causes hardening of the skin on the hands and face, and pain in the joints. In some forms it hardens internal tissue, causing organ failure and death.

webTitle: O'Neill insists he believes in a strong dollar

fields.headline: O'Neill insists he believes in a strong dollar
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: US treasury secretary Paul O'Neill launched a damage limitation exercise yesterday after his apparent abandonment of the Clinton administration's strong-dollar policy alarmed the markets.
fields.body:
US treasury secretary Paul O'Neill launched a damage limitation exercise yesterday after his apparent abandonment of the Clinton administration's strong-dollar policy alarmed the markets.

Making his debut at the year's first meeting of G7 finance ministers and central bank governors, Mr O'Neill expressed confidence that the US economy would rebound in the second half of the year and resume its role as global economic locomotive.

He insisted his comments at the end of last week about being in favour of a strong economy rather than a strong dollar did not signal a policy change.

"I guess I made a mistake in thinking it was OK to talk beyond simplistic things," Mr O'Neill said. "So I'll make it very clear: I believe in a strong dollar, and if I decide to to shift that stance I will hire out the Yankee Stadium and some rousing brass bands, and announce that change in policy to the whole world."

Concern about the outlook for the US - highlighted by the IMF's downgrading of its 2001 growth forecast to 1.7% from 3.2% - dominated Saturday's discussion of the global economy. Sir Eddie George, governor of the Bank of England, said there was a general feeling that America would recover quickly from the sharp slowdown expected in the first half of the year.

Policymakers would need, however, to be "extremely sensitive to what's going on" - a hint that central bankers must be ready to cut interest rates to stimulate demand if necessary.

The big fear is that US consumers, having borrowed heavily to finance consumption in the upswing, will close their wallets, sending the economy into a full-blown recession.

The US, Canada and Britain have cut rates this year to boost confidence, a move that should keepthe global economy moving forward this year, although the G7 participants said in a communique that they expected growth to be "somewhat slower" than forecast at their last meeting, in Prague in the autumn.

Only the European Central Bank has left monetary policy unchanged. With Europe widely forecast to to be the fastest growing region this year, ECB president Wim Duisenberg signalled rates would stay on hold in the short term by stressing that last year's surge in the oil price and past weakness of the euro still posed an inflationary threat. There was "no automaticity" that borrowing costs would fall.

While economists have attacked the ECB for not doing enough to sustain growth, there was no criticism of it at the meeting. "There was no suggestion that they should have acted until now," Sir Eddie said.

Japan, flirting with recession again after years of anaemic growth, was urged to keep monetary policy easy and make enhanced efforts to strengthen its financial sector.

Despite Mr O'Neill's denial of a change of tack, currency market experts believe he may have betrayed his true feelings in last week's German newspaper interview and is now covering them up to avoid a collapse of the dollar.

"This guy is an industrialist and he must see that the dollar has appreciated by 70% in 70 months against Europe. He can see the damage that's causing in the US economy," said Nick Parsons, chief currency strategist at Commerzbank in London.

fields.headline: Prince Ardaye Coffi Ankrah
fields.trailText: Prince Ardaye Coffi Ankrah, who has died aged 86, was one of the sons of Nil Kpakpo Oti II, the head of a Ghanaian royal family.
fields.body:
Prince Ardaye Coffi Ankrah, who has died aged 86, was one of the sons of Nil Kpakpo Oti II, the head of a Ghanaian royal family. However, in 1944, he left his family home to make the then dangerous sea voyage to Liverpool and seek fame and fortune as an artist.

His arrival proved timely. In April 1946, Les Ballets Negres, Europe's first African-Caribbean dance company, gave its premiere performance in London - and Ankrah was one of the two principal drummers in the orchestra. "He could make the drums sound like birdsong, like rainfall, like thunder," said Richie Riley, a founding member of the company. Alexander Korda recognised his exceptional abilities and featured him as a dancer in the film A Man Of Two Worlds.

When Les Ballets Negres gave its final performance in 1953, Ankrah formed his own company. Touring Finland, Germany, Holland, Romania, and Bulgaria, he was both artist and showman, and the star of the ensemble. He took Africa and Africans to parts of the globe where its culture was virtually unknown. He gave audiences an insight into a world where dancing on broken glass might be both a circus trick and a spiritual exercise, and where dancers imitated living creatures and danced with them (the ensemble travelled with a giant anaconda snake which featured in the performances).

Ankrah's support for the Pan African movement had always been strong and his friendship with Kwame Nkrumah, the first president of Ghana, prompted his return home in 1962, with a view to promoting cultural development, the formation of the Ghanaian arts council and a prospective national theatre. But things moved too slowly, and, in spite of his cousin, General Ankrah, subsequently taking over from Nkrumah, Ankrah returned again to London.

His skills in organisation, and in choreographing move- ment between Africa and other countries, now blossomed with the formation of the OTI Trading Company. Frozen salt fish were imported from Iceland and exported to Ghana, Nigeria and the Caribbean.

But his artistic enthusiasms also permeated his business acumen. Theatre lighting was exported from Britain to Ghana, and Kente cloth was imported from Ghana to Britain; in fact, Ankrah's enthusiasm for the rich patterns and meanings of Kente cloths led to him assembling one of the finest collections of these ceremonial cloths. His skills as a showman also found an outlet at Ghanaian weddings and funerals in London, which he costumed and supervised. Three days before he died of cancer, Ankrah could still get out of bed and dance for his friends.

He is survived by his two sons and two daughters (Andrew, Nikolai, Katarina and Alexandra) from a dissolved marriage.

Prince Ardaye Coffi Ankrah, drummer and dancer, born March 21 1914; died January 3 2001

webTitle: Suddenly Summers is last season's fashion

fields.headline: Suddenly Summers is last season's fashion
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Political friendships can be ephemeral. A few months ago, British officials were stressing how close Gordon Brown was to Larry Summers, the US treasury secretary turfed out of office by the new Bush administration.
fields.body:
Political friendships can be ephemeral. A few months ago, British officials were stressing how close Gordon Brown was to Larry Summers, the US treasury secretary turfed out of office by the new Bush administration.

Together, they helped to put in place the building blocks for a new financial architecture in the wake of the Asian financial crisis, according to the spin at the time.

Now, Mr Summers is persona non grata. Instead of praising his towering intellect, senior British officials whisper about how awkward and arrogant he could be.

In the former academic economist's place there is Paul O'Neill, the multi-millionaire former metals company executive. A pragmatic conservative with a reputation for plain speaking, he ought to be a natural enemy for the chancellor. But both sides hid any animosity at their first encounter.

Mr Brown had a bilateral meeting with Mr O'Neill before Saturday's G7 meeting. It was described by senior Treasury officials as "very constructive, very informal" and conducted in a "very friendly atmosphere".

There was a "meeting of minds" on the need for Russia to meet its obligations on Soviet-era debt.

Another official said the chancellor and Mr O'Neill shared the same opinions on the importance of micro-economic reform to improve productivity.

Mr Brown walked into the group discussion side by side with his new best friend, they sat together at lunch and discovered they share a Scottish heritage. Mr O'Neill's father was from Glasgow and emigrated to America in the 1920s.

Treasury officials say there is certainly something to build on. The two men have agreed to meet again soon, without setting a date.

fields.headline: Imam Mohammed Shamseddin
fields.trailText: The death from lung cancer of Imam Mohammed Mahdi Shamseddin, at the age of 67, caused trepidation among Lebanon's 1.2m Shi'ite Muslems. Who could possibly replace the man who had represented their community for 22 years?
fields.body:
The death from lung cancer of Imam Mohammed Mahdi Shamseddin, at the age of 67, caused trepidation among Lebanon's 1.2m Shi'ite Muslems. Who could possibly replace the man who had represented their community for 22 years? In a nation still recovering from civil war, Shamseddin (the name means "sun of religion" in Arabic) championed reconciliation between Christian and Muslim, and between Shi'ite and Sunni.

Shamseddin wrote some 25 books, on issues ranging from Shi'ite history and social ethics to the status of women in Islam. He epitomised a scholastic tradition that had flourished quietly for centuries in Lebanon's most impoverished and neglected region, the southern Jabal Amil. But the imam found himself dragged willy-nilly into politics and, as patron of a strong Shi'ite bloc in Lebanon's national assembly, he made enemies. Would-be assassins targeted him twice - once, near his home in 1990, and again, in 1997, while he was praying at a Beirut mosque.

Shamseddin was born to Lebanese parents in Najaf, southern Iraq, the spiritual cradle of Shi'ism. There he studied Arab sciences and Islamic jurisprudence, and argued for divine governance according to sharia law. However, returning to a religiously heterogeneous Lebanon in 1968 changed his views. In 1985, he coined the term adadiyya, or dialogue between the Abrahamic faiths.

Initially, he basked in the reflected glory of his charismatic mentor, Imam Sayid Musa Sadr. He served as Sadr's deputy on the higher Shi'ite council and promoted Sadr's new movement, Amal, which galvanised the Shi'ite downtrodden. For while Shi'ites represented the largest single sect in Lebanon, they played third fiddle to Beirut and Tripoli's Christian and Sunni elites.

Three events in 1978 irrevocably altered Shamseddin's life. First came the disappearance of Musa Sadr in Libya. This mysterious affair played to the archetypal Shi'ite motif of a hidden imam, who would return victorious on some unspecified day of judgment. For Shamseddin to claim Sadr's throne was obviously unthinkable. Only in March 1994 was he named president of the higher council. Yet as Musa Sadr's de facto successor, he gained renewed authority.

Also in 1978 came Ayatollah Khomeini's Islamic revolution in Iran. Lebanese Shi'ites were elated and Shamseddin welcomed Tehran's subsequent patronage. All the same, he cherished his community's autonomy, and realised that Iranian-style velayat e-faqih (or rule by religious jurists) would alienate his more worldly adherents.

Finally, Israeli incursions in 1978 exacerbated Shi'ite animosity towards Palestinians, whom they blamed for these reprisals. Four years later, though, a much larger invasion displaced thousands of Shi'ites, leading the imam to demand "total civil resistance against Israel". Paradoxically, this campaign also spawned Hizbullah, a rival to Amal.

Shamseddin rejected zionism, yet grudgingly accepted the reality of Israel. Just prior to the 1973 Geneva talks, he implored Arabs to adopt a "new style" to protect themselves against the "dangers of peace with the Jews". Hizbullah may have later boasted of marching on Jerusalem, but Shamseddin was more circumspect. "If Israel withdraws from Lebanon," he told an American audience in 1995, "our differences would be over. There would be no more bullets between us."

He also fought against corruption and injustice. He highlighted the plight of poverty-stricken farmers, railed against "monstrous" government institutions and protested about human rights abuses. Last May, he condemned the absence of an independent judiciary in Lebanon, a body "trusted by the weak, not an object of whispers and accusations".

He opposed sectarianism with equal virulence. "There is no Lebanon without its Christians", he once declared. When Hizbullah threatened to wreak vengeance on Jezzine, a largely Christian stronghold from which Israeli forces withdrew in 1998, the imam ordered the guerrillas to respect residents as fellow Lebanese. In 1999, he warned against "returning Lebanon to partition in the guise of decentralisation".

Never fond of secularism, he argued against using civil marriage as a tool for fostering inter-communal harmony. Increasingly, his gratitude to Damascus as "a guarantor of civil peace" irritated those Lebanese who yearned to see Syrian troops leave.

Ultimately, Shamseddin will be remembered for two major successes: indirectly ensuring the departure of Israeli troops from Lebanon last year, and winning a place at the high table for Lebanon's Shi'ites. He is survived by a second wife and three sons.

All the same, he cherished his community's autonomy, and realised that Iranian-style velayat e-faqih (or rule by religious jurists) would alienate his more worldly adherents. Finally, Israeli incursions in 1978 exacerbated Shi'ite animosity towards Palestinians, whom they blamed for these reprisals. Four years later, though, a much larger invasion displaced thousands of Shi'ites, leading the imam to demand "total civil resistance against Israel". Paradoxically, this campaign also spawned Hizbullah, a rival to Amal. Shamseddin rejected zionism, yet grudgingly accepted the reality of Israel. Just prior to the 1973 Geneva talks, he implored Arabs to adopt a "new style" to protect themselves against the "dangers of peace with the Jews". Hizbullah may have later boasted of marching on Jerusalem, but Shamseddin was more circumspect. "If Israel withdraws from Lebanon," he told an American audience in 1995, "our differences would be over. There would be no more bullets between us." He also fought against corruption and injustice. He highlighted the plight of poverty-stricken farmers, railed against "monstrous" government institutions and protested about human rights abuses. Last May, he condemned the absence of an independent judiciary in Lebanon, a body "trusted by the weak, not an object of whispers and accusations". He opposed sectarianism with equal virulence. "There is no Lebanon without its Christians", he once declared. When Hizbullah threatened to wreak vengeance on Jezzine, a largely Christian stronghold from which Israeli forces withdrew in 1998, the imam ordered the guerrillas to respect residents as fellow Lebanese. In 1999, he warned against "returning Lebanon to partition in the guise of decentralisation". Never fond of secularism, he argued against using civil marriage as a tool for fostering inter-communal harmony. Increasingly, his gratitude to Damascus as "a guarantor of civil peace" irritated those Lebanese who yearned to see Syrian troops leave. Ultimately, Shamseddin will be remembered for two major successes: indirectly ensuring the departure of Israeli troops from Lebanon last year, and winning a place at the high table for Lebanon's Shi'ites. He is survived by a second wife and three sons. Mohammed Mahdi Shamseddin, Shi'ite religious leader, born 1933; died January 11 2001

fields.headline: NEC widens its window on the world
fields.standfirst: £200m masterplan marks 25th anniversary
fields.trailText: £200m masterplan marks 25th anniversary.
fields.body:
The annual trophy-engraving exhibition is the smallest event held at the National Exhibition Centre, occupying a mere 1,500 sq metres of the NEC's 190,000 sq metres of floor space. But along with events such as the cake decorating exhibition, the teddy bear pageant and the CD collectors fair it helps make the NEC the busiest exhibition venue in Europe.

Last year more than 4m people visited the NEC for 200 exhibitions. But when in the early 1970s Birmingham's city council and chamber of commerce mooted the idea of building an exhibition centre at the edge of the city the experts said it would be another white elephant to join the city's much-derided Bull Ring shopping centre and Rotunda office block.

The city fathers pressed ahead and the National Exhibition Centre, which opened its doors to the public 25 years ago this month, has expanded from 89,000 sq metres in 1976. A 12,600-seat arena has been created beside its exhibition halls. and the NEC today announces that Alfred McAlpine, Amec and Miller are on its shortlist to work on a £200m "strategic masterplan" to give the centre a 21st century look including new hotels, banqueting suites and a 1,500-seat conference hall plus airport-style travelators to speed pedestrian movement.

This week the National Boat, Caravan and Leisure Show celebrates its 40th anniversary as well as 25 years of coming to the NEC. The NEC is home to events such as the International Motor Show and Crufts and in 2003 will host the largest single-sector exhibition in the world, the International Textile Machinery Association show.

Barry Cleverdon, NEC Group's chief executive, said the annual Spring Fair at the NEC last year was the biggest exhibition in Britain since the 1851 Great Fair in Crystal Palace.

The centre has also raised Birmingham's international profile by building and running the International Convention Centre, the National Indoor Arena and the Symphony Hall. On top of that, it is making a profit and has helped offset the decline in Birmingham's traditional manufacturing base.

Independent research by KPMG in 1999 estimated that venues managed by the NEC Group generated £711m of business and visitor spending in 1998-99, and supported the equivalent of 22,000 full-time jobs in the region. To date, the venues have staged more than 12,000 events and attracted more than 80m people.

Mr Cleverdon, who joined NEC Group the year after the exhibition site opened in February 1976, said the company moved into profit in 1998-99. Last year the exhibition centre made an operating profit of £31.8m, against a £2.4m loss by the ICC and and a £1.3m deficit for the NIA.

Shareholders accept that the revenues which the NIA, the ICC and the Symphony Hall bring to the city more than make up for their small trading losses.

"The convention centre holds about 300 conventions a year," Mr Cleverdon said. "That's about 70% utilisation, which is pretty good. We run it on pretty commercial lines, but, having said that, it does not deliver a profit."

The convention centre was built partly on the site of Bingley Hall, the city's old exhibition hall which was destroyed by fire. Its island site, which makes security arrangements easy, helped it to win the G8 summit meeting in 1998 and Nato defence ministers' meeting last year.

The exhibition halls operate at about 45% capacity, which is high for the industry. Birmingham's central location, and its road, rail and air links, have attracted high-profile events including the Eurovision Song Contest.

"People ask why we court television so much," Mr Cleverdon said. "Well, the televised last day of Crufts was watched in 43m homes in America, while the Eurovision song contest was seen by 140m people. It helps put Birmingham on the map."

The NEC's 20 interconnecting halls, set in 628 acres, mean it can stage several exhibitions at the same time, including niche trade fairs. About 70% of last year's exhibitions there were trade shows.

The company has developed a consultancy business which has worked on plans to build a new conference centre in Dublin and hopes to win the contract to manage it. Mr Cleverdon denied this was merely fostering potential NEC rivals, saying modern exhibitions tend to rove the world.

He is equally dismissive about the threat from "virtual exhibitions" being set up solely on the internet. "It will never happen. People like to debate things, exchange ideas and do business at exhibitions. They also like to be able to touch and feel things on show."

The NEC has just signed a deal with Expocentric to create electronic versions of physical exhibitions. They are seen as powerful marketing tools which will increase the number of people attending exhibitions. Birmingham's 1970s city fathers can feel vindicated.

fields.headline: Balthus
fields.standfirst: Controversial painter of disquieting themes
fields.trailText: Controversial painter of disquieting themes.
fields.body:
Balthazar Klossowski, Count de Rola, better known as the artist Balthus, who has died aged 92, was arguably the last great figurative painter of the 20th century. He was also one of its most enigmatic and controversial.

Self-invented and self-taught, Balthus created a private and poetic universe which revolved around a few obsessively repeated themes: landscapes full of foreboding, portraits which laid bare the inner lives of their sitters, and, most notoriously, his favourite subject - the bodies of pubescent girls.

Some critics have dismissed these psychologically-charged tableaux - where young girls in various states of undress loll, dream and examine themselves in mirrors - as the prurient products of a peverted imagination; others see them as unique insights into the troubled territory of adolescence, and intimate studies of feminine reverie on a par vith Degas or Vermeer.

Whatever the point of view, there is no disputing Balthus's extraordinary ability to conjure up ominous frozen psycho-dramas with an almost unbearably erotic and emotional intensity. His own statements - such as "Balthus is a painter about whom nothing is known" - only added to the mystery of his paintings and his persona; a desire to remain aloof and independent was crucial to every aspect of his existence.

Art and exile were built into the family history. Balthus's Polish father and Russian-Jewish mother had assumed German citizenship and settled in Paris, where the two sons, Pierre and Balthazar, were born. Both parents were artists and Balthus grew up surrounded by their friends, who included Bonnard and Matisse. When war broke out in 1914, the family became enemy aliens and settled in Geneva, where Balthus's mother became romantically involved with another exile, the poet Rainer Maria Rilke.

Rilke immediately recognised her younger son as a prodigy when he saw a series of ink drawings commemo rating the boy's angora cat, and was so astonished by their skill and sophistication that he wrote a preface and had them published in 1920. At the age of 13, Balthus, the artist, was born.

Instead of attending art school, he bicycled to Arezzo to copy the Piero della Francescas. Throughout his career, the presence of the quattrocento masters remained a pervasive, albeit an unlikely one: whether in the monumental modelling of Balthus's chunky young girls, with their aloof smiling faces, or in his later - and only partially successful - use of the chalky-textured "casein" tempera.

These were spliced with a disparate range of influences, from Bonnard, Gustave Courbet and Seurat, to Poussin, John Tenniel and Wuthering Heights. One of Balthus's early masterpieces is the disquieting 1933 painting, The Toilet Of Cathy.

He may have been a loner and a non-joiner who stood apart from the artistic movements of his time, but this did not stop Balthus from winning the admiration of his contemporaries. His closest artist friend was the sculptor and painter Alberto Giacometti, who shared his detachment from the outer world; one of the earliest Balthus paintings of adolescents, The Children (1937), was acquired by Picasso; while his portraits of a ferocious Derain, a childlike Miro and a boot-faced Vicomtesse de Noailles indicate an intimacy with uncomfortable areas of the sitters' psyches that is be almost too revealing.

Balthus's first one-man show was held in Paris in 1934, but it was in America that his reputation was made - largely due to the efforts of the dealer Pierre Matisse and the pay-phone millionaire collector James Thrall Soby, who pushed for his first show in New York in 1956. His work broke the million-dollar barrier in 1984, the same year as his twin retrospectives in New York and Paris. In 1993, there was another retrospective in Lausanne, and in 1994 a major exhibition in Tokyo.

In the early 1960s, Balthus was made special adviser to Andre Malreux, during his term as French minister of culture. Malreux made him the head of the Villa Medici, the French cultural centre in Rome, where Balthus lived until 1976.

As his international reputation burgeoned, however, he moved to the village of Rossiniere near Gstaad, Switzerland, where he lived a secluded life in an 18th-century mansion with his Japanese wife of over 30 years, Setsko Ideta, and their daughter Harumi. (He also had two sons, Stanislaas and Thaddé, from his first marriage to Antoinette de Watteville).

Although he shied away from publicity, Balthus allowed two major works to be published in tribute to him - Balthus: A Catalogue Raison Of The Complete Works, and Balthus, a biography by Nicholas Fox Webber. To celebrate his last birthday, he threw an extravagant fancy-dress party, attended by Tony Curtis, U2 and a last remaining member of the Russian dynasty, Nicholas Romanov.

In spite of failing health, he painted every day in his studio."I am always eager not to tire the canvas," he once said. "So many painters today have found a trick. I have never been able to find one." Perhaps that was his secret.

webTitle: Brown strikes blow for the poor

fields.headline: Brown strikes blow for the poor
fields.standfirst: G7 leaders are persuaded to deliver UN development goals
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown achieved a breakthrough in the fight against global poverty when he secured backing from the world's richest nations to deliver universal primary education, cut infant mortality by two-thirds and halve the number of poor people by 2015.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown achieved a breakthrough in the fight against global poverty when he secured backing from the world's richest nations to deliver universal primary education, cut infant mortality by two-thirds and halve the number of poor people by 2015.

These are the UN's international development targets and for the first time finance ministers and central bank governors from the Group of Seven nations - the US, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada - made an explicit commitment to reach the goals set by the UN in 1995.

In the G7's first summit of the year, Mr Brown led the development part of the discussion on Saturday with strong support from his Italian hosts. Speaking at a press conference later, the chancellor said: "The agreement here today that we are going to make it a priority to get resources channelled to social services - health and education - is very important."

G7 sources said the UN targets had long been regarded as outside the domain of finance ministers and the responsibility of the development community and UN agencies.

But now that the people in charge of the finances of some of the world's richest countries were on record as wanting to achieve them, there was every prospect that they would become more than aspirations.

A programme of work has begun which it is hoped will lead to the World Bank and International Monetary Fund being required to spell out exactly how the UN targets will be achieved in the countries they lend to and supervise.

Mr Brown's initiative will be taken forward in London next Monday when he and Clare Short, the international development secretary, host a conference on child poverty, which will be attended by UN secretary general Kofi Annan, Jim Wolfensohn, president of the World Bank, Horst Koehler, managing director of the IMF, and addessed by video link by Nelson Mandela.

It wil be followed up by the Budget on March 7, when the chancellor is expected to announce a tax credit to encourage pharmaceuticals companies to devote more resources to developing drugs for eradicating preventable diseases such as malaria and TB.

The spring meetings of the IMF and World Bank and the G7 leaders' summit in Genoa in the summer will also be focal points.

Mr Brown and his G7 counterparts discussed progress of debt relief, noting that 22 of the 41 countries originally identified were receiving assistance under the enhanced, heavily indebted poor countries initiative and that many of the rest were prevented from doing so by armed conflicts.

But they did not talk in any detail about a proposal from Drop the Debt, successor to the Jubilee 2000 campaign, to call in outside auditors to see whether the IMF and World Bank could afford to write off more debt.

Jamie Drummond, spokesman for Drop the Debt, said: "The poorest countries cannot fight poverty when scarce cash, which could go towards health care and education, is instead going on payments to the IMF and World Bank. The G7 are on dangerous ground and the 2015 poverty alleviation targets will remain a pipe dream until they agree to deeper debt cancellation and a new deal on debt for the Genoa summit."

fields.headline: Making waves
fields.standfirst: River swim record
fields.trailText: After 106 days hauling herself through 1,523 miles of swirling brown water, Tammy van Wisse reached the mouth of the Murray, south of Adelaide, yesterday, breaking the record for swimming down Australia's longest river.
fields.body:
After 106 days hauling herself through 1,523 miles of swirling brown water, Tammy van Wisse reached the mouth of the Murray, south of Adelaide, yesterday, breaking the record for swimming down Australia's longest river.

Van Wisse, who adds the feat to her record swim across Loch Ness, celebrated chopping 35 days off Graham Middleton's 1991 record by calling for a national campaign to save the river.

The extraction of water from the Murray for irrigation has reduced its average flow by 80% and severely damaged fish stocks and riverbank ecosystems.

"I feel like I've got Murray water flowing through my veins now," she said.

"The Murray is a vital part of our existence and we really need to do something about it."

The Australian Conservation Foundation supported her call for action to save the river.

"The federal government needs to take a much stronger role in managing the Murray-Darling basin," its rivers spokesman, Stuart Blanch, said.

"Without putting more water back into the river, the gains made by other environmental restoration projects, whether salinity mitigation or revegetation of river banks, is going to be hamstrung."

The Murray-Darling network of rivers sustains a $A3bn (£1.2bn) agricultural industry, including water-thirsty rice and cotton farms.

The trout cod, the silver perch and, in Victoria, the unique Murray cod are all threatened with extinction.

South Australia depends on the Murray for much of its drinking water, but it is predicted that by 2020 it will not meet World Health Organisation quality standards.

Van Wisse, 32, was the first person to swim the Bass Straight, between the Australian mainland and Tasmania. She survived a stomach virus, water snake scares and hazardous floating logs to complete her Murray adventure.

fields.headline: Co-op is shown how to sharpen its edge
fields.trailText: Ten years ago, chief executives of co-op societies would try to outdo each other in hard-boiled realism. Talk of principles or social goals was anathema. The mantra was: "We have to become a better food retailer." To do that, the Co-op had to be good at everything, including running superstores.
fields.body:
Ten years ago, chief executives of co-op societies would try to outdo each other in hard-boiled realism. Talk of principles or social goals was anathema. The mantra was: "We have to become a better food retailer." To do that, the Co-op had to be good at everything, including running superstores.

Now market share in food has slipped from nearly 8% to 6%. Last year the societies made £87m on turnover of £8.3bn, just 1.1% of sales. With hindsight they realise they should have got out of superstores earlier and concentrated on what they do well, a mix of convenience stores and town centre supermarkets.

More positively, their "jewel in the crown", the Co-operative Bank, has shown that an ethical policy can underpin commercial success.

The threat of demutualisation and the way competitors stole the Co-op's clothes by rewarding loyalty opened minds to the "co-operative advantage". This is a magic formula by which commercial success and the social aims of the Co-op are both met through building on the edge that being a co-op brings.

Most retailers go through an occasional crisis but the Co-op has been in crisis for 50 years. The report of the commission published last week is the latest attempt by the movement to sort itself out.

The last Co-operative Commission reported in 1958. The changes demanded were mainly structural: nearly 1,000 independent co-op societies had to be merged into around 50 regional societies to compete with the multiples.

Board members of small societies refused to vote themselves out of existence and ageing managers were content with the philosophy "It'll see me out". Together, they squandered the assets of the movement, hid their losses in obfuscation at annual meetings and only merged with stronger societies when they had no choice.

What this new commission wants is not more consolidation - the numbers are down to 46 societies, the top 10 of which account for 83% of business - but reforms aimed at creating a virtuous circle in which the co-operative advantage gives commercial success, which pays for social goals to be met, which demonstrates the co-operative advantage, and you get the idea.

To get the advantage, three kinds of reform are needed.

First, societies need to set targets based on commercial principles such as return on capital, to agree commercial and social performance indicators, and to present these in a form members can understand. Second, they need to demonstrate the advantage by returning individual and social dividends to members. Third, they need to learn to co-operate with each other.

The commission recognises the importance of turning customers into members. Accurate membership lists and a national membership card are essential if a new emphasis on the value of membership is to be worked through.

There are some good ideas about membership: that employees seen as stakeholders should have reserved places on the board, and that customers of the bank and Co-operative Insurance Society should be able to become members.

But renewing membership lists could play into the hands of demutualisers and the total could fall from the boasted 9m to nearer 2m members. Still, they would be real members.

John Monks, the commission chair, warns that if the movement chooses to implement only the easy bits, or (as in 1958) adopts the report unanimously and then puts it on a shelf, he fears for the future. The Co-op's competitors will ensure this opportunity does not come again.

fields.headline: Railtrack 'facing bankruptcy'
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack was last night said to be facing bankruptcy amid allegations by the rail industry regulator that it was incapable of managing its business.
fields.body:
Railtrack was last night said to be facing bankruptcy amid allegations by the rail industry regulator that it was incapable of managing its business.

The charge from the strategic rail authority (SRA) came as Railtrack confirmed that it had approached the government for an extra £2bn to ease its cash crisis, caused mainly by the increasingly heavy burden resulting from the Hatfield rail crash.

Senior sources in the authority, the government's strategy arm for the industry, said: "Railtrack is close to bankruptcy. It cannot survive as it is without the injection of further government money."

Sir Alastair Morton, the SRA's chairman, has ordered a halt to any further funding for rail maintenance because it is appalled at the way Railtrack is managing the network. His decision has been backed by the SRA's board.

He is arguing that Railtrack's funding should be separated into maintenance and enhancement, and that closer vigilance will have to be exercised by Railtrack on how it spends its money. Other companies may be brought in to carry out Railtrack work.

A senior industry source said Railtrack could only get extra funding from the government or the rail regulator, but that either way the money would have to come out of the same pot through the Treasury. Or Railtrack could be sold off to the international infrastructure firm, Bechtel, if ministers were not prepared to take it back into state ownership.

The sources said the government still appeared reluctant to take any action against Railtrack until after the election. Ministers are relying on an imminent shakeup of the company, starting with the appointment of a new chairman by the end of the month.

One of the more radical changes being canvassed is a further realignment of the railway into the old divisions of British Rail. This, it is argued, might control the spread of subcontractors and help the train operating companies to run better services.

Railtrack's admission that the cost of modernising the east coast main line from London to Scotland could double from £1.9bn to £3.8bn has as tonished the SRA and ministers. Railtrack says it is only a feasibility study but it has stopped the SRA awarding a new franchise for the second fast mainline on the route.

Railtrack's continuing problems have obscured the increasingly difficult position of the SRA and its lack of leadership. Failure by the SRA to come up with any strategy for the industry or to award new franchises is putting pressure on Sir Alastair and Mike Grant, his franchising director.

Both are at odds with the government on the award of the east coast franchise. The two final bidders are Great North Eastern Railway and Stagecoach-Virgin.

Railtrack said in a statement that it had not made a formal offer to anyone to take on the position of chairman, and that its financial position "remains unchanged from that which was announced to the stock market on 15 January 2001".

It said talks were continuing with the SRA and the Department of Transport over the timing of "deferred grants in excess of £1bn of revenue which the regulator has agreed that Railtrack needs to spend on the rail network".

webTitle: Aiming for low inflation holds risks

fields.headline: Aiming low may cost us all dear
fields.trailText: Labour loves a target. It has targets for teachers, targets for pupils, targets for hospitals, targets for the police, targets for court clerks, targets for traffic wardens. Targets have not been this popular since Henry V told his archers to twang off a few practice arrows ahead of Agincourt.
fields.body:
Labour loves a target. It has targets for teachers, targets for pupils, targets for hospitals, targets for the police, targets for court clerks, targets for traffic wardens. Targets have not been this popular since Henry V told his archers to twang off a few practice arrows ahead of Agincourt.

In the circumstances, it is only natural that the Bank of England should have a target - to keep inflation at the level laid down by the chancellor of the exchequer when he handed over control of interest rates. Gordon Brown was precise - the target was not 2% or 3%, but 2.5% - it would be for inflation excluding mortgage interest payments, and he would be just as cross if inflation were too low as he would be if it came in too high.

That, at least, was the theory. The purpose of targets is that performance can be measured, and it is easy to see how the Bank has fared. Because it takes around 18 months for monetary policy to have full effect, we can only judge the monetary policy committee since the beginning of 1999, in which time inflation has been consistently below 2.5%. Last week's figures showed that the underlying inflation rate had dropped to 1.8%, its lowest level since the series began in 1976. What is more, according to the Bank's own projections, it will stay below 2.5% for the next two years, climbing back to its target level only at the very end of the Bank's two-year forecasting period.

Actually, regular readers of the Bank's quarterly inflation report will not be surprised by the notion that inflation will back at 2.5% in two years' time, because that is what the Bank always says. Tucked away in the inflation report there is a paragraph that says inflation has come in a bit lower than was expected three months ago but that over the medium term price pressures will build up, thus returning inflation to its target without the MPC having to do anything about it.

Oblique reference

Mervyn King, the Bank's deputy governor, said last week that, given the lags involved in monetary policy, there was no point doing anything now artificially to return to the target because that would risk inflation going too high, which would necessitate harmful remedial action.

If Mr King thought this oblique reference to the risks of returning to boom and bust would be enough to deter any criticism from our hawkish chancellor, he was almost certainly right. However, the deputy governor's argument raises a number of interesting points. First, if monetary policy only works with a lag - which it does - and inflation is well below 2.5%, this seems conclusive proof that the MPC was wrong 18 months ago to have tightened policy so aggressively. Logically, if the Bank was wrong about inflationary risks 18 months ago, it might be wrong about inflationary risks again now. That certainly seems to be what another member of the MPC, Sushil Wadhwani, thinks. He said last Friday that the Bank should publish the inflation forecasts made by individual members of the committee, a move that would lift the lid on one of the world's worst kept economic secrets - that Sushil thinks Mervyn has got it wrong.

Secondly, there seems to be an asymmetry in the Bank's thinking, such that when inflation is below target it is invariably a temporary phenomenon that will be reversed automatically at some point in the future (two years) but when inflation is above target it will go on rising unchecked unless the MPC steps in and does something about it.

Finally, when you think about it, this state of affairs could carry on pretty much indefinitely, with the Bank saying every quarter that inflation has somehow turned out to be lower than expected three months earlier but that all will be hunky-dory 24 months hence.

However, let us be fair. Attempting to hit a precise inflation target with one policy weapon is supremely difficult, perhaps impossible. The fact that the Bank has managed to keep inflation within spitting distance of 2.5% for so long is no mean feat and, given Britain's recent economic record, it is understandably concerned about recidivist behaviour. There are plenty of reasons, fully documented in the inflation report, for thinking that there could be problems ahead. Last week's labour market data, for example, showed that unemployment is coming down while earnings are starting to nudge up. Skill shortages are becoming more common, threatening to bid up the price of labour.

Figures from the high street show that consumer demand - buoyed by high levels of employment - is strong. Growth in spending was robust all through last year and remained so solid over Christmas and the new year that retailers and manufacturers are starting to wonder whether this time round they can make price rises stick. To crown it all, investment performance has been poor, underlining an age-old defect in the economy - the failure of supply potential to rise in line with strong consumer demand.

So, while the trade-off between the four big macro-economic indicators - growth, unemployment, inflation and the balance of payments - is as good as it has been since the early 1960s, some on the MPC are concerned that the future could be a carbon copy of the past and that after eight years of growth this is the time for maximum vigilance.

Death of inflation

But, as the inflation report itself acknowledges, there is no reason why history should repeat itself. The Bank believes that the supply-side performance of the economy has improved, and that this is reflected in the way wages and prices have been much better behaved. Throughout the 1980s, for example, average earnings growth did not once drop below 7.5%; it currently stands at 4.4%, even though the claimant count measure of unemployment is considerably lower than it was in the 1980s. Part of this has to do with a low-inflation environment which people expect to persist, and the Bank may have played its part in engendering the new mood. But, as the graph shows, inflationary pressure in both the domestic and global economies has been falling steadily for 20 years or more, with only the blip at the end of the 1980s interrupting the downward trend. Roger Bootle was one of the first to detect that times had changed, arguing in his book, The Death of Inflation, that the real danger ahead could be deflation. The end of big government, globalisation, technological innovation, privatisation, increased competition, the emasculation of the unions were all changing the economic climate, he argued.

Japan has shown that coping with deflation can be just as problematical as coping with inflation. And what is interesting is how close the US and Britain are to deflation even after such long periods of growth. A downturn of even moderate size could lead to the first generalised fall in prices since the Depression. There is little margin for error.

Mr Wadhwani appears to be aware of this risk, even though the MPC as a whole is not. "Over the last decade, forecasters have systematically underestimated GDP growth and overestimated inflation," Mr Wadhwani said in an interview with the Central Banking journal. What this means is that policy is too tight and has a bias towards deflation, despite the small cut in interest rates earlier this month.

In their defence, the cautious members of the MPC would no doubt say that inflation is never really licked and will sooner or later make a comeback. They are no doubt right. But in the meantime they should perhaps ponder on a piece of City wisdom. What do you call someone who is right ahead of his time? Answer: wrong.

fields.headline: Mine kills three Serb policemen
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Serbia
Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: The death of three Serbian policemen whose truck ran over anti-tank mines in Kosovo yesterday led to further calls for a crackdown on ethnic Albanian guerrillas in southern Serbia.
fields.body:
The death of three Serbian policemen whose truck ran over anti-tank mines in Kosovo yesterday led to further calls for a crackdown on ethnic Albanian guerrillas in southern Serbia.

The incident took place in on an earth road in the village of Lucane, on the frontline between Yugoslav troops and the Albanian rebel.

It happened two days after at least seven Serbs were killed in Kosovo when the bus in which they were travelling was blown up. Forty-three people were injured in the incident.

"We want to solve the conflict in a peaceful way but obviously horrific tragedies are taking place," a Yugoslav defence ministry official, Milovan Coguric, said.

The mine explosion happened as the Serbian deputy prime minister, Nebojsa Covic, was discussing the possibility of holding peace talks with Albanian leaders in a week's time. Mr Covic's plan for democratic reform and investment in the region was backed by Nato and the EU on Thursday.

But there were fears among the Nato-led peacekeeping force, K-For, that the latest violence could bolster support for those in the Yugoslav government seeking military intervention.

"It is clear that we are at a perilous time with the submission of the Covic plan in Brussels," Brigadier General Robert Fry, the commander of British troops in Kosovo, said.

A political adviser to the head of K-For commented: "There are many parties who could benefit from this act [the mine], on both sides."

Yesterday forensic experts said that the death toll from the bus bombing could be much higher than seven. Captain Claus Irrgang, a member of a German police team, said a final number would not be known for several days.

"There may be more than 10 people, but it's difficult for us. I cannot give you an exact count."

In the Serbian enclave of Gracanica, the bus's destination, officials said the number could be 16. About 1,500 people gathered yesterday to remember the dead and demand increased security from K-For.

webTitle: Euro jokers could ruin Brown's hand

fields.headline: Euro jokers could ruin Brown's hand
fields.trailText: For a contest that was supposed to herald online political campaigning, the US presidential election was more like a return to the industrial revolution. Its enduring images were of mechanical machines counting pile after pile of disputed ballot papers and pregnant chads.
fields.body:
For a contest that was supposed to herald online political campaigning, the US presidential election was more like a return to the industrial revolution. Its enduring images were of mechanical machines counting pile after pile of disputed ballot papers and pregnant chads.

But before the dark days of Florida, the US did offer web evangelists a taste of future elections. And since the US is five years ahead of the world with anything web-related, the results are being studied by party strategists in the UK.

Both Democrats and Republicans invested heavily in web campaigning during the election. But a survey by America's e-Voter institute - a non-partisan company promoting the use of the internet as a political tool for campaigning and analysis - found that their investment yielded disappointing results. Gore's adverts enticed Republican supporters to vote for Bush, and vice versa: 60% of Democrats who saw online adverts for Bush voted for Gore.

From the industry's point of view, the only good news was that swing voters who identified themselves as Democrats were 18% more likely to vote for Gore once they had seen an online advert. The same figure for swing voters who identified themselves as Republicans was 4%.

The survey tracked 40,000 customers of Juno Online Services, a free ISP in the US that required users to allow their surfing habits to be tracked, from June to November 2000. Participants registered their sympathies before the study began and their exposure to advertising was then monitored, and voting behaviour tracked after the election.

The apparent adverse reaction threw Labour's Millbank appratchiks into a tizzy two weeks ago as they rushed to deny reports that they would abandon a top-secret internet advertising blitz. But Dennis Kavanagh, professor of politics and communication studies at Liverpool University, believes they have had a rethink.

"The Labour party was intending to use this general election as a prototype for five years' time where we really could see some proactive marketing on the web," he says. "That's now on the back burner as strategists realise that these ads, especially the pop-up-style ones, are very potent but need to be handled with care because people find them irritating."

That view is partially borne out by the latest findings from Forrester Internet User Monitor, which shows that 51% of British net users object to pop-up banners or internet advertising. American online strategist Steve Clift, who runs Web, White and Blue - a consortium of American political portals - believes much of the time and effort of website designers was misguided and that a simple email list was often the best form of online campaigning.

He says: "The key element is to register email details and create an electronic loop of information. The Gore website was beautiful to look at and very features-rich, whereas the Bush site was more message-orientated with a 2m sign-up target for emails."

Clift's own research shows that while just 15% of the American online public visited a political site, 50% sent or received a political email. That fact is not lost on Conservative Central Office, which last week launched a William Hague audio-email urging supporters to save the pound - and forward the email.

Labour denies shelving its internet campaign (the official line being that since no details of what it had planned had been released, no change of direction had taken place) and is now keen to play up a policy of letting webmasters put "Labour party sign up email" boxes on their sites.

A spokesman for its election strategy team says: "It's something we've been studying carefully for years. There are so many styles of internet advertising - banners on non-political websites, pop-ups, email lists, click through, region-specific ads - but you have the same dilemmas in the new medium as you do in the old. You know what they say, 'In advertising, half the money you spend is wasted, it's a question of which half.' The main website is a fantastic resource for getting your message across unmediated by the press and broadcasters, and for telling constituencies exactly what cuts the Tories are planning in their home town. We would be silly not to enlarge it in the years to come - especially if you look at projected rates of growth and penetration."

David Walter, head of communications and chief strategist for the Liberal Democrats, agrees: "For the LibDems, everything has to come back to finances. We don't get the £5m cheques the larger parties pick up, and so our resources will be concentrated on our internet site, both as a point of reference for voters on policy issues, and for selling ourselves through pro-active campaigns, such as the petition currently running to save our tube at www.savethetube.org. That's proved hugely successful and also gives us a database of emails to contact."

One said: "A party website does not count as campaign spend because people visit it unsolicited. However, a mass email to 400,000 subscribers should be registered, but how do you measure the cost of an email? It's not as simple as auditing 400,000 first class stamps."

fields.headline: Two beers, please
fields.standfirst: Saying the above very loudly is the closest most Brits get to speaking a foreign lingo. And as Dolly Dhingra finds, it's the biggest bar (no, not that sort) to European integration
fields.trailText: Saying the above very loudly is the closest most Brits get to speaking a foreign lingo. And as Dolly Dhingra finds, it's the biggest bar (no, not that sort) to European integration.
fields.body:
Britain is a nation where cappuccinos have become an everyday beverage, wine an every evening tipple and curry the nation's favourite dish. Yet the biggest barrier to European integration remains our poor language skills.

Last week the German and French ambassadors to Britain jointly deplored the state of language learning in this country, and recent UCAS figures have shown a decrease in the number of students taking language degrees.

Students are now more likely to study cinematics, media studies, drama and even sport science at university than to take a language degree. Uptake for combined languages degrees is down by almost 10%, and the subject now ranks in the bottom 10, alongside music, sociology and mechanical engineering. Unsurprisingly, these figures are causing many to speculate how the shift will effect the competitiveness of the UK's workforce in Europe.

Minna Miller, 27, left Sweden to work in London more than seven years ago, and speaks Finish, Swedish and English. She uses all her languages in her job as PA to the MD of Fox Kids, a Scandinavian children's cable TV channel in central London.

Appointments Bi-Language, an agency that specialises in multilingual support staff, found her the job, a permanent position, less than a week after she registered with it.

"Even if our temps don't use their knowledge of languages within their jobs, international companies prefer them purely because they tend to be more culturally aware, are often better educated and won't get into a panic if someone should call up and speak to them in another language," says James Munroe, temporary divisions manager of Appointments Bi-Language.

The shortfall of bilingual workers in Britain's workforce is also a worry for the government. The Department for Education and Employment is an enthusiastic supporter of the Socrates-Erasmus programme, through which more than 12,000 people have already travelled abroad to improve language skills. Many have lived abroad for a year without paying any language tuition fee.

Working for an international company, Miller is used to switching from one language to another. Correspondence and emails are written in Swedish and workers can use discretion when answering the phone - calls can be taken in Swedish or English. Does she ever forget to use the right language at the right time? "I do when I'm stressed out!"

While a foreign accent can sometimes be a disadvantage - Miller lost all trace of her Swedish intonation after one employer told her she would be sacked otherwise - she feels that being multilingual allows her to be more expressive and eloquent. "In our offices you might find us speaking in a garble of both languages. Sometimes there are better words to express yourself in a certain way in a particular language and it's nice to be able to use both."

Those who struggle to order a beer on holiday may look at her in envy, but, says Miller, she has to work at keeping her languages in shape - "I'm always concerned that they might get rusty" - so she works part time as a translator. Practice, after all, makes perfect.

fields.headline: Dedicated follower
fields.standfirst:
It is London Fashion Week and, as Tonie Myles-White tells Tom Twentyman, behind the cool of the catwalk, the heat is on

Special report: London Fashion Week 2001
fields.trailText: It is London Fashion Week and, as Tonie Myles-White tells Tom Twentyman, behind the cool of the catwalk, the heat is on.
fields.body:
The Natural History Museum is not a place that immediately springs to mind as the epicentre of the stylish world of couture. But over the next few days, it is the HQ for London Fashion Week, during which the autumn/winter 2001 collections of more than 200 designers will be given their first public airing.

It is also the base for Tonie Myles-White, who is part of the team managing the British Fashion Council office there. "I'll be greeting the press and buyers, and helping to ensure that the shows run on time," she says. Myles-White was in the front line at both versions of this biannual event last year, and her experience is that "things can get quite frantic".

Take the example of the designer who had been sponsored by a bottled water company. "Supplies had been placed in goodie bags, but for safety reasons, no glass bottles were allowed in the auditorium and they had to be removed. During the hold-up, the entrance to the hospitality area was literally under siege and I had to sprint over to the caterers, smile sweetly, and beg them to start serving champagne."

Despite being so close to the action, this doesn't guarantee she will see any of the shows. "Usually, I'm too busy. If I am lucky enough to get away, I like people-watching," says Myles-White, who agrees that the audiences - clad in their collective finery - are a sight worth seeing in themselves. She recalls overhearing Stella McCartney and Sara Cox discussing "the pair of ultra-trendy boots Sara had on, and she said it felt as if she was wearing wellingtons. It was a completely normal girly conversation, really."

Together with owning and organising London Fashion Week, the council also helps those with inquiries about the industry - from educational options to business advice. Myles-White, 27, has worked as assistant to John Wilson, the council's chief executive, and administrator Simon Ward since November 1999.

Established names are spared the process of actually qualifying for the week. For others, last November's vetting day was their chance to be considered - and Myles-White had to notify them of the outcome. For that duty, more than one standard letter was needed. "We have four different categories - two catwalk, plus two exhibition stands. Some wanted to be considered for all of them, or perhaps two or three. Which, of course, meant a number of different replies to send out."

Myles-White allocated each designer a slot in the schedule, but despite her best efforts, not everyone got their preferred choice. And when dealing with the irate on the phone, it pays to be diplomatic. "This is important to them, so I make sure I go calmly through their concerns. I then keep a written note, and discuss it with John and Simon." If she is shouted at down the line, she asks them to call back in half an hour, after they have calmed down.

She has had other forays into fashion. Sandwiched between two spells in PR was 18 months as advertising coordinator for shoe designer Patrick Cox.

"The public have this Ab Fab image of the business - constantly flitting from party to party, and calling everybody 'darling'." Sadly, it isn't like that for her. "In amongst any exciting moments, a lot of it is very hard work."

A dress code, as such, is not in force at the council - smart, especially if meeting people, is the general idea. Although she enjoyed what she describes as a "generous" clothing allowance while working for Cox, that perk is deemed inappropriate here. Nor is she kitted out from top to toe in freebies. "We don't look after one specific designer, and we can't even appear to favour one over another," she explains.

All of which left her in the lurch in the run up to London Fashion Week. "It's at times like this," she says, "that I realise I simply haven't got a thing to wear."

 London Fashion Week runs until Friday.

webTitle: Boat people put France on the spot

fields.headline: Boat people put France on the spot
fields.standfirst:
Politicians divided over what to do next after more than 900 Iraqi Kurds are dumped on the French Riviera by a people-smuggling ring

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Politicians divided over what to do next after more than 900 Iraqi Kurds are dumped on the French Riviera by a people-smuggling ring.
fields.body:
As France debated what to do with its first mass wave of illegal immigrants, 910 Iraqi Kurds whose rusting freighter was deliberately run on to a Riviera beach on Saturday were recovering in an army camp from their eight-day ordeal.

"They're doing just fine," Eric Painsec, head of aid operations for the French Red Cross, said. "Many are extremely tired, weak and dehydrated, but no one is in danger. Given the conditions they were travelling in, it's a miracle no one died."

The 480 children, 180 women and 250 men - plus three babies born during the voyage - spent more than a week locked in the holds of East Sea, a decrepit Cambodian-registered freighter that sank at sea soon after it was pulled off the sandbank by a French tug.

The captain and crew - hired by an Iraqi-Turkish people-smuggling ring, according to French police - had locked the steering and jumped ship as soon as the freighter grounded between the upmarket resorts of Cannes and St Raphael. They destroyed the ship's papers and, although their beached dinghy was discovered yesterday morning, they have not yet been traced.

Daniel Chazé, deputy director of the French border police, said: "This was an organised operation by a known Iraqi-Turkish criminal gang. The migrants had no set destination, just Europe - they did not expect to arrive in France."

Mr Chazé said the Kurds, mainly from northern Iraq, had paid between $200 and $300 (£140 to £210) to be brought to the Turkish border. They were then loaded on to the ship for a squalid, standing room-only voyage for which they paid $4,200 (£2,900) per adult and $1,700 (£1,200) per child.

While mass landings of migrants are fairly frequent on the Italian coast, where East Sea was probably headed, this was France's first such experience. President Jacques Chirac said he was "profoundly shocked by an event unprecedented in France, marking the utterly unscrupulous behaviour of people who make business out of the misery of others".

With immigration from France's former north African colonies already a hot political issue, politicians were divided about what to do. The conservative former interior minister Charles Pasqua called for the refugees to be sent back immediately to where they came from. "If we accept them on our territory, we will open the floodgates," he said.

François Hollande, the head of prime minister Lionel Jospin's Socialist party, said the Kurds should be "welcomed with humanity", but "not given the illusion or hope of integration into our country". Immigration and asylum procedures should be strictly adhered to, he said.

webTitle: German prosecutors open Fischer perjury inquiry

fields.headline: German prosecutors open Fischer perjury inquiry
fields.trailText: Joschka Fischer, Germany's embattled foreign minister, flies to Washington today for talks with the new US administration, his political career in the balance as an investigation begins into allegations that he lied in a murder trial.
fields.body:
Joschka Fischer, Germany's embattled foreign minister, flies to Washington today for talks with the new US administration, his political career in the balance as an investigation begins into allegations that he lied in a murder trial.

He will be investigated by Frankfurt state prosecutors, who aim to establish whether he committed perjury by claiming at last month's trial of Hans-Joachim Klein not to have harboured terrorists or given refuge to the Red Army faction terrorist Margit Schiller in his flat in the 1970s.

According to Welt am Sonntag, the prosecutors have information from a former flat mate of Mr Fischer's that his flat was a shelter for urban guerrillas, particularly the RAF.

Last week another witness claimed that the radical group to which Mr Fischer belonged was used by the RAF as a channel through which to recruit members.

According to the magazine Focus, Ms Schiller stands firmly by her claim, in an update of her autobiography, that she stayed in the future foreign minister's flat.

Mr Fischer said he could not rule out the possibility that she had stayed in a different flat in the same building, and acknowledged that he might have met her over breakfast, but during the time before she was sought by the police.

webTitle: BT forced into rethink on mobile phones

fields.headline: BT forced into rethink on mobile phones
fields.trailText: BT is rethinking the future of its mobile phone business, BT Wireless, in response to increasing pressures on the company to grapple with its vast levels of debt.
fields.body:
BT is rethinking the future of its mobile phone business, BT Wireless, in response to increasing pressures on the company to grapple with its vast levels of debt.

The group is considering a range of options for BT Wireless including a full or partial demerger, a trade sale or even the stock market flotation of a larger stake than the 25% previously stated.

The review has been instigated by finance director Philip Hampton who oversaw the break-up of British Gas and joined BT in October last year.

A BT spokesman confirmed that the company had been forced back to the drawing board. "We have committed to restructuring our debt and we would be foolish not to consider what other options there are for doing so," he said.

"Philip Hampton, in particular, is keen not to dismiss any other innovative ideas for bringing down the debt and realising value from BT Wireless. That could be a full demerger or perhaps a trade sale. We can't be tied down by any pre-ordained course of action."

BT is facing a growing clamour from shareholders to resolve its crisis which has left the business with £30bn of debt and narrowing options for a way out.

The company announced plans last August for a series of disposals and the flotation of up to 25% of its directories business, Yell, and BT Wireless as part of a commitment to reduce its debt by £10bn this year.

The calamitous flotation of Orange, however, demonstrated a lack of appetite for new mobile phone equity in the market and forced BT to look anew at ways of raising cash.

The company admitted last month that adverse market conditions would be likely to derail its part flotation of Yell, which was to have raised £1bn, in favour of demerger.

The pressure on BT was made explicit at the end of last week when ratings agency Standard & Poor's warned it might cut the company's credit rating unless it could come up with a more credible path for reducing its debt.

The agency gave BT just eight weeks to come up with a new set of plans, threatening otherwise to remove its A-grade rating and raising the spectre of more expensive borrowing.

The demerger option would see BT shareholders receiving new shares in BT Wireless, the parent company of Britain's second-largest mobile network, Cellnet.

The new company would be loaded with much of BT's debt - £10bn of which has come from bidding in the auction of third-generation mobile phone licences in Britain and Germany alone. A demerger would mirror Mr Hampton's break-up of British Gas into BG and Centrica.

The BT spokesman shrugged off reports at the weekend that suggested either chairman Sir Iain Vallance or chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield might resign in response to shareholder unrest.
fields.bodyText: BT is rethinking the future of its mobile phone business, BT Wireless, in response to increasing pressures on the company to grapple with its vast levels of debt. The group is considering a range of options for BT Wireless including a full or partial demerger, a trade sale or even the stock market flotation of a larger stake than the 25% previously stated. The review has been instigated by finance director Philip Hampton who oversaw the break-up of British Gas and joined BT in October last year. A BT spokesman confirmed that the company had been forced back to the drawing board. "We have committed to restructuring our debt and we would be foolish not to consider what other options there are for doing so," he said. "Philip Hampton, in particular, is keen not to dismiss any other innovative ideas for bringing down the debt and realising value from BT Wireless. That could be a full demerger or perhaps a trade sale. We can't be tied down by any pre-ordained course of action." BT is facing a growing clamour from shareholders to resolve its crisis which has left the business with £30bn of debt and narrowing options for a way out. The company announced plans last August for a series of disposals and the flotation of up to 25% of its directories business, Yell, and BT Wireless as part of a commitment to reduce its debt by £10bn this year. The calamitous flotation of Orange, however, demonstrated a lack of appetite for new mobile phone equity in the market and forced BT to look anew at ways of raising cash. The company admitted last month that adverse market conditions would be likely to derail its part flotation of Yell, which was to have raised £1bn, in favour of demerger. The pressure on BT was made explicit at the end of last week when ratings agency Standard & Poor's warned it might cut the company's credit rating unless it could come up with a more credible path for reducing its debt. The agency gave BT just eight weeks to come up with a new set of plans, threatening otherwise to remove its A-grade rating and raising the spectre of more expensive borrowing. The demerger option would see BT shareholders receiving new shares in BT Wireless, the parent company of Britain's second-largest mobile network, Cellnet. The new company would be loaded with much of BT's debt - £10bn of which has come from bidding in the auction of third-generation mobile phone licences in Britain and Germany alone. A demerger would mirror Mr Hampton's break-up of British Gas into BG and Centrica. The BT spokesman shrugged off reports at the weekend that suggested either chairman Sir Iain Vallance or chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield might resign in response to shareholder unrest.
