webTitle: Leader: Labour is going off the Lib Dems

fields.headline: End of the affair
fields.standfirst:
Labour is going off the Lib Dems

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Blair admits Labour and the Liberal Democrats do not work closely together, stressing that the real vehicle of change in British life is and will remain the Labour party.
fields.body:
Thanks to the internet, it is now possible for anyone to read a full text of the speech Tony Blair gave yesterday to Labour's spring conference in Glasgow. Better still, the technology lets them scan the text for specific words, seeing how often they appear. They can, for example, punch in "liberal" or "democrat" or even "Liberal Democrat" to see how and when the prime minister used those terms. It will, however, be a brief task - for Mr Blair did not let those words pass his lips.

It was a useful illustration of how far the PM has come since the golden days of 1997 when he and his circle gushed evangelically about "the Project." Back then the plan was to end the Lib-Lab division which had kept the centre-left out of power for 70 of the previous 100 years. "My heroes aren't just Ernie Bevin, Nye Bevan and Attlee," Blair told the Labour conference that year. "They are also Keynes, Beveridge, Lloyd George."

The message was clear: Blair's Labour party would work ever closer with the Liberal Democrats so that the 21st century would be "the century of the radicals". To that end, he and Paddy Ashdown issued a rare joint statement late in 1998, expanding the cooperation between their two parties. The deal seemed straightforward: Lib Dems would side with Labour against the Tories while Labour would deliver that most cherished of Liberal aspirations, electoral reform.

But look at them now. While Mr Ashdown enjoyed the respect of the Labour inner circle, Charles Kennedy has won few admirers. For their part, Liberals cry betrayal, as they see Labour's earlier commitment to a referendum on voting reform melt into worthless fudge. Last week the parties' joint committee on constitutional reform broke up after Labour pulled the plug (the Lib Dems wanted too much democracy in the reformed House of Lords). Now Mr Blair admits the two parties do not work closely together, stressing that the real vehicle of change in British life is and will remain the Labour party.

The explanation for this shift is not complicated. The two factors which led to the earlier closeness are no longer there. The personal chemistry between the leaders has gone and so, in Mr Blair's eyes, has the once urgent need for unity. Today Labour's top brass look at the polls and believe they can win by themselves; they don't think they need the Lib Dems.

They are wrong. Not only is voting reform right as a matter of principle, but the reunification of the centre-left remains the only long-term strategy for Labour. The party can win this year without the Lib Dems, and maybe next time, too. But for the century ahead, cooperation is surely the only answer.

webTitle: Boots puts top staff on trial

fields.headline: Boots puts top staff on trial
fields.standfirst: 250 executives put through their paces as retail chain tries to avoid the M&S effect
fields.trailText: Some 250 senior and middle ranking executives at Boots have been told their jobs are under review as part of a root-and-branch overhaul of the retailer, designed to fend off fierce competition from supermarket rivals over health and beauty products.
fields.body:
Some 250 senior and middle ranking executives at Boots have been told their jobs are under review as part of a root-and-branch overhaul of the retailer, designed to fend off fierce competition from supermarket rivals over health and beauty products.

Chief executive Steven Russell has indicated that Boots' 50 top executives and 200 middle managers are to be summoned to the company's headquarters in Nottingham to justify their roles.

Dismissals have not been ruled out and a spokesman said Mr Russell "wants to make sure he has the right people for the job".

The review, which is already under way, is reported to include an interview of up to three hours and psychometric tests.

The existing management structure at Boots has been criticised for its lack of integration. Critics say individual businesses have evolved into fiefdoms and the group has begun to stagnate.

The review of management is one of a number of changes Mr Russell is implementing in an effort to ensure Boots avoids the decline experienced by other well-established retailers such as Marks & Spencer.

The retail chemist and health care group is also trying out a various additional services at is 200 largest stores in an effort to retain its customer base. Ultimately, a single store might provide shoppers with laser hair removal, dentistry, eye tests, Alexander technique coaching, homeopathy, chiropody and full-body seaweed wraps.

A spokesman for Boots said: "It will mean customers getting the equivalent of a full spa treatment on the high street."

Under the plans, the emphasis at the 1,200 smaller stores would be on speed and convenience, with a high number of checkouts

A spokesman for Boots, which currently enjoys high margins on many of its own-brand products, said the group was undergoing a sea change under Mr Russell.

"Boots recognises it needs a cultural change as the market becomes more competitive."

Also under review is Halfords, the bicycle and car accessories chain. It is understood Boots does not regard Halfords - which is not part of its core business - as having significant growth prospects in Britain and would consider offers for the chain. Halfords is reportedly worth £450m.

A Boots spokesman said their was no truth to weekend reports that Boots Healthcare International - the maker of Ibuprofen, E45 and Clearasil - is to be demerged or sold. "On the contrary, we are in acquisition mode," he said.

"BHI - which is the fastest growing business of its kind - is looking for acquisitions among skin care, pain relief, or cough and cold brands. There are no plans to sell it. It's a perfect fit with our health and beauty portfolio."

BHI is thought to be worth £1.3bn.

The future of Boots' 82 stores in the far east, which made losses of £19.5m in the six months to October last year, is less certain.

While the company is thought to be keen to persevere with operations in Thailand, Japan and Taiwan, Boots' international expansion programme, which began three years ago, has not fulfiled expectations.

It is understood that an option to close all overseas branches is being considered, although this is unlikely in the near future. Boots has already sold its stores in the Netherlands.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

Having been turned down by the strategic rail authority, Railtrack is appealing to the government for a £2bn cash injection to stave off financial crisis.

Hermes , one of the country's biggest institutional investors has attacked "clubbiness" within the Scottish financial establishment. It is incensed by a recent decision from Scottish Investment Trust to hatch a deal with a US "vulture fund".

Russia is considering renationalising Stolichnaya , the vodka brand, casting a shadow over Allied Domecq's purchase of US rights to the brand.

Sunday Times

Irvine Laidlaw is planning to float his International Institute for Research on the New York stock exchange later this year, valuing the conference and training company at £700m.

Sunday Telegraph

Marcus Beresford is expected to be named as the new chief executive of GKN when the engineering group announces its long-awaited restructuring this week.

Bass has pulled out of the bidding for the £3bn Granada Compass hotel business, which includes Le Meridien and Posthouse chains. Both Nomura private finance group and hotels group Marriott are still thought to interested.

IoS

Analysts are warning against treating the recent spate of "brown-outs"in California as a purely American phenomenon. Investment bank Salomon Smith Barney reckons that, if liberalised electricity markets continue to fragment, similar problems of soaring demand and hamstrung supply could trigger a similar power crisis here.

Mail On Sunday

Five of George Davies' former executive colleagues who worked with him at Asda's George clothing division are to follow the retailer to Marks & Spencer .

Britain's flood coastal defences are in line for a £100m boost in the Budget . While the Treasury has ruled out a central national disasters unit like the US federal emergency agency, a restructuring of the way emergencies are dealt with is expected to lead to a strengthened role for the Environment Agency.

Sunday Business

BMW is threatening to end production of Rolls-Royce cars in Britain if it fails to get planning permission to build a new plant at Goodwood, near Chichester. The proposed plant has been opposed by local residents and the Sussex Downs Conservation Board.

London Clubs International is preparing to sell out of the troubled Aladdin casino complex in Las Vegas. First, however, it will have to buy out most of the stake held by its partner in the venture, American property investor Sommer Trust .

Singapore Telecom has sparked a bidding war for Cable & Wireless' Optus telecom business in Australia, lodging an offer worth £7.2bn. Vodafone made a similar proposal two weeks ago.

webTitle: Oftel cuts red tape around local loop

fields.headline: Oftel cuts red tape around local loop
fields.trailText: The complicated process designed to allocate space in BT's local exchanges on a fair basis has been abandoned due to lack of interest from rival companies.
fields.body:
The complicated process designed to allocate space in BT's local exchanges on a fair basis has been abandoned due to lack of interest from rival companies.

The so called "bow wave" process was intended to deal with the anticipated demand for space. Rivals hoping to install equipment in exchanges were asked to submit a maximum of 1,500 priority requests for space to the Electoral Reform Society.

But Oftel, the telecoms regulator, said yesterday that applications could now go direct to BT instead.

The about-turn is the result of a growing number of BT's rivals abandoning plans to compete in local exchanges. Kingston Communications, Thus, Global Crossing and World Online are among those pulling out, blaming the intransigence of BT and financial hurdles put in place by the former monopoly.

Orders for space were placed in only 14 of the first 25 BT exchanges opened, with an average of one or two operators per site instead of the anticipated seven or eight.

An Oftel spokeswoman said the process of loosening BT's grip on the local network -unbundling the local loop - was still going ahead. Rival companies can place orders for space in 700 of BT's 6,000 local exchanges.

Access to BT exchanges allows use of digital subscriber lines that upgrade the copper wire network for the high-speed internet's broadband applications.

The rethink may revive interest from some telecoms companies which argued it was difficult to draw up business plans under the bow wave process.

fields.headline: £300m on offer to hi-tech start-ups
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Evidence that institutional investors are still willing to back young hi-tech start-ups emerges today with news that Advent Venture Partners has raised £300m for a new venture capital fund.
fields.body:
Evidence that institutional investors are still willing to back young hi-tech start-ups emerges today with news that Advent Venture Partners has raised £300m for a new venture capital fund.

The fund, which will rank as one of the largest British-based pools of venture capital targeted specifically at the information technology and life sciences sectors, has drawn support from the likes of Abbey National and the Shell UK pension fund.

Sir David Cooksey, chairman of Advent Venture Partners, said: "We are particularly pleased to have a significant amount of new capital to invest at a time when the quality and range of new opportunities is better than ever before and valuations are returning to more sensible levels.

"We are excited by the positive changes taking place in the environment for young growth companies, providing opportunities for attractive returns for all of our investors."

The new fund has already made four investments, three in life sciences and one in IT.

Lazy Software, a start-up developing what is described as a "novel associative database structure" targeting a number of e-commerce applications, has received £3.5m from Advent.

The fund was one of the largest investors in a £20m round of financing for Cardiac Assist, a US company that is developing a blood pump worn outside the body. The device is said to have a potential £700m market.

fields.headline: Mori in the bunker as key ally says go
fields.trailText: A key member of the Japanese coalition government threatened to quit yesterday unless the unpopular prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, is replaced before the upper house elections in July.
fields.body:
A key member of the Japanese coalition government threatened to quit yesterday unless the unpopular prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, is replaced before the upper house elections in July.

The threat coincided with a poll which showed that public support for Mr Mori has slumped to 8% since his decision to carry on playing golf when he learned that a US submarine had sunk the Japanese fisheries training ship Ehime Maru on 10 days ago.

"Public criticism of prime minister Mori's behaviour is enormous," said Tetsuzo Fuyushiba, secretary general of the New Komeito party, which holds the balance of power in parliament. Asked in a television interview if his party would leave the coalition if Mr Mori stayed until July, he said: "Yes, that will be the case."

Outrage at Mr Mori's woeful political performance on the 15th hole of the Totsuka country club has been exacerbated by the revelation that he had been given two golf club memberships worth 60m yen (£360,000). The gifts were not registered, and Mr Mori is accused of failing to pay 18m yen in taxes on them.

The Liberal Democratic party (LDP) is already under attack for an influence-peddling scandal which has led to the arrest of an MP, forced a cabinet minister to resign, and ensnared more than a dozen other politicians.

Coalition insiders say Mr Mori is likely to be replaced soon after the budget, which is expected early next month.

He has promised to "hang on".

His only chance of survival is that his possible successors may balk at taking over before an election drubbing.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Havel must rest in hospital
fields.body:
Havel must rest in hospital

The Czech president, Vaclav Havel, must stay in hospital for a week after renewed clogging of his chronically ill lungs, doctors said.

The 64-year-old's condition worsened early yesterday but improved later with a new course of antibiotics. Mr Havel's term as president ends in 2003.

Reuters, Prague

Italy's textbook murder charge

An alleged killer who supposedly taunted police with clues inspired by the crime writer Patricia Cornwell has been charged in Padua, northern Italy, with murder. Another charge of murder is pending. Michele Profeta, 53, a debt collector, allegedly left playing cards at the murder scene.

Rory Carroll, Rome

New quake in El Salvador

An aftershock measuring 5.3 on the Richter scale has rocked El Salvador, causing landslides and collapsing unstable walls near the capital San Salvador. No one was hurt.

Reuters, El Salvador

Venice: a bridge too far out

Venice has taken a controversial plunge into futurism by commissioning a glass bridge over its grand canal.

After four years of deliberation, a daring design by the Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava has been approved. The 91-metre (300ft) bridge is meant to symbolise the harmony between past and present by linking the Piazzale Roma with Santa Lucia. Critics call it "beautiful but useless".

Rory Carroll, Rome

webTitle: Style: Five almost famous British designers

fields.headline: The almost famous five
fields.standfirst:
You may not have heard of them but those in the know have them firmly in their sights. As London fashion week kicks off, Hadley Freeman profiles a handful of names to watch

Special report: London Fashion Week 2001
fields.trailText: You may not have heard of them but those in the know have them firmly in their sights. As London fashion week kicks off, Hadley Freeman profiles a handful of names to watch.
fields.body:
Markus Lupfer

Markus Lupfer, 30, probably the best known of the designers featured here, is a series of contradictions. He is a German with a giggly sense of humour. He claims to work in fashion "just to have a good time for myself" but later reveals dreams of starting a fashion empire similar to LVMH. His forthcoming collection - "Let's say kind of romantic hi-tech" - sounds an improbable clash, yet when he elaborates, it seems logical: "I mix strong spectrum colours, like black and red, and strong materials, like Chinese cashmere and silk." Finally, his clothes are uniquely attention-grabbing, but you and I could wear them every day. Even the American fashion press, who tend towards the conservative, have taken him to their hearts.

After fashion college, Lupfer worked for two years at Clements Ribeiro and the collection he is showing today, "Proper Little Madam", marks his fifth season. His show is now a recognised highlight of London fashion week, but will we lose him to Europe, as we have so many of our talented designers? "Oh no! I would find it so boring back in Germany! This is my home."

David Wyatt

For the past two seasons, David Wyatt, 29, has been the true darling of the British fashion press. His simple yet desirably cool clothes had at least one fashion editor standing on her seat and cheering at his show last season - and this from a profession in which a raised eyebrow is seen as an extreme emotional response.

Wyatt trained with that other fashion pet, Marc Jacobs, while the New York designer was consulting for Iceberg and Wyatt says the two share a sense of aesthetics. "I have always liked that clean-cut American thing, clean and simple sportswear, which is why I wanted to work for him in the first place." Certainly Wyatt's spring/summer 2001 collection - one of last season's most eagerly awaited - recalled elements of Jacobs: low hipster trousers were slouchy and elegant, short shift dresses were classic and simple.

For autumn/winter 2001, Wyatt has found a new kind of touchstone. "This time, the look is a mix of English schoolgirls and The Great Gatsby - white tights and simple jackets - with a real washed-out, dreamy, summery feel to it. Marcus Constable

"You know, I had tickets for the McQueen show last season, but I didn't go. I'd had enough of fashion by that point." Gosh, the young are hard to please these days, aren't they? But the coolness of Marcus Constable, 32, is excusable. His collection for spring/summer 2001, which was his second, was widely praised. The asymmetric tops and sexy pleated mini-skirts dovetailed perfectly with fashion's return to the new and improved 80s. He also designs a capsule collection for Top Shop which, in London, is about as big an honour as a young designer can get.

He describes his style as "strict and prim", by which he means the focus is on tailoring. In his forthcoming collection, there is, as ever, an Edwardian feel to the clothes, but with a twist. He cites this season's dual inspirations as "a felt sculptor and the manta ray, in that I have slit and draped big pieces of felt, then cut them into jackets borrowing the shape of the ray". The flirty little fishtails on the back of the skirts give an aquatic feel to this collection coming from a most English designer.

Sara Berman

It is a strange fact of fashion journalism that "wearable" is often read as a euphemism for "boring". Such instinctive reinterpretation should not be applied to the following sentence: Sara Berman's clothes are deliciously wearable.

Berman, 25, won the Marks & Spencer New Generation Award last season. She was one of the highlights of fashion week - and it was her first collection on schedule. She designs sweetly elegant 1950s-inspired clothes that flatter. There are no self-indulgent forays into extremist, unwearable designs: "I don't understand this whole slashing the top of the dress to symbolise the rape of the woman, or whatever. Her autumn/winter 2001 collection sticks with the 50s theme ("Fashion was so romantic then but grown-up"). But the clothes are not anachronistic: "A-line skirts with pleats make your bum look big, so my skirts are straight down the hips, then pleat out." Other stand-out pieces are tops with enormous knitted corsages - "Not as ridiculous as those on Sex and the City!"

Light, airy and elegant is probably the best way to describe clothing from Mulligan. Skirts tend to be A-line with sweet but not cloying patterns, while the men's clothing is fitted but comfortable. Going to a Mulligan show in the middle of London fashion week can feel like taking a breath of crisp air after leaving a smoky, crowded pub.

In contrast with the lightness of her designs, Mulligan, 37, is trenchant in her views, particularly on the problems faced by British designers. webTitle: Leader: The BBC should welcome a Scouse lilt

fields.headline: Accentuate the positive
fields.standfirst:
The BBC should welcome a Scouse lilt

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The media rumour mill suggests that the veteran Today programme presenter, Sue McGregor, will eventually be replaced by one Sarah Montague - in part because of the latter's southern English accent.
fields.body:
Equality and justice for the south-east of England may not be much of a rallying cry for progressives, but it seems to be an effective plea at the BBC. The media rumour mill suggests that the veteran Today programme presenter, Sue McGregor, will eventually be replaced by one Sarah Montague - in part because of the latter's southern English accent.

Earlier speculation had centred on Winifred Robinson, whose most striking vocal feature is a strong lilt of Merseyside (though some sceptics wonder if she has been toning it down a little in recent months, perhaps to ingratiate herself with Today's bosses). But it seems the powers-that-be fear listeners will rebel at being woken by a troika of non-southern accents - John Humphrys' Welsh, Jim Naughtie's Scottish and Ms Robinson's Scouse. So they plan some affirmative action for the English south, by opting for a broadcaster born in Guernsey and educated in Bristol.

We have no objection to Ms Montague, but we do wish the BBC would give us a bit more credit. Britain is a diverse country of (at least) four nations. Yet all too often the voices of southern England dominate, especially on the radio. If our flagship news programme were to break that habit it would be a cause for celebration, not a fate to be avoided.

fields.headline: After the bombing, the inquest
fields.trailText: We are calling on the prime minister immediately to recall parliament to allow the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, to make a statement about Friday's bombing of Iraq by US and British aircraft, and answer questions by MPs.
fields.body:
We are calling on the prime minister immediately to recall parliament to allow the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, to make a statement about Friday's bombing of Iraq by US and British aircraft, and answer questions by MPs. This air raid was launched a matter of hours after parliament went into recess, and without the House being afforded any opportunity to express its views.

The defence secretary claims that the attack was justified as "a proportionate response" to a threat to US and British air patrols (Allied planes bomb Baghdad, February 17). He subsequently stated on radio that he was prepared to go ahead with the attack even if it were to lead to war. We believe that a substantial proportion of MPs would strongly disagree with the defence secretary, given the democratic opportunity to do so.

The US-British bombing raid on Iraq was an illegal act and took place without any authorisation by the United Nations. Specifically, on January 25, in answer to a written question on the no-fly zone, the prime minister stated: "We regularly discuss all aspects of our Iraq policy with the UN secretariat including the secretary general." This has not been done.

No UN resolutions make provision for air exclusion zones or air patrols. Indeed, three security council members, France, Russia and China, have opposed the unilateral decision to establish air patrols and have vigorously protested against the latest bombing.

What happened on Friday evening cannot be justified in international law and will certainly increase tension in the Middle East at a time when the Palestinian-Israeli situation is worsening.
Alice Mahon MP, Tam Dalyell MP, Tony Benn MP

 The sheer hypocrisy of our policy towards Iraq apparently knows no bounds. After a joint bombing raid by British and American planes, we are still insisting that these attacks are carried out to protect the lives of our air-crew.

Whatever our motives for illegally overflying a sovereign country against its will, it is unreasonable to expect its ground defences to remain passive under such provocation; yet we claim that the tracking of our planes by Iraqi radar constitutes an aggressive act.

As for the no-fly zones being there to protect the Kurds and Shia, that is a complete nonsense since we take no steps to prevent our "ally" Turkey from attacking its own Kurds.
Harvey Quilliam
Maghull, Merseyside

 That the UK would obediently accompany the US in its latest bloody onslaught against the Iraqi people was predictable; but for the British defence secretary to claim that this action was "humanitarian" was an obscene perversion of language.

In what way is it now a humanitarian act to kill, maim and wound innocent men, women and children?
Adrian Marlowe
Amsterdam

 Friday's terrorist action by the two rogue states on the UN security council hardly sets an example for the much vaunted democratic values which they continually preach. So dangerous has Iraq become from the British and American actions in the "safe havens" of the no-fly zones that the UN have withdrawn their personnel from the south of the country and instructed them only to travel between 12.30 and 3pm in the north - in case they are injured or killed by US and UK bombs.

In November I visited the priest in charge of the Christian monastery on Mount Maqloub, in northern Iraq, where St Matthew is reputed to be buried. He attends to the bereaved whose loved ones have been killed in the area by UK and US missiles. These include the families of child shepherds blown to bits along with the sheep they mind. Sheep apparently present a serious threat to allied planes, with eight flocks bombed in 17 months and with them, their small minders.

"Please tell Tony Blair that he is a very, very bad man," implored the priest solemnly. Heaven knows what he thinks now.
Felicity Arbuthnot
London

 Which is tougher: a) ordering your airforce to bomb Iraq without being accountable to anybody nor having to offer any evidence for your justifications? Or b) admitting your own responsibility for the ongoing humanitarian disaster befalling Iraq under UN sanctions and genuinely seeking an alternative policy that does not punish an entire civilian population for the actions of one man?

If Bush and Blair are so desperate to gain our respect, I know which option I would prefer to see them pursue.
Matthew Ward
Bournemouth, Dorset
mattward@mcmail.com

 How short memories are! If Britain and France had reacted militarily to Hitler's occupation of the Rhineland in 1936, the second world war might never have happened, millions of lives would have been saved and Hitler's regime might well have collapsed. Dictators only ever understand force; appeasement never works. That Tony Benn should today be playing the role of Neville Chamberlain is just one of history's little ironies. Eric Bourne
Ashbourne, Derbyshire
ericbourne@talk21.com

webTitle: Letter: Channel 4's Peer of the Year Award

fields.headline: Peer group
fields.trailText: Roy Hattersley suggests (Endpiece, February 12) that Baroness Young won Peer of the Year Award at the Channel 4 Political Awards because she was the only Conservative peer "on a shortlist drawn up by Channel 4".
fields.body:
Roy Hattersley suggests (Endpiece, February 12) that Baroness Young won Peer of the Year Award at the Channel 4 Political Awards because she was the only Conservative peer "on a shortlist drawn up by Channel 4".

Channel 4 did not draw up a list of peers from which to choose. We invited nominations from all members of the House of Lords with no suggestion as to who they might nominate. We received many more nominations for Baroness Young than for anyone else. That is why she made the shortlist - and why it was no great surprise that she won the full ballot.
David Lloyd
Head of News, Current Affairs and Business, Channel 4 Television

fields.trailText: Tony Blair and Margaret Beckett are looking in the wrong place for the sources of voter cynicism (Cynicism threatens Labour, says Beckett, February 17). No need to blame the Tories in the week when New Labour has torn up the last vestiges of the comprehensive ideal and upheld its ethical foreign policy by bombing Iraq.

No need to blame the Tories in the week when New Labour has torn up the last vestiges of the comprehensive ideal and upheld its ethical foreign policy by bombing Iraq.

Newton Aycliffe, Co Durham

Corsham, Wilts

Peter Regent
Newport-on-Tay, Fife

fields.headline: But what's my motivation?
fields.trailText: Best Of Both Worlds | 101 Rent Boys
fields.body:
Being an air stewardess is bound to drive you to drink or madness. Dishing out frigid meals you know no one likes is bad enough, but having to go through that safety demonstration - faux blowing into the whistle to attract attention and everything - when passengers either aren't remotely interested or else regard you as some performing animal must gnaw away at your sanity.

This must be - in part at least - the explanation for Diane's decision in Best Of Both Worlds (BBC1, Sunday) to take up with and then marry Italian Mark while her other husband baked bread in Wales. That, and the inevitable personality disorder which must result from looking a bit like Daryl Hannah and a bit like a newsreader on a regional news programme.

For really there is little else to explain Diane's actions. Unusually for writer Paul Abbott, Best Of Both Worlds' characters are sketchy and hollow, while the plot hurtled along with the elegance and measure of a runaway rickshaw.

Occasionally sensitive and true, Best Of Both Worlds too often errs on the side of unrealistic clumsiness. There are gloriously accurate details - Diane's mischievous streak is apparent, as is her détente with her mother-in-law - but the whole fails to convince. Apart from a vague reference to her being an orphan, there isn't a hint of her motivation for beginning to lead a double life.

Of course, there need not be one event which acts as a catalyst to spur Diane onwards, but there does need to be an empathetic character whom we can understand having a moment of madness.

Unfortunately, there isn't. Diane is simply too blank and too shallow to be worth caring about. Indeed, the only time I felt slightly concerned for Diane was when she got into a blue taxi and out of a white one on the same trip. They must have magic cabs in Bologna.

With James Cosmo popping up in a quarry as if he were hewn from the mountainside (which he may well have been), Best Of Both Worlds wasn't without its moments, but its opening episode was a thorough disappointment. Taking a holiday from your real life never seemed so uninspiring.

One hundred rent boys in a weekend is enough for anyone (except, perhaps, Liberace) so 101 Rent Boys (Channel 4, Saturday) was simply overkill.

Why film-makers Randy Barbato and Fenton Bailey settled on 101 male escorts to interview about their lives and not a round 100 is anyone's guess. (Personally, I think 99 Rent Boys sounds better than 101 but that's probably because I can imagine it being sung along to the tune of Ninety-Nine Red Balloons by Nena).

Perhaps Randy (insert obvious joke here) and Fenton simply wanted to pay homage to 101 Dalmatians, though what rent boy and spotty dog have in common is beyond me. Aside from the fact that old men in country houses have a fondness for both.

So in their keenness to commemorate Dodie Smith, not to mention dazzle us with tens of ten men who did it for money, Randy and Fenton forgot the practicalities of having over 100 subjects. Hence some of the rent boys only appeared to say "I love my ass" and "my foreskin is very popular". Hardly profound insight into the world of the male prostitute. But at least this gimmickry gave a hint of the documentary style-over-content approach. Rather than make sincere, intelligent points about the sex industry, the documentary opted for butt shots, muscled lads peeling off their T-shirts and speeded up footage of a drive down Santa Monica Boulevard, cliché-blurred neon and all.

Still, once you got past all of that - and worked out exactly how much Randy and Fenton had spent paying each of the participants $50 for their time - 101 Rent Boys revealed some interesting stories. There was Bobby, who was 12 when he started having sex for money with the man in the lawn-mower shop. Dustin, meanwhile, told of how he watched his mother overdose on heroin. And a peculiar fellow named Dominic J Shufelino III was adamant that "no one touches my hair". Not even a hairdresser, by the looks of things.

All peachy bottoms and tweaked nipples, 101 Rent Boys came over as titillation masquerading as a serious documentary. It should have been a lot cleverer: serious documentary disguised as cheap thrills. If only.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Dick Tracy | Live Cross-Country Skiing | Star Trek: Voyager
fields.body:
Films

Dick Tracy
(Warren Beatty, 1990)
6am, 4.30pm, Sky Premier

Beatty's square-jawed Dick Tracy is firmly rooted in the detective's comic-strip origins. He creates a 30s mobsterland of gleaming night-time city streets and livid costumery, while the bad guys - with names like Pruneface and Flattop - are obscured under heaps of grotesque make-up. Beatty, as Tracy, is impeccable in bright yellow overcoat; Al Pacino is Richard III-like as crimelord Big Boy Caprice; Dustin Hoffman is furtive supergrass "Mumbles"; and taking the biscuit is Madonna as nightclub floozy Breathless Mahoney. An extraordinary visual experience; it hardly matters that there's no emotional involvement.

The Butcher's Wife
(Terry Hughes, 1991)
8pm, Sky Cinema

A blonde Demi Moore stars as a clairvoyant smalltown girl whose offal premonition leads her to wed overweight butcher George Dzunda. While he serves steaks at his Greenwich Village shop, she offers insights into his customers' love lives. Psychiatrist Jeff Daniels asks her to cut it out, in this light and likeable romantic comedy.

Ma Vie En Rose
(Alain Berliner, 1997)
8pm, FilmFour

The charming tale of sweet Ludovic, a boy who's really a girl inside. Plays with dolls, puts on dresses, wants to marry the boy next door - all very disturbing for his family trying to settle into their new suburban idyll. Ludovic's fantasies are shot like sweet ads, and the parents' suffering is swiftly cured, but it's an engaging modern-day fable of family relationships.

Another Day In Paradise
(Larry Clark, 1998)
11.55pm, Sky Premier

Clark, who gave us that other hunk of raw reality in Kids, tones things down here, but it's still not for the faint-hearted. This is a road movie in which middle-aged drug dealer James Woods and his lover Melanie Griffiths (both terrific) take a younger couple (Vincent Kartheiser, Natasha Gregson Wagner) under their wing, leading them into a life of crime in dirty 70s Oklahoma, all back roads and sleazy motels. Grimly compelling stuff.
Paul Howlett

Sports

Live Cross-Country Skiing
12noon, British Eurosport

Last week, sports fans gorged themselves on a feast of live sport. Now we pay. Today's the day to bring out that 1992-93 season highlights video. Just keep the TV turned off. When the day's only live sport is cross-country skiing at noon, something's gone badly wrong.
Simon Burnton

Sci-fi

Star Trek: Voyager
8pm, Sky One

Last time on Voyager: Seven of Nine discovered that Unimatrix Zero, the dreamworld she shares with semi-individual Borg is real, and about to be destroyed by the Collective. In the ensuing rescue mission, three of the crew (Torres, Tuvok, Captain Kath) have been Borgalised ... In other words, series seven, episode one of the third-generation sci-fi spin-off is not the place to come aboard. But long-time adherents will notice the scriptwriters having a little more fun these days. Doctor to Seven: "I'd like to make a few adjustments to your alcove." Wouldn't we all, Doc.
Andy Bodle

webTitle: Letters: Free trade or fair trade

fields.headline: Free trade or fair trade
fields.trailText: As someone involved with the anti-sweatshop campaigns I read your article (Cheap labour, ruined lives, February 16) with mixed feelings. I can't see how the free market will save peoples' jobs.
fields.body:
As someone involved with the anti-sweatshop campaigns I read your article (Cheap labour, ruined lives, February 16) with mixed feelings. I can't see how the free market will save peoples' jobs. In a global free market their livelihoods are permanently up for tender; areas of China offer a cheaper rate than many South American factories, and you can be sure that's where the contract will eventually go.

Poorer countries are simply a resource for big business - cheap labour, cheap dumping grounds, cheap plunder. And there are so many to choose from! As long as poor countries plan their future as part of the trickle-down-economic family they will always remain poor. As long as behemoths such as the WTO, IMF and World Bank remain there will always be a supply of countries with little education, weak government and debts.
Tomas Rawlings
Bristol
tomas@pivotalgames.com

 The article attempts to address the issue of ethical consumerism but makes an important omission. While there are dilemmas about whether it is better to exploit than not to exploit at all, there are other options. Quality goods which positively assist disadvantaged people in developing countries are available from a range of outlets including Oxfam, Traidcraft, British Association of Fair Trade shops. It may be that as a result some sweatshops do not benefit, but who can argue that this is really a bad thing?
Gary Lancet
London
sales@bookchair.com

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: The condition of starvation of oxygen to the brain, as we described it in a report, page 5, February 15, is cerebral anoxia (not inoxia).
fields.body:
The condition of starvation of oxygen to the brain, as we described it in a report, page 5, February 15, is cerebral anoxia (not inoxia).

In a column headed The awful truth about the tartan, page 22 (Comment), February 16, we referred to the Edinburgh team Hibernians. It is Hibernian or Hibs, or even more familiarly the Hibees. Celtic beat Rangers 6-2 not 6-0 (August 27, last year).

In an obituary for Stephen Barry, the theatre director and administrator, page 28, November 9, last year, we said: "He worked with three artistic directors in Sheffield - Mark Brickman, Michael Rudman and Deborah Paige - through a period in which a major decline in subsidy made for a significant reduction in the quality of the work produced in the Crucible." That should have said, "reduction in the quantity of work" etc.

fields.headline: Dachau's last secrets
fields.trailText: Your article (Germans knew of Holocaust horror, February 17) is a timely reminder, following Holocaust memorial day, that there was popular support for and knowledge of the camps.
fields.body:
Your article (Germans knew of Holocaust horror, February 17) is a timely reminder, following Holocaust memorial day, that there was popular support for and knowledge of the camps. Dachau (1933-45) opened by interning 15,000-20,000 Bavarians, mainly socialist and communist workers. Was this known in Britain?

Churchill's response to Jewish requests to bomb Auschwitz in 1944 was answered in a memo he sent to Eden on July 7: "Get anything out of the Air Force that you can and invoke me if necessary." This was subverted by officials at the Foreign Office.

Robert Gellately's new book may reveal the extent of German knowledge. I suggest that future studies broaden the scope to analyse the international decision-making process. A first step would be to open our government archives to enable historians to study why Dachau was able to operate for so long. Popular support for and knowledge of the camps was not confined to Germany. Responsibility lies with all citizens of all countries who had knowledge of the camps but did not act to halt them.
Gordon Munro
Edinburgh
gjmunro@talk21.com

 Those of us who fought in the second world war will be reassured to learn that we really fought against the Germans. Let us hope that the media euphemism that the allies fought "the Nazis" will be put to rest. The war was no more declared against the Nazis than Hitler declared war against the Tories.
Eric Powell
Cardiff
e.e.powell@btinternet.com

fields.headline: A dreadful beauty
fields.standfirst: Buckenham, Norfolk
fields.trailText: Buckenham, Norfolk.
fields.body:
Across the flooded pastures at this RSPB reserve we could see thousands of lapwings hunkered down and packed together facing south into the prevailing wind. Yet every now and then a small party would detach itself from the general mass and rise inexplicably on broad piebald wings. It was fascinating to see how the momentary nervousness of a few was soon communicated to them all, sending them skywards in great waves of panic.

These collective responses by birds are known as "dreads" and, while they're sometimes triggered by a genuine threat such as a hunting predator, they often have no identifiable cause. They're just a reaction to fear itself; a time-consuming and energy-wasting byproduct of life in the flock.

Purposeless though they may have seemed, the lapwing dreads at Buckenham were extremely beautiful to watch. Sinuous lines of birds moved like a single organism and sometimes the effects of distance and foreshortening would make it appear as if one party were crashing into another. The separate groups would then either condense together and return to earth as one, or shatter across the horizon as if in a thousand pieces.

Although these large flocks give a comforting impression of the lapwing's abundance, the birds are mainly migrants from continental Europe. While about 150 pairs remain to breed on these marshes, the overall picture is far more depressing. Lapwing numbers have halved in East Anglia in just 11 years. Even though the bird's joyous sky-dance is one of the quintessential images of the British spring, we may soon find that it disappears almost completely from the wider landscape.

webTitle: TV and Radio: New gardening shows

fields.headline: Horticulture clash
fields.standfirst: Taking the odd couple format into Britain's gardens sounds like the recipe for a sure-fire hit. But will it work for real-life partners Gordon Taylor and Guy Cooper?  Matt Wells  investigates
fields.trailText: Taking the odd couple format into Britain's gardens sounds like the recipe for a sure-fire hit. But will it work for real-life partners Gordon Taylor and Guy Cooper? Matt Wells investigates.
fields.body:
If Gore Vidal had met Quentin Crisp and gone into gardening, there might have been no need for Gordon Taylor and Guy Cooper. Fortunately, he didn't, otherwise the BBC might have been forced to pay rather more for its latest odd couple.

Not that Gordon and Guy come cheap. They have designed the odd herbaceous border for Sir Elton John, after all, so one does not imagine that their invoices make particularly comfortable reading. But if they deliver a hit to the ratings-starved corporation, which is seriously lagging behind its commercial rivals in the "talked-about TV" league, then BBC2 controller Jane Root will be happy.

Whether the Curious Gardeners have the tonic concealed under their cravats is unclear: on first glance, the show seems desperately derivative. Take a couple of English toffs, send them round Britain to poke around people's property in a vintage vehicle and film them muttering archly to each other about what they find - you get the idea. The comparison is so obvious that we might as well get it out of the way to begin with: "Yes, well we know Clarissa, actually", mutters Gordon, irritated.

But there is something of a tradition of odd couples on British television. From Fanny and Johnny to Richard and Judy, there is something about them that seems to deliver a sure-fire hit. And if the formula works this time round, Gordon and Guy, like Clarissa and Jennifer, will be household names.

Gordon and Guy (it sounds much better than Taylor and Cooper) pretend to care little about such matters. In their own world they are already mini-celebrities - Terence Conran is another satisfied customer - and they play down their own role in this series. It's about gardens, not them, they would have you believe. But already there have been flickers of Fleet Street interest - and you can tell they are loving it. ("We held a little screening for 35 of our very best friends in New York", says Gordon in his deep Californian drawl. "They said, 'But there aren't enough close-ups!'")

Anyway, Gordon and Guy are not fat. At least, Guy isn't. Gordon looks as though he enjoyed the cream teas of Cornwall when the pair toured the region for the first programme. And unlike the tedious trawl of how-to programmes that seem to be stuffing the BBC schedules these days (almost a quarter of peak-time viewing on BBC1, according to a recent survey), this show is more about pretty pictures than potting plants.

"We made a very strong suggestion that they look for gardens that were traditional, eccentric and contemporary", says Gordon, who does most of the talking. "Other TV programmes dealt with these types of gardens individually but we think this is one of the first showings of the contrast between these three types of gardens."

It's aspirational and inspirational, rather than practical, says Guy. "They can look at this and say, 'We can do that'."

"Or they can get ideas," interjects Gordon.

"Ideas", echoes Guy.

(Yes, they even finish each other's sentences.)

So this is all about promoting the interest in gardening, whether as a pastime or a full-time career, then. Uh, right. We all know that what we're really interested in is a couple of old queens sniffing around country houses and back yards, delivering their acidic verdict on each. "I think of what Noel Coward said: 'To me, hanging baskets are an irritation to the retina'," rasps Gordon at one of Britain's exponents of the genre, in a delightful exchange in the first episode, prompting the basket expert to display some rather less gaudy examples.

And to the nice young Plymouth man who spent one winter "freezing my arse off" decorating a private corner of his back garden in a mosaic of colourful tiles and shells. Cue Gordon: "Have you been to Barcelona? Do you know about Gaudi?" Rather sheepish, the young man confesses that he has not. "But I've seen posters", he pleads.

The pair insist that such remarks are unscripted - and it's easy to believe them. Their on-screen performance matches off-screen reality: they have been together so long (they met in 1973) that they don't even appear to notice that they finish each other's sentences.

Where the joke is strained, however, is in the clearly rehearsed recorded links, delivered as the pair slide along country lanes in their silver 1964 Alvis soft-top sports car.

Guy: "You know why this area is a mecca for gardeners?"

Gordon: "I know you're dying to tell me!"

Guy: "Well, we're so far south and the landscape is so contoured, there's plenty of shelter and, once you find cover, the growing conditions are perfect."

Gordon: "Yes! In fact, they're nearly tropical."

Of course, the image that they happen upon triumphs of horticulture while out for a Sunday spin in the Alvis is equally contrived. The Alvis isn't theirs - it lives in a garage in Birmingham - and was transported between shoots in a special container. "Covered in lint!" exclaims Gordon, as if to stress that they wouldn't drive around in just any old Alvis.

Gordon and Guy, unlike Clarissa and Jennifer (last comparison, promise), were not thrown together for the cameras. They have been garden designers for quarter of a century, and have been together for all that time.

They now live together in what would be an extremely spacious flat in Kensington, were it not so cluttered with the accoutrements of more than 25 years of international travel. Art, artefacts and literature - including their own successful publications - tumble out from every corner. Even on the stairs leading up to the apartment, you have to pick your way around assorted bits of garden sculpture. Somehow it all fits with the bohemian image - the only thing missing is a garden. Clearly they have plenty to be going on with, what with everyone else's to worry about.

In any case, they have not always been gardeners. Guy, 63, graduated from Cambridge in law ("which I have practised for not one day") and went on to be an international marketing executive for Unilever. Gordon, 65, a liberal arts graduate of Berkeley, used to work for Sam Wanamaker as deputy director of the Globe Playhouse Trust. They stumbled into gardening rather by accident, when they were asked to look after a friend's herb farm while on a short visit to Somerset. They stayed for six years.

Now they are leading exponents in their field, and their books have become standard texts. But there are still hangovers from past lives. Gordon owns the rights to Virginia Woolf's Orlando (we never quite got around to discussing why) and he still deals with licensing. "They want to make an opera," he says contemptuously. You get the impression that he is rather attached to Orlando, and nothing that anyone does with it would be any good. Of the Sally Potter film, he says: "It was a brave attempt." Guy adds: "Tilda Swinton is a great actress, but never remotely was she a man."

If the Curious Gardeners flops, the couple will not be on their uppers. They are supporting the young Belgian designer Walter Raes in some sort of complicated project - the explanation of which was utterly confusing because Gordon failed to mention until part-way through that it didn't involve gardening.

And they have their business to run. "Most of our friends are retiring," says Gordon with the utter disdain that makes you realise that Gordon and Guy clearly have no intention of doing anything of the sort.

 The Curious Gardeners, Fridays, 8pm, BBC2. An accompanying book is published by Headline.

Where the joke is strained, however, is in the clearly rehearsed recorded links, delivered as the pair slide along country lanes in their silver 1964 Alvis soft-top sports car. Guy: "You know why this area is a mecca for gardeners?" Gordon: "I know you're dying to tell me!" Guy: "Well, we're so far south and the landscape is so contoured, there's plenty of shelter and, once you find cover, the growing conditions are perfect." Gordon: "Yes! In fact, they're nearly tropical." Of course, the image that they happen upon triumphs of horticulture while out for a Sunday spin in the Alvis is equally contrived. The Alvis isn't theirs - it lives in a garage in Birmingham - and was transported between shoots in a special container. "Covered in lint!" exclaims Gordon, as if to stress that they wouldn't drive around in just any old Alvis. Gordon and Guy, unlike Clarissa and Jennifer (last comparison, promise), were not thrown together for the cameras. They have been garden designers for quarter of a century, and have been together for all that time. They now live together in what would be an extremely spacious flat in Kensington, were it not so cluttered with the accoutrements of more than 25 years of international travel. Art, artefacts and literature - including their own successful publications - tumble out from every corner. Even on the stairs leading up to the apartment, you have to pick your way around assorted bits of garden sculpture. Somehow it all fits with the bohemian image - the only thing missing is a garden. Clearly they have plenty to be going on with, what with everyone else's to worry about. In any case, they have not always been gardeners. Guy, 63, graduated from Cambridge in law ("which I have practised for not one day") and went on to be an international marketing executive for Unilever. Gordon, 65, a liberal arts graduate of Berkeley, used to work for Sam Wanamaker as deputy director of the Globe Playhouse Trust. They stumbled into gardening rather by accident, when they were asked to look after a friend's herb farm while on a short visit to Somerset. They stayed for six years. Now they are leading exponents in their field, and their books have become standard texts. But there are still hangovers from past lives. Gordon owns the rights to Virginia Woolf's Orlando (we never quite got around to discussing why) and he still deals with licensing. "They want to make an opera," he says contemptuously. You get the impression that he is rather attached to Orlando, and nothing that anyone does with it would be any good. Of the Sally Potter film, he says: "It was a brave attempt." Guy adds: "Tilda Swinton is a great actress, but never remotely was she a man." If the Curious Gardeners flops, the couple will not be on their uppers. They are supporting the young Belgian designer Walter Raes in some sort of complicated project - the explanation of which was utterly confusing because Gordon failed to mention until part-way through that it didn't involve gardening. And they have their business to run. "Most of our friends are retiring," says Gordon with the utter disdain that makes you realise that Gordon and Guy clearly have no intention of doing anything of the sort.  The Curious Gardeners, Fridays, 8pm, BBC2. An accompanying book is published by Headline.

fields.headline: Radio review
fields.standfirst: Smarter than the average pair
fields.trailText: The Friday Play - A Capital Case: Sherlock Holmes Meets Karl Marx | World Routes
fields.body:
If you've just had a tricky weekend, be thankful that Sherlock Holmes wasn't part of it. Not only was Sherly a cokehead, with all the

intensity that entails, but he was the quintessential smarty-pants too. He could tell when a lady friend was at the door in The Friday Play - A Capital Case: Sherlock Holmes Meets Karl Marx (Radio 4). "The doorbell was pressed by a feeble finger," he deduced; rather like the delicate digit that almost switched this silliness off for something more lively in my house.

But then I got it - it's the allure of a fantastical, postmodern meeting of Marx (real) and Holmes (fictional). Both were scaling the heights of the Most Irritating Man In History charts, and this was a meeting of equals.

When Holmes and Marx first meet, Karl's been moaning on about representation for the pages of Das Kapital, with lots of screechy violin music giving a nails-on-blackboard feeling. Holmes can tell that he's come from Kentish Town by reading the wind direction in Marx's hair. Marx explains he's lost the most precious thing. "How old is the offspring?" asked Holmes. "Seven hundred pages," replies Marx, foxily.

It worked, just, but only in the way almost any mingling of fact and fiction does. It reminded us how repulsive a prospect living with a Great Man must always be, whether he exists or not, and did at least lend itself to a cheap night in imagining new pairings: Phil Archer meets Sara Cox; Pete Tong rolls another phat one with Jolene "You're not going to disappoint me Sidney?" Rogers, still frisky from Valentine's Day.

World Routes (Radio 3) was much more real, even though it reported from half a world away. The first in four programmes focusing on South African musicians, this was thrilling stuff; far too good, in fact, for an 11pm slot on a Sunday. Eugene Skeef, the musician and broadcaster presenting this programme on Zulu-inspired gospel music, knows how to open a show. "Ask a Zulu where he's from and he'll tell you where his umbilical chord is buried." Skeef is the oldest of 47 children. Gulp.

He met Joseph Shabalala, pastor and member of Ladysmith Black Mambazo. In his church, the Sunday School choir - children between the ages of five and 11 - sing hauntingly of Aids, the new tragedy. Once again, as was for so long under apartheid, only hope, a diminishing glint, sustains the congregation. It is enough, somehow.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Isaac Babel Stories | Churchill The European
fields.body:
In 1934 the Soviet writer Isaac Babel told the Russian Writer's Congress he was practising a new literary art. He was, he said, "the master of the genre of silence". This quiet act of dissidence, in protest against Stalin's betrayal of the revolution, led to imprisonment and a bullet in the back of the head, though the exact circumstances of his death remained unknown until the collapse of the Soviet Union. Babel, a Russian Jew from Odessa, had fought with the nascent Red Army during the Civil War alongside Cossack Cavalry units. He later turned his experiences into a collection of dramatic and masterfully crafted short stories, a selection of which are read by David Suchet this week in Isaac Babel Stories (3.30pm, Radio 4).

Europe's people, wildlife and political culture are examined in a week-long series, Europe And Us, on Radio 4. In Churchill The European (8pm) David Sells unpicks Winston Churchill's ambiguous role in the history of European integration. When the ungrateful British electorate voted him out of office in 1945, Churchill turned to the Continent. He urged Franco-German reconciliation and did much to encourage the nascent EU. Truly one of Europe's "founding fathers", Churchill believed whole-heartedly in integration - but for the Continentals, not for Britain and her Empire.

webTitle: Arts: German painter Caspar David Friedrich

fields.headline: The ghost of Germany's past
fields.standfirst: The haunting landscapes of Caspar David Friedrich satirised the Napoleonic empire. They would later do the same for the Third Reich.  Jonathan Jones reports
fields.trailText: The haunting landscapes of Caspar David Friedrich satirised the Napoleonic empire. They would later do the same for the Third Reich. Jonathan Jones reports.
fields.body:
If we are honest about why Caspar David Friedrich has become Germany's best-loved painter and an icon of Germanness, it is because when we look at his landscapes we can smell the brimstone. We know, before the historians tell us, that Hitler liked his paintings. The emptiness and mysticism of Friedrich's vistas, populated only by the ghosts of German heroes, have made him the visual equivalent to Wagner: a grimly scarred anti-hero in the hall of cultural giants. Not that this has stood in his way. This Romantic landscape painter, all but forgotten after his death in 1843, has been rediscovered in the last 30 years.

In the 1970s, German artists and film-makers returned to the charred forest of their cultural heritage to re-imagine a landscape shattered by Nazism, then muffled in felt by postwar blandness in the west and supranational Stalinism in the east. They went looking for Germany and what they found was Friedrich.

In a series of performances called Occupations, the German painter Anselm Kiefer had himself photographed in Friedrichesque landscapes, with his back to us like the figures in Friedrich's paintings, giving a Nazi salute. His rival, Gerhard Richter, has also revisited Friedrich's landscape, but painted it blurred, as if seen through a car window on the autobahn on a rainy day.

When Werner Herzog remade FW Murnau's film Nosferatu in 1979, he turned the story of a vampire invading a north German town into an essay on Romanticism. Characters ride across mist-covered hills straight out of Friedrich and, at the end, the vampire disappears into a vast, empty vista of sand and sky like the black-robed figure in Friedrich's greatest painting, The Monk by the Sea (c1809). Herzog sees the German landscape through Friedrich's paintings as a cursed place; the vampire is Hitler, and Friedrich. He might also be Joseph Beuys, whose face was as wasted as Klaus Kinski's in Nosferatu, and whose visionary performances and sculptures repeat Friedrich's appropriation of landscape as symbol.

Beuys's installation of giant basalt pillars lying flat on the floor at Tate Modern, The End of the 20th Century (1983-5), is chillingly similar to the shattered blocks of Friedrich's The Sea of Ice (1823-4). It goes on, this fatal attraction to Friedrich. The British-based German artist Mariele Neudecker restages his landscapes as dioramas in glass vitrines, the liquid filling the tanks evoking the airlessness of Friedrich's forests and mountains. His paintings appear on the cover of almost any classic book connected to German Romanticism or the Gothic (a cursory inspection reveals him adorning both Goethe's Elective Affinities and Bram Stoker's Dracula).

When the National Gallery's exhibition of 19th-century German paintings from collections in Berlin, opens next month there is one name who will pull in the crowds: Friedrich. Yet when the National Gallery bought Friedrich's Winter Landscape (c1811) in 1987, it was the first of his paintings to be acquired by a museum outside Germany.

Friedrich has conquered the world, but at a price - a radical misunderstanding of who he was and what his art attempts to do. Friedrich has become the supreme icon of the German romantic visionary, the artist as mountain climber, throwing away his oxygen to get a better taste of the sublime, in love with the void, an image of German history. We love him like we love Dracula, because he makes us shudder.

But Friedrich was not an operatic megalomaniac, but a man who participated in his own times rationally and with a politically astute eye. His letters, some of which are reprinted in Werner Hofmann's new study of the artist, might disappoint connoisseurs of Germanic nuttiness. Friedrich emerges as a critic of authority, a rebellious sympathiser with students jailed for protesting against autocratic regimes in the divided mini-states of Germany after the Congress of Vienna in 1815, and a passionate advocate of change - in short, a 19th- century liberal.

The true father of Romantic landscape painting was Napoleon. The self-crowned Emperor's apparently invincible armies made the landscape of Europe visible in a new way as they marched across the continent. Friedrich saw the German statelets defeated humiliatingly by Napoleon, just as Goya experienced the annexation of Spain, and Turner saw Britain turn its sea into a defensive wall.

But what made Friedrich see the danger of landscape was Napoleon's fall. Napoleon was brought down by space, weather, nature. His march on Russia ended in the empty wastes of a northern winter. Romantic landscape painting is convulsed by the Napoleonic wars; in Turner's Snowstorm: Hannibal and his Army Crossing the Alps (1812), Boney is personified by the ancient Carthaginian general dwarfed by the might of mountains and weather.

In Friedrich's paintings he suffers a far worse fate. In 1814, the year after the retreat from Moscow, Friedrich painted The Chasseur in the Woods. A French soldier, cut off from his comrades, stands in a narrow clearing in a forest he will obviously never escape. A massing of brown firs rise as high as towers above him, sealing him inside. He seems to have given up, is resigned, letting his sword drag at his side, awed by the impenetrable, irresistible darkness that engulfs him.

This Napoleonic Blair Witch Project figures Napoleon as one of his doomed soldiers, but instead of the Russian steppe it is the German forest that defeats him. This painting is often seen as a nationalist statement. Germany, suggests Friedrich, is a tangled, deathly forest that will swallow up its enemies.

To see any of Friedrich's paintings as simply nationalist is, however, mistaken. His paintings are not celebrations of German mysticism so much as examinations of it. Friedrich uses the emptiness of the Baltic shore and the Thuringian forest to suggest the hubris of empire. He is not the prophet of German territorial ambition but its satirist.

Friedrich's theme is the unconquerability of space. Human beings are tiny interlopers in a world they can never hope to rule. He exposes authority - of the monarchical states, Prussia and the rest, from which German liberals felt so alienated - as a cosmic vanity. In 1810 he sent his most famous pair of paintings, The Monk by the Sea and The Abbey in the Oak Wood, to be shown in the Prussian capital, Berlin; Prussia had been crushingly defeated by Napoleon in 1806.

The paintings were a sensation and bought by the royal family; but are they assertions of national greatness, visions of the Teutonic eagle avenging itself? On the contrary, they are melancholy acceptances that defeat is not just temporary, but the human condition.

Friedrich's landscape is a place where you cannot get a foothold. Try to conquer it, and you fall through the ice. Napoleon is doomed by this landscape, and so is Hitler. This art is not irrational; it is about the irrational. In his painting Woman at the Window (1822), coming to the National Gallery, a woman with her back to us - his wife, Caroline - looks out of a secluded interior, at a boat's mast on a canal outside the house.

The house is the safe realm of bourgeois domesticity, which Friedrich aspired to and achieved; outside is the ship, an ominous presence, coming into town out of the German landscape. It represents everything Friedrich fears and desires. It might be the Flying Dutchman's ship - or it might be the vessel that brings the vampire to town with his army of rats.

 Spirit of an Age: 19th-Century Paintings from the Nationalgalerie, Berlin, is at The National Gallery, London WC2 (020-7747 2885), from March 7 until May 13. Werner Hofmann's Caspar David Friedrich is published by Thames and Hudson, £39.95.

fields.headline: Screen grabs
fields.standfirst: Coming to a box near you
fields.trailText: Coming to a box near you.
fields.body:
 We're sorry. But we felt we had to pass on the news that the all-conquering Sopranos may soon be facing a self-inflicted whacking. With the much-loved mob drama's third series about to begin in the US, series creator David Chase has told interested parties that, once a fourth batch of shows is in the can, he's planning on bringing the curtain down for good. "My deal goes through four seasons," Chase revealed last week, "and, at present, it would be my wish that the show end then. A lot of us on the show have an aversion to the idea of a show existing past its prime."

 On a rather more cheerful note, BBC1 has announced the launch of Bedtime Reading Week, in which various minor celebs (mostly contracted to the corporation, strangely) will sing the praises of settling down with a good book. Now, is it us, or is this the most self-sabotaging behaviour for a TV channel since the halcyon days of half-term favourite Why Don't You?, with the subversive invitation of its theme song to "switch off your television set and go and do something less boring instead"?

 Channel 4, meanwhile, look set to shock even their most worldly viewers with the bold and innovative Doing The House Up. Airing early next month, this potentially incendiary show promises to focus on six households across the country as they - and here's the clever part - Do The House Up. You've got to admit, this one's straight out of left-field (even if Screen Grabs remains sceptical that such wacky programme ideas could ever hope to attract viewers).

webTitle: Lorry lane plan to beat gridlock

fields.headline: Lorry lane plan to beat gridlock
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Some of the most radical traffic control measures ever used in Britain may be tested on the M62 in a bid to prevent gridlock on a route vital to the economy of the north.
fields.body:
Some of the most radical traffic control measures ever used in Britain may be tested on the M62 in a bid to prevent gridlock on a route vital to the economy of the north.

The motorway, England's most northerly, runs from the outskirts of Liverpool to Humberside, crosses wild Pennine hill country and during blizzards is often the only east-west road link to remain open. New measures may include lanes reserved either for lorries or for vehicles with one or more passengers.

The M62 now carries up to 190,000 vehicles a day on some of its busiest sections (compared with 225,000 on the M25) and drivers are plagued by long snarl-ups and unpredictable journey times.

Forecasts show that traffic will increase by an average of 35% by 2010 and almost doubling on the busiest sections. Congestion around junctions 26 and 27 near Leeds and Bradford will increase from three hours a day to nine hours.

If nothing is done, the average time for the 53-mile trip from the junction with the M6 west of Manchester to the M1 south of Leeds will rise from 1hr 31min to 1hr 55min.

The journey from Liverpool to Hull would take 3hr 14min, making a mockery of the brave predictions made in a brochure published when the Queen opened the M62 in 1971: "By the mid 1970s, the 100-mile journey from Liverpool to Hull will be cut from five exhausting hours to an easy cruise of less than two hours."

Although ministers have done a u-turn on road-building, relief schemes for the M62 are unlikely after disastrous proposals for a new six-lane highway around north-west Manchester were abandoned in the mid-1990s. The plan blighted hundreds of homes.

Neil Hewitt, the highways agency's area manager for the north-west, said: "We are testing the water on how we manage traffic growth without major road improvements."

Mr Hewitt and his team have outlined two possible lane segregation schemes, both of which would involve widening the motorway to four lanes on the most congested sections.

Under one scheme, two lanes would be reserved for lorries; with the so-called HOV scheme (high occupancy vehicles), two lanes would be reserved for vehicles with two or more occupants (cars, buses, taxis).

If HOV lanes - common in US cities - were introduced, a driver with one or more passengers could speed from Manchester to Leeds in 43 minutes in 2010, five minutes quicker than now. But drivers of other vehicles would find that their journeys took eight minutes longer.

If lorry lanes were created, truckers could make the same trip in just 49 minutes in 2010. But other drivers, confined to just two lanes, would find that their journey time had increased to 72 minutes.

A preliminary sift of consultation forms suggests a preference for lorry lanes - but that could mean more forms were completed by truckers than other drivers.

If nothing is done, the average time for the 53-mile trip from the junction with the M6 west of Manchester to the M1 south of Leeds will rise from 1hr 31min to 1hr 55min. The journey from Liverpool to Hull would take 3hr 14min, making a mockery of the brave predictions made in a brochure published when the Queen opened the M62 in 1971: "By the mid 1970s, the 100-mile journey from Liverpool to Hull will be cut from five exhausting hours to an easy cruise of less than two hours." Although ministers have done a u-turn on road-building, relief schemes for the M62 are unlikely after disastrous proposals for a new six-lane highway around north-west Manchester were abandoned in the mid-1990s. The plan blighted hundreds of homes. Neil Hewitt, the highways agency's area manager for the north-west, said: "We are testing the water on how we manage traffic growth without major road improvements." Mr Hewitt and his team have outlined two possible lane segregation schemes, both of which would involve widening the motorway to four lanes on the most congested sections. Under one scheme, two lanes would be reserved for lorries; with the so-called HOV scheme (high occupancy vehicles), two lanes would be reserved for vehicles with two or more occupants (cars, buses, taxis). If HOV lanes - common in US cities - were introduced, a driver with one or more passengers could speed from Manchester to Leeds in 43 minutes in 2010, five minutes quicker than now. But drivers of other vehicles would find that their journeys took eight minutes longer. If lorry lanes were created, truckers could make the same trip in just 49 minutes in 2010. But other drivers, confined to just two lanes, would find that their journey time had increased to 72 minutes. A preliminary sift of consultation forms suggests a preference for lorry lanes - but that could mean more forms were completed by truckers than other drivers.

fields.headline: Woman sought for village shooting
fields.standfirst: No motive, say police, as female friend of nightclub boss is hunted after he was injured and his bodyguard shot dead
fields.trailText: Police were last night hunting for a woman and two children after a nightclub boss was seriously injured and his bodyguard killed in a shooting in a Berkshire village on Saturday.
fields.body:
Police were last night hunting for a woman and two children after a nightclub boss was seriously injured and his bodyguard killed in a shooting in a Berkshire village on Saturday.

Arthur de Sousa, 33, was last night described as being "critical but stable" after being hit by an automatic pistol in Pangbourne.

But the wealthy businessman's bodyguard, Al El-Hachadi, 27, was pronounced dead on arrival at hospital after being shot several times in the stomach.

Thames Valley police issued an all ports alert and warned the public to report sightings of a red Audi saloon, which was believed to contain the woman and two children, and a blue Range Rover seen speeding away from the scene of the shootings just after 9pm.

Last night armed police swooped on a house in Reading and detained a 23-year-old man in connection with the shootings. A police spokesman said a blue Range Rover had also been seized in the raid, but the red Audi and its occupants were still at large. The two men were shot outside a terrace house belonging to a woman with two children who is believed to have been friendly with Mr de Sousa.

Neighbours reported hearing several loud bangs ring out just after 9pm on Saturday. Armed police, who were on the scene in minutes, found Mr de Sousa in the garden of the house and Mr El-Hachadi lying in the grounds of the next door Methodist church, just a few hundred yards from a police station. Neither of the victims lived in the village.

Thames Valley police confirmed they had been called to an altercation at the property involving the two victims earlier on Saturday, but the situation had been defused.

A police spokesman said: "At this stage there is no clear motive for these shootings. There are numerous inquiries being carried out across the country.

"We do not know the involvement of the woman and children but we are happy that there is not a kidnapping involved here."

Neither of the victims has been officially named by the police. Ian Crimp, 59, who lives opposite the house where the shootings occurred, said he heard between eight and 10 loud bangs.

"After about 10 minutes an elderly neighbour who lives on her own rang me to say she was concerned about the noises," he said. " I opened my front door and there were teams of police officers already there. Many were armed.

"I saw paramedics remove a person on a stretcher. It's a fairly sleepy little village and it has come as a shock to everyone. It's not what you would expect to happen in Pangbourne."

Neighbours said Mr de Sousa lives alone in a detached bungalow on an exclusive estate in Tilehurst, Berkshire. His wife and young son and daughter had moved to the Isle of Wight earlier this year.

A woman, who asked not to be named, said it was not unusual to see police cars outside the electronic gates of the luxury property, which is protected by guard dogs.

Mr de Sousa's father, Judice, said from his home in Reading: "We are awaiting news from the police. At the moment we do not know what is behind this.

"We are very, very upset and worried about Arthur. We have not been able to see him in hospital and are just waiting for the police to tell us something,"

Police closed the main road through the village for more than 12 hours following the shootings while forensic experts looked for evidence.

Detectives were last night still waiting to speak to Mr de Sousa, who is being kept under guard at the Royal Berkshire hospital in Reading.

Detective Inspector Paul Cassell, of Thames Valley police, said: "With guns being used, these are clearly highly dangerous criminals.

"This was a shocking crime committed near a busy main road in a town which has never experienced anything like this before."

Mr Cassell added: "Anybody else who knows anything about these shootings should contact the police as soon as possible."
