fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Home buyers' bedroom eyes
fields.body:
Home buyers' bedroom eyes

Findings from an internet survey of more than 1,000 new home owners show that two out of three said the number of bedrooms was the most important consideration in making their choice of dwelling.

In the footsteps of power

A collection of footwear comprising the shoes of 12 US presidents - ranging from Abraham Lincoln to Ronald Reagan - is to go on display at Birmingham's National Exhibition Centre on Wednesday. The exhibition has never before travelled outside the US.

Forgetfulness over Pill

One in five young women aged between 16 and 24 forgets to take her contraceptive pill at least twice a month, according to research by the contraceptive implant manufacturer Organon.

Ethical policing

Barry Shaw, chief constable of Cleveland police, has ruled that all the force's 2,000 police and civilian staff must attend a one-day course in ethics at Teesside University. The force will also recruit ethics counsellors.

Cash on the line

Consumers are spending a record amount on ordering goods over the phone or the internet, according to a survey by the HSBC Bank. One in three people said they were spending more than 12% of their average weekly household income without the need of leaving home.

Snack with a bite

Simon Macdonald, 49, who owns Macdonald's Smoked Produce in Lochailort, Inverness-shire, has put smoked rattlesnake on his menu. He is taking delivery of meat from 80 snakes a week from a farmer in Texas. He says the meat costs £90.80 a kilo and tastes "almost fishy".

£7.7m lottery winner

One ticket holder won last night's £7.7m National Lottery jackpot, Camelot said. Winning numbers were 10, 14, 31, 35, 40 and 45. Bonus number was 26. There was one winner of the £250,000 Thunderball jackpot. Numbers were 3, 6, 25, 30 and 31. Thunderball was 5. No one won the Lottery Extra game. Numbers were 1, 4, 11, 12, 34 and 35.

webTitle: Drug company's legal battle puts price savings at risk

fields.headline: Drug company's legal battle puts price savings at risk
fields.trailText: Supplies of cheaper prescription medicines which save the NHS more than £80m a year are threatened by a legal battle between a German-based multinational drug company and the European commission, the Consumers' Association warns today.
fields.body:
Supplies of cheaper prescription medicines which save the NHS more than £80m a year are threatened by a legal battle between a German-based multinational drug company and the European commission, the Consumers' Association warns today.

Victory for Bayer would end the whole practice of parallel trade in drugs in the EU.

Manufacturers sell products at different prices to different EU countries. But some "parallel" distributors buy drugs from wholesalers in countries with relatively low prices and re-sell them in countries at a level that undercuts the higher prices of the same products supplied directly by the manufacturers.

The row over the trade which helps the NHS control its annual £5.5bn drugs budget comes as companies are also under heavy fire from aid agencies for charging too much in developing countries.

Bayer has so far successfully fought through the courts a £1.9m fine levied by the commission in 1996 for trying to prevent the parallel trade of the heart drug Adalat into Britain. The commission and a German group of parallel traders have now taken the case to the European court of justice.

Douglas Macarthur, of the European Association of Euro Pharmaceutical Companies, said, in CA's consumer policy review, that parallel trade posed no danger to safety since the drugs had the same active ingredients as the branded drugs and they were administered in the same way, as well as being made by the same manufacturers.

"Parallel trade means increased competition which can also generate substantial savings," he said.

Clare Mackay, editor of the review, said the trade acted as an informal price control and a brake on monopolistic practices by multinationals.

"The EU, and member countries, support parallel trading in this field," she said. "It means that discounted pharmaceutical products can enter the market, reducing overall drugs budgets for member states. Diversion of sales from one EU country to another has not led to the industry cutting back on research and development, nor has it meant that a market for counterfeit or substandard products has been created."

 All NHS patients should pay the first £60 of their annual prescription bill, with better off people paying up to £120 a year, said Ian Senior, an analyst for the Adam Smith Institute thinktank. This would help to provide an extra £2.2bn for the annual medicines budget and bring an end to the postcode lottery approach to rationing expensive new treatments, he added.

webTitle: £6m plan to show geographical society archives

fields.headline: £6m plan to show geographical society archives
fields.trailText: David Livingstone may have been gone for some time, but he was never lost. He had his Royal Geographical Society brass compass with him.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
David Livingstone may have been gone for some time, but he was never lost. He had his Royal Geographical Society brass compass with him.

Nevertheless, the society eventually sent Henry Morton Stanley to find him, leading to the most famously stiff upper lip exchange in the history of exploration.

The compass, together with Livingstone's sketches of the Victoria Falls and Stanley's notes and journals, is at the society in Kensington, London. Today the society will announce a £6m lottery-backed project to open its archive of the history of exploration to the public for the first time.

It was to this building, since the Royal Geographical Society was formed in 1830, that explorers and scientists, including Richard Burton, Lord Hunt, Edmund Hillary, Sherpa Tenzing, Wilfred Thesiger, Thor Heyerdahl, Chris Bonington and Ranulph Fiennes, came to report on their adventures.

Scholars come from all over the world to consult the archive, which holds, at a conservative estimate, 2m maps, drawings, photographs, charts and books - and includes Livingstone's flat black cap which still bears the rips from a lion's claw, and 22,000 photographs of Mount Everest.

The society also owns a magnificent 1486 atlas, which was owned by William Morris and influenced his recreation of medieval styles of typography and book illumination. It also has the pocket sextant which Charles Darwin took on the Beagle expedition.

Ranulph Fiennes's polar sledge is in the basement and Captain Scott's sledge is on temporary loan to the South exhibition at the Maritime Museum.

The development scheme, which is 75% lottery funded, will add an elegant light glass entrance, designed by Studio Downie, leading to new exhibition and reading room areas, 6 built under the remaining garden.

Putting the card index catalogues and other material on the internet is as important to the project as the building.

Rita Gardner, director of the society, said: "We have been very aware of a responsibility to share this extraordinary collection with the public, but it has been impossible in the present building."

The library also includes records of 1,000 years of exploration and adventure, including Captain Sharp's Journal over the Isthmus of Darien and Expedition into the South Seas written by himself, which begins: "That which often spurs men on to the undertakings of the most difficult adventures is the sacred hunger of Gold; and 'twas Gold was the bait that tempted a Pack of merry boys of us, near Three Hundred in number."

In April 1680, the "merry boys" were briefly distracted from their quest: "The inhabitants for the most part are very handsome especially the Femail sex who are also exceeding loving and free to the embraces of Strangers. We found our entertainment so good in this place that we tarried here all the next day."

The society still gives grants and advice to scientists and explorers: last year's grant winners included teams studying rock art in Lesotho, Nubian place names, the conservation of the African clawless otter and soil erosion along the Yangtze.

fields.headline: MoD inquiry into 'privacy breach'
fields.trailText: Ministry of Defence police have ordered an internal inquiry into allegations that its officers extracted private information stored on a mobile phone of an anti-nuclear protester, the Guardian can reveal.
fields.body:
Ministry of Defence police have ordered an internal inquiry into allegations that its officers extracted private information stored on a mobile phone of an anti-nuclear protester, the Guardian can reveal.

The information, including messages from a senior MoD police officer as well as 80 personal telephone numbers, were allegedly taken from the phone of Juliet McBride, a frequent protester at the atomic weapons establishment in Aldermaston, Berkshire.

The friendly messages were allegedly from Superintendent Ivor Richards, well known to Ms McBride as a result of her regular incursions into the establishment. She dropped her phone after being escorted out of the Aldermaston base last month. It was returned to her 24 hours later with a flat battery.

A spokesman for the MoD police said the inquiry was to determine whether the information was taken in accordance with the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act.

The act states that such data cannot be taken without a warrant signed by a cabinet minister. If the MoD police did not obtain a warrant, on the face of it they would have committed a criminal offence.

It is understood that one senior officer at the MoD police headquarters in Weathersfield in Essex ordered the personal information extracted from Ms McBride's mobile phone to be destroyed. His instructions were allegedly ignored.

webTitle: Britons in UAE court on drugs charges

fields.headline: Britons in UAE court on drugs charges
fields.trailText: Five Britons appeared in court in the United Arab Emirates yesterday on drugs charges. Three face the death penalty if they are convicted by the sharia court in the northern emirate of Ras Al Khaimah.
fields.body:
Five Britons appeared in court in the United Arab Emirates yesterday on drugs charges. Three face the death penalty if they are convicted by the sharia court in the northern emirate of Ras Al Khaimah.

Stacy Simpson, 28, and his girlfriend Anne Kidd, 32, from Leeds, are charged with importing, possessing and using cocaine and hashish. They both deny the charges.

Anna Bartlett, 22, from Southend, admitted bringing cocaine and hashish into the UAE, but denied any intent to sell or use the drugs.

When she was asked by the three-judge panel why she smuggled the drugs, she replied: "I was paid for bringing the drugs into the country. Someone convinced me to do it. I was simply carrying the drugs for somebody else."

When further questioned by the head judge through a translator as to who gave her the drugs, Ms Bartlett told the court: "They were given to me by Stacy Simpson, in Germany."

Simpson denied the allegation.

Daniel Maalouf, from London, who works for an investment company in Abu Dhabi, denied possessing hashish but admitted using it.

The fifth British defendant, Katherine Jenkins, 29, from Neath in south Wales, an air stewardess living in Dubai, denied possessing cocaine.

They are on trial with Abdul Hamid, 25, from Lebanon, and Heidi Deboer, 24, from Australia, both residents of the UAE.

The accused were brought into court handcuffed in pairs.

webTitle: Getting to know you, after an intimately Christian fashion

fields.headline: Getting to know you, after an intimately Christian fashion
fields.standfirst:
Special report: religion in
the UK
fields.trailText: Getting to know someone in the Biblical sense has just got easier - all you need do is employ a quick flick of your mouse and exchange your favourite piece from the scriptures.
fields.body:
Getting to know someone in the Biblical sense has just got easier - all you need do is employ a quick flick of your mouse and exchange your favourite piece from the scriptures.

Thousands of single Christians are logging on to become part of a world wide flock where true love and romance could be just a web page away.

Organisers of www.christianconnection.com believe their matchmaking service will fill a hole in the hearts of many young people for whom the traditional church is no longer the place to meet Mr and Mrs Right.

By exchanging their details online - including perhaps their passion for Proverbs 7:18 - they hope to ensure a match made in heaven. Jackie Elton, the founder and director, said: " We know there have been lots of successful dates through it and generally the feedback is very positive."

Members looking for a partner build their own profiles on the site much like any other dating service. But the heavy emphasis on faith and moral values is the aspect which makes Christian Connection unique.

There are an estimated 300,000 single Christians in Britain. The site currently attracts more men than women and 85% of its members are under 40."Single people are very much encouraged to form relationships with others who are Christian but it can be a struggle. Those in small churches often find it hard to meet enough single people. Those in large churches feel under the spotlight, or find it hard to get to know people well," Ms Elton said.

"One of the main problems is that churches tend to attract more women than men. There are a lot of men on our website who are single and are Christian but don't go to church so much. They might feel they do not fit into the church and don't feel comfy going. The website is a way of bringing everyone together and giving people more choice.

"Singleness in general is definitely on the increase. By the year 2011, 39% of men, and 31% of women will be single. For Christians the issue is even more acute as the choices are narrower."

Franciscan monk Gerry McCann is one member of the faith who won't be logging on to make use of the website's services despite its popularity.

The 63-year-old from Gillingham, Kent, gave up the priesthood and a 40 year vow of celibacy after falling in love with a woman he met at a Christian conference in London.

Mr McCann deliberated for two years over whether to give up his lifetime's work before finally deciding his love for his wife-to-be, Sue, was his real calling.

He left the friary at the Franciscan Study Centre in Canterbury, Kent, in September 1995 and married Sue, a divorcee, a month later.

Mr McCann said that the reason he had come forward was that he wanted to make a plea to allow Catholic priests to marry.

Speaking on a Meridian television documentary, The Things we do For Love, to be broadcast tonight, he stressed: "I was a Catholic friar and I kept my vow of celibacy right until I left. But I believe it is unnatural and not everyone can manage it."

Jackie Elton, the founder and director, said: " We know there have been lots of successful dates through it and generally the feedback is very positive." Members looking for a partner build their own profiles on the site much like any other dating service. But the heavy emphasis on faith and moral values is the aspect which makes Christian Connection unique. There are an estimated 300,000 single Christians in Britain. The site currently attracts more men than women and 85% of its members are under 40."Single people are very much encouraged to form relationships with others who are Christian but it can be a struggle. Those in small churches often find it hard to meet enough single people. Those in large churches feel under the spotlight, or find it hard to get to know people well," Ms Elton said. "One of the main problems is that churches tend to attract more women than men. There are a lot of men on our website who are single and are Christian but don't go to church so much. They might feel they do not fit into the church and don't feel comfy going. The website is a way of bringing everyone together and giving people more choice. "Singleness in general is definitely on the increase. By the year 2011, 39% of men, and 31% of women will be single. For Christians the issue is even more acute as the choices are narrower." Franciscan monk Gerry McCann is one member of the faith who won't be logging on to make use of the website's services despite its popularity. The 63-year-old from Gillingham, Kent, gave up the priesthood and a 40 year vow of celibacy after falling in love with a woman he met at a Christian conference in London. Mr McCann deliberated for two years over whether to give up his lifetime's work before finally deciding his love for his wife-to-be, Sue, was his real calling. He left the friary at the Franciscan Study Centre in Canterbury, Kent, in September 1995 and married Sue, a divorcee, a month later. Mr McCann said that the reason he had come forward was that he wanted to make a plea to allow Catholic priests to marry. Speaking on a Meridian television documentary, The Things we do For Love, to be broadcast tonight, he stressed: "I was a Catholic friar and I kept my vow of celibacy right until I left. But I believe it is unnatural and not everyone can manage it."

fields.headline: QPR say goodbye with a rare win
fields.trailText: With Queens Park Rangers sitting at the bottom of the table, being up for sale with no rush of takers and now finding themselves trying to find a new manager, the chant of "One Gerry Francis" that filled the stadium after only six minutes spoke volumes.
fields.body:
With Queens Park Rangers sitting at the bottom of the table, being up for sale with no rush of takers and now finding themselves trying to find a new manager, the chant of "One Gerry Francis" that filled the stadium after only six minutes spoke volumes.

Quite what the reaction would have been if QPR's director of football for the past 2 seasons had delivered another fifth-place Premiership finish, which he had in his first spell as recently as 1993, or even matched the runners-up spot they achieved in the old First Division as a player in 1975-76, is anybody's guess.

But to mark his last appearance in the home dugout Francis's players rose to the occasion and produced only their fifth league win of the season, a result that lifted them out of the bottom three and left the majority to head home with very mixed emotions.

"It's been a very sad and an emotional day," said Francis, who announced on Friday that he will be taking a back seat for the rest of the season - but who has been offered a seat on the board in the summer and has been asked to stay on as director of football until then to assist with the academy and contractual matters. He will take the team for tomorrow's trip to Gillingham if a successor - Ian Holloway, who was in the director's box, and Graham Rix are the favourites - is not named in time.

"I've got 20-odd contracts up at the end of the season and I don't think I should be deciding on their futures and livelihoods as someone who's not going to be here," Francis said. "This had to happen. Now is the time to bring players in too, certainly Bosmans, but how can I do that if I am not going to be around?"

QPR's most pressing problem right now is trying to stay in the First Division, if only to help smoke out a buyer for the owner Chris Wright and to allow the board to finalise a budget for next term. Safety is worth £3m from the improved TV deal compared with the current £750,000, while for clubs in the Second Division the fee is £1.4m, up from £350,000.

It is a problem Barnsley are aware of, too, and after falling away here despite a bright opening their manager Nigel Spackman, five games in and still looking for a win, is already flirting with disaster.

"You mustn't lose games to teams who are around you in the table but the announcement about Gerry Francis was always going to have a knock-on effect on us," he said later.

Barnsley started brightly, passing the ball with ease and probing for openings, the first of which fell to Isaiah Rankin, who should have done better with a diving header.

But QPR, who owed much to the industry of Gavin Peacock allied to the efforts of the wonderful Peter Crouch, soon had their measure and were difficult to contain. Both goals were headers from corners, the first when Chris Kiwomya's looping effort from a flick-on beat the goalkeeper and the second when Crouch beat Kevin Miller for pace.

Francis, who has handed the board two names for a short list that includes his assistant Iain Dowie, Steve Coppell and Dave Bassett as well as Rix and Holloway, was delighted. "I might have stayed on if someone had come in and said 'we want to go forward and we want you to take us there'. But the transfer situation has to be resolved before people start saving clubs."

fields.headline: The inside track
fields.standfirst:
Fashion industry

<A HREF="http://www.work.guardian.co.uk/">Work site
fields.trailText: Fashion industry
fields.body:
Kate Moss surprised some observers this week by attacking the fashion industry. Now she has banked the money, the supermodel has had second thoughts. "It's mind-numbing," she told London's Time Out magazine, "repeating yourself like Groundhog Day".

It's comforting to know that Moss can be as bored as the rest of us in her work. But to condemn fashion as false is to miss the point: the fashion industry is not about glamour so much as about creating the illusion of glamour.

A working environment built on illusion has lots of room for people whose flair exceeds their qualifications. Some jobs will inevitably be reserved for those who have put in the time acquiring skills - designers, photographers, pattern-cutters - but plenty of others live off sheer front.

There are a few corners of the fashion industry that are inaccessible for no good reason (to work on the glossiest of glossies, you may need a tinge of blue blood, at least if you hope to go far). But overall, it is a democratic business. One of the country's best fashion editors grew up on a Dublin council estate. The pop of the flashbulb is only a few steps away from the whirr of the sewing machine in the backroom, and generally people remember that. But a lot of jobs are created in between. These can range from straightforward public relations to all sorts of idiosyncratic roles. Many celebrities retain personal assistants to borrow designer outfits for their public appearances, for example.

It is a dedicated business. Nobody is in fashion and something else. Fashion journalists, fashion PRs, even fashion drivers tend to work exclusively for the industry. It is a tight circle, but not a closed one.

Beware, though. When fashion people say "it's to die for", they're not joking. Their attitude to fashion makes Bill Shankly's approach to football look like a casual interest. And if you've ever lain awake at night wondering to what extent Ivan Karamazov is morally responsible for his father's death, it may not be the business for you.

webTitle: Office hours: Let the good times roll

fields.headline: Let the good times roll
fields.standfirst: Come on to your manager and your career will flourish, promises a new book. But as  Fiona Campbell  finds, flirting is not as straightforward as you may think
fields.trailText: Come on to your manager and your career will flourish, promises a new book. But as Fiona Campbell finds, flirting is not as straightforward as you may think.
fields.body:
Imagine the scene: your office has a constantly colourful, happy rapport between colleagues. The lively atmosphere lifts the spirits as soon as you walk in. People encourage one another, giving out genuine compliments and lending an ear to each other's difficulties. They like to share a good joke. No one is having an extramarital affair, because they have genuine integrity. You can practically see the energy flowing between the desks.

Is this where you work? The odds are, it's not. Many people view their careers as an isolated operation, with colleagues seen for the most part as rivals. I once worked at a small company where three of the (married) directors were having affairs with the staff. The atmosphere was viperous and loaded with jealousy. And yet, strangely enough, people never flirted in the office. On the surface it was a cold, tense place to work, with lots of fake enthusiasm, while under the surface it festered.

Peta Heskell, whose book The Flirt Coach has just been published, says flirting with integrity can not only enhance the atmosphere in the office, but also further one's career. Disguised under a garish pink cover, and peppered with heart-shaped bullet points, the book claims to be about the beauty of human interaction, describing how to "put the fun and joie de vivre into communication to get success at work and relationships." It promises that "flirting [can be] a way of life . . . for you. It is simply about feeling great about who you are and spreading it to other people, which makes them feel great too. When people feel great they are open to suggestions, opportunities and invitations. Their hearts, minds and support become available to you because you give genuine value to them."

Heskell, a petite, bubbly woman, explains effusively that the key to flirting is to "aim to make every place you work a place where people are really having a good time because you're around". She advises me to list all the things I like about myself. If I find it difficult to think of good qualities, then I need to start learning to love myself, "to start working on myself".

Flirting is titillating people and having them enjoy being with you, she maintains. Flirts tantalise and tease everyone, giving off signals of desirability and interest. Learn how to "glow" from inside, she says, and become a "sunshiner" - a positive, genuine person who faces challenges and notices possibilities in all situations. Then make eye contact, smile, and say hello. Give plenty of genuine compliments, and learn how to accept them gracefully and with thanks.

According to Heskell, this is not a superficial thing, but a process that comes from "giving out the fizz that everyone has inside them." It means "being who you are and liking yourself, finding the best in yourself, the steel core that's really you so that on the outside you can be flexible and go with the flow." Once you begin to do that, she says, people are automatically drawn in.

Somehow flirting has a slightly dubious image. An old friend of mine is a very strict French evangelical Protestant. She once said to me solemnly, "I must try not to charm people." She genuinely considered flirting to be underhand, and tried to go through life in Paris without ever flirting with anyone - an admirable feat in a city where flirting is the currency of life.

Heskell raves about the French. "Flirting makes you feel good. The French have turned it into a fine art and a national pastime. What a shame the British haven't done the same. Over here we are so reserved that we have forgotten how to flirt."

Some people deeply believe they cannot flirt, or that they are bad at it. Looking at me firmly, Heskell says: "These are all self-imposed. We bad-mouth ourselves so much."

She teaches people how to "trigger their best flirting states" by recalling a positive moment from their past. "Your body changes as you imagine that moment, and you become more attractive," she says.

However, in the current climate where even the mildest of personal compliments about a woman's looks can be construed as sexual harass ment, flirting can be like the 80s cult game of Mousetrap - you can go so far but after a certain point you are simply on the hell train. "You have to learn to listen to yourself and to others and be aware of the effect your behaviour is having and gauge the mood of other," says Heskell.

Alternatively, advises writer and consummate flirt, Dan Griffiths, "Try noticing shoes and hair. It doesn't suggest that you're coming on to them, but it does say you are interested and plugged in because you noticed."

Clarity is crucial for Heskell. "There are too many women who say yes when they mean no." If you overdo the flirting, then you may well end up with your own personal stalker. It's important not to flirt with someone who could get the wrong idea. Remember that some people can be easily misled, so be careful how you behave with them. The best strategy is to flirt with everyone, indiscriminately, and then no one can take it the wrong way.

Heskell tells the story of a married man who came to her for counselling. After some weeks he announced that he had fallen in love with his colleague. "I told him to take back that energy to his wife and sort out the relationship. Instead he wrote the colleague a love letter, left his wife and moved in with her in a week. People won't be told."

The idea of being nice to your colleagues is hardly revolutionary, but I really don't think I could go through life flirting relentlessly with everyone I meet - it sounds exhaustingly superficial. Nevertheless, Heskell does have a knack of opening doors and helping people to interact in a more positive and less restrained way. So, if you can overlook the little heart-shaped bullet points and the psychobabble, not to mention the exhortation to "love yourself" through masturbation, I would recommend that you have a look at The Flirt Coach. It might just improve the atmosphere in the office - and we all need a little of that.

10 ways to a more flirtatious you

1) Seek out "sunshiners" and stay way from "black-clouders". Surround yourself with things that make you feel good, like quotes and pictures that motivate you. Post them on your walls and use them as a screensaver.

2) Are you laughing enough? Watch TV programmes and read books that make you laugh. Subscribe to a daily joke list.

3) Whenever you stand in front of the mirror ask yourself: "What's true of me when I am at my best? What am I like when I'm being the word that best describes me?" Aim for that emotion/feeling.

4) Ask yourself the following questions when you wake up each morning: What am I happy about in my life? What am I excited about in my life? What am I proud about in my life? What am I grateful about in my life? Who do I love? Who loves me?

5) As you go about your business, take in the world through each individual sense. Notice the different information that becomes available .

6) Choose the animal that is your symbol. Learn all about that animal and discover which of its qualities you need.

7) Decide that each day you will do something in a different way.

8) Every day write down three pages of whatever comes into your head. This will open you up to recognition of what you have learned and to new ideas.

9) Start smiling at strangers. As you see people coming towards you, focus on them and think of how good you feel, and as they get closer, smile and say "Hi" if you wish.

10) Does you external appearance reflect your true style? Do the colours that you wear suit your skin tone? Is your haircut flattering? Do the clothes you wear reflect you at your best? Are there certain fashions or clothes or jewellery you would like to wear but don't, yet? Buy something like that and wear it.

 Adapted from The Flirt Coach by Peta Heskell, published by Harper Collins, price £7.99

 For more information, see www.flirtingacademy.com

fields.headline: A show-stopping Joe Jackson
fields.standfirst:
Joe Jackson
Royal Festival Hall
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Joe Jackson
Royal Festival Hall
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
New technology is a wonderful thing. Leaving the South Bank with the sound of Joe Jackson's Slow Song in your ears, you can stroll to the limo, dial up joejackson.com on the web and, for just a few dollars, download the sheet music straight to your laptop complete with acidic words: "But I'm brutalised by bass and terrorised by treble ... and I get tired of DJs, why's it always what he plays ..."

Appropriately, there were no DJs on Saturday - in fact no support at all. Joe Jackson, who claimed to have retired from pop music in the 1990s, has a reputation for putting on good shows, hiring the best musicians, giving good value and playing smart new arrangements of his old hits. That's exactly what he did - playing for nearly two and a half hours with encores. He has always been one of the most musicianly of pop singer-bandleaders: unlike many of his peers in the late 1970s, he seemed to arrive with a fully developed musical language. He's more like a composer who writes his own libretto than a songwriter who sticks lyrics over chords and riffs. Each song's melodic figures, rhythms, structures and words are woven into a coherent whole, with the result that you can often identify a Joe Jackson song from just a couple of chords or a drumbeat.

For the current tour he extended the style of one of his most successful and enduring albums for a new set of Broadway lullabies and nightmare vignettes. The original Night and Day used a Latin American backline crowned by acoustic piano and overdubbed keyboards. Whatever the tempo or subject-matter the rhythm section remained rock steady. For this tour, to promote his new album Night and Day II, Jackson employed the brilliant Sue Hadjopoulos (percussion) and old friend Graham Maby (bass) from the earlier album, plus the great Roberto Rodriguez (who drummed with Marc Ribot's Prosthetic Cubans at the Jazz Cafe last June). Jackson's arrangements were fleshed out by Andy Ezrin (keyboards) with cellist Catherine Bent and Allison Cornell (violin and keyboards), who also took the lead vocal for Glamour and Pain.

Starting with Prelude's looped hi-hats and solo spotlit cello, then crashing into Hell of a Town, the band began to explore the leader's large back catalogue with songs such as Fools in Love and Another World. A confident reinvention of Becker and Fagen's Reeling in the Years threw the band's many qualities into sharp relief. For Breaking Us in Two, Cornell played a trill-perfect transcription of the original synth solo.

The second set began with four solo numbers, including It's Different For Girls and the Beatles' For No One. fields.bodyText: New technology is a wonderful thing. Leaving the South Bank with the sound of Joe Jackson's Slow Song in your ears, you can stroll to the limo, dial up joejackson.com on the web and, for just a few dollars, download the sheet music straight to your laptop complete with acidic words: "But I'm brutalised by bass and terrorised by treble ... and I get tired of DJs, why's it always what he plays ..." Appropriately, there were no DJs on Saturday - in fact no support at all. Joe Jackson, who claimed to have retired from pop music in the 1990s, has a reputation for putting on good shows, hiring the best musicians, giving good value and playing smart new arrangements of his old hits. That's exactly what he did - playing for nearly two and a half hours with encores. He has always been one of the most musicianly of pop singer-bandleaders: unlike many of his peers in the late 1970s, he seemed to arrive with a fully developed musical language. He's more like a composer who writes his own libretto than a songwriter who sticks lyrics over chords and riffs. Each song's melodic figures, rhythms, structures and words are woven into a coherent whole, with the result that you can often identify a Joe Jackson song from just a couple of chords or a drumbeat. For the current tour he extended the style of one of his most successful and enduring albums for a new set of Broadway lullabies and nightmare vignettes. The original Night and Day used a Latin American backline crowned by acoustic piano and overdubbed keyboards. Whatever the tempo or subject-matter the rhythm section remained rock steady. For this tour, to promote his new album Night and Day II, Jackson employed the brilliant Sue Hadjopoulos (percussion) and old friend Graham Maby (bass) from the earlier album, plus the great Roberto Rodriguez (who drummed with Marc Ribot's Prosthetic Cubans at the Jazz Cafe last June). Jackson's arrangements were fleshed out by Andy Ezrin (keyboards) with cellist Catherine Bent and Allison Cornell (violin and keyboards), who also took the lead vocal for Glamour and Pain. fields.headline: Schumann
fields.standfirst:
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Once something of a rarity, complete performances of Schumann's Myrthen have proliferated of late. The work itself, however, remains a puzzle, and has provoked considerable diversity of approach. Written in 1840, it ostensibly formed Schumann's wedding gift to his wife, though lurking beneath the surface of its 26 songs is a disparity between subject and intent. The tone is often dark. A wide spectrum of sexual experience is examined, from marital consummation and gay desire to sibling incest. There is also a divergence of opinion as to whether it forms an integrated whole. Is it a genuine song cycle, dependent for its impact on jolting emotional and stylistic contrast rather than linear narrative? Or is it simply an arbitrarily assembled collection?

Christiane Oelze and Wolfgang Holzmair seemingly took the latter view on this occasion, plonking an interval in the middle of it, which seriously weakened its cumulative effect. They also proved an oddly ill-matched pair. Holzmair's voice has thickened a bit of late. His once velvety tone has now become a tangy, opulent bronze, though he has also mercifully lost his old habit of occasionally sacrificing pitch for verbal nuance. Sound, sense and line are now immaculately welded in his singing. The words bite. Each song is sharply characterised. Aus Den Hebräischen Gesängen has a rapt, mystic flow. He turns the seducer of the Venetian songs into a world-weary roué. The final invocation to "my sister, my bride" is urgently sexual, though he tried to duck the homoerotic implications of Aus Den Schenkenbuch by portraying its narrator as an out-of-control drunk.

Oelze is markedly different. Her voice has an easy, silvery shimmer, appealing in itself, but placing her next to Holzmair reveals an absence of subtlety. There's an emotional sameness in her singing and a chastity of utterance that sits uneasily with the innuendo and eroticism in the texts: you miss the seditious undertones of the Highland Lullaby; her Bride, hankering after physical pleasure before the wedding, seems merely coy.

Myrthen was flanked by two sets of Schumann's vocal duets - gorgeous works that still seem avant-garde. The chromatic probings of the Lullaby at the Bedside of a Sick Child, for instance, are years ahead of their time. Schumann's fondness, however, for pitting the upper extremes of the baritone voice against the lower registers of the soprano can lead to problems of balance, and even though Holzmair scaled his tone down, there were moments when he almost swamped Oelze completely. The pianist, Roger Vignoles, is one of the finest of all Schumann accompanists, playing with emotional density and limpidity throughout.

fields.headline: BBCPO/Renes
fields.standfirst:
Bridgewater Hall
Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Bridgewater Hall
Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.body:
The scores of Mahler's symphonies are littered with instructions for the instruments of the wind section to raise their bells in the air: Schalltrichter auf! In general the players do not take much notice, for lots of reasons. By putting your instrument in a different position you risk losing control of intonation, a major sin in today's orchestras. It also becomes almost impossible to keep your eyes on the music; and the last thing you want to do in one of those headlong Mahler scherzos is to lose your place. So woodwind and trumpeters just raise their bells a tiny bit, hardly visible to the audience and making very little difference to the sound.

So it was a joyful and exciting moment when the BBC Philharmonic clarinets threw caution to the winds, adopted what must have been extremely uncomfortable playing positions (something else you don't much want to do in a symphony that lasts over an hour and needs enormous stamina) and really hit out with raucous gypsy sounds. That had its effect on the rest of the orchestra, because their performance of Mahler's Fifth Symphony was a touch cautious.

Lawrence Renes was a late replacement conductor, appearing for the first time with the BBC Philharmonic. He had been going for safety, as well he might, and so had the orchestra. It began as a performance with not much care for the louds and softs, just so long as the notes were mostly in the right place. At first even the trumpet solos of the unflappable Patrick Addinall and the horn solos of Jonathan Goodall (who seems incapable of playing a wrong note) were tentative. But then the sheer sound of the thing took over and everybody seemed to remember that this is an orchestra that really doesn't much need a conductor for a work so firmly in the repertory; and there were times when it wasn't clear whether the orchestra was following the conductor or the other way round.

The accumulating confidence and intensity produced a shattering effect at the end. Things had been very different earlier on, with the Mozart piano concerto still called the "Elvira Madigan". Renes was plainly well in tune with the playing of Michel Dalberto, a man who unashamedly uses the full tonal range of the modern piano to play in a modern concert hall. This was confident, full-bodied playing from the start; the orchestra responded with equal confidence and considerable grace. That the last two movements were accomplished in what seemed like record time was no problem. It was a performance with a clear vision and a consistent manner from beginning to end.

fields.headline: Pick of the week
fields.standfirst: A sticky problem for a cash-strapped student, financial advice from Gary the Rat, 63 episodes of a Hackney soap
fields.trailText: A sticky problem for a cash-strapped student, financial advice from Gary the Rat, 63 episodes of a Hackney soap
fields.body:
A Stand Up Guy
(www.ifilm.com)

One of the joys of webfilm is that since it makes little demand on your time and almost none on your pocket, you can afford to be more adventurous, or even cavalier, in your choices. That kind of bran-tub thinking brought me to Michael Ivankay's good-natured slacker comedy this week. Perhaps 90 minutes of his laid-back, low-fi style would be 80 minutes too much for most of us, but this short monochrome take on a student bet gone horribly wrong has an unpolished, goofy charm all of its own. Will our hero make the hundred dollars he needs to save his skin at the amateur comedy contest ? Or will his big mouth have to earn it a less appetising way? Stick with it until after the final credits to find out how this, uh, spunky little film ends. (KS)
 View the film

Gary the Rat
(www.mediatrip.com)
Hollywood talent piled onto the Net in droves a year ago, and then mostly piled out again sharpish when 'intertainment' ventures started collapsing like fallen souffles. One of American television's biggest names, Kelsey Grammer, is still in the ring however, serving up episodes of his enjoyably edgy animated series Gary the Rat. Here he stars as an unscrupulous Wall Street lawyer whose success in the rat race has a Kafkaesque reward when he wakes up one morning transformed into a giant rodent. He has a ball with the character, whose weary and irredeemable cynicism he plays like a 21st century George Sanders - telling a delivery boy to: "Run along now, spray some solvent into a paper bag then inhale deeply, there's a good chap." If you've enjoyed Grammer's portrayal of Sideshow Bob on The Simpsons, you'll already know that Frasier Crane isn't the only flavour he comes in. If not, you'll be pleasantly surprised. (KS)
 View the film

map50
(www.map50.com)
Gritty, urban realism is not something you associate with Flash animation. But give Flash to a load of artists - some of them with no previous experience of it - and you can suddenly say adios to clean lines and cuddly bears. map50 is a new 63-part drama based around the 63 grid references that make up page 50 of the London Street Atlas, each grid with its own episode. Seven groups of artists have nine episodes each to tell the tale of a woman trying to cash bent giro cheques around the London borough of Hackney and the different storytellers ensure that map50 offers more than its fair share of stylistic collisions, as animation, photography and text pile up to an often disorientating effect. Desolate in places too, but also full of tender, beaten up charm, and as close to a truly interactive movie as you are likely to get. Believe me, you won't have seen a flash "movie" quite like it. (SD)
 View the film

fields.headline: A call for change
fields.standfirst:
Competition for staff is finally improving conditions in call centres, finds Kate Hilpern

<A HREF="http://www.work.guardian.co.uk/">Work site
fields.trailText: Competition for staff is finally improving conditions in call centres, finds Kate Hilpern.
fields.body:
Almost one in 50 employees now works in a call centre. By 2008, that figure is expected to reach one in 30. The industry has become the fastest growing job market in the UK, employing more than the combined number working in coal mining, steel andcar production. Secretarial skills, already a valuable commodity, are particularly sought after. Can we assume, then, that the industry's original sweatshop image is dead and buried?

Apparently not, according to a new report by the TUC. It's Your Call not only found that call centre salaries amount to a mere 60% of average earnings, but that many workers face Dickensian conditions. "We have testimonies from call centre workers who report being monitored over the length of time they spend going to the toilet," says a TUC spokesperson. "Some are listened to on the phone when discussing union business, or are expected to pay for their own headsets.

One man who fainted at his desk had the time it took him to be driven to hospital deducted from his wages." A health representative at a call centre was even suspended for using the company's phone to contact the health and safety executive about a gas problem. Meanwhile, a woman who wanted to start three-quarters of an hour late had to produce a letter from her child's school before the "concession" was considered.

Sandy Boyle, deputy general secretary of the Banking, Insurance and Finance Union, is unsurprised by the report's fundings. "In some call centres, there is a rather sinister emphasis on teamwork to make sure nobody gets the chance to complain." Nor are BT call centre staff surprised. Staff have, in the past, gone on strike over insufficient staffing and tight deadlines that prohibit calls being handled in a professional manner. "We're skilled workers yet we feel as though we're on assembly lines," says one employee.

It is not all doom and gloom, however. The TUC's report found that although call centres remain characterised by outrageously low pay, their concentration in areas such as Glasgow and South Wales is set to drive up standards as employers compete with each other to keep staff. "In fact, we are already witnessing some changes for the better," says the report. "Although starting salaries can be as little as £7,500, some call handlers earn more than £20,000."

Philip Pearson, author of the study Personnel Issues in Call Centres Today, believes it may only be a matter of months before improvements become more widespread. "Faced with intensifying labour-market competition, most centres will soon be forced to discard their factory-rate wages. Indeed, two-thirds of employers surveyed for our report said their salaries were influenced by objective market analyses of pay for similar jobs in the locality. In areas such as Leeds and Bradford, with 30 telebusinesses employing around 16,000 staff, undercutting is out of the question."

Likewise, claims the TUC, the competition will force the centres to improve working conditions - something that some are already striving to do. The customer-service management provider, Ventura, for instance, is working out ways to make staff feel valued. "We take a holistic approach. There is direct access between staff and directors and we also encourage staff to come up with their own solutions for improvements," says human resources director Kate Marsden. Employees also have access to a gym and TV room during breaks. These, says Marsden, "make good business sense because they help in keeping staff turnover low".

Many centres offer learning rooms where staff can go in their spare time. The theory is that they will feel recognised, stimulated and valued.

Thomas Cook believes even more has to be done to beat the competition. "We offer training, but in addition, we offer staff an enjoyable atmosphere," says Phil Ginn, head of call centre operations in Falkirk. "That's why we have created a holiday-type environment." Staff walk into work though the company's "sensorama" corridor where they are greeted with the sound of waves crashing, bright, changing colours and the smell of coconut oil. Ginn says the centre still wants staff to achieve targets - "but we don't want them to suffer unreasonable pressure as a result." Particularly lucky staff even get to visit the holiday resorts to gain hands-on experience of the products they are selling.

Similarly, call centres run by the telecommunications company Orange offer theme days in the hope that staff will delight in coming to work. "We have had pirate days and beach days," says a spokesperson.

The TUC acknowledges such innovations as a far cry from those call centres that resemble "communications factories". But, it says, "a handful of centres becoming staff-friendly isn't good enough. Every employer should be negotiating deals with staff, offering flexible working arrangements, compensation for working unsociable hours, sensitive monitoring of calls and setting of targets - along with added benefits wherever possible. The alternative is nothing less than exploitation of staff."

fields.headline: Driving a good deal
fields.standfirst: Rachel Gordon on financing a deal for that new car you've promised yourself
fields.trailText: Rachel Gordon on financing a deal for that new car you've promised yourself.
fields.body:
With Y registration cars coming out in March, now is the time many people are looking to buy, but it's becoming an increasingly tricky task. In the end, deciding which car you want may be easier than choosing the right finance deal.

The most obvious options all involve a monthly payment. They include the standard loan or normal hire purchase schemes from the seller, or a personal contract purchase scheme (PCP).

The PCPs are largely offered by car manufacturers and are a type of deferred loan. The dealer will set a minimum guaranteed future value (MGFV) - which is what they think the car will be worth in two or three years' time when the deal ends.

The buyer puts down a deposit from 10%, which is deducted from the price of the car, along with the MGFV, and the rest is paid in monthly instalments.

At the end of the term, either the MGFV that was calculated at that start is paid back or the car returned Ð any surplus from the resale value of the car is returned or used as a deposit on another car.

A key benefit is that by taking into account the future value of the vehicle, the monthly repayments can be lower than a normal loan. They are often linked to new cars though and can mean the customer is locked into one manufacturer.

If that doesn't suit, there is a new breed of product on the market, such as those offered by Alliance & Leicester and Marks & Spencer Financial Services. With Alliance & Leicester, for example, a maximum of 60% can be deferred if you repay over one year, but you defer only 30% if you repay over four years.

Alliance & Leicester says its loan is similar to a PCP but has none of the restrictions. Its rates are 10.4% for borrowing £5,000 to £10,000, 9.8% £12,500 to £15,000 and 8.9% for £12,500 to £15,000.

Marks & Spencer also offers a similar scheme with its Car Buying Plan, which allows borrowers to defer up to 60% of the total loan amount. Customers can borrow from £2,500 to £20,000 at a rate of between 9.8-13.5%. At the end of the initial term, the deferred amount is payable, leaving a number of options. These are either to keep paying, take out another deferred plan, pay off the loan or sell the car and use the proceeds to pay off the loan.

The AA is among those that offer a hire purchase option where a deposit of 10% or more is paid and the balance paid off in a pre-arranged term. The car can be repossessed if payments are not kept up and there can also be early redemption penalties. Loans can either be taken out unsecured or secured on the car.

With any finance deal, watch out for the payment protection insurance that many providers try and push. It tends to be expensive and riddled with exclusions. Of course, some people do need to claim on this, but lenders make high commission from selling it and if you feel you can do without, it is probably a wise move.

The Consumers' Association also reminds people that depreciation is the biggest single cost in running a new car and advises avoiding buying new models that depreciate quickly and never paying the full list price for a car.

For information on finding more about used car prices check out sites such as carbusters.com or carpricecheck.com

fields.bodyText: With Y registration cars coming out in March, now is the time many people are looking to buy, but it's becoming an increasingly tricky task. In the end, deciding which car you want may be easier than choosing the right finance deal. The most obvious options all involve a monthly payment. They include the standard loan or normal hire purchase schemes from the seller, or a personal contract purchase scheme (PCP). The PCPs are largely offered by car manufacturers and are a type of deferred loan. The dealer will set a minimum guaranteed future value (MGFV) - which is what they think the car will be worth in two or three years' time when the deal ends. The buyer puts down a deposit from 10%, which is deducted from the price of the car, along with the MGFV, and the rest is paid in monthly instalments. At the end of the term, either the MGFV that was calculated at that start is paid back or the car returned Ð any surplus from the resale value of the car is returned or used as a deposit on another car. A key benefit is that by taking into account the future value of the vehicle, the monthly repayments can be lower than a normal loan. They are often linked to new cars though and can mean the customer is locked into one manufacturer. If that doesn't suit, there is a new breed of product on the market, such as those offered by Alliance & Leicester and Marks & Spencer Financial Services. With Alliance & Leicester, for example, a maximum of 60% can be deferred if you repay over one year, but you defer only 30% if you repay over four years. Alliance & Leicester says its loan is similar to a PCP but has none of the restrictions. Its rates are 10.4% for borrowing £5,000 to £10,000, 9.8% £12,500 to £15,000 and 8.9% for £12,500 to £15,000. Marks & Spencer also offers a similar scheme with its Car Buying Plan, which allows borrowers to defer up to 60% of the total loan amount. Customers can borrow from £2,500 to £20,000 at a rate of between 9.8-13.5%. At the end of the initial term, the deferred amount is payable, leaving a number of options. These are either to keep paying, take out another deferred plan, pay off the loan or sell the car and use the proceeds to pay off the loan. The AA is among those that offer a hire purchase option where a deposit of 10% or more is paid and the balance paid off in a pre-arranged term. The car can be repossessed if payments are not kept up and there can also be early redemption penalties. Loans can either be taken out unsecured or secured on the car. With any finance deal, watch out for the payment protection insurance that many providers try and push. It tends to be expensive and riddled with exclusions. Of course, some people do need to claim on this, but lenders make high commission from selling it and if you feel you can do without, it is probably a wise move. fields.headline: The Royal Ballet's fresh new heroines
fields.standfirst:
Romeo and Juliet
The Royal Opera House
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Romeo and Juliet
The Royal Opera House
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
The past 12 months have seen some interesting shifts in the ranks of the Royal Ballet, with an influx of talent that has been altering our perception of who will be leading the company in the next decade. One of the first new arrivals was Alina Cojocaru, a Romanian dancer who had spent six months in the Royal Ballet School, moved to Kiev Ballet to dance principal roles, then applied to join the Royal. Hardly anyone noted her arrival in the corps de ballet until she suddenly appeared in the lead role of Symphonic Variations - replacing an injured dancer at short notice.

She was startlingly good, displaying an instinct for the music and stillness of the choreography that belied her 18 years. Subsequent performances of Clara in The Nutcracker confirmed she was a force to be reckoned with. Then, to add a touch of instant glamour, Cojocaru made an unscheduled debut as Juliet this Saturday, learning the role in eight days after the advertised Leanne Benjamin sustained an injury.

This came straight after Tamara Rojo, another outsider, made her own debut in the same role. Rojo, 26, is less of an unknown - she was a principal with English National Ballet before transferring to the Royal this season. But the timing is still delicious. The two women tipped to become the Royal's next-generation ballerinas have both taken on one of the company's most prized roles within the same week.

Rojo's debut was entirely engrossing. Her opening scenes play Juliet as a very sweet, naive child and, while there are moments when she verges on the cute, these are cancelled by glimpses of a visceral intensity. During the Capulet ball Rojo's Juliet darts confused glances down at Paris's hands as he partners her - trying to follow his lead but also resenting his touch. This man doesn't feel right to her but she doesn't yet know why. When she first meets Romeo she's girlish still, yet with heady rushes of energy that prefigure her capacity to gamble everything for love.

And Rojo steadily intensifies this energy throughout. She is unlucky in having Inaki Urlezaga as her Romeo - a good dancer but a limited actor - and their pas de deux don't generate real heat. Rojo's own dancing, however, gets more sweeping and dangerous in its phrasing and her instincts more naked and fierce. She peels away layers of prettiness and in the final death scene her grief is a silent howl, wrenched so painfully from her guts that it shatters the air.

Given Cojocaru's limited rehearsal time it is not surprising that her Juliet is less dramatically articulate - never quite travelling the full distance from virginal modesty to tragedy. But that barely matters given the drama of her dancing. Cojocaru may be tiny but her body encompasses a huge range - a luxuriant adagio that seems to stretch a phrase into white space, an allegro so light she skims the stage and a dazzling variety of nuances in between. By the end we're weeping, less for Juliet's fate than for the thrill that Cojocaru, being this good at 19, is going to be extraordinary at 30.

Her Romeo on Saturday was Johan Kobborg. He too started out with a conventional reading of the role, but became mesmerising in acts two and three - his dancing and acting both registering the anguish of a heart and intelligence trapped by fate. Ricardo Cervera as Mercutio performed one of the most credible death scenes I've seen in ages, agony that made us flinch, and Luke Heydon was a fine Tybalt handling his sword with the kind of brute purpose that made you believe he was a grim familiar of death.

 In repertory until April 18. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

webTitle: Tesco and Asda trade shots in price war

fields.headline: Tesco and Asda trade shots in price war
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Tesco and Asda, two of Britain's leading supermarket chains, exchanged a fresh shots in their ongoing price war at the weekend.
fields.body:
Tesco and Asda, two of Britain's leading supermarket chains, exchanged a fresh shots in their ongoing price war at the weekend.

Tesco said £70m worth of price cuts covering more than 750 basic grocery and household products would take effect in its stores from today, with the sector leader claiming that typical households would save up to 21%, or £14, on their weekly shopping bills.

Asda, which is owned by the American discount stores group Wal-Mart, brought forward cuts planned for the spring on top of the £52m worth of reductions it announced last month.

Tesco said products earmarked for price cuts had been chosen during a survey of 2,000 shoppers. John Gildersleeve, a Tesco director, said: "When it comes to saving money, every single one of our customers is an expert, so we decided to ask them."

The supermarket chain believes that falling food prices are a significant factor in pulling down inflation in Britain. It cited a recent survey by retail analyst AC Neilson which showed that while food prices in the UK had fallen by almost 2% over the past year prices in France, Belgium, Germany and the Netherlands had risen by up to 7.3%.

The price cuts from Asda, codename Project Gopher, are being introduced a day before the chain reports performance figures for the past year. It claims to be 11% cheaper than rivals.

fields.headline: Too many stars at the Barbican
fields.standfirst:
McCoy Tyner
Barbican
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
McCoy Tyner
Barbican
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Each member of the UK Allstar Big Band was given an individual round of applause as he found his spot on the stage at the Barbican. And almost as if the sound engineer was mixing the levels, each round had a different intensity, a different flavour - the brightest, of course, saved for McCoy Tyner himself. It was the star quality of the night that gave this gig its highlights - and its dark spots.

Since playing piano for the inspirational John Coltrane quartet of the 1960s, Tyner has worked in a variety of settings that reflect his conviction that "all kinds of music are interconnected". This broad listening is shown through the variety of line-ups he has used, but also through his improvisation at the piano. At the Barbican, this was best heard when the 15-piece band dropped back to a quartet with Mark Mondesir (drums), Bosco D'Oliveira (percussion) and Alec Dankworth (bass). It's not just a case of left-hand accompaniment, right-hand tune with Tyner. He wades in with both at the lower end of the keyboard, creating rich clusters that somehow don't become muddy and unclear - partly because of his sensitivity to dynamics and balance. He is famed for his power, but that is partly because he knows how to frame dramatic explosions with lightness of touch. And that drumming-like approach to the keyboard is always ready to burst free, one hand darting to the top of the keyboard and trickling down, dazzlingly, before feeding back into the chords chugging away below.

In the middle of the first set, he pushed this sound effortlessly, in a solo number, through more traditional piano styles (such as stride) right through to a bracing modal ending with an impressionistic, almost classical close. In the bold funky numbers this approach worked: there was an elemental excitement - a kind of smooth power - that made you feel you could take on the world.

Mondesir's drumming, constantly filling and flirting with the beat (more like rhythm than beating) helped the sound have weight without becoming bogged down. There were great opportunities to hear different musical characters at work during the solos though sadly not from the tuba (Andy Grappy) or French horn (Jim Ratigan). There was squealing showmanship from Claude Deppa (trumpet); focused melodic bass from Dankworth; Andy Sheppard's trademark honk; and Jason Yarde's richly influenced ideas.

The trouble was that often the group sounded like a collection of individuals rather than a band, and there were quite bad lapses of ensemble in the less strident moments. "If the music's working," Tyner once said, "then in a way the players love each other. Maybe not always off the bandstand, but in the music itself". It didn't feel like that was always the case here. That's one of the problems of the all-star big band, which gets together only occasionally, perhaps with limited rehearsal time. After all, you can't make up a football team with just star strikers - even though, in this case, the highlights were well worth hearing.

fields.headline: WPM
fields.trailText: • So, now we know the secret of a successful career is to flirt your pants off (not literally, WPM might add, in case she is billed for a sexual harassment case that some reader unfairly feels she has incited with that comment). Following Peta Heskell's advice (see cover story), all that remains is to take the test to see whether you are the flirtiest of all the flirts in your office.
fields.body:
 So, now we know the secret of a successful career is to flirt your pants off (not literally, WPM might add, in case she is billed for a sexual harassment case that some reader unfairly feels she has incited with that comment). Following Peta Heskell's advice (see cover story), all that remains is to take the test to see whether you are the flirtiest of all the flirts in your office.

The modern workplace is charged with sexual energy, according to officeflirttest.com, a pretty-in-pink question and answer session on the web. This, claims the site in simple speak, is an evolutionary hangover from the days when procreation and survival were the name of the game.

Apparently the average office worker spends more than 260 full days a year with their colleagues, and the ways in which we interact with one another in person, via email and even on the phone can be indicative of the ways we repress and sublimate our innate behaviour. And the only way to find out about our inner desires it to put them to the test. Which, of course, is what WPM did.

On her first visit she answered the multitude of questions and came out as the Shark, ("silent, predatory and direct in your approach, the office is your hunting ground and within it no one is safe"). It sounded so inaccurate that WPM was forced to pay a second visit to the Q&A site on Tuesday only to come out as the Cat ("cool, calm and sometimes regarded by colleagues as aloof, you slink around at work and show little outward interest in the sexual politics"). Curiouser and curiouser. Especially when on Wednesday she again answered the questions, only to be labelled rather unflatteringly as the Lizard ("Retiring, friendly and totally laidback, you lounge around the office and tend not to be regarded as a player when it comes to office sexual politics").

None of which does WPM much justice. Having said that, the lack of Valentines cards she received last week left her with only one possible animal-related conclusion to draw from this sorry state of affairs: she is, in fact, the office dog.

 "Hello, you've reached WPM at the Guardian. I'm either away from my desk or on the phone which I know is a really boring excuse but the truth is I just don't want to speak to you so don't bother to leave a message because I'm not going to get back to you anyway. Beep".

Oh, how WPM longs for the day when honesty - or at the very least originality - reaches the world of voicemail. Enough of the "I'm on the other line" excuses, and let's do away with the "I'm out of the office until (insert date that is long past) . . ." WPM is lobbying for more fun on the phone and voicemail is the perfect place to start.

In an attempt to remedy the tedium of unoriginal outgoing messages, WPM has joined with small business and home office retailer, Staples - The Office Superstore, to invite all budding Office Hours scribes to send in original suggestions for voicemail scripts. We are rewarding writers of the 10 most entertaining entries with a fantastic pre-pay WAP mobile phone. Entries must be realistic, legal and no more than 45 words. Send yours to: Staples Competition, PO Box 6, Hampton, Middx TW12 2HH. Closing date is February 28.

 WPM has been limbering up with ashtanga yoga after receiving a press release espousing the benefits of being flexible. However, a further perusal of the Office Angels survey suggests it is flexible benefits, rather than supple figures, that are sought after by employees. It says 57% of workers would prefer to receive flexible benefits rather than a pay rise or promotion. The research revealed employees' "most wanted" benefits, with training, voted by an overwhelming majority (93%), topping the list.

It goes almost without saying, of course, that WPM wants them all. That is, a pay rise, a promotion, flexible benefits and a bend-over-backwards yogatastic body to boot.

fields.headline: Sec's tips
fields.standfirst:
21. Taking messages

<A HREF="http://www.work.guardian.co.uk/">Work site
fields.trailText: 21. Taking messages.
fields.body:
Message-taking is a vital part of working life, especially for the secretary and PA. You are the one who looks incompetent when you can't answer simple questions, such as, "Do they want me to ring back or not?" To help you gain brownie points, Cambridge, the message-taking and administration notebooks range, has compiled this list of top tips.

*Be thorough. Always write the date and time of the call on the message and ask callers to spell their names. These may be used to address a letter and it is irritating to receive correspondence with an incorrectly spelt name. It doesn't reflect well on the company, either.

*Use a dedicated messaging pad with duplicate sheets. That way if your boss is careless and loses your note, you have your own records. Messages are also stored neatly together rather than on pieces of paper strewn all over your desk.

*Make sure you take the caller's contact telephone number - don't assume your boss has it. If you only have an office phone number and the caller is out for the day, there may be no way to contact him or her unless you ask for a mobile number, for example. Always repeat specific details or instructions back to the caller. Road directions, especially, can be confusing and if you take down a left instead of a right, there is no telling where your boss may end up!

*If a caller is in a hurry and is rattling a complicated message at you, don't be afraid to ask them to slow down. If you can't understand what they're saying, they might as well not be making the call. Ask them to repeat anything you didn't catch - in the long run they will thank you for your efficiency.

*Make sure you understand what the recipient of the message is supposed to do next. Should they call back, email, or wait for the caller to ring again? Be clear on this, especially with urgent messages, so both parties are not sitting waiting for the other to respond.

*Be an intelligent message-taker. Does it need to go to your boss? Can you redirect the caller or help them yourself? It is a chance to show your initiative, rather than loading it all on to your manager.

*So take a moment to write full, clear, intelligent notes. It minimises the chance of errors, displays your efficiency, and is guaranteed to make sure your boss gets the message.

 Penny Cottee is editor of Executive PA magazine.

fields.trailText: Is Damien Hirst overpriced? Economists usually leave questions about value to others - if someone is prepared to pay £1m for his works, then the market has determined that that is its worth. Notions of the work's intrinsic value are up to art critics to argue over.
fields.body:
Is Damien Hirst overpriced? Economists usually leave questions about value to others - if someone is prepared to pay £1m for his works, then the market has determined that that is its worth. Notions of the work's intrinsic value are up to art critics to argue over.

One area where economics can shed some light is whether modern art is likely to be a good investment. Historical studies of the art market usually suggest that today's top artists are getting prices for their works beyond the dreams of their predecessors. However, Wolfgang Wilke* of Dresdner Bank points out that simply adjusting for the ravages of inflation the prices artworks achieved fails to take account of the general rise in prosperity over the past 300 years.

Adjusting for the rise in disposable incomes, he calculates the top prices of works by 25 dead artists during their lifetimes rivalled and in some cases outstripped today's prices, as the graph shows. The average top price for the artists he looked at was £6.8m. Average top prices for modern German artists are less than 7% of this, according to Mr Wilke.

The highest price tags among the earlier artists, were achieved by a painter few people today will have heard of, the British salon painter, Sir Lawrence Alma-Tadema, whose work quickly fell out of fashion although it is undergoing a minor revival today.

Looking at his earlier group, Mr Wilke concludes that in general those works that sell for exorbitant prices during an artist's life turn out to be a bad long-term investment. "Painters that are highly acclaimed and accordingly highly priced during their lifetimes tend more towards subsequent weakness," he says. Works by painters such as Van Gogh, who was scarcely recognised during his lifetime, have proved to be the best investment. Van Gogh's works rose in price by 20% a year on average during the 30 years after his death.

Some surprisingly famous names have turned out to be bad investments. Andy Warhol's works have failed to increase in value, as have Degas', Ingres', and Monet's. The exceptions to the rule are Picasso and Turner, whose works achieved phenomenal prices during their lifetimes and further increased in value after their deaths. In the end, economists cannot provide an answer to the question of whether Damien Hirst will turn out to be a Picasso or a Alma-Tadema.

*Art market: expensive modern art? Trends, Dresdner Bank, November 2000
